text: When 74-year-old Penny Sweat was evicted from the HUD-subsidized Glendale Senior Housing in Salt Lake City last month, she moved to a nonsubsidized apartment at five times her previous rent because she was unaware of her rights.It turns out the manager of the seniors complex, its attorneys and government overseers were unaware, too.Lee Kemp, a hearing-impaired World War II disabled vet, also was evicted, but he contacted Utah Legal Services and was told to stay put.Attorney Marty Blaustein then notified Utah Nonprofit Housing Corp., the building's owner, that Kemp's eviction was not legal and that he had a right to a hearing.That didn't stop Utah Nonprofit Housing's attorneys from then sending Kemp a summons to show cause why he had not moved out.Meanwhile, Sweat's granddaughter called Salt Lake City housing officials, federal housing officials, state officials and several agents of Utah Nonprofit Housing to find out about her grandmother's rights.Nobody knew.Blaustein then took Sweat's case along with Kemp's and demanded her ousting be rectified.Utah Nonprofit Housing President Marion Willey returned from an out-of-town trip and learned HUD procedures were not followed.The eviction was activated because of ongoing personality conflicts among seniors in the complex, he said, and the new building manager decided the problems were with Sweat and Kemp.Several tenants blame other neighbors as perpetrators of the rift, however.Willey said when his building manager called attorneys retained by the company, they erroneously told her she could go ahead and kick out the tenants.When she called HUD to make sure, the inquiry got bogged down in bureaucracy and nobody called her back.Willey says he has offered Sweat and Kemp apartments in another complex operated by his company at their old rates.He also is retaining new attorneys.
summary_1: Penny Sweat and Lee Kemp, both elderly residents of Glendale Senior Housing in Salt Lake City, were wrongfully evicted due to miscommunication and lack of understanding regarding tenant rights. Sweat, who was unaware of her rights, moved into a more expensive non-subsidized apartment after being evicted. Meanwhile, Kemp, upon receiving advice from Utah Legal Services, stayed put. When attorney Marty Blaustein intervened on behalf of Kemp, it was discovered that the eviction was illegal and Kemp should have been granted a hearing. Despite this, Kemp received a summons for failing to vacate the premises. Sweat's family reached out to various authorities including local, federal, and state representatives, as well as Utah Nonprofit Housing Corporation (UNHC) agents; however, no one seemed to know the specifics of senior tenant rights. After learning of the situation, UNHC president Marion Willey acknowledged procedural errors made during the evictions. The mix-up stemmed from communication breakdown between the building manager and UNHC lawyers, resulting in improper instructions given to the manager. Following these revelations, Willey apologized and offered Sweat and Kemp alternative accommodations within another UNHC property at their former rental rate. Additionally, UNHC hired new legal counsel to prevent future mishaps.
summary_2: Elderly residents Penny Sweat and Lee Kemp were mistakenly evicted from Glendale Senior Housing in Salt Lake City. Unaware of tenants' rights, Sweat moved to a costlier unit while Kemp, with guidance from Utah Legal Services, remained. Eviction deemed illegal, Kemp still got a notice to vacate. Authorities struggled to explain senior tenant rights until UNHC president Marion Willey admitted procedural mistakes. Offering new housing options at original rates and engaging fresh legal counsel, UNHC aimed to avoid similar issues going forward.
summary_3: After realizing their mistake, Glendale Senior Housing attempted to evict two elderly residents, but after intervention from Utah Legal Services, they rectified the situation by offering alternative housing at the original rate and securing new legal counsel to prevent future mishaps.

text: The hijackers attacked at 9:28.While traveling 35,000 feet above eastern Ohio, United 93 suddenly dropped 700 feet.Eleven seconds into the descent, the FAA's air traffic control center in Cleveland received the first of two radio transmissions from the aircraft.During the first broadcast, the captain or first officer could be heard declaring "Mayday" amid the sounds of a physical struggle in the cockpit.The second radio transmission, 35 seconds later, indicated that the fight was continuing.The captain or first officer could be heard shouting:" Hey get out of here-get out of here-get out of here."On the morning of 9/11, there were only 37 passengers on United 93-33 in addition to the 4 hijackers.This was below the norm for Tuesday mornings during the summer of 2001.But there is no evidence that the hijackers manipulated passenger levels or purchased additional seats to facilitate their operation.The terrorists who hijacked three other commercial flights on 9/11 operated in five-man teams.They initiated their cockpit takeover within 30 minutes of takeoff.On Flight 93, however, the takeover took place 46 minutes after takeoff and there were only four hijackers.The operative likely intended to round out the team for this flight, Mohamed al Kahtani, had been refused entry by a suspicious immigration inspector at Florida's Orlando International Airport in August.Because several passengers on United 93 described three hijackers on the plane, not four, some have wondered whether one of the hijackers had been able to use the cockpit jump seat from the outset of the flight.FAA rules allow use of this seat by documented and approved individuals, usually air carrier or FAA personnel.We have found no evidence indicating that one of the hijackers, or anyone else, sat there on this flight.All the hijackers had assigned seats in first class, and they seem to have used them.We believe it is more likely that Jarrah, the crucial pilot-trained member of their team, remained seated and inconspicuous until after the cockpit was seized; and once inside, he would not have been visible to the passengers.
summary_1: Flight United 93 experienced a sudden drop of 700 feet over eastern Ohio around 9:28 AM on September 11, following a mayday call from the cockpit amidst sounds of struggle. This was approximately 46 minutes post-takeoff, slower than the usual 30-minute cockpit takeovers observed in the hijacking of three other commercial flights on the same day. The flight had only 37 passengers, significantly fewer than typical for a Tuesday morning in the summer of 2001, although there's no indication of manipulation of passenger numbers by the hijackers. The four hijackers, operating without their originally planned fifth member (Mohamed al Kahtani), commenced their takeover later than in previous instances. While theories suggest a hijacker might have occupied the cockpit jump seat, investigations reveal no such evidence. Instead, it is speculated that the lead pilot-trained hijacker, Ziad Jarrah, stayed inconspicuous until seizing the cockpit. All hijackers initially adhered to their allocated first-class seats. No signs indicate any passenger or crew resistance prior to the tragic outcome.
summary_2: On Sept 11, Flight UA93 dropped 700ft after a mayday call at 9:28 AM. Four hijackers took control about 46 mins into the flight, which had only 37 passengers - less than typical. Unlike other flights, there was no sign of struggle before the tragic end. Investigations found no proof of an extra hijacker in the cockpit; instead, they suspect the leader, Ziad Jarrah, hid until he seized control.
summary_3: On September 11, Flight UA93 descended 700 feet after a distress signal at 9:28 AM due to four hijackers, including Ziad Jarrah who likely concealed himself until seizing control, resulting in no pre-incident struggles despite fewer passengers than usual.

text: Nathan read the package of words in silence, his only motions the steady progress of his eyes and occasional replacement of pages.Allan sat nervously across from him in a chair Nathan had probably upholstered himself, a patchwork design of fabric containing easily more stuffing than any other furniture item of the period.At long last, Nathan reached the end and set down his reading on the table between them.Allan leaned forward unconsciously."It's the best story you've ever written."Allan exhaled and leaned back into the chair, his face relaxing in imitation of his thoughts."So," he asked, "you don't think it's a waste of ink and paper, a futile expedition into morbidity or literary debauchery?""Heavens, no," said Nathan, aghast."This is one of the strongest works I've read in ages.It speaks to the deepest storyteller's instinct within us all, yet is entirely original.My dear friend, you have done it.Oh, they may rail against you at first; they may decry you as a heathen or a literary savage; but while those in power say such things, others will read your tales and see their true worth.Believe me when I say that you will be read a century from now."Allan, though dubious as to that possibility, felt some temptation from the compliment; mainly, it granted him the encouragement he still needed.Nathan promised to show the story to a printer he knew and Allan left it with him, then walked home under the spreading maples with a smile lingering on his face.He felt now that perhaps Nathan was right; although the man was somewhat peculiar, he had both an unimpeachable honesty and a certain propensity for insight.Certainly, it was undeniable that the stories had an originality to them.His mind's strangest fruit had ripened at last, and he found the taste less bitter than expected.These thoughts and others like them filled his head as he walked the long road home.It was evening, and the sky burned orange in the west when he neared home at last.
summary_1: Nathan finished reading Allan's story, causing Allan to lean forward anxiously. Assured by Nathan's praise, Allan relaxed, taking in the positive feedback. Nathan commended the uniqueness of the work, assuring Allan that it would be recognized despite potential criticism. Despite initial doubts, Allan felt encouraged by Nathan's support and decided to trust his judgment. Handing over his work, Allan left it with Nathan, who agreed to share it with a trusted printer. As Allan walked home beneath the setting sun, he pondered Nathan's comments, feeling hopeful about the future of his unique creations.
summary_2: Allan shares his writing with Nathan, seeking approval. Impressed, Nathan praises its originality, easing Allan's worries. Encouraged, Allan decides to trust Nathan, leaving his work for him to print. As Allan walks off, optimistic, he reflects on Nathan's reassurance.
summary_3: Impressed by Allan's writing, Nathan alleviates Allan's concerns and prints the work, boosting Allan's confidence.

text: Earthquakes seemed to outline a special feature of earth's crust.Earthquakes let scientists know where the crust was moving.This led to the discovery that the Earths crust was broken up into regions, or plates.Earthquakes happen most often along these plate boundaries.This was evidence that continents can move.The movements of the plates are called plate tectonics.The Earths crust is divided into plates.There are about a dozen large plates and several small ones.Each plate is named for the continent or ocean basin it contains.Scientists know he plates are in motion.They now know the direction and speed of this motion .Plates dont move very fast.They move only a few centimeters a year.This is about the same rate fingernails grow.So you might wonder, what could cause this motion?What supplies the energy to cause this change?
summary_1: Earthquakes delineate unique characteristics of Earth's crust, serving as indicators of its movement. This revelation has unveiled the existence of fragmented sections, referred to as plates, which constitute Earth's crust. These geological fault lines are predominantly active at plate boundaries, signifying the dynamic nature of continental drift. The science behind this phenomenon is termed plate tectonics. Approximately a dozen major and numerous minor plates exist, each identified by the continent or ocean basin they encompass. Despite their slow pace, equivalent to fingernail growth, these plates demonstrably migrate at speeds varying from two to ten centimeters per year. The driving force behind this constant motion remains a subject of intrigue - an investigation into the source of energy instigating such transformation.
summary_2: Earthquakes reveal Earth's crust moves, divided into shifting plates. Known as plate tectonics, this science studies around a dozen major plates, slowly drifting like nail growth. Most activity occurs at boundary edges. Each plate corresponds to a continent or ocean basin. A mystery persists about what powers this continuous motion.
summary_3: Earth's crust constantly shifts due to plate tectonics, a geological phenomenon involving the movement of approximately a dozen major plates that form continents and ocean basins, with most seismic activity occurring along their boundaries.

text: The world can be divided into three climate zones.The first climate zone is the polar zone.As it sounds, the polar zone is near earths poles.The polar zone has very long and cold winters.Brrr!!!!Near the equator is the tropical zone.The tropical zone is known for being hot and wet.Between these two zones is the temperate zone.Temperatures there tend to be mild.Its not too hot and not too cold.You might expect places near the equator to be hot and wet.Thats not always the case.Sometimes there are other factors at work.These factors can affect the local climate type or a region.Oceans and mountain ranges can have a major impact.They can greatly influence the climate of an area.Many factors influence an areas climate.
summary_1: The Earth is categorized into three primary climate regions - the Polar Zone, Tropical Zone, and Temperate Zone. The Polar Zone, situated near the planet's poles, experiences extremely lengthy and frigid winters. Contrarily, the Tropical Zone, located near the equator, is recognized for its high temperatures and precipitation. Between these two zones lies the Temperate Zone, where the weather remains moderately pleasant without excessive heat or cold. However, expectations can sometimes be misleading. Areas neighboring the equator aren't necessarily hot and humid due to various influencing factors like oceans and mountain ranges that significantly shape regional climates. Various elements indeed contribute to determining an area's climate.
summary_2: Earth has three main climate areas: Polar, Tropical, and Temperate Zones. The Polar Zone, at the poles, endures long, freezing winters; the Tropical Zone, by the equator, sees high temps and rainfall; between them, the Temperate Zone enjoys milder conditions. But reality may defy assumptions, with nearby equatorial areas varying from typical warmth and wetness due to factors such as seas and mountains shaping local climates.
summary_3: Polar, Tropical, and Temperate Zones define Earth's climate based on location, but actual conditions can vary due to geographical features like seas and mountains.

text: We need natural resources for just about everything we do.We need them for food and clothing, for building materials and energy.We even need them to have fun.Table 2.1 gives examples of how we use natural resources.Can you think of other ways we use natural resources?Use Vehicles Resources Rubber for tires from rubber trees Steel frames and other metal parts from minerals such as iron Example iron ore Electronics Plastic cases from petroleum prod- ucts Glass screens from minerals such as lead lead ore Use Homes Resources Nails from minerals such as iron Timber from trees Example spruce timber Jewelry Gemstones such as diamonds Minerals such as silver silver ore Food Sunlight, water, and soil Minerals such as phosphorus corn seeds in soil Clothing Wool from sheep Cotton from cotton plants cotton plants Recreation Water for boating and swimming Forests for hiking and camping pine forest Some natural resources are renewable.Others are not.It depends, in part, on how we use them.
summary_1: Natural resources play an essential role in various aspects of life, including sustenance, shelter, leisure activities, and luxury items. Table 2.1 highlights some applications of these resources. For instance, vehicles utilize rubber from rubber trees and metals derived from minerals like iron (e.g., iron ore) for their construction, while electronics incorporate plastics from petroleum products and glass from minerals such as lead (lead ore). In residential settings, nails originate from minerals like iron, timber comes from trees like spruce, jewelry features gemstones sourced from elements like carbon (diamonds), and precious metals stem from ores like silver. Basic necessities like food source components, such as sunlight, water, and soil, along with minerals like phosphorus, facilitate agriculture. Similarly, clothing production relies on animal fibers, such as wool from sheep, and plant derivatives, such as cotton. Natural resource utilization extends to recreational pursuits, encompassing water sources for boating and swimming, forests for outdoor activities like hiking and camping, and more. Renewability of certain resources depends on usage patterns; some replenish naturally over time, whereas others face depletion risks due to finite supplies.
summary_2: Natural resources are vital for many facets of life, from basic needs to luxuries. Vehicles use rubber, metal, plastic, and glass, all natural resources. Homes contain materials like iron nails, wooden furniture, diamond jewelry, and silverware. Agriculture requires sunlight, water, soil, and minerals. Clothing uses animal and plant fibers. Recreation involves using lakes, forests, etc. Resource renewal varies - some replenish, but others risk depletion.
summary_3: Various aspects of life, from necessities to indulgences, rely on natural resources such as rubber, metal, wood, water, and animal fibers; however, while some resources renew, others face potential depletion.

text: Responding to a wave of public dismay over the first designs for rebuilding Lower Manhattan, Gov. George Pataki has sent word that it's time to go back to the drawing board.It is the right message, sent while it is still early enough to do something constructive about the disappointing quality of the work so far.The governor, like Mayor Michael Bloomberg, now seems committed to creating a better mix of uses for ground zero, and a 24-hour community in Manhattan's downtown.While rethinking the plans will delay the original rebuilding schedule slightly, it does not need to stall progress if the governor keeps the pressure on the Lower Manhattan Development Corp. and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.New York cannot afford to have a gaping hole that mocks the city and its process for rebuilding what was destroyed.Pataki openly questioned the Port Authority's requirement that any plan for the site replace all the office, hotel and retail square footage lost in the attack on Sept. 11.More than anything else, that specification limited the designs to the undistinguished options presented two weeks ago.Renegotiating that issue with the World Trade Center leaseholders should begin immediately.Opening the process to other designers, both here and internationally, will help separate this urban plan from the ordinary.The city also needs to begin openly discussing what happens underground, in particular with the transportation network.At this point, planners have focused on short-term repair of PATH and subway lines, with medium-range proposals being shopped in Washington that could untangle the disorganized web of subway lines downtown.Within the next few weeks the Lower Manhattan Development Corp. and the Port Authority should offer some bigger ideas about how to connect the downtown area better to the rest of the region.Lowering West Street alongside the World Trade Center site and building a park or esplanade on top is another option that has been popular with those reviewing the first six public proposals.But it would be expensive, and the governor, the mayor and their friends in Washington will have to look at long-range ways to pay the bill.Pataki's recent remarks are a sign that he understands how central the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan will be to his own political legacy.Now he needs to follow through with action, to keep demonstrating that his core concern is coming up with the best possible plan, not simply keeping the issue on hold until after this fall's election.
summary_1: Governor George Pataki has expressed intent to revise the initial blueprints for reestablishing Lower Manhattan, following widespread criticism towards the preliminary layouts. The revision aims to enhance the proposed design blend and foster a lively 24-hour neighborhood in Downtown Manhattan. Although alterations may cause minor delays, Governor Pataki urged the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation (LMDC) and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to maintain momentum. A significant critique targeted the Port Authority's insistence on replacing every square foot of commercial, lodging, and retail space lost during the September 11 attacks. This prerequisite constrained architectural creativity, leading to underwhelming concepts. To broaden perspectives, negotiations with the World Trade Center leaseholders must commence promptly. Additionally, incorporating international designers into the planning process might generate more innovative solutions. Furthermore, discussions regarding improvements to the transport infrastructure beneath Ground Zero are essential. While immediate focus remains on fixing damaged PATH and subway systems, future strategies to streamline the chaotic downtown subway system should be considered. Proposals include lowering West Street adjacent to the WTC site and establishing a park or promenade above. However, these changes require substantial funding, necessitating careful financial planning by Governor Pataki, Mayor Bloomberg, and their allies in Congress. Governor Pataki's statements indicate an understanding of the importance of redeveloping Lower Manhattan for his political reputation; thus, decisive actions supporting the project's success are expected.
summary_2: After receiving backlash against early designs, NY Governor George Pataki plans to modify Lower Manhattan reconstruction plans, aiming to create a vibrant 24/7 community. Criticism targets the Port Authority's demand to replace all commercial losses, limiting innovation. Suggestions involve negotiating with lessees and involving global designers. Transportation upgrades below Ground Zero are also crucial, including potential modifications to nearby streets and transit. Funding is vital, requiring cautious fiscal management from Governor Pataki, Mayor Bloomberg, and congressional supporters.
summary_3: Governor Pataki modifies Lower Manhattan plans to foster a 24/7 community, addressing criticism of the Port Authority by negotiating with lessees, incorporating global design input, and prioritizing transportation upgrades, while ensuring necessary funding.

text: The side of Malaquez's parcel gave way to reveal a greenmunk caught in a sheen of solid air.Bits of leaf mold flew from under his feet as he ran to greet a friend or a bringer of food.Tasha oohed in awe.I said, "Frodo's been visiting you, eh?"Malaquez said, "Your pet?""Hardly.He lives around here somewhere.I suppose he was attracted to the commotion up the hill.""Ah," Malaquez said."Why 'Frodo'?"Tasha said, "A little fellow with big, furry feet.What else could he be called?"She handed the sculpture to me.I almost dropped it; I expected it to weigh no more than a holo."Heavy," I said, as if he might not have known.He laughed."My last piece was of four old Undersiders crouched around a trash fire.Be glad someone didn't toss that to you."He spoke of his art with the enthusiasm of a seven-year-old."Um, I should wait to importune you, but..."
summary_1: Malaquez's package revealed a trapped greenmunk within a bubble of solid air. The creature seemed excited, possibly due to anticipation of food or seeing a familiar face. Tasha expressed her admiration for the sight. In response to the assistant's comment about the resemblance of the situation to J.R.R Tolkien's character Frodo Baggins, Malaquez questioned the usage of the name Frodo. Tasha explained the name's appropriateness due to the small size and hairy feet of the creature. She then passed the sculpture to the assistant who found it surprisingly heavy, leading Malaquez to humorously compare it to one of his previous works - a depiction of four elderly people huddled around a fire. He concluded by expressing his willingness to discuss further at a later time.
summary_2: Malaquez's package contains a joyful, trapped greenmunk. Tasha admires it, comparing its small size and furry feet to Frodo Baggins from Lord of the Rings, which Malaquez finds amusing. Handling the surprisingly heavy sculpture, Malaquez jokes about its weight compared to his past work before proposing future discussion.
summary_3: Malaquez shows Tasha a heavy greenmunk sculpture, reminiscent of Frodo Baggins, sparking humor and future discussions.

text: The highest point of a wave is the crest.The lowest point is the trough.The vertical distance between a crest and a trough is the height of the wave.Wave height is also called amplitude.The horizontal distance between two crests is the wavelength.Both amplitude and wavelength are measures of wave size.The size of an ocean wave depends on how fast, over how great a distance, and how long the wind blows.The greater each of these factors is, the bigger a wave will be.Some of the biggest waves occur with hurricanes.A hurricane is a storm that forms over the ocean.Its winds may blow more than 150 miles per hour!The winds also travel over long distances and may last for many days.
summary_1: Ocean waves consist of crests, which are the high points, and troughs, their low counterparts. The vertical space from a crest to a trough signifies the wave's height, also known as its amplitude. Wavelength denotes the horizontal span between two successive crests. Both amplitude and wavelength serve as indicators of wave magnitude. Ocean wave dimensions primarily hinge on three elements related to wind: speed, reach, and duration. As any of these factors intensify, so does the resulting wave's size. Among the most substantial waves emerge during hurricanes - cyclonic phenomena characterized by extreme wind speeds often surpassing 150 mph, persisting across vast stretches, and enduring for extended periods.
summary_2: Waves have crests (high points) and troughs (lows), with height measured from crest to trough (amplitude). Wavelength spans between consecutive crests. Larger waves stem from stronger winds regarding speed, distance, and time. Hurricane winds, typically over 150 mph, generate some of the largest ocean waves due to their expansive reach and longevity.
summary_3: Larger ocean waves result from stronger winds, especially during hurricanes, with heights measured between crests and troughs, while wavelength connects successive crests.

text: Joey got a German Shepherd for his birthday present.He had never had any pets before, but was always excited to see the other dogs and cats in his neighborhood.Since his birthday was in June, he spent a lot of time playing outside with his new puppy, which he named Max.Max and Joey would often run through fields in a game of chase.They also liked to go through the small forest behind the house, making a game of hide and seek.They never went near the lake because Joey was afraid of water.One day, Max hid a little too well and Joey couldn't find him.Joey spent the afternoon looking for his German Shepherd where they often played, like the field and forest.Joey was a shy boy who often read by himself, and Max was his best friend.After dinner, he went to look for Max one last time before he had to take a bath and go to bed.He heard some barking on the next street, so he ran to see if it was his puppy.Sure enough, he saw Max playing with a poodle.The dogs were having so much fun.Joey brought Max home, happy that he had his puppy back.Max seemed to be happy to have his human by his side as well as a new doggy friend.All summer long, Joey took Max to the poodle's house so they could play without having to worry about losing his present.
summary_1: June marked the arrival of a new companion for Joey - a German Shepherd pup named Max. With no prior pet ownership experience, Joey found joy in observing neighborhood animals, and now, he had his own furry buddy. The pair reveled in outdoor activities; running amok in meadows, engaging in hide-and-seek within the nearby woods, yet carefully avoiding the local lake due to Joey's aquaphobia. One fateful afternoon, Max temporarily vanished during their games, leading Joey on a frantic search covering their favorite haunts – open fields and woodland areas. A reserved child, books kept Joey company when alone, while Max remained his closest pal. Post-supper, another hunt commenced, driven by Joey's concern. He followed distant barks, eventually locating Max frolicking alongside a poodle from the adjacent street. Overjoyed at finding Max safe and sound, Joey escorted him home, content knowing Max had gained a four-legged friend. From then on, regular visits ensued, allowing both dogs to enjoy each other's company under supervision, preventing further separation anxiety for either party.
summary_2: Joey, an inexperienced pet owner, finds joy in his new German Shepherd, Max. They explore outdoors, but avoid the lake due to Joey's fear of water. When Max disappears, Joey searches and finds him playing with a poodle. Relieved, they become friends, visiting regularly.
summary_3: Joey happily discovers his dog, Max, befriending another dog near their feared lake after initially worrying about its absence.

text: Mastermind Charlie Mascarenhas and his accomplice Riya are one of the greatest pair of thieves in India .A friend of Charlie , Raj is killed by the Russian mafia .At Raj's funeral , his wife hands Charlie a CD containing information about the transfer of gold by train from Russia to Romania .Charlie decides to rob the train with the help of imprisoned Don and con-artist Victor Braganza .They hire a team of criminals to join them in the robbery .The group includes Spider , who is a world-class hacker , an explosives expert Bilal Bashir , a prosthetic makeup artist Sunny , and an illusionist Ronnie .Charlie is also having an affair with Victor's daughter , Naina , who knows nothing about her father and Charlie's criminal activities .The group devise a plan to rob the Russian train in the sliest way possible .Spider hacks into a Russian satellite system and Ronnie uses his illusion to trick the soldiers guarding the gold while the rest of the team transfer the gold from the train .The robbery is executed successfully , however while celebrating Spider double crosses the gang and tries to flee with all of the gold .Spider is stopped by Ronnie , who is then shot multiple times by Spider's assassins .The group are chased by the assassins and Ronnie and Riya are killed .Charlie , Bilal and Sunny manage to escape after Spider blows up the location and flees with the gold .Charlie calls Victor to tell him about the betrayal , but Naina overhears the conversation .At the same time Spider's assassins breaks into the house and murder Victor .
summary_1:
Charlie Mascarenhas, a master thief, teams up with various individuals for a daring heist on a train carrying gold from Russia to Romania. The mission is sparked when Charlie receives information regarding the shipment at his late friend Raj's funeral. To execute this elaborate scheme, they enlist the help of a don, a con-artist named Victor Braganza, and other skilled professionals such as a hacker called Spider, explosives specialist Bilal Bashir, a prosthetic makeup artist known as Sunny, and an illusionist named Ronnie.

While planning the operation, Charlie has a romantic relationship with Victor's unsuspecting daughter, Naina. Together, they pull off the successful train robbery using Spider's hacking skills and Ronnie's illusions to deceive the guards. However, during their celebration, Spider attempts to steal all the gold and shoots Ronnie upon being caught. Injured, Ronnie manages to stop Spider before succumbing to gunshot wounds inflicted by Spider's hired assassins. A chase ensues, resulting in the deaths of both Ronnie and Riya, while Charlie, Bilal, and Sunny narrowly escape. Upon discovering Spider's treachery, Charlie contacts Victor, which ultimately leads to Victor's demise at the hands of Spider's hitmen. Unbeknownst to Charlie, Naina learns about the conspiracy through eavesdropping on the phone call just as Spider's henchmen invade their home.
summary_2: Master thief Charlie allies with a don, con-artist, hacker, explosives expert, makeup artist, and illusionist for a train heist, learning of the gold shipment at a friend's funeral. They succeed, but romance with Victor's daughter, Naina, turns sour when Spider, the hacker, betrays them, shooting Ronnie and stealing the gold. After a deadly chase, Spider kills Ronnie, injures Riya, and murders Victor. Naina discovers the plot, setting up a dangerous confrontation.
summary_3: Charlie teams up with a crew to steal gold from a train after learning about it at a friend's funeral, but their plan goes awry due to a betrayal, leading to deaths and injuries, until Naina uncovers the truth, setting up a perilous showdown.

text: Jack and Mackenzie wanted to do something fun during their day off from school.They knew that the library had story time on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday.Their mother told them they could go to the library every Tuesday for their story time.They packed up the car and drove to the library, ready for a fun morning.When they arrived to the story room, there were lots of other children their age, all sitting cross-legged and ready for the story of the day.The teacher told them they would be reading "The Wild Horse".She began to tell the story of Majestic, the wild horse who could not be calmed.His people had tried and tried to break him, but he was wild at heart.Every time they took him to the river to drink, he would run straight into the water and get soaking wet!He would splash and play until he was ready to go back home, where he would sleep for hours, having worn himself out playing.
summary_1: Jack and Mackenzie, eager for an exciting day off from school, opted for the library's story time, held every weekday. Their mother approved their weekly visit, specifically on Tuesdays. The siblings journeyed to the library, looking forward to a fun-filled morning. Upon reaching the story room, they found many children their age, seated comfortably in anticipation. A teacher announced they would read "The Wild Horse," sparking curiosity among the young audience. The tale revolved around Majestic, a spirited stallion impossible to tame. Despite numerous attempts by his handlers to domesticate him, Majestic remained untamed. Each attempt involved leading him to the river for drinking; however, instead of drinking, Majestic charged into the water, frolicking and enjoying himself before returning home exhausted.
summary_2: Eager for excitement, Jack and Mackenzie attend library storytime, where a lively tale of Majestic, an unbreakable wild horse who frolics in rivers instead of being tamed, delights them and other kids.
summary_3: At library storytime, children enjoy a thrilling tale about Majestic, an untamable wild horse that plays in rivers.

text: Above were just a few things that caused habitat loss or change.There are many ways in which living organisms can affect their ecosystem.In some areas, it is because of fire management.Fire is a natural event, so managing fire correctly is very important.In other areas, fisherman have taken too many fish from one area.This places the species at risk of extinction.It also affects other living things that may rely on these fish for food.The image below shows a picture of a mine.Mining changes the Earths surface.This area may once have been a forest or a prairie.Think about how many plants and animals may once have lived here.Now it is a giant hole in the ground.Pollution is also a major factor in habitat loss and change.
summary_1: Habitat loss or alteration results from various factors, including human activities and natural events. Fire management plays a crucial role in preserving habitats; although fire is a natural occurrence, its improper handling can lead to adverse effects on ecosystems. Overfishing poses another concern, where excessive removal of fish threatens species survival and impacts other organisms dependent on them for sustenance. Human activities like mining significantly modify landscapes, transforming forests or grasslands into barren land—in this case, a large pit in the earth's crust. Pollution constitutes yet another significant contributor to habitat degradation, further exacerbating the issue.
summary_2: Fire mismanagement, overfishing, mining, and pollution all harm habitats. While fires naturally occur, poor handling causes damage. Overfishing endangers species and affects their dependents. Mining drastically alters landscapes, turning diverse areas into bare ones. Contamination also harms environments, worsening the situation.
summary_3: Improper fire management, overfishing, mining, and pollution all negatively impact habitats by causing harm and alteration.

text: Ratners Group PLC, a fast-growing, acquisition-minded London-based jeweler, raised its price for Seattle-based specialty jeweler Weisfield's Inc. to $57.50 a share, or $62.1 million, from $50 a share, or $55 million, after another concern said it would be prepared to outbid Ratners's initial offer.The other concern wasn't identified.Ratners's chairman, Gerald Ratner, said the deal remains of "substantial benefit to Ratners."In London at mid-afternoon yesterday, Ratners's shares were up 2 pence (1.26 cents), at 260 pence ($1.64).The sweetened offer has acceptances from more than 50% of Weisfield's shareholders, and it is scheduled for completion by Dec. 10.The acquisition of 87-store Weisfield's raises Ratners's U.S. presence to 450 stores.About 30% of Ratners's profit already is derived from the U.S.
summary_1: London-based Ratners Group PLC, an expanding jewelry retailer, increased its bid for Seattle-based specialist jeweler Weisfield's Inc. to $57.50 per share, totaling $62.1 million, from the initial offering of $50 per share, or $55 million. This adjustment follows another company expressing willingness to surpass Ratners's preliminary proposal. However, the identity of this second party remains undisclosed. Gerald Ratner, the chairman of Ratners, maintains that the transaction will continue to significantly advantage Ratners. On the London market during mid-afternoon, Ratners's stocks rose by 2 pence, equivalent to 1.26 cents, settling at 260 pence, or approximately $1.64. The revised offer has received approval from over half of Weisfield's stockholders and is projected to finalize by December 10th. With this acquisition of Weisfield's 87-store chain, Ratners expands its US presence to 450 stores, given that around 30% of their profits are generated from US operations.
summary_2: Ratners Group PLC raised its bid for Weisfield's Inc. to $57.50 per share, up from $50, after another firm showed interest. Ratners' chairman, Gerald Ratner, expects benefits. Following the increase, Ratners' shares slightly rose on the London market. Over half of Weisfield's stockholders approved the deal, which could close by Dec 10th. If successful, Ratners would control about 450 U.S. stores, with roughly 30% of their earnings coming from American operations.
summary_3: Ratners Group increased its offer for Weisfield's to $57.50, aiming to control about 450 US stores and gain 30% of earnings from American operations, with over half of Weisfield's shareholders approving the deal.

text: Marsha loves playing with her noodle friend.She had it for a long time so it is now a dark brown color.When her mom first made it, it was white.The night she met her noodle friend was spaghetti night.Marsha's favorite dinner was spaghetti, which happened to be every Tuesday night.On one Tuesday, a piece of spaghetti fell on the kitchen floor.To Marsha, it looked like a stick man so she kept him.She named her new noodle friend Joey and took him everywhere she went.Sometimes Joey gets a little dried out so Marsha's mom told her to soak him in water every few days.There were a couple times that the family dog, Mika, has tried to take Joey from Marsha and eat him!So from now on, Marsha takes extra special care to make sure Joey is safe and sound at all times.During the day she keeps him in a plastic bag in her pocket.At night, she puts him under her pillow.She loves Joey and wants to always be friends with him.
summary_1: Marsha cherishes a long-held companion, affectionately known as "noodle friend," initially white but now a deep brown due to extended use. The moniker originates from an incident during spaghetti night when Marsha discovered a pasta fragment resembling a miniature figure after a mishap left it on the kitchen floor. Named Joey, this novelty quickly became Marsha's constant companion, accompanying her wherever she ventured. Due to occasional dryness, Marsha ensures Joey is periodically submerged in water to maintain his integrity. Regrettably, their bond faced early peril from Marsha's familial canine, Mika, who attempted to consume Joey twice. Consequently, Marsha adopted stringent precautions to safeguard Joey, storing him within a protective plastic pouch during waking hours and placing him beneath her pillow while sleeping. Her devotion to preserving their friendship remains unwavering.
summary_2: Marsha deeply values a treasured object named 'Noodle Friend,' originally white but now brown from prolonged usage. After discovering a spaghetti piece shaped like a tiny person, Marsha dubbed it 'Joey.' Since then, Joey accompanies Marsha everywhere. To preserve Joey, Marsha keeps him moist by occasionally soaking him in water. Initially threatened by her dog, Mika, who tried eating Joey, Marsha now secures Joey in a protective pouch and stores him under her pillow at night. Despite challenges, Marsha's commitment to maintaining their bond stays firm.
summary_3: Marsha cherishes a stained 'Noodle Friend' accessory, nicknamed 'Joey', which she safeguards with a special pouch and nightly submergence, after thwarting her dog, Mika's attempts to consume it.

text: The new administration had already begun exploring possible diplomatic options, retracing many of the paths traveled by its predecessors.U.S.envoys again pressed the Taliban to turn  Bin Laden "over to a country where he could face justice" and repeated, yet again, the warning that the Taliban would be held responsible for any al Qaeda attacks on U.S. interests.The Taliban's representatives repeated their old arguments.Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage told us that while U.S. diplomats were becoming more active on Afghanistan through the spring and summer of 2001, "it would be wrong for anyone to characterize this as a dramatic shift from the previous administration."In deputies meetings at the end of June, Tenet was tasked to assess the prospects forTaliban cooperation with the United States on al Qaeda.The NSC staff was tasked to flesh out options for dealing with the Taliban.Revisiting these issues tried the patience of some of the officials who felt they had already been down these roads and who found the NSC's procedures slow."We weren't going fast enough,"Armitage told us.Clarke kept arguing that moves against the Taliban and al Qaeda should not have to wait months for a larger review of U.S. policy in South Asia."For the government," Hadley said to us,"we moved it along as fast as we could move it along."As all hope in moving the Taliban faded, debate revived about giving covert assistance to the regime's opponents.Clarke and the CIA's Cofer Black renewed the push to aid the Northern Alliance.Clarke suggested starting with modest aid, just enough to keep the Northern Alliance in the fight and tie down al Qaeda terrorists, without aiming to overthrow the Taliban.Rice, Hadley, and the NSC staff member for Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, told us they opposed giving aid to the Northern Alliance alone.They argued that the program needed to have a big part for Pashtun opponents of theTaliban.They also thought the program should be conducted on a larger scale than had been suggested.Clarke concurred with the idea of a larger program, but he warned that delay risked the Northern Alliance's final defeat at the hands of the Taliban.During the spring, the CIA, at the NSC's request, had developed draft legal authorities-a presidential finding-to undertake a large-scale program of covert assistance to the Taliban's foes.
summary_1: The new administration resumed past diplomatic efforts regarding Afghanistan, urging the Taliban to hand over Bin Laden and cautioning them about potential repercussions for any al Qaeda assaults on US interests. The Taliban continued to present their usual counterarguments. Despite increased US diplomatic activity throughout spring and summer 2001, Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage maintained that there wasn't a significant change from prior administrations. In late June deputies meetings, Director of Central Intelligence George Tenet was assigned to evaluate possibilities for Taliban collaboration against al Qaeda, while the National Security Council (NSC) staff was entrusted with devising strategies for managing the Taliban issue. As hopes for negotiating with the Taliban waned, discussions resurfaced concerning clandestine support for the Taliban's adversaries. Officials including Clarke and the CIA's Cofer Black advocated for assisting the Northern Alliance, suggesting initial help merely to sustain their resistance and distract al Qaeda operatives, rather than toppling the Taliban. Rice, Hadley, and Khalilzad disagreed, favoring a substantial role for Pashtun opponents of the Taliban and a broader initiative. While acknowledging the value of a bigger operation, Clarke cautioned that further delays might lead to the Northern Alliance's ultimate defeat. By spring, the CIA, upon the NSC's request, prepared legal authorizations for an extensive covert aid plan targeting the Taliban's enemies.
summary_2: In early 2001, the new administration resumed previous attempts to persuade the Taliban to extradite Bin Laden, warning of consequences for any al Qaeda attacks on U.S. interests. Diplomatic efforts intensified in spring and summer, but Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage saw little difference from past approaches. Discussions ensued about supporting the Taliban's adversaries, with officials divided between focusing on the Northern Alliance or involving Pashtun opponents in a larger initiative. Amidst these debates, the CIA drafted legal authorizations for aiding the Taliban's foes by spring, aiming to bolster resistance and divert al Qaeda forces.
summary_3: The US government tried convincing the Taliban to hand over Bin Laden in 2001, threatening action if al Qaeda attacked American interests; diplomatic talks continued through spring and summer, with discussions including potential support for the Taliban's enemies, specifically the Northern Alliance or Pashtun opponents.

text: At 8:38, Ong told Gonzalez that the plane was flying erratically again.Around this time Sweeney told Woodward that the hijackers were Middle Easterners, naming three of their seat numbers.One spoke very little English and one spoke excellent English.The hijackers had gained entry to the cockpit, and she did not know how.The aircraft was in a rapid descent.At 8:41, Sweeney told Woodward that passengers in coach were under the impression that there was a routine medical emergency in first class.Other flight attendants were busy at duties such as getting medical supplies while Ong and Sweeney were reporting the events.At 8:41, in American's operations center, a colleague told Marquis that the air traffic controllers declared Flight 11 a hijacking and "think he's [American 11] headed toward Kennedy [airport in New York City].They're moving everybody out of the way.They seem to have him on a primary radar.They seem to think that he is descending."At 8:44, Gonzalez reported losing phone contact with Ong.About this same time Sweeney reported to Woodward, "Something is wrong.We are in a rapid descent .we are all over the place."Woodward asked Sweeney to look out the window to see if she could determine where they were.
summary_1: Flight attendant Amy Sweeney informed manager Michael Woodward about suspicious activities onboard American Airlines Flight 11. At approximately 8:38 AM, fellow flight attendant Betty Ong reported that the plane was behaving erratically once more. Sweeney shared crucial details with Woodward; multiple hijackers, predominantly Middle Eastern, had taken control of the cockpit. Two of them possessed limited English proficiency, whereas another exhibited exceptional English skills. The perpetrators had managed to breach the cockpit without detection from the crew. Simultaneously, passengers remained unaware of the escalating crisis, assuming it to be an ordinary medical issue within the first-class cabin. Meanwhile, other flight attendants focused on attending to regular tasks or gathering medical equipment. By 8:41 AM, both radio communication loss between Ong and ground staff occurred, along with Sweeney announcing a sudden, drastic descent accompanied by chaotic navigation. She attempted to identify their location through observing landmarks outside the aircraft windows. Concurrently, American Airline's operation center received updates declaring Flight 11 a confirmed hijacking, suspecting its trajectory towards John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York City.
summary_2: Flight attendant Amy Sweeney alerts manager Michael Woodward to suspicious behavior on American Airlines Flight 11 at 8:38 AM. Fellow attendant Betty Ong reports erratic plane activity. Sweeney reveals hijackers, mostly Middle Eastern, have seized the cockpit, two speaking poor English, one fluent. They entered undetected. Passengers see it as a medical issue. Other attendants continue routine tasks. By 8:41 AM, Ong loses contact with ground staff, Sweeney announces a steep descent and chaos, trying to locate position via landmarks. American Airline's operations center confirms Flight 11's hijacking, predicting a path toward JFK airport, NYC.
summary_3: At 8:38 AM, flight attendants Amy Sweeney and Betty Ong report suspicious behavior by Middle Eastern hijackers who had taken control of American Airlines Flight 11, leading to its eventual crash into the North Tower of the World Trade Center in New York City.

text: Sam Farragut is a sociopathic business executive in Southern California who forces a team of advertising agency employees to embark on a dangerous dirtbike trip to the Baja California desert in order to compete for his business . The men are Warren Summerfield , a suicidal middle-aged ad executive who has been fired from the agency ; the straightlaced Paul McIlvain who is inattentive to his wife , and brash art designer Maxon who feels suddenly trapped after his girlfriend announces she is pregnant . There are numerous long sequences of motorcycle riding on desert backroads . Summerfield has been having an affair with McIlvian's wife . He has not told his wife that he was fired and is simply serving out his tenure at the agency while looking for a new position . His wife is actually aware of the affair . Farragut convinces the ad men to make the motorcycle journey on the pretext of looking for a location to shoot a commercial . In reality , Farragut is reckless and looking to involve the men in spontaneous edgy adventure of his own manipulation . After they leave , McIlvain's wife suspects that Summerfield is planning to kill himself for the insurance money , but she can not convince Summerfield's wife to instigate a search . The four men travel deeper into Mexico on isolated dirt roads . At one point Summerfield contemplates plunging off a cliff . After being humiliated by a young American couple in a Baja bar , Farragut tracks them down on the beach while accompanied by Maxon .
summary_1: Sociopathic businessman Sam Farragut coerces three advertising agency employees, including suicidal Warren Summerfield, uptight Paul McIlvain, and expectant father Maxon, on a perilous dirt bike expedition across the Baja California desert. Ostensibly hunting locations for a commercial, their actual purpose lies in experiencing Farragut's self-indulgent escapades. While Summerfield hides his recent unemployment due to a firing, he maintains an extramarital relationship with McIlvain's unsuspecting spouse. She fears Summerfield plans to exploit his life insurance policy through suicide; however, unable to persuade her counterpart, she fails to initiate any rescue efforts. As the quartet delves further into Mexico via desolate trails, Summerfield ponders driving off a cliff before ultimately refraining. Following public embarrassment at a local bar, Farragut hunts down a young American duo alongside Maxon along the coastline.
summary_2: Sam Farragut, a ruthless entrepreneur, forces three ad executives on a hazardous motorbike trip in Baja California, supposedly scouting commercial sites but actually indulging in reckless adventures. Among them are depressed Warren Summerfield, hiding both job loss and infidelity with colleague Paul McIlvain's wife, who suspects Summerfield might kill himself for insurance money. The group faces various challenges while navigating remote paths until they encounter two Americans near the shore, which leads to unexpected consequences.
summary_3: Entrepreneur Sam Farragut takes three ad executives on a dangerous motorbike trip in Baja California, leading to unexpected encounters and personal revelations, particularly for the suicidal Warren Summerfield.

text: But I think it is certain that most of the early Christians understood these words of our Lord's ascension and coming again in glory. They believed that He was coming again in a very little while during their own life-time, in a few months or years, to make an end of the world and to judge the quick and the dead. And as they waited for His coming, one generation after another, and yet He did not come, a sadness fell upon them. Christ seemed to have left the world. The little while that He had promised to be away seemed to have become a very long while. Hundreds of years passed, and yet Christ did not come in glory. And, as I said, a sadness fell on all the Church. Surely, they said, this is the time of which Christ said we were to weep and lament till we saw Him again--this is the time of which He said that the bridegroom should be taken from us, and we should fast in those days. And they did fast, and weep, and lament; and their religion became a very sad and melancholy one--most sad in those who were most holy, and loved their Lord best, and longed most for His coming in glory.
summary_1: The early Christians anticipated the imminent return of Jesus Christ in glory within their lifetime, believing his second coming would occur soon after his ascension. This belief led to great anticipation among believers, but as centuries passed without Christ's appearance, disappointment settled in. A sense of sorrow enveloped the Christian community, especially devout followers eagerly awaiting His glorious arrival. Their faith evolved into a somber and solemn practice, marked by mourning and fasting due to the prolonged absence of their Messiah.
summary_2: Early Christians expected Jesus' quick return, leading to fervent anticipation. As years passed without his arrival, disappointment set in, replaced by sadness and sober reflection amongst devoted followers. Over time, Christianity became characterized by somber practices, including fasting, stemming from ongoing delays in Christ's Second Coming.
summary_3: Disappointment over delayed Second Coming led early Christians to adopt solemn practices like fasting.

text: As his car slid downtown on Tuesday morning the mind of Arnold Thorndike was occupied with such details of daily routine as the purchase of a railroad, the Japanese loan, the new wing to his art gallery, and an attack that morning, in his own newspaper, upon his pet trust.But his busy mind was not too occupied to return the salutes of the traffic policemen who cleared the way for him.Or, by some genius of memory, to recall the fact that it was on this morning young Spear was to be sentenced for theft.It was a charming morning.The spring was at full tide, and the air was sweet and clean.Mr. Thorndike considered whimsically that to send a man to jail with the memory of such a morning clinging to him was adding a year to his sentence.He regretted he had not given the probation officer a stronger letter.He remembered the young man now, and favorably.A shy, silent youth, deft in work, and at other times conscious and embarrassed.But that, on the part of a stenographer, in the presence of the Wisest Man in Wall Street, was not unnatural.On occasions, Mr. Thorndike had put even royalty— frayed, impecunious royalty, on the lookout for a loan—at its ease.The hood of the car was down, and the taste of the air, warmed by the sun, was grateful.It was at this time, a year before, that young Spear picked the spring flowers to take to his mother.A year from now where would young Spear be?It was characteristic of the great man to act quickly, so quickly that his friends declared he was a slave to impulse.It was these same impulses, leading so invariably to success, that made his enemies call him the Wisest Man.He leaned forward and touched the chauffeur's shoulder."Stop at the Court of General Sessions," he commanded.What he proposed to do would take but a few minutes.A word, a personal word from him to the district attorney, or the judge, would be enough.
summary_1: Arnold Thorndike, known as the Wisest Man in Wall Street, was driving downtown when he recalled that it was the day young Spear was being sentenced for theft. Despite his preoccupation with various business matters, including a recent article attacking one of his trusts, he took note of the pleasant weather and spared a thought for the impact of sending someone to prison on such a fine day. He felt regret over writing a weak letter for Spear's probation, remembering him as a shy, hardworking young man. Inspired by sudden impulse, which often led to his successes, he ordered his driver to stop at the Court of General Sessions. A brief word from him to either the district attorney or the judge could make a difference. This decision underscored his reputation for quick action and wisdom.
summary_2: Renowned investor Arnold "Wisest Man" Thorndike halted his car near the courthouse where youth Spear faced judgment. Though busy with work issues, like an unfavorable article about one of his trusts, he pondered the beauty of the day and regretted submitting a tepid support letter for Spear's parole. Driven by whimsical inspiration, he instructed his chauffeur to pause at the court. His swift move highlighted both his decisiveness and sagacity.
summary_3: Investor Arnold Thorndike paused his car outside the courtyard, defying busyness to personally submit a strong support letter for Spear's parole, showcasing his wisdom and resolve.

text: After the August missile strikes, diplomatic options to press the Taliban seemed no more promising than military options.The United States had issued a formal warning to the Taliban, and also to Sudan, that they would be held directly responsible for any attacks on Americans, wherever they occurred, carried out by the  Bin Laden network as long as they continued to provide sanctuary to it.For a brief moment, it had seemed as if the August strikes might have shocked the Taliban into thinking of giving up  Bin Laden.On August 22, the reclusive Mullah Omar told a working-level State Department official that the strikes were counterproductive but added that he would be open to a dialogue with the United States on  Bin Laden's presence in Afghanistan.Meeting in Islamabad with William Milam, the U.S. ambassador to Pakistan, Taliban delegates said it was against their culture to expel someone seeking sanctuary but asked what would happen to  Bin Laden should he be sent to Saudi Arabia.Yet in September 1998, when the Saudi emissary, Prince Turki, asked Mullah Omar whether he would keep his earlier promise to expel  Bin Laden, the Taliban leader said no.Both sides shouted at each other, with Mullah Omar denouncing the Saudi government.Riyadh then suspended its diplomatic relations with the Taliban regime.(Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, and the United Arab Emirates were the only countries that recognized the Taliban as the legitimate government of Afghanistan.) Crown Prince Abdullah told President Clinton and Vice President Gore about this when he visited Washington in late September.His account confirmed reports that the U.S. government had received independently.Other efforts with the Saudi government centered on improving intelligence sharing and permitting U.S. agents to interrogate prisoners in Saudi custody.The history of such cooperation in 1997 and 1998 had been strained.Several officials told us, in particular, that the United States could not get direct access to an important al Qaeda financial official, Madani al Tayyib, who had been detained by the Saudi government in 1997.67Though U.S. officials repeatedly raised the issue, the Saudis provided limited information.In his September 1998 meeting with Crown Prince Abdullah, Vice President Gore, while thanking the Saudi government for their responsiveness, renewed the request for direct U.S. access to Tayyib.The United States never obtained this access.An NSC staff-led working group on terrorist finances asked the CIA in November 1998 to push again for access to Tayyib and to see "if it is possible to elaborate further on the ties between Usama bin Ladin and prominent individuals in Saudi Arabia, including especially the  Bin Laden family."One result was two NSC-led interagency trips to Persian Gulf states in 1999 and 2000.During these trips the NSC, Treasury, and intelligence representatives spoke with Saudi officials, and later interviewed members of the  Bin Laden family, about Usama's inheritance.
summary_1: Following the August missile strikes, diplomacy attempts towards the Taliban appeared unpromising, mirroring military strategies. The US warned both the Taliban and Sudan that they'd be held liable for any Bin Laden network assaults on Americans, demanding Bin Laden's extradition from the Taliban. Post-strike, there was a glimmer of hope as Mullah Omar expressed openness to discuss Bin Laden's presence in Afghanistan with the US. However, after Saudi envoy Prince Turki's visit in September, Mullah Omar backtracked on his promise to expel Bin Laden, leading to Saudi Arabia severing diplomatic ties with the Taliban. Cooperation talks focused on enhancing intel exchange and granting US interrogators access to Saudi-held prisoners, although past collaborations (1997-1998) faced challenges. Specifically, obtaining access to significant al Qaeda financier Madani al Tayyib, detained by Saudi authorities in '97, proved difficult despite repeated requests. In September '98, during Vice President Gore’s meeting with Crown Prince Abdullah, Gore restated the need for direct US access to Tayyib, yet failed to secure it. Two interagency visits to Persian Gulf states followed in 1999-2000, where NSC, Treasury, and intelligence teams met with Saudi officials and Bin Laden family members regarding Usama's inheritance.
summary_2: After August missile attacks, U.S.-Taliban diplomacy seemed unlikely due to military strategies. The U.S. threatened both the Taliban and Sudan over Bin Laden network attacks, demanding Bin Laden's extradition. Initially, Mullah Omar showed interest in discussing Bin Laden's presence but later reneged. This led to Saudi Arabia cutting ties with the Taliban. Discussions centered around improving intelligence sharing and allowing U.S. interrogators access to Saudi-held prisoners. Earlier collaborations had issues, such as getting access to key al Qaeda financier Madani al Tayyib, who was detained by Saudi authorities in '97. Despite repeated requests, this remained unresolved until at least 2000.
summary_3: U.S.-Taliban diplomacy on Bin Laden stalled after August missile strikes, despite initial Taliban willingness, leading to Saudi Arabia severing ties and unresolved issues regarding access to al Qaeda financiers.

text: Thursday, and Mr. Strong arrived with the inevitableness of dreaded events.Bambi felt convinced that his coming meant the premature death of her new-born career, so, naturally, she was prepared for grief.An element of amusement was added, however, by Jarvis's astonishing behaviour.Ever since the first mention of Mr. Strong's name he had shown unmistakable signs of dislike for that gentleman.'It was the most remarkable revelation of his strange character.Having totally ignored Bambi himself, it distressed him to think of any other man being attracted by her.His references to Mr. Strong's coming were many and satirical.This display of manly inconsistency was nuts and ale to Bambi.She wondered how much Mr. Strong would play up, and she decided to give Jarvis Jocelyn an uncomfortable hour.She herself was an adept in amatory science, but she was a trifle unsure of Mr. Strong.However, she remembered a certain twinkle in his eye that augured well.Because it was necessary to enlighten him as to the situation in advance, she arrayed herself most carefully to go and meet him.She encountered Jarvis on the stairs.He inspected her charming self, in a frock the colour of spring green leaves, topped by a crocus-coloured hat, like a flower.She deliberately pranced before him.
summary_1: On Thursday, Mr. Strong arrives, causing Bambi anticipation of imminent doom due to their strained relationship. Meanwhile, Jarvis displays unexpected animosity towards Mr. Strong, revealing a peculiar protectiveness over Bambi. Despite previously ignoring Bambi, he now seems bothered at the thought of another man taking interest in her. This behavior puzzles Bambi, who finds humor in this sudden masculine possessiveness from Jarvis. She decides to make things awkward for him. Although confident in romantic matters, Bambi feels slightly uncertain about Mr. Strong's response. However, she recalls a glimmer in his gaze suggesting potential mutual attraction. Hoping to inform Mr. Strong about the circumstances ahead of time, Bambi dresses elegantly - wearing a green outfit reminiscent of spring leaves under a bright yellow hat resembling a blooming flower. As they cross paths, she flaunts her appearance intentionally in front of Jarvis.
summary_2: Bambi expects trouble when Mr. Strong visits due to past conflicts. Surprisingly, Jarvis shows hostility toward him, protective of Bambi despite previous indifference. Puzzled by this change, Bambi amusedly observes Jarvis' newfound male territoriality. Dressing up, she passes before them, hoping to prepare Mr. Strong for upcoming events. Though unsure of his reaction, she notes his intrigued glance earlier.
summary_3: Bambi observes Jarvis acting protectively towards her around Mr. Strong, surprising her but also amusing her; dressing up, she hopes to impress Mr. Strong with an intriguing appearance.

text: California lags far behind comparable states in funding legal services for the poor, a situation so dire that only 28 percent of the civil legal needs of the state's poor and lowerincome residents are being addressed.That figures translates into 2 million people without the ability to access the justice system, according to a new study by the California Commission on Access to Justice, which also found that despite increased spending, the gap between need and services remains substantial."As a practical matter, in most cases there can be no access to justice without access to legal assistance," said Jack Londen, past commission chair and a partner with Morrison & Foerster in San Francisco."Whether we like it or not, sometimes landlords illegally evict tenants, children with disabilities are denied proper care, veterans don't get services guaranteed to them, and elderly people need legal assistance to escape the abuse of a caregiver."California has the highest number of people in poverty in the nation - 6.4 million, including nearly one in five children.Half the nation's increase in poverty in the 1990s, when the number of poor jumped 30 percent, occurred in California, and nearly 25 percent of the nation's poverty increase occurred in Los Angeles County alone.Even those with jobs are suffering: 26 percent of California workers earn poverty level wages.The commission's report, "The Path to Equal Justice: A Five-Year Status Report on Access to Justice in California," examined how the legal needs of the state's poor have changed in the last five years as well as both the shortcomings of the justice system and the improvements during that period.Despite increases in state funding to meet the legal needs of the poor, low interest rates (which have reduced the IOLTA fund), high unemployment and the present economic downturn have threatened any gains.
summary_1: California significantly trails other states in financing civil legal aid for impoverished individuals, leaving 72% of their legal requirements unmet. This equates to two million underprivileged Californians unable to utilize the judicial system, per a recent analysis by the California Commission on Access to Justice. The research indicates that even though expenditure has risen, the disparity between demand and supply persists. According to Jack Londen, former commission chairman and Morrison & Foerster partner in San Francisco, effective access to justice hinges on accessibility to legal support. Instances include illegal tenant evictions, disabled kids being refused appropriate treatment, military personnel failing to obtain entitled benefits, and senior citizens requiring legal help against abusive caretakers. With 6.4 million inhabitants living below the poverty line, California ranks first among U.S. states in terms of poverty incidence, affecting close to one out of every five minors. Half of America's overall rise in poverty throughout the '90s took place in California, while L.A. County experienced almost 25% of this surge. Despite having employment, 26% of Californian employees still earn at poverty levels. The commission's latest report, titled "The Path to Equal Justice: A Five-Year Progress Report on Access to Justice in California", investigates alterations in the legal demands of California's disadvantaged population over the previous five years alongside advancements and insufficiencies within the justice network. Although public funding has grown to cater to the indigent's legal necessities, low-interest rates diminishing the IOLTA fund, escalating joblessness, and current financial recession jeopardize these enhancements.
summary_2: California lags behind other states in providing civil legal aid for poor residents, leaving many needs unfulfilled. Two million impoverished Californians cannot access the legal system, according to a study by the California Commission on Access to Justice. Expenditure has increased but cannot meet high demand. Effective justice requires accessible legal assistance, says Jack Londen, ex-chairman of the commission. Issues like unfair tenant eviction, denied medical services for disabled children, veterans not receiving due benefits, and elderly abuse require legal intervention. Over six million Californians live in poverty, with half of the nationwide increase since the 1990s occurring there. Even employed Californians struggle financially - 26%. Funding improvements may be reversed due to economic downturn and rising unemployment.
summary_3: California faces challenges meeting demands for civil legal aid, affecting millions of low-income residents and impacting various issues such as housing, healthcare, and veteran benefits.

text: After the disruption of the plot in Amman, it had not escaped notice in Washington that Hijazi had lived in California and driven a cab in Boston and that Deek was a naturalized U.S. citizen who, as Berger reminded President Clinton, had been in touch with extremists in the United States as well as abroad.Before Ressam's arrest, Berger saw no need to raise a public alarm at home- although the FBI put all field offices on alert.Now, following Ressam's arrest, the FBI asked for an unprecedented number of special wiretaps.Both Berger andTenet told us that their impression was that more Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) wiretap requests were processed during the millennium alert than ever before.The next day, writing about Ressam's arrest and links to a cell in Montreal, Berger informed the President that the FBI would advise police in the United States to step up activities but would still try to avoid undue public alarm by stressing that the government had no specific information about planned attacks.At a December 22 meeting of the Small Group of principals, FBI Director Louis Freeh briefed officials from the NSC staff, CIA, and Justice on wiretaps and investigations inside the United States, including a Brooklyn entity tied to the Ressam arrest, a seemingly unreliable foreign report of possible attacks on seven U.S. cities, two Algerians detained on the Canadian border, and searches in Montreal related to a jihadist cell.The Justice Department released a statement on the alert the same day.Clarke's staff warned, "Foreign terrorist sleeper cells are present in the US and attacks in the US are likely."Clarke asked Berger to try to make sure that the domestic agencies remained alert."Is there a threat to civilian aircraft?"he wrote.Clarke also asked the principals in late December to discuss a foreign security service report about a  Bin Laden plan to put bombs on transatlantic flights.The CSG met daily.Berger said that the principals met constantly.Later, when asked what made her decide to ask Ressam to step out of his vehicle, Diana Dean, a Customs inspector who referred Ressam to secondary inspection, testified that it was her "training and experience."It appears that the heightened sense of alert at the national level played no role in Ressam's detention.There was a mounting sense of public alarm.The earlier Jordanian arrests had been covered in the press, and Ressam's arrest was featured on network evening news broadcasts throughout the Christmas season.The FBI was more communicative during the millennium crisis than it had ever been.
summary_1: Following the thwarted attack in Amman, authorities discovered that suspect Ahmed Ressam had resided in California and worked as a taxi driver in Boston, while another conspirator named Deek held American citizenship and had connections to radical groups both domestically and overseas. Prior to Ressam's capture, National Security Advisor Sandy Berger opted against publicly addressing potential threats within the U.S., though he did order increased vigilance among FBI field offices. Post-arrest, the FBI sought additional FISA wiretaps, leading Berger and CIA head George Tenet to observe a surge in such surveillance requests. The FBI cautioned local law enforcement without causing widespread panic. On December 21, FBI Director Louis Freeh updated senior officials on ongoing probes into ties between Ressam and a Montreal-based terror cell, along with other leads like alleged plots targeting multiple U.S. urban centers and encounters involving suspicious individuals near the Canadian border. In response to these developments, Clarke urged relevant domestic agencies to maintain high readiness levels. A contentious internal debate ensued regarding the likelihood of aviation-related assaults, culminating in the Principals Committee discussing a foreign intelligence report suggesting al-Qaeda aimed to plant explosives aboard transatlantic flights. Despite escalating public concern over potential strikes, Ressam's apprehension seemed unrelated to any heightened national vigilance; instead, customs officer Diana Dean attributed the bust to her professional training and expertise.
summary_2: Ahmed Ressam was found living in California after an attempted attack in Amman. He drove taxis in Boston, and his accomplice, Deek, was an American citizen linked to extremist organizations. Before Ressam's arrest, National Security Advisor Sandy Berger chose not to disclose possible US threats but ordered enhanced vigilance by FBI field offices. After Ressam's arrest, the FBI applied for more FISA wiretaps, prompting Berger and CIA chief George Tenet to note a rise in such applications. The FBI alerted local police without causing alarm. By December 21, FBI Director Louis Freeh informed top officials about investigations linking Ressam to a Montreal terrorist group and various US city targets. Officials were advised to stay vigilant due to suspected plans to bomb airplanes, based on a foreign intel report. However, Ressam's arrest appeared unconnected to increased national watchfulness, being rather credited to custom agent Diana Dean's skills.
summary_3: After Ahmed Ressam's arrest in Washington state, it's learned he lived in California and had an American accomplice, Deek; before his arrest, increased FBI vigilance was ordered due to potential US threats, leading to more FISA wiretap requests and heightened local law enforcement awareness; Ressam's ties to a Canadian terror cell targeting US cities with plane bombings were discovered, but his capture resulted from a customs agent's actions, not boosted national surveillance.

text: What if you could drain all of Earths oceans?What would it look like?You might be really surprised.You see that the surface has two main features.It has continents and ocean basins.Continents are large land areas.These are the areas that are mostly above sea level.Ocean basins extend from the edges of continents.They include the ocean floor and Earths deep ocean trenches.You will also notice the ocean floor is not flat.It too has many Continents are much older than ocean basins.Some rocks on the continents are billions of years old.Ocean basins may only be millions of years old.Because the continents are so old, a lot has happened to them!As we view the land around us, we see landforms.Landforms are physical features on Earths surface.These features change over time, but how?There are actually two types of forces at work.
summary_1:
Imagine draining all of Earth's oceans. The resulting landscape would be unlike anything you'd expect. The planet's surface primarily consists of two elements: continents and ocean basins.
