text: The mighty fane, with its three massive towers, rises majestically over the red roofs of the town.Its most striking feature is the great Norman screen, running up without buttresses or projections to the parapet and hiding the bases of the square, richly decorated towers of the west front.The plain centre of the screen is the work of Remigius, the first bishop.The rest of it is relieved with rich arcading of Late Norman and Early English periods.The wooden spires which crowned the towers were removed in 1807.In 1192 Hugh of Avalon determined to rebuild the Norman building of Remigius, which an earthquake had shaken.To him we owe the choir and eastern transept.His successors completed the western transept and began the west end of the nave.So much money had to be spent in rebuilding the central tower, which fell in 1239, that the canons could not rebuild the nave entirely, but had to incorporate the Norman end by Remigius.Unfortunately the axis of the west front does not correspond to that of the nave, which is too wide for its height.The low vaulting is a serious defect in the choir built by St. Hugh, but of the superb beauty of the Angel Choir, which encloses his shrine, there can be no doubt.In its richness of sculpture it is one of the masterpieces of Gothic architecture in England.The interior of the cathedral is remarkable for the harmony of its style, which is Lancet-Gothic, and the dim lighting of the nave only adds to its impressiveness.
summary_1: Lincoln Cathedral stands proudly above the town, recognized by its trio of colossal towers. The structure features a grand Norman façade, characterized by a monumental screen reaching the top uninterrupted by supports or extensions, concealing the base of the decorative towers at the west front. The center section is attributed to Remigius, Lincoln's inaugural bishop, while the remaining parts showcase elaborate arcading from both the Late Norman and Early English eras. Originally, wood adorned the pinnacles until their removal in 1807. In 1192, Bishop Hugh of Avalon resolved to reconstruct Remigius' damaged Norman edifice after an earthquake. This led to the creation of the choir and eastern transept. Subsequent leaders continued the construction of the western transept and initiated the nave's western portion. However, financial constraints due to the collapsing central tower in 1239 forced the inclusion of Remigius' initial design into the nave's completion. Regrettably, the main entrance's alignment deviates from the nave's width, resulting in lower vaulting within the choir designed by St. Hugh. Nevertheless, the resplendent Angel Choir, housing his shrine, remains a gem of Gothic architecture thanks to its exquisite stonework - making it a standout architectural marvel in England. Overall, the cathedral captivates visitors with its consistent Lancet-Gothic motifs and subdued illumination throughout the nave.
summary_2: Lincoln Cathedral boasts three large towers and a mix of Norman and Gothic styles. Its original wooden pinnacles were replaced with stone ones in 1807. Construction began with Bishop Remigius, who built the Norman façade and west front. An earthquake in 1192 led to rebuilding by Bishop Hugh, creating the choir and eastern transept. Financial issues halted progress, merging new designs with Remigius' original plan for the nave. Despite misalignment causing lower vaulting in the choir, the Angel Choir, featuring fine stonework and St. Hugh's shrine, stands out as a Gothic masterpiece.
summary_3: Lincoln Cathedral features three towers and combines Norman and Gothic architectural elements, including an earthquake-damaged choir rebuilt in Gothic style, resulting in a notable mismatch that distinguishes its unique appearance.

text: Alexis de Tocqueville and Gustave de Beaumont in America: Their Friendship and Their Travels edited by Oliver Zunz, translated by Arthur Goldhammer (University of Virginia Press; 2011) 698 pages; Includes previously unpublished letters, essays, and other writings Du systeme penitentaire aux Etats-Unis et de son application en France (1833) - On the Penitentiary System in the United States and Its Application to France, with Gustave de Beaumont.De la democratie en Amerique (1835/1840) - Democracy in America.It was published in two volumes, the first in 1835, the second in 1840.English language versions: Tocqueville, Democracy in America, trans.and eds., Harvey C. Mansfield and Delba Winthrop, University of Chicago Press, 2000; Tocqueville, Democracy in America (Arthur Goldhammer, trans.; Olivier Zunz, ed.) (The Library of America, 2004) ISBN 978-1-931082-54-9.L'Ancien Regime et la Revolution (1856) - The Old Regime and the Revolution.It is Tocqueville's second most famous work.Recollections (1893) - This work was a private journal of the Revolution of 1848.He never intended to publish this during his lifetime; it was published by his wife and his friend Gustave de Beaumont after his death.Journey to America (1831-1832) - Alexis de Tocqueville's travel diary of his visit to America; translated into English by George Lawrence, edited by J-P Mayer, Yale University Press, 1960; based on vol.V, 1 of the OEuvres Completes of Tocqueville.L'Etat social et politique de la France avant et depuis 1789 - Alexis de Tocqueville Memoir On Pauperism: Does public charity produce an idle and dependant class of society?(1835) originally published by Ivan R. Dee.Inspired by a trip to England.One of Tocqueville's more obscure works.Journeys to England and Ireland 1835
summary_1: Titled "Alexis de Tocqueville and Gustave de Beaumont in America," this book offers insights into the friendship and travels of two influential French thinkers. It includes their correspondence, essays, and other writings from their time in America, providing a comprehensive view of their observations and reflections. Key works include "Democracy in America" (1835/1840), which examines American democracy and its implications for modern societies, and "On the Penitentiary System in the United States and Its Application to France" (1833). Additionally featured are "The Old Regime and the Revolution" (1856), reflecting on the causes and consequences of the French Revolution, and "Recollections" (1893), initially meant as a personal record but later published posthumously. Other notable works comprise "Journey to America" (1831-1832), documenting Tocqueville's experiences and impressions during his voyage to the United States, and "Memoir On Pauperism" (1835), inspired by his visit to England. Overall, these texts offer valuable perspectives on Enlightenment thought, political philosophy, and societal development.
summary_2: This compilation brings together Alexis de Tocqueville and Gustave de Beaumont's works, including "Democracy in America" and "On the Penitentiary System." Also included are "The Old Regime and the Revolution," "Recollections," "Journey to America," and "Memoir On Pauperism." These texts provide insights into American democracy, societal development, and Enlightenment thought, based on their travels and observations.
summary_3: Alexis de Tocqueville and Gustave de Beaumont's works, including "Democracy in America" and others, offer insights into American democracy, societal development, and Enlightenment thought based on their travels and observations.

text: What a time of it Dawson's Landing was having! All its life it had been asleep, but now it hardly got a chance for a nod, so swiftly did big events and crashing surprises come along in one another's wake: Friday morning, first glimpse of Real Nobility, also grand reception at Aunt Patsy Cooper's, also great robber raid; Friday evening, dramatic kicking of the heir of the chief citizen in presence of four hundred people; Saturday morning, emergence as practicing lawyer of the long-submerged Pudd'nhead Wilson; Saturday night, duel between chief citizen and titled stranger. The people took more pride in the duel than in all the other events put together, perhaps. It was a glory to their town to have such a thing happen there. In their eyes the principals had reached the summit of human honor. Everybody paid homage to their names; their praises were in all mouths. Even the duelists' subordinates came in for a handsome share of the public approbation: wherefore Pudd'nhead Wilson was suddenly become a man of consequence. When asked to run for the mayoralty Saturday night, he was risking defeat, but Sunday morning found him a made man and his success assured.
summary_1: Dawson's Landing experiences rapid succession of significant events: on Friday, the town sees nobility for the first time, attends a grand reception at Aunt Patsy Cooper's, and witnesses a robbery. That evening, the heir of the leading citizen is publicly kicked. On Saturday, Pudd'nhead Wilson begins his law practice. That night, the leading citizen and a nobleman engage in a duel, an event that fills the citizens with immense pride. The duelists are highly esteemed, and even those associated with them gain respect. By Sunday, Wilson's popularity surges, making him a serious contender for mayor.
summary_2: This weekend in Dawson's Landing, nobility visits, causing a stir. A reception is held at Aunt Patsy Cooper's, ending in a robbery. The leading citizen's heir is publicly humiliated. On Saturday, lawyer Pudd'nhead Wilson starts work. A notable duel occurs, boosting everyone's status, including Wilson's. His popularity soars, positioning him well for the mayoral race.
summary_3: Nobles visit Dawson's Landing, leading to a robbery at a reception, public humiliation, and a boost in status for a new lawyer named Pudd'nhead Wilson, who becomes popular after a notable duel.

text: How can you describe your location?You might use a familiar system.You might say, 'I live at 1234 Main Street, Springfield, Ohio.' You could also say, 'I live right behind the Elementary School.' This method uses the school as a point of reference.Another example is, I am at the corner of Maple Street and Main Street. Both streets may be a good reference for anyone living in your town.Scientists must be able to pinpoint a feature they are studying.Scientists use a special system to describe locations.They use latitude and longitude as a reference.Lines of latitude and longitude form a grid.You may have used a grid system while doing graphing.This grid is centered on a reference point.Zero latitude is the equator.Lines of latitude run east to west.They divide the Earth from North to South.Lines of longitude run from north to south.They divide the Earth from East to West.Zero longitude runs through Greenwich, England.You may have heard the term, Greenwich Mean Time, or GMT.The system of latitude and longitude works well for objects that do not move.
summary_1: People often specify their whereabouts using a recognized framework. They might express their location as '1234 Main Street, Springfield, Ohio,' or 'behind the Elementary School.' Another instance would be 'the intersection of Maple Street and Main Street.' These references should be clear to any local inhabitants. Scientific exploration necessitates precise positioning of subjects. Researchers employ a specialized coordinate system utilizing latitude and longitude. Latitude and longitude establish a grid pattern. Similar to graph paper, this layout incorporates a central reference point. The equator signifies zero latitude, which extends east to west. Lines of latitude, running north to south, segment the Earth. Longitude lines, extending from north to south, bisect the Earth from east to west. Zero longitude traverses Greenwich, England, corresponding to Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). This latitude/longitude system functions optimally for stationary entities.
summary_2: Locations can be specified through familiar systems like addresses or landmarks. For precision, researchers use latitude and longitude, forming a global grid with the equator at zero latitude. Meridians, measured from GMT's Greenwich, divide earth longitudinally. Ideal for fixed objects, it may not suit moving targets well.
summary_3: Researchers utilize latitude and longitude, including meridians from Greenwich, to precisely locate fixed objects on Earth.

text: Magnets are able to place a force on certain materials.This force is called a magnetic force.The force a magnet exerts is a little different from the forces you may normally think about.You exert a force on a book when you lift it.You also exert a force on the pedals of your bicycle.In both those cases, those forces cause a change.The change you see in both these cases is called motion.Magnets, too, can produce change.They can produce motion just like you do.Unlike you, magnets do not have to touch something to exert a force.A magnetic force is exerted over a distance.Thats right, a magnet can push or pull certain items without ever touching them.Thats how the maglev train works.Do you know another type of force that does not require objects to touch?These forces are known as non-contact forces.Another type of non-contact force you may be familiar with is gravity.Gravity too can cause changes in motion.Gravity holds our moon in orbit without touching it.
summary_1: Magnets possess the ability to exert a force known as magnetic force, which distinguishes itself from typical forces humans might encounter. When one lifts an object such as a book or applies pressure on bike pedals, they generate a force resulting in motion. Similarly, magnets can induce movement, albeit differently. In contrast to human interaction, magnetic force operates even without physical contact between objects. This phenomenon allows for actions such as pushing or pulling items remotely. A practical application of this principle is the Maglev (magnetic levitation) train, illustrating the capacity of magnets to create motion at a distance. Another example of non-contact force is gravity, which shares similar characteristics by causing alterations in motion without requiring direct contact, much like Earth retaining its lunar orbit through gravitational influence.
summary_2: Magnets have unique 'magnetic force,' differing from common forces humans apply. Like moving a book or pressing bike pedals, magnets cause motion without touch due to their distinct force. An instance is the Maglev train, demonstrating remote action potential. Similar to gravity, it causes changes without contact, maintaining the moon's orbit via attraction.
summary_3: Magnets generate a distinctive force causing motion without physical contact, exemplified by the Maglev train and Earth's gravitational pull on the moon.

text: Tim had always a red bike.His birthday party was coming up and he hoped that his parents would finally get him the bike.When his friends came over for the party, Tim was very worried that he wouldn't get the bike.He looked at all the presents and none of them seemed big enough to have a bike in them.Tim was sad.When it was time to open the presents he opened them one at a time.The first present was not a bike.The second present was not a bike.The third present was the biggest one.Tim knew if the bike was going to be in any of the presents it was going to be in this box.Tim opened it and there was no bike inside.Just as Tim tried not to look too upset, his Dad brought in the biggest present of them all.His Dad had been hiding the present all along.Tim opened it and his new bike was inside the box.Tim put the bike together with his Dad's help.
summary_1: At Tim's birthday party, he eagerly anticipated receiving a long-desired red bicycle from his parents. As his friends arrived, they exchanged gifts. Each gift Tim opened wasn't his coveted bike, intensifying his disappointment. Finally, his father presented an oversized package, which turned out to contain another non-bicycle item. Ultimately, his father revealed the pièce de résistance—a hidden, sizable gift containing Tim's brand-new red bicycle. Together, they assembled the cherished present.
summary_2: At Tim's birthday, each gift unwrapped fueled his disappointment, but when all hope seemed lost, his dad unveiled a large gift, concealing his prized red bicycle, leading to a joyful ending where Tim finally got his dream bike.
summary_3: Tim received his longed-for red bicycle from his father at his birthday, ending his initial disappointments.

text: Growing up on a farm near St. Paul, L. Mark Bailey didn't dream of becoming a judge.Even when he graduated from North Decatur High School in 1975, sitting on the bench someday seemed more like a leisurely activity than a career.Somewhere along the line, all of that changed.Bailey received his bachelor's degree from the University of Indianapolis in 1978 and a jurisprudence doctorate from Indiana University-Indianapolis in 1982.After several years of private practice from 1982-90, he became the judge of Decatur County Court for a year.The Indiana legislature renamed that judgeship and Bailey was tabbed Decatur Superior Court judge from 1992-98, winning reelection twice.From there, his career continued on the fast track and Bailey was appointed by Gov. Frank O'Bannon to sit on the Indiana Court of Appeals First District, where he works today.Despite his quick climb up the legal ladder, Bailey has always found time to help out in causes he feels strongly about.It was for his dedication to the law and the people that are affected by it that he was recently recognized.The Indiana Pro Bono Commission hosted its annual celebration event, the Randall T. Shepard Dinner, at French Lick Springs Spa in October.More than 100 judges, lawyers and dignitaries were present for the gathering.One of the highlights of the event was the presentation of the first-ever Randall T. Shepard award for excellence in pro bono work.Bailey received the award for his three years of volunteer work at Indiana Pro Bono Commission.The award was named after the chief justice of the Indiana Supreme Court to honor his statewide vision on justice.The qualifications for the award were based upon demonstrated dedication to the innovative development and delivery of legal services to the poor in one of the 14 pro bono districts of Indiana."This award came as a real surprise to me.It is truly an honor.Just being the first chair of the commission which began the implementation of the pro bono process was somewhat humbling.
summary_1: L. Mark Bailey, a judge at the Indiana Court of Appeals First District, pursued a legal career despite initially viewing it as a hobby rather than a profession. Graduating from North Decatur High School in 1975, Bailey went on to earn a bachelor's degree in 1978 and a Juris Doctor in 1982 from the University of Indianapolis and Indiana University-Indianapolis, respectively. Following several years in private practice (1982-90), he served as Decatur County Court Judge (1991-92) before assuming the role of Decatur Superior Court judge (1992-98). Governor Frank O'Bannon later appointed him to the Indiana Court of Appeals First District. Parallel to this successful trajectory, Bailey remained committed to community involvement. In recognition of his dedication to law and those impacted by it, the Indiana Pro Bono Commission presented him with the inaugural Randall T. Shepard Award for outstanding pro bono service. The esteemed accolade acknowledged Bailey's three-year commitment to volunteering at the Indiana Pro Bono Commission, aligning with the Chief Justice of the Indiana Supreme Court's vision for justice across the state.
summary_2: Judge L. Mark Bailey, after graduating in 1982, practiced privately before becoming Decatur County Court Judge in 1991, then Decatur Superior Court Judge in 1992, and finally, an Indiana Court of Appeals First District Judge, all while engaging in community work. He received the first Randall T. Shepard Award for his three-year volunteer effort at the Indiana Pro Bono Commission, reflecting his devotion to law and its affected individuals.
summary_3: After practicing privately, Judge L. Mark Bailey became a Decatur County Court Judge, later moving on to become Decatur Superior Court Judge and eventually an Indiana Court of Appeals First District Judge, all while doing community work; he was honored with the first Randall T. Shepard Award for his pro bono efforts.

text: It's just this hard when I try to answer the question: Why do older Oklahomans need lawyers?The answers are important enough that they will be a discussion topic of this year's Senior Day at 9 a.m.March 25 in the House Chamber at the Capitol.The following is a preview of some of the answers for review: We can all agree that older Oklahomans need medical care.But even the best care is worthless if an older patient can't drive to the doctor for ongoing treatment because his or her car has been wrongfully seized in a debt dispute.Therefore, lawyers are part of the prescription for regular medical care for many of the 600,000 Oklahomans age 60 and older.Another example: if a doctor treats an elderly patient for a lung ailment, the doctor's treatment will be undone and he will see the patient again and again, if the patient is sent home to an unheated apartment.Lawyers know how to make landlords heat apartments so the medical treatment can stick.(By the way, a May 16, 2001, article in The New York Times reports on a program at Boston Medical Center providing a walk-in legal clinic in the hospital to help fight their patients' legal and administrative battles.) We also can agree that older Oklahomans - like all citizens - have rights to control their health care until they become incapacitated or these rights are transferred to another by legal document or process."Old" is not a legal classification that results in automatic loss of these rights.Moreover, having an old parent does not automatically confer on children the right to make the parents' health care choices.It follows that an important role lawyers provide for aging Oklahomans is not only to create rights - transferring documents such as durable powers of attorney and guardianship orders, but also to monitor their use.In family situations, for example, lawyers must ensure that powers of attorney and guardianships are used to serve only the person transferring or losing rights.They are not to be used to help a family "manage" their mother or help a doctor or nursing home get permission for a pill or procedure they feel is in the best interest of a patient.Good news: Oklahoma now has a Public Guardianship Program, albeit unfunded, that will supply lawyers to perform this rights-monitoring process Oklahoma grandparents should be able to enjoy their grandchildren, not raise them.But owing to the social problems of divorce and drug use, grandparents are increasingly being called on to raise their grandchildren because of missing parents.Adding to the physical, emotional and financial burden they take on, grandparents face legal problems.All the decisions parents made without a second thought now require evidence of legal authority when made by grandparents.
summary_1:
Older Oklahomans often find themselves requiring legal assistance due to various reasons related to healthcare, housing, and childcare. This necessity for legal aid makes it a crucial topic for the upcoming Senior Day on March 25th at the State Capitol. A few significant issues include:

Firstly, access to consistent medical care can be jeopardized when elders cannot drive to appointments due to vehicle repossession from debt disputes. Lawyers play a vital role in helping seniors maintain transportation for essential treatments.

Secondly, living conditions impact overall wellbeing; therefore, lawyers are necessary to address landlord negligence concerning adequate heating in residences where elderly individuals reside. Addressing these environmental factors ensures proper medical treatment adherence.

Thirdly, while aging doesn't legally strip one's autonomy over personal healthcare decisions, lawyers remain pivotal in drafting and monitoring documentation outlining power of attorney and guardianship orders. They protect vulnerable seniors from potential misuse of authority within families or institutions.

Lastly, increased responsibility among grandparents raising minor relatives creates new challenges. Legal support helps navigate decision-making processes regarding custody, finances, and other critical matters.

To summarize, there are several compelling reasons why older Oklahomans rely on legal professionals for guidance through complexities pertaining to healthcare, housing, and familial obligations.
summary_2: Elderly Oklahomans need legal help with health, home, and family matters, especially before the state's Senior Day. Key issues involve maintaining transport for medical visits amidst debt disputes, handling landlords who neglect tenants' needs, managing power of attorney and guardianship documents, and assisting grandparents caring for younger relatives. Legal experts ensure seniors get consistent care, safe homes, clear directives, and family support.
summary_3: Elderly Oklahomans require legal assistance for various health, housing, and familial issues, including transportation, landlord negligence, power of attorney, and childcare, ensuring their safety, comfort, and familial support.

text: While Nashiri was in Afghanistan, Nibras and Khamri saw their chance.They piloted the explosives-laden boat alongside the USS Cole, made friendly gestures to crew members, and detonated the bomb.Quso did not arrive at the apartment in time to film the attack.Back in Afghanistan,  Bin Laden anticipated U.S. military retaliation.He ordered the evacuation of al Qaeda's Kandahar airport compound and fled- first to the desert area near Kabul, then to Khowst and Jalalabad, and eventually back to Kandahar.In Kandahar, he rotated between five to six residences, spending one night at each residence.In addition, he sent his senior advisor, Mohammed Atef, to a different part of Kandahar and his deputy, Ayman al Zawahiri, to Kabul so that all three could not be killed in one attack.There was no American strike.In February 2001, a source reported that an individual whom he identified as the big instructor (probably a reference to  Bin Laden) complained frequently that the United States had not yet attacked.According to the source,  Bin Laden wanted the United States to attack, and if it did not he would launch something bigger.The attack on the USS Cole galvanized al Qaeda's recruitment efforts.Following the attack,  Bin Laden instructed the media committee, then headed by Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, to produce a propaganda video that included a reenactment of the attack along with images of the al Qaeda training camps and training methods; it also highlighted Muslim suffering in Palestine, Kashmir, Indonesia, and Chechnya.Al Qaeda's image was very important to  Bin Laden, and the video was widely disseminated.Portions were aired on Al Jazeera, CNN, and other television outlets.It was also disseminated among many young men in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, and caused many extremists to travel to Afghanistan for training and jihad.Al Qaeda members considered the video an effective tool in their struggle for preeminence among other Islamist and jihadist movements.
summary_1: Bin Laden associate Ramzi Binalshibh, known as "Nibras," and another man named Khamri, piloted a boat loaded with explosives next to the USS Cole in October 2000, causing its destruction and loss of life. This was in response to Bin Laden's desire for a larger attack due to the lack of US retaliation after the bombings in Africa. The event boosted al Qaeda's recruitment drive significantly. Following this, Bin Laden moved around various locations in Afghanistan, including Kandahar, where he frequently changed residences and sent his associates to separate areas to avoid being targeted. In early 2001, Bin Laden expressed frustration over America's inaction and threatened further attacks. After the Cole bombing, al Qaeda produced a propaganda video featuring a reenactment of the incident, highlighting Muslim struggles worldwide. The video aimed to enhance al Qaeda's reputation and attracted more recruits from Saudi Arabia and Yemen.
summary_2: In October 2000, Ramzi Binalshibh and an accomplice rammed a boat filled with explosives into the USS Cole at Bin Laden's command, resulting in deaths and significant damage. This followed Bin Laden's call for a major assault due to insufficient U.S. reaction to African bombings. The incident bolstered al Qaeda's recruitment efforts. Post-incident, Bin Laden shifted bases across Afghanistan, often changing homes and dispatching allies to different places to dodge detection. By early 2001, Bin Laden grew discontented with American inactivity and vowed additional strikes. A post-Cole al Qaeda video dramatized the event, emphasizing global Muslim conflicts, aiming to elevate their status and draw more supporters from Saudi Arabia and Yemen.
summary_3: Ramzi Binalshibh, under Bin Laden's orders, rammed a boat full of explosives into the USS Cole in October 2000, causing casualties and damage, and this incident boosted al Qaeda's recruitment; by early 2001, Bin Laden, frustrated with American inaction, threatened further attacks, while an al Qaeda video highlighting the USS Cole attack aimed to gain support from Saudi Arabia and Yemen.

text: In 1878, Martinez Campos was Governor-General of Cuba, and Maximo Gomez was Commander-in-Chief of the Cuban forces.Both parties were weary of the prolonged hostilities, and neither was able to compel the other to surrender.Spain, however, professed a willingness to yield an important part of the demands of her rebellious subjects.Martinez Campos and Gomez met at Zanjon and, on February 10, 1878, mutually agreed to what has been variously called a peace pact, a treaty, and a capitulation.The agreement was based on provisions for a redress of Cuban grievances through greater civil, political, and administrative privileges for the Cubans, with forgetfulness of the past and amnesty for all then under sentence for political offences.Delay in carrying these provisions into effect gave rise to an attempt to renew the struggle two years later, but the effort was a failure.Matters then quieted down for a number of years.The Cubans waited to see what would be done.The Spanish Governor-General still remained the supreme power and, aside from the abolition of slavery, the application of the Spanish Constitution and Spanish laws to Cuba, and Cuban representation in the Cortes, much of which was rather form than fact, the island gained little by the new conditions.Discontent and protest continued and, at last, broke again into open rebellion in 1895.
summary_1: In 1878, Martinez Campos, the Governor-General of Cuba, and Maximo Gomez, the Commander-in-Chief of the Cuban forces, both fatigued by ongoing conflict, sought an end to the strife. Spain showed readiness to concede significant parts of the rebels' claims. The two leaders convened at Zanjon, culminating in an accord on February 10, 1878 - a truce, treaty, or surrender, depending on interpretation. This pact aimed to address Cuban grievances via enhanced civil, political, and administrative rights, with forgiveness for those incarcerated for political crimes. However, implementation delays sparked another uprising two years later, though it ultimately failed. A period of calm ensued until 1895 when discontent resurfaced, escalating into full-blown rebellion due to lingering dissatisfaction despite some changes like abolishing slavery, applying the Spanish Constitution and laws to Cuba, and Cuban representation in the Cortes, most of which proved more symbolic than substantial.
summary_2: In 1878, Martinez Campos and Maximo Gomez sought peace in Cuba, leading to the Zanjon Accord. This agreement aimed to resolve Cuban grievances through expanded civil, political, and administrative rights, and amnesty for political prisoners. Despite this, delays led to another uprising in 1880. Dissatisfaction persisted, resulting in a major rebellion in 1895 due to unfulfilled promises, including abolition of slavery and Cuban representation in the Cortes. While these changes were implemented, they largely remained symbolic rather than substantive.
summary_3: The Zanjon Accord in 1878 failed to fully address Cuban grievances, leading to further unrest and a major rebellion in 1895 due to unfulfilled promises, despite some symbolic changes.

text: Heat supplies the energy that causes motion.The deeper you go into toward the Earths core, the hotter it gets.At the core it is really hot.All that heat tries to rise toward the surface.In the Mantle, the rock is partially melted and is able to move.As it is heated, the material in the mantle moves toward the surface.As the mantle material rises, it cools.When it reaches the Earths crust, it is mostly stopped.A little of the material can break through the surface, but not all.Instead, it begins to move horizontally.The mantle material moves horizontally away from a mid-ocean ridge crest.Toward the surface, the mantle material starts to cool.As it cools it sinks back down into the mantle.These areas are where deep sea trench occur.The material sinks back down to the core.The system operates like a giant conveyor belt.The motion due to heating and cooling is called convection.
summary_1: Earth's core is extremely hot, providing the heat that fuels movement within the planet. This heat attempts to ascend towards the surface, initiating a complex process. In the mantle, the intense heat causes partial melting of the rock, enabling its movement. As this molten material rises, it eventually reaches the Earth's crust, where it encounters resistance and cannot proceed further upwards. However, some of it manages to breach the surface, spreading out horizontally. This horizontal movement is most noticeable near mid-ocean ridges. The rising material then starts to cool, becoming denser and sinking back into the mantle. This descent typically occurs at deep-sea trenches. The overall process resembles a colossal conveyor belt, driven by the continuous cycle of heating and cooling, known as convection.
summary_2: The Earth's core heats the mantle, causing partial rock melting and movement. Rising molten material meets resistance at the crust but spreads out horizontally near mid-ocean ridges. Cooling ensues, increasing density, leading to sinking back into the mantle at deep-sea trenches. A giant convection cycle results from constant heating and cooling.
summary_3: Heat from Earth's core causes rock melting in the mantle, resulting in horizontal spreading at mid-ocean ridges, cooling, densification, sinking at deep-sea trenches, and overall convection.

text: Allan crouched over his desk once more, pen in hand and mind blank.He contemplated a story, an outline he had laboriously constructed some time ago.He had filled his pen and raised it, the nib descending towards the paper, before the sound came: the gentle, persistent tapping of the gnarled, primeval willow touching the window with long, insistent fingers.His eyes awoke with a passionate, determined flame, though the only light came from the glutted moon.Allan filled page after page, the words escaping from his mind onto the paper.Where before they had marched in regiments, practiced in ranks and followed their leaders' commands, the words now escaped in their true forms, unhindered by any stricture.He continued long into the night, until the eldritch orb had sunk into the waiting hands of the willow, raised perpetually skyward.Arthur looked up from the results of a night's frenzied labors and looked Allan in the eye."What is this?"he queried, indicating the pages he held in his left hand."I decided that… since I wasn't having much success with more – traditional – stories, I might see what sort of work I produced if I let my imagination go freely," Allan replied, somewhat less self-assured than he had been the previous night."What in G-d's name could have possessed you to do such a thing," cried Arthur, nearly raising his voice."After all I said the day before, why have you abandoned centuries of literary progress for some self-indulgent fantasy?"He shook the papers at Allan, raising them like a belt above the head of a disobedient son."This is nothing but a glorified Grimm's tale, a miscarried child of Stoker, a creation less fit to be published than to be told around an open fire at the hovel of some peasant!"He spoke the last word with such heavy intonation that Allan shrank back before the physical wave of sound emanating from Arthur's throat."Do you hate the modern system of literature?Do you personally despise the works the Enlightenment or the progress made since Shakespeare?"For a moment, Allan could hardly do more than shake his head."No, of course not… I– " "Then why," Arthur barreled on, "do you disregard them all and return to this superstitious babble, this morbid, paganistic drivel?
summary_1: Allan resumed his position at his desk, poised to write. He pondered an idea he'd previously outlined. As he prepared to put pen to paper, a soft, rhythmic tapping caught his attention. The willow tree outside his window seemed to reach out to him, its branches grazing the glass. Inspired, Allan began to write, his thoughts flowing freely onto the page. He wrote throughout the night, the quill moving swiftly across the parchment. By morning, he had filled numerous sheets with his imaginative prose. Arthur, reviewing the work, questioned Allan about the nature of his writing. He was puzzled by the departure from tradition, expressing concern over the shift from structured narrative to a more fantastical style. He likened Allan's work to a mix of Grimm's fairy tales and Bram Stoker's horror stories, deeming it unfit for publication. He accused Allan of rejecting literary progress and returning to primitive storytelling. Allan, taken aback, denied any intentional slight against modern literature, assuring Arthur that he did not despise the advancements of the Enlightenment or the progression of literature since Shakespeare's time.
summary_2: Allan writes all night, inspired by a tapping willow tree. His work impresses but confuses Arthur due to its blend of fantasy and traditional narrative. Accusing Allan of regressive storytelling, Arthur questions his motives, sparking a defense of his innovative approach.
summary_3: Allan writes a confusing yet impressive piece, blending fantasy with tradition, leading to disagreement between him and Arthur over its artistic value.

text: The after-action review had treated the CIA as the lead agency for any offensive against al Qaeda, and the principals, at their March 10 meeting, had endorsed strengthening the CIA's capability for that role.To the CTC, that meant proceeding with "The Plan," which it had put forward half a year earlier-hiring and training more case officers and building up the capabilities of foreign security services that provided intelligence via liaison.On occasion, as in Jordan in December 1999, these liaison services took direct action against al Qaeda cells.In the CTC and higher up, the CIA's managers believed that they desperately needed funds just to continue their current counterterrorism effort, for they reckoned that the millennium alert had already used up all of the Center's funds for the current fiscal year; the  Bin Laden unit had spent 140 percent of its allocation.Tenet told us he met with Berger to discuss funding for counterterrorism just two days after the principals' meeting.While Clarke strongly favored giving the CIA more money for counterterrorism, he differed sharply with the CIA's managers about where it should come from.They insisted that the CIA had been shortchanged ever since the end of the Cold War.Their ability to perform any mission, counterterrorism included, they argued, depended on preserving what they had, restoring what they had lost since the beginning of the 1990s, and building from there-with across-the-board recruitment and training of new case officers, and the reopening of closed stations.To finance the counterterrorism effort, Tenet had gone to congressional leaders after the 1998 embassy bombings and persuaded them to give the CIA a special supplemental appropriation.Now, in the aftermath of the millennium alert, Tenet wanted a boost in overall funds for the CIA and another supplemental appropriation specifically for counterterrorism.To Clarke, this seemed evidence that the CIA's leadership did not give sufficient priority to the battle against  Bin Laden and al Qaeda.He told us that James Pavitt, the head of the CIA's Directorate of Operations, "said if there's going to be money spent on going after  Bin Laden, it should be given to him.My view was that he had had a lot of money to do it and a long time to do it, and I didn't want to put more good money after bad."The CIA had a very different attitude: Pavitt told us that while the CIA's  Bin Laden unit did"extraordinary and commendable work," his chief of station in London "was just as much part of the al Qaeda struggle as an officer sitting in [the  Bin Laden unit]."The dispute had large managerial implications, for Clarke had found Ailies in the Office of Management and Budget (OMB).
summary_1: Following the post-incident analysis, the CIA assumed responsibility for leading operations against Al-Qaeda, with the Principals concurring to enhance the CIA's capacity for such tasks during their gathering on March 10th. The Counterterrorist Center (CTC) interpreted this as progressing with 'The Plan', initially proposed six months prior - focusing on enlisting and preparing additional case officers and enhancing partner nations' abilities who shared intelligence through liaisons. Occasionally, these collaborative services directly acted against Al-Qaeda cells, similar to the incident in Jordan in December 1999. In both the CTC and above, CIA officials felt pressured financially, believing that the resources allocated for counterterrorism were depleted due to the millennium alert, leaving the Bin Laden unit having utilized 140% of its budget. Post the millennium alert, Tenet approached Berger discussing finances for counterterrorism merely two days later. Although Clarke advocated for increased financing for counterterrorism, he disagreed with the CIA management regarding its source. While the CIA administration claimed insufficient financial support since the end of the Cold War, affecting every operation including counterterrorism, Clarke thought otherwise. He held reservations about allocating further funds when the CIA hadn't effectively tackled the issue despite previous attempts. Despite the CIA pleading for added funds to preserve existing efforts, restore past losses, and expand operations by recruiting and coaching new personnel, along with reviving shuttered stations, Clarke hesitated. After obtaining a unique supplementary allowance following the 1998 embassy attacks, Tenet now sought extra general funds for the CIA and another exceptional supplement for counterterrorism. However, Clarke perceived this as proof of the CIA leadership undervaluing the fight against Bin Laden and Al-Qaeda. As per Clarke, James Pavitt, the Directorate of Operations leader at the CIA, expressed that any monetary contribution towards combatting Bin Laden should be directed solely to him. Conversely, Pavitt maintained that the CIA station chief in London contributed equally to the Al-Qaeda conflict, similarly to those within the Bin Laden unit. This argument carried significant organizational ramifications, as Clarke encountered obstacles dealing with the Office of Management and Budget (OMB).
summary_2: CIA takes charge of Al-Qaeda ops after CIA-Principal meeting; CTC interprets this as advancing 'The Plan'. Finances are tight due to millennium alert, causing tension between CIA and Clarke over funding. Post-1998 attack funds nearly exhausted, CIA requests more money from Congress. Clarke skeptical, sees it as CIA undervaluing Bin Laden/Al-Qaeda fight. Funding debate has broader implications, impacting CIA-Clarke relationship and negotiations with OMB.
summary_3: Following a CIA-Principal meeting, the CIA assumes control of Al-Qaeda operations, causing funding tension between the CIA and Clarke due to financial constraints and differing priorities in fighting Al-Qaeda.

text: French and British Ties and Occupation: The daughter of Ferdinand and Isabella married the son and heir of the Holy Roman Emperor, Maximilian of Hapsburg.The Spanish crown duly passed to the Hapsburgs, and Spain remained in their hands until the feeble-minded Carlos II died in 1700, leaving no heir.France seized the chance to install the young grandson of Louis XIV on the Spanish throne.A rival Hapsburg claimant was supported by Austria and Britain, who saw a powerful Spanish-French alliance as a major threat.In the subsequent War of the Spanish Succession (1702 –1713) most of the old kingdom of Aragón, including the Balearics, backed the Hapsburgs.Britain seized Gibraltar — in the name of the Hapsburg claimant — and retained it when the war was over.In 1708 Britain captured Menorca, and the magnificent harbor of Mahón (Maó), for the Royal Navy.England clung to it even when Bourbon forces captured Mallorca at the end of the war.Menorca changed hands between Britain, France, and Spain five more times in less than a century.Britain finally ceded the island to Spain in the year 1802, under the terms of the Treaty of Amiens.By 1805, Spain was once more aligned with France, and Spanish ships fought alongside the French against Nelson at Trafalgar.Napoleon came to distrust his Spanish ally and forcibly replaced the king of Spain with his own brother, Joseph Bonaparte.A French army marched in to subdue the country.The Spanish resisted and, aided by British troops commanded by the Duke of Wellington, drove the French out.What British historians call the Peninsular War (1808–1814) is known in Spain as the War of Independence.In the 19th century, practically all of Spain’s possessions in the Americas broke away in the wake of the Napoleonic Wars, and the few that remained were lost at the end of the 19th century.The Balearics, further neglected, were beset with poverty and outbreaks of disease.However, toward the 20th century, things began to improve on the islands, with Mallorca reaping the rewards of successful agricultural crops and Menorca launching an export shoe industry.
summary_1: Spain's connection to France and Britain has been marked by power struggles and territorial changes. After the marriage of the Spanish monarchs' daughter to the Holy Roman Emperor's son, Spain fell under Hapsburg rule until the childless Carlos II's death in 1700. France installed a Bourbon king, while Austria and Britain, fearing a Franco-Spanish alliance, backed another claimant in the War of the Spanish Succession. Spain's division continued as Aragon, along with the Balearic Islands, supported the Hapsburgs. Britain took Gibraltar and Menorca, retaining them after the war ended in 1713. Menorca switched hands multiple times between Britain, France, and Spain until its return to Spain in 1802. Following Napoleon's rise, Spain joined France, leading to the Peninsular War (1808-1814). Post-Napoleon, Spain experienced American colonies' independence and domestic issues, but the Balearics started to recover economically by the 20th century.
summary_2: Spain's history with France and Britain involves power shifts, wars, and territorial changes since the late 1600s. Key events include Spain's Hapsburg rule, the War of the Spanish Succession, and the Peninsular War. Territorial transitions occurred due to conflicts like these, resulting in Britain gaining Gibraltar and Menorca, which later returned to Spain. The region faced numerous challenges, including colonial independence movements and economic instability, but eventually saw some economic recovery in the Balearics during the 20th century.
summary_3: Since the late 1600s, Spain's relationship with France and Britain has been marked by power struggles, wars, and territorial adjustments, with key events like Spain's Hapsburg reign, the War of the Spanish Succession, and the Peninsular War leading to territorial transfers, such as Britain's temporary possession of Gibraltar and Menorca before their return to Spain; meanwhile, Spain grappled with colonial independence movements and economic volatility, achieving partial economic recovery in the Balearics during the 20th century.

text: Military Notification and Response.Boston Center did not follow the protocol in seeking military assistance through the prescribed chain of command.In addition to notifications within the FAA, Boston Center took the initiative, at 8:34, to contact the military through the FAA's Cape Cod facility.The center also tried to contact a former alert site in Atlantic City, unaware it had been phased out.At 8:37:52, Boston Center reached NEADS.This was the first notification received by the military-at any level-that American 11 had been hijacked: FAA: Hi.Boston Center TMU [Traffic Management Unit], we have a problem here.We have a hijacked aircraft headed towards New York, and we need you guys to, we need someone to scramble some F-16s or something up there, help us out.NEADS: Is this real-world or exercise?FAA: No, this is not an exercise, not a test.NEADS ordered to battle stations the two F-15 alert aircraft at Otis Air Force Base in Falmouth, Massachusetts, 153 miles away from New York City.The air defense of America began with this call.At NEADS, the report of the hijacking was relayed immediately to Battle Commander Colonel Robert Marr.After ordering the Otis fighters to battle stations, Colonel Marr phoned Major General Larry Arnold, commanding general of the First Air Force and NORAD's Continental Region.Marr sought authorization to scramble the Otis fighters.General Arnold later recalled instructing Marr to "go ahead and scramble them, and we'll get authorities later."General Arnold then called NORAD headquarters to report.F-15 fighters were scrambled at 8:46 from Otis Air Force Base.
summary_1:
On September 11, 2001, Boston Center deviated from standard procedure by directly contacting the military about the hijacking of American 11, instead of following the established chain of command within the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). At 8:34, Boston Center contacted the military via the FAA's Cape Cod facility. They also attempted to reach a now-defunct alert site in Atlantic City. At 8:37:52, they successfully connected with NEADS, marking the initial notice to the military, at any level, about the hijacking. The dialogue between Boston Center and NEADS unfolded as follows:

FAA: Hi, Boston Center Traffic Management Unit, we have a problem here. We have a hijacked aircraft headed towards New York, and we need you guys to, we need someone to scramble some F-16s or something up there, help us out.

NEADS: Is this real-world or exercise?

FAA: No, this is not an exercise, not a test.

Upon receiving this information, NEADS promptly directed two F-15 alert aircraft at Otis Air Force Base in Falmouth, Massachusetts, approximately 153 miles from New York City, to battle stations, thereby initiating the nation's air defense response. This order was given by Colonel Robert Marr, Battle Commander at NEADS, who subsequently informed Major General Larry Arnold, the commanding general of the First Air Force and NORAD's Continental Region. Seeking approval to dispatch the Otis fighters, Colonel Marr consulted with General Arnold, who advised him to 'go ahead and scramble them, and we'll get authorities later.' Following this conversation, General Arnold notified NORAD headquarters that F-15 fighters had been dispatched from Otis Air Force Base at 8:46.
summary_2: On September 11, 2001, Boston Center breached protocol by directly contacting the military about American 11's hijacking, instead of following the FAA's chain of command. At 8:34, they reached the military via the FAA's Cape Cod facility and succeeded at 8:37:52, connecting with NEADS. The FAA urgently requested military assistance. Upon realizing it wasn't a drill, NEADS scrambled F-15s from Otis Air Force Base. Colonel Robert Marr, NEADS' Battle Commander, sought permission from Major General Larry Arnold, the commanding general of the First Air Force and NORAD's Continental Region. After getting approval, General Arnold informed NORAD headquarters that F-15s were deployed from Otis Air Force Base at 8:46.
summary_3: On September 11, 2001, Boston Center contacted the military directly about American 11's hijacking, leading to F-15s being scrambled from Otis Air Force Base after the FAA's urgent request for military assistance was granted.

text: Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin (/'pUSkIn/; Russian: Aleksandr Sergeevich Pushkin, tr.Aleksandr Sergeyevich Pushkin; IPA: [aljI'ksandr sjI'rgjejIvjItc 'puskjIn]; 6 June [O.S. 26 May] 1799 - 10 February [O.S. 29 January] 1837) was a Russian author of the Romantic era who is considered by many to be the greatest Russian poet and the founder of modern Russian literature.Pushkin was born into Russian nobility in Moscow.His matrilineal great grandfather was Abram Gannibal, who was brought over as a slave from what is now Cameroon.Pushkin published his first poem at the age of fifteen, and was widely recognized by the literary establishment by the time of his graduation from the Tsarskoye Selo Lyceum.While under the strict surveillance of the Tsar's political police and unable to publish, Pushkin wrote his most famous play, the drama Boris Godunov.His novel in verse, Eugene Onegin, was serialized between 1825 and 1832.Notoriously touchy about his honour, Pushkin fought as many as twenty-nine duels, and was fatally wounded in such an encounter with Georges-Charles de Heeckeren d'Anthes.Pushkin had accused D'Anthes, a French officer serving with the Chevalier Guard Regiment of attempting to seduce the poet's wife, Natalya Pushkina.
summary_1: Alexander Pushkin, a celebrated Russian Romantic author, is hailed as one of Russia's finest poets and a pivotal figure in its literature. Born in Moscow to a noble family, Pushkin's lineage included his maternal great-grandfather, Abram Gannibal, who was enslaved in Cameroon before being brought to Russia. By fifteen, Pushkin had already published his first poem and garnered recognition from the literary community upon his graduation from Tsarskoye Selo Lyceum. Despite being monitored by the Tsar's secret police and prohibited from publishing, he crafted his renowned play, "Boris Godunov." Serialized between 1825 and 1832, his novel in verse, "Eugene Onegin," further solidified his legacy. Known for his sensitivity regarding honor, Pushkin engaged in approximately twenty-nine duels throughout his life. Tragically, one such confrontation with Georges-Charles de Heeckeren d'Anthes resulted in Pushkin's death. The conflict stemmed from Pushkin's belief that d'Anthes tried to woo Pushkin's wife, Natalya.
summary_2: Renowned Russian Romantic author Alexander Pushkin, born to nobility, became a key literary figure despite state surveillance. Publishing at fifteen, he gained fame after graduating from Tsarskoye Selo Lyceum. His notable works include plays like "Boris Godunov" and the novel in verse, "Eugene Onegin". Honor disputes led him into numerous duels; tragically, one ended his life due to suspicion over his wife Natalya's affections towards Georges-Charles de Heeckeren d'Anthes.
summary_3: Alexander Pushkin, a noble-born Russian Romantic author, achieved literary prominence despite government scrutiny, publishing at fifteen and gaining recognition post-graduation from Tsarskoye Selo Lyceum; known for works like "Boris Godunov" play and "Eugene Onegin" novel, his life was marked by honor disputes that culminated in a fatal duel triggered by suspicions around his wife Natalya's relationship with Georges-Charles de Heeckeren d'Anthes.

text: On Monday, departing Gov. Roy Barnes will spend his first day as a private citizen by starting his new job as a full-time, pro-bono (unpaid) lawyer at the Atlanta Legal Aid Society.The decision by Barnes, the most improbable casualty of Election Day 2002, to go to work for legal aid was almost as unexpected as his November defeat.As a legal services attorney, Barnes will help women escape domestic violence, Mauricio Vivero is vice president seniors fight predatory lending scams and parents obtain child support for their kids.of Legal In doing so, he will take his place on the front line of the U.S. legal community's Services Corporation, the uphill and underpublicized struggle to achieve equal access to justice for millions of Washington-Americans too poor to afford legal representation.based nonprofit corporation chartered by The inaccessibility of the U.S. civil justice system is hardly a new development, but it Congress in took Barnes' decision to put the national media spotlight on our country's ongoing 1974 to promote equal access to access-to-justice crisis.civil justice.The 2000 U.S. census reports that more than 43 million Americans qualify for free federally funded legal assistance, yet fewer than 20 percent of eligible clients (annual income: $11,075 or less) are able to obtain legal help when they need it, according to the American Bar Association.In Georgia, there is just one legal aid lawyer for every 10,500 eligible poor people.Barnes understood this problem long before he became governor.While in private practice, he handled many pro-bono cases and was a frequent volunteer in the Cobb County office of the federally funded Atlanta Legal Aid Society.Most memorably, he secured a $115 million judgment in 1993 against Fleet Finance for victimizing 18,000 homeowners -- many of them senior citizens -- with its widespread predatory lending mortgage practices.His long-standing commitment to the underserved is certainly admirable, but it should not be viewed as a rare and laudable act of civic virtue.To be admitted to practice law, every attorney must take a professional oath to promote justice -- and every state's ethical rules include language indicating lawyers' responsibility to be guardians of fair play for those living in poverty.In Georgia, many law firms, corporations and private attorneys are working pro bono to serve the neediest clients.Yet only 23 percent of the state's 23,598 active lawyers reported meeting the Georgia State Bar's goal of 50 hours of pro-bono service in 2002.The need for volunteers is most severe outside the five-county Atlanta metropolitan area, where 70 percent of the state's poor people are served by only 24 percent of the state's lawyers.National pro-bono participation is even worse.Only 23 percent of the roughly 1 million attorneys in America volunteer even one hour of pro-bono service annually, according to the ABA.
summary_1: Roy Barnes, former Governor of Georgia, starts his post-governorship tenure as an unpaid attorney at Atlanta Legal Aid Society from Monday. His role involves assisting victims of domestic violence, safeguarding seniors from predatory loans, and helping parents secure child support. This move places him at the forefront of the relentless battle to ensure equal justice access for financially disadvantaged Americans who cannot afford legal representation. The US civil justice system's inaccessibility isn't novel; however, Barnes' action has brought renewed attention to this issue. According to the 2000 US Census, over 43 million Americans meet eligibility criteria for complimentary federal legal aid, but merely 20% of these individuals effectively secure such assistance due to insufficient resources. For instance, Georgia has only one legal aid lawyer per 10,500 eligible impoverished residents. Despite understanding this challenge while in private practice, Barnes' dedication towards serving the underserved stands out, though it shouldn't - all lawyers pledge to advocate for justice upon admission into the profession. Regrettably, only 23% of Georgia's 23,598 practicing attorneys fulfilled the Georgia State Bar's recommended 50 hours of pro-bono service in 2002. National data indicates that only 23% of around 1 million American lawyers offer any pro-bono hours yearly.
summary_2: Former Georgia Governor Roy Barnes begins work at Atlanta Legal Aid Society, offering free legal help to those in need, like domestic violence victims or senior citizens targeted by predatory lending. He also assists with child support cases. With few legal aid lawyers available, many poor Americans lack legal representation. Although required to provide pro bono services, less than a quarter of U.S. lawyers do so annually.
summary_3: Roy Barnes now works for Atlanta Legal Aid Society, providing free legal assistance to vulnerable individuals, while less than a quarter of U.S. lawyers engage in annual pro bono work.

text: Surely, you have noticed the tall poles along the roadside.Do you know what is on top of those poles?Thats right, wires that carry electric current.These wires carry electric current to your home.But what is electric current?Electric current is actually the flow of electrons.You may recall, an electron is the outer-most particle in an atom.They have a negative charge.Electricity is the continuous flow of these particles.Electrons are able to move through wires.Their speed can even be measured.The SI unit for electric current (or speed) is the ampere (A).Ampere is often shortened to amp.Electric current may flow in just one direction, or it may keep reversing direction.Direct current (DC) flows in only one direction.Direct current is what is used in devices like flashlights.Alternating current (AC) flows in two directions.This is the type of current that flows into your home through wires.
summary_1: Tall poles alongside roads hold wires conducting electric current to homes. Electric current is the movement of negatively charged electrons, which form atoms' outermost particles. The standard metric unit measuring this flow is the ampere (amp), representing the speed of electrons. Direct current (DC) moves in one direction, utilized by single-direction devices such as flashlights. Alternating current (AC), however, alternates its direction; this is the kind received at home via electrical wire conduits.
summary_2: Electricity flows through tall roadside poles to homes, powered by moving negative electrons measured in amperes. DC travels one way for single-use gadgets like flashlights, while AC alternates directions, supplying most residences.
summary_3: DC and AC electricity power devices using negatively charged electrons that flow from tall poles into homes, with DC traveling once and AC reversing direction.

text: As noted above, the 9/11 plotters spent somewhere between $400,000 and $500,000 to plan and conduct their attack.The available evidence indicates that the 19 operatives were funded by al Qaeda, either through wire transfers or cash provided by KSM, which they carried into the United States or deposited in foreign accounts and accessed from this country.Our investigation has uncovered no credible evidence that any person in the United States gave the hijackers substantial financial assistance.Similarly, we have seen no evidence that any foreign government-or foreign government official-supplied any funding.We have found no evidence that the Hamburg cell members (Atta, Shehhi, Jarrah, and Binalshibh) received funds from al Qaeda before late 1999.It appears they supported themselves.KSM, Binalshibh, and another plot facilitator, Mustafa al Hawsawi, each received money, in some cases perhaps as much as $10,000, to perform their roles in the plot.After the Hamburg recruits joined the 9/11 conspiracy, al Qaeda began giving them money.Our knowledge of the funding during this period, before the operatives entered the United States, remains murky.According to KSM, the Hamburg cell members each received $5,000 to pay for their return to Germany from Afghanistan after they had been selected to join the plot, and they received additional funds for travel from Germany to the United States.Financial transactions of the plotters are discussed in more detail in chapter 7.Requirements for a Successful Attack As some of the core operatives prepared to leave for the United States, al Qaeda's leaders could have reflected on what they needed to be able to do in order to organize and conduct a complex international terrorist operation to inflict catastrophic harm.We believe such a list of requirements would have included leaders able to evaluate, approve, and supervise the planning and direction of the operation; communications sufficient to enable planning and direction of the operatives and those who would be helping them; a personnel system that could recruit candidates, vet them, indoctrinate them, and give them necessary training; an intelligence effort to gather required information and form assessments of enemy strengths and weaknesses; the ability to move people; and the ability to raise and move the necessary money.The information we have presented about the development of the planes operation shows how, by the spring and summer of 2000, al Qaeda was able to meet these requirements.By late May 2000, two operatives assigned to the planes operation were already in the United States.Three of the four Hamburg cell members would soon arrive.
summary_1: Al Qaeda financed the 9/11 attacks, providing approximately $400,000 to $500,000 for the operation. The 19 operatives were primarily funded by al Qaeda via wire transfers or cash supplied by Khalid Sheikh Mohammed (KSM). No significant financial aid was given to the hijackers from individuals or entities within the United States or from any foreign governments or officials. Before joining the plot, the Hamburg cell members, including Mohamed Atta, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, Marwan al-Shehhi, and Ziad Jarrah, appeared to fund themselves. Post selection, however, they started receiving funds from al Qaeda. For instance, each member got $5,000 for their return to Germany from Afghanistan and further funds for traveling from Germany to the U.S. Al Qaeda met several operational requirements for executing the 9/11 plot, including competent leadership, secure communication channels, effective recruitment and training processes, reliable intelligence gathering, efficient manpower allocation, and adequate financing. By May 2000, at least two operatives involved in the planes operation were present in the U.S., with three out of four Hamburg cell members arriving shortly thereafter.
summary_2: Al Qaeda financed the 9/11 attacks, supplying about $400,000-$500,000. The 19 hijackers received most funds from Al Qaeda via Khalid Sheikh Mohammed. Previously, the Hamburg cell members self-funded; post-selection, they got funds for travel to the U.S. At least two operatives were in the U.S. by May 2000. Al Qaeda covered various needs, including leadership, secure communication, recruitment, training, intelligence, manpower allocation, and funding.
summary_3: Al Qaeda provided around $500,000 for the 9/11 attacks, primarily through Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, covering costs like travel, communication, and training.

text: Fossils may form in other ways.Fossils can be preserved almost completely.In this process, the organism doesnt change much.As seen below, tree sap may cover an organism.With time, the sap hardens.It turns to into amber.The original organism is preserved.This is very exciting for scientists.They are able to study the DNA of the organism that no longer lives on Earth.Some animals have been found frozen in ice.Others have been found in tar pits after falling in.Molds and casts are another way organisms can be fossilized.Have you ever walked in soft mud and left footprints?Once in a while, these traces of organisms can be preserved.In this case, nothing is left of the organism.A mold is an imprint of an organism that is preserved in rock.The organisms remains break down completely.There is nothing left of the original plant and animal.
summary_1: Fossils can form through various means. One method involves preservation without significant alteration of the organism. This occurs when tree sap covers an organism, subsequently hardening into amber, which retains the original organism. Scientists find this particularly thrilling as they can examine the DNA of long-extinct earthbound entities. Occasionally, animals are discovered frozen in ice or trapped in tar pits. Fossilization can also occur through molds and casts. For instance, footprints left in soft mud can sometimes be preserved. Here, no remnants of the organism remain; instead, an imprint of the organism is preserved in rock (a mold), with the actual organic material having decomposed entirely. No trace of the original plant or animal remains.
summary_2: Fossils result from diverse processes. Some fossils preserve unaltered organisms, like those covered by tree sap turning into amber, keeping the original creature intact for scientific study. Animals found frozen in ice or stuck in tar pits offer other examples. Molds and casts cause fossilization too, such as footprints left in mud that solidifies, creating an impression in rocks after decomposition. In these cases, no physical traces of the organism endure.
summary_3: Various preservation methods create fossils, including entrapment within substances like amber, freezing conditions, or tar; alternatively, impressions remain when organic matter decomposes, leaving behind molds and casts.

text: Mary loved walking through the woods with her dog, Max.Max and Mary would go on all sorts of adventures together.They really loved looking for blueberries together and then falling asleep next to each other in the tall grass.One day, as Mary was picking the blueberries, she turned around to find that Max was not there.She became worried and ran off to look for her dog.She looked in all of their favorite spots...next to the stream, in their secret hiding place behind the raspberry bushes, and even inside the old cabin that sat in the woods.But poor Max was nowhere to be found.Nonetheless, Mary would not give up.She kept looking and she found him not very far away.He had seen a squirrel and run to chase it.When Mary called Max's name he left the squirrel and happily returned to Mary, wagging his tail as he went.
summary_1: Mary, accompanied by her dog Max, frequently embarked on woodland excursions, enjoying berry searches and shared naps amidst towering grasses. One afternoon, while gathering blueberries, Mary discovered Max missing. Anxiety prompted her to search familiar haunts - near the creek, hidden spot behind raspberry shrubs, and within an ancient forest cottage. Despite extensive searching, Max remained elusive until Mary heard faint whimpering nearby. She followed the sound and found Max chasing a squirrel; upon hearing Mary's call, Max abandoned the pursuit and joyfully reunited with her, tail wagging enthusiastically.
summary_2: Mary, with dog Max, often explored woods for berries. Once, she lost Max but eventually found him happily chasing a squirrel after mistaking it for his owner's voice.
summary_3: Mary found her dog Max cheerfully pursuing a squirrel instead of responding to Mary's calls due to mistakenly hearing its chatter as her voice.

text: To protect its seagoing interests and trade routes, Portugal established strategic garrisons in Goa (India), Malacca (East Indies), and Hormuz in the Persian Gulf.Portuguese explorers then embarked upon Macau (now Macao), the Congo, and various other parts of Africa, including the Sudan.The Portuguese policy was to avoid armed strife and to develop a trade empire, rather than to conquer nations.To this end it succeeded with relatively few blood-soaked episodes in its colonial history.Adventures abroad, however, proved disastrous during the second half of the 16th century.In 1557 the 14-year-old boy-king Sebastião ascended the throne, the beginning of a calamitous reign that was to end at the battle of Alcacer-Quiber (Morocco) in pursuit of a vain crusade.Sebastião's untimely demise, alongside some 18,000 ill-prepared, badly led followers, set the stage for a crisis of succession.For many years afterwards, legends and rumors bizarrely insisted that the king was still alive, and imposters turned up from time to time claiming the throne; those who were plausible enough to be deemed a threat were summarily executed.In fact, the only rightful claimant to the crown was the elderly Prince Henry.But after two years of alternating between the throne and his sickbed, he died, heirless.Surveying the situation and smelling an opportunity, Spain occupied the power vacuum, and Portugal's neighbor and long-time antagonist became its master.Spanish rule dictated Portugal's inadvertent involvement in Spain's ongoing wars.In 1587 a squadron of British ships commanded by Francis Drake attacked the Algarve (now a "legitimate target" as Spanish territory) and sacked Sagres, thus depriving the world of the relics of Henry the Navigator.Nine years later Faro was torched.The 1386 Treaty of Windsor, by which Britain and Portugal had pledged eternal friendship, seemed a distant memory.Portugal's empire was gradually eroded, and many of its trading posts (with the notable exception of Brazil) were picked off by the British and Dutch.Finally, after 60 years of Spanish rule, Portuguese noblemen (aided by the French, then at war with Spain) organized a palace coup and restored independence.The Great Disaster Portugal's greatest misfortune struck on All Saint's Day, 1 November 1755.
summary_1: During the 16th century, Portugal established significant garrisons in Goa, India; Malacca, East Indies; and Hormuz, Persian Gulf, to safeguard its maritime interests and trade routes. The country expanded to Macau, the Congo, and other African regions, aiming to build a trade empire without extensive conflict. However, the latter part of the 16th century brought adversity when King Sebastian I assumed the throne at age 14, leading to unfortunate events such as the Battle of Alcacer-Quiber where he and approximately 18,000 supporters perished in a fruitless crusade. After Sebastian I's death, uncertainty ensued due to unsubstantiated claims about his survival and several false pretenders emerging, causing instability. Eventually, the elderly Prince Henry surfaced as the legitimate heir but passed away shortly afterward, leaving no successor. Seizing the opportunity, Spain took control of Portugal, involving the nation in their conflicts. In 1587, English privateer Sir Francis Drake targeted the Algarve region, previously protected under the 1386 Treaty of Windsor, looting Sagres and destroying historical artifacts. By 1596, Faro suffered a similar fate. As a result, much of Portugal's empire diminished, and numerous trading posts fell into the hands of the British and Dutch. Following six decades of Spanish dominance, internal revolts among nobles backed by France led to Portugal regaining independence. Ultimately, Portugal faced one of its most devastating catastrophes on All Saints' Day in 1755, marking the end of the monarchy era.
summary_2: In the late 16th century, Portugal built a vast trade empire, securing strategic locations like Goa, Malacca, and Hormuz. Ambitions extended to Macau and Africa. However, misfortune struck with the untimely demise of young King Sebastian I in battle, sparking rumors of survival and ushering in an era of imposters. Elderly Prince Henry eventually emerged as the rightful heir but died swiftly, enabling Spain to seize power. English privateer Sir Francis Drake plundered Portuguese territories during this period, weakening the once formidable empire. Despite internal uprisings against Spanish rule, it wasn't until 1755 that Portugal reclaimed independence, facing a disastrous earthquake that signaled the end of the monarchy era.
summary_3: After King Sebastian I's death, Portugal's trade empire weakened due to false claimants, Spanish seizure, English piracy, internal rebellions, and natural disasters, leading to Portugal regaining independence in 1755 under a new regime after the monarchy ended.

text: Here the omnibus came up, and I rode back to Manchester. The whole conversation took up very little more time than it will take to read it; but I thought it worth recording, as characteristic of the people now suffering in Lancashire from no fault of their own. I know the people well. The greatest number of them would starve themselves to that degree that they would not be of much more physical use in this world, before they would condescend to beg. But starving to death is hard work. What will winter bring to them when severe weather begins to tell upon constitutions lowered in tone by a starvation diet--a diet so different to what they have been used to when in work? What will the 1s. 6d. a-head weekly do for them in that hard time? If something more than this is not done for them, when more food, clothing, and fire are necessary to everybody, calamities may arise which will cost England a hundred times more than a sufficient relief--a relief worthy of those who are suffering, and of the nation they belong to--would have cost. In the meantime the cold wings of winter already begin to overshadow the land; and every day lost involves the lives, or the future usefulness, of thousands of our best population.
summary_1: The narrator shares a brief yet impactful interaction with a Lancashire worker affected by unemployment due to industrial changes. Despite the brevity of the exchange, its significance lies in encapsulating the struggles of the local community amidst economic adversity. Characterized by resilience, these individuals prefer laboring over begging, even at the expense of their health. However, prolonged deprivation weakens their ability to endure harsh winters, rendering them increasingly vulnerable. As such, insufficient aid could exacerbate the situation, leading to irreversible consequences for both the affected populace and the nation. With winter looming, immediate action becomes crucial to prevent further loss of life and potential productivity among the working class.
summary_2: A Lancashire worker embodies community resilience despite job losses from industrial shifts. Preferring work over begging, they persevere despite worsening health. Yet, ongoing hardship leaves them ill-equipped for harsh winters, risking severe outcomes without adequate support. Immediate assistance is vital to preserve lives and maintain productivity within the working class.
summary_3: Despite declining health, a Lancashire worker persists through industry changes but needs immediate aid to face harsh winters and maintain productivity.
