A Comanche catches the boy , and startled , he runs away with the rabbit's foot . The Native American places the spear back , realizing too late that the rabbits foot is now gone . After that , white men come and start drilling for oil . Skip to current time , a divorced father , Mance Cashen , moves to the area with his new wife , baby , and his son from his first marriage , Willy ( played by ( ( Chris Miller , who is visiting . Willy notices something peculiar in the house and tries to warn his father and step-mother . They do not believe him . Willy is attacked while on a tire swing over a small water hole . The creature grabs his foot and Willy struggles , eventually getting away . He eventually befriends the local drunk , T. C. van Houten . A nice old man with some bad memories who knows something about the evil near the oil well and was in a situation similar to Willy's . In the meantime a Comanche Indian , Chief Sam John , comes to warn Mance of the evil and the need to keep it contained . Sam John informs Mance the evil was originally intended to stop the white man , but it is indiscriminate in whom it kills instead . Mance will have none of it . Willy eventually takes a spear he finds on his property to Sam John and tries to find out what is going on .
summary_1: The Comanches had imprisoned an amalgamated animalistic embodiment of evil within their lands, held at bay by a protective spear. This evil entity was released when a young boy removed the spear and took its talisman, a rabbit's foot. Years later, Mance Cashen, a divorced father, relocates with his family, including his son Willy, to this location. Here, Willy senses something unusual and attempts to alert his parents, but they dismiss his concerns. While playing outside, Willy encounters the creature, managing to escape after a struggle. He then meets T.C. Van Houten, a local alcoholic who shares knowledge about the ancient evil and his own past experiences. Meanwhile, a Comanche chief named Sam John arrives to caution Mance about the awakened malevolent force, initially meant to deter invading whites, but now harming anyone in its path. Despite these warnings, Mance remains skeptical. Eventually, Willy discovers the spear and approaches Sam John seeking answers.
summary_2: A family moves to land once inhabited by Comanches, where a supernatural evil was contained. A boy, Willy, finds an ominous creature instead of peace. His disbelieving father ignores Willy's pleas for help. After encountering the beast, Willy befriends a local man aware of the area's dark history. The Comanche chief responsible for guarding the evil warns the father, yet he remains dubious. Intrigued, Willy locates the magical spear that kept the menace trapped.
summary_3: Willy discovers an ancient evil on his family's new property, finding the creature after his father dismisses his concerns; with the aid of a knowledgeable neighbor and a mystical spear linked to the Comanche tribe, Willy tries to protect his family from the danger.

text: Roger was a grasshopper.He loved to hop.He hopped everywhere by himself.One day when he was hopping around he bumped into a frog sitting on a log.The frog told him his name was Gilbert.Gilbert told Roger that it had been a long time since he bumped into anybody.Roger told him that since both grasshoppers and frogs like to jump they would make great friends.The next day they were hopping through a field and they saw something very strange.In a pond they saw a spider floating on a lily pad.The spider was very sad because he did not have any friends.Roger and Gilbert asked him why he didn't have any friends.The spider told them that everybody would scream and run away when they saw him.Roger and Gilbert told him that he didn't look scary to them and that he could come along with them if he wanted.So Sam the spider said yes, and the three of them began a life time friendship full of adventures.
summary_1: Grasshopper Roger frequently jumped alone until he encountered Frog Gilbert. The duo soon discovered Spider Sam, who lived unhappily on a lily pad due to perceived scariness. Despite others shying from Sam, curious Roger and open-minded Gilbert welcomed him, forming an unlikely trio embarking on lifetime friendships filled with thrilling escapades.
summary_2: Roger the grasshopper befriended both Frog Gilbert and outcast Spider Sam, leading to exciting adventures for all three.
summary_3: Roger the grasshopper embarks on thrilling escapades with friends Frog Gilbert and outcast Spider Sam.

text: Alien Planet starts out with an interstellar spacecraft named Von Braun , leaving Earth's orbit . Traveling at 20 % the speed of light , it reaches Darwin IV in 42 years . Upon reaching orbit , it deploys the Darwin Reconnaissance Orbiter , Which looks for potential landing sites for the probes . The first probe , Balboa , explodes along with its lifting body transport during entry , because one of its wings failed to unfold . Two backup probes , Leonardo da Vinci and Isaac Newton , successfully land on the planet , and learn much about its bizarre indigenous lifeforms , including an apparently sapient species . The robotic probes sent out to research on Darwin IV are called Horus Probes . Each Horus probe consists of an { { convert } } long inflatable , hydrogen-filled balloon , Which is covered with solar receptors , a computer ` brain ' , a ` head ' covered with sensors , and several smaller robots that can be sent to places too dangerous for the probes themselves . The probes have a limited degree of artificial intelligence , very similar to the ` processing power ' of a 4-year-old . All the real thinking is done by a supercomputer in the orbiting Von Braun . The probes are programmed with different personalities ; Ike is more cautious , while Leo is the risk-taker . The two probes are also equipped with a holographic message that will be projected to any sentient life found on Darwin . After the two probes inflate their gas-bags , they encounter a voracious Arrowtongue and watch it pursue a Gyrosprinter .
summary_1: The novel "Alien Planet" begins with the launch of the spaceship Von Braun from Earth's orbit, traveling at 20% the speed of light towards Darwin IV, taking 42 years to reach its destination. Upon arrival, the Darwin Reconnaissance Orbiter is deployed to scout suitable landing sites for probes. The first probe, Balboa, fails to land due to a wing malfunction leading to an explosion. Backup probes, Leonardo da Vinci and Isaac Newton, successfully land and discover unique indigenous life forms, including what appears to be a sentient species. These robotic probes, known as Horus Probes, consist of hydrogen-filled balloons covered in solar receptors and sensors, with a rudimentary artificial intelligence similar to a 4-year-old's cognitive ability. A supercomputer aboard the Von Braun handles complex tasks, while each probe has a distinct personality; Ike being cautious and Leo, the risk-taker. Equipped with holographic messages, they encounter a predatory creature, the Arrowtongue, pursuing another native species, the Gyrosprinter.
summary_2: Spaceship Von Braun embarks on a 42-year journey to alien planet Darwin IV, deploying probes that find intelligent life. Three probes are launched, but one crashes. Two remain, named Leonardo da Vinci and Isaac Newton or 'Ike' and 'Leo'. They possess basic AI and distinct personalities, with Ike being careful and Leo adventurous. Landing safely, they discover local creatures like the Arrowtongue and Gyrosprinter.
summary_3: Two probes, Leonardo da Vinci and Isaac Newton, successfully land on Darwin IV after a 42-year spaceship voyage, finding native creatures despite a crashed probe.

text: Duane was hungry, but he hurried through the ample supper that was set before him, urged on by curiosity and astonishment.The only way he could account for his presence there in a ranger's camp was that MacNelly hoped to get useful information out of him.Still that would hardly have made this captain so eager.There was a mystery here, and Duane could scarcely wait for it to be solved.While eating he had bent keen eyes around him.After a first quiet scrutiny the rangers apparently paid no more attention to him.They were all veterans in service--Duane saw that--and rugged, powerful men of iron constitution.Despite the occasional joke and sally of the more youthful members, and a general conversation of camp-fire nature, Duane was not deceived about the fact that his advent had been an unusual and striking one, which had caused an undercurrent of conjecture and even consternation among them.These rangers were too well trained to appear openly curious about their captain's guest.If they had not deliberately attempted to be oblivious of his presence Duane would have concluded they thought him an ordinary visitor, somehow of use to MacNelly.As it was, Duane felt a suspense that must have been due to a hint of his identity.
summary_1: Duane, feeling both hunger and curiosity, quickly ate his dinner while trying to understand why he was at a ranger's campsite. He speculated that Captain MacNelly wanted information from him. However, this didn't explain the captain's eagerness. Duane observed that the rangers were seasoned veterans with robust constitutions. Despite some lighthearted banter, Duane sensed that his unexpected arrival had sparked speculation and even concern among them. Their professionalism prevented them from overtly showing their curiosity. If they hadn't seemed to ignore his presence, Duane might have assumed he was just another helpful visitor. Instead, he felt a growing suspense, suggesting they knew more about him than they let on.
summary_2: Hungry and curious, Duane dines while pondering his presence at a ranger station, suspecting Captain MacNelly seeks info. The experienced rangers seem intrigued but maintain composure, making Duane feel conspicuous and uneasy due to their hidden knowledge about him.
summary_3: Duane suspiciously dines with rangers who know more about his situation than they reveal, making him uncomfortable.

text: You will remember the name of Garibaldi, the Italian patriot, who with Mazzini had been stirring up trouble for the Austrians.They finally pursued him so closely that he had to leave Italy.He came to America and set up a fruit store in New York City, where there were quite a number of his countrymen.By 1854, he had made a great deal of money in the fruit business, but had not forgotten his beloved country, and was anxious to be rich only in order that he might free Italy from the Austrians.He sold out his business in New York, and taking all his money, sailed for Italy.When the war of 1859 broke out, he volunteered, and fought throughout the campaign.But the compromising terms of peace galled him, and he was not satisfied with a country only half free.In the region around Genoa, he enrolled a thousand men to go on what looked like a desperate enterprise.Garibaldi had talked with Cavour, and between them, they had schemed to overthrow the kingdom of the Two Sicilies and join this land to the northern country.Of course, Cavour pretended not to know anything about Garibaldi, for the king of Naples and Sicily was supposed to be a friend of the king of Sardinia.Nevertheless, he secretly gave Garibaldi all the help that he dared, and urged men to enroll with him.
summary_1: Garibaldi, an Italian patriot, left Italy due to Austrian pursuit, settling in New York City by 1854. He established a successful fruit business, amassing wealth yet never forgetting his homeland. His primary aim was to liberate Italy from Austrian rule. Once he sold his business, he returned to Italy with his earnings. When the 1859 war began, he joined the fight and remained active throughout the campaign. Despite the compromise in the resulting peace treaty, Garibaldi sought complete independence for Italy. In the area surrounding Genoa, he rallied a force of one thousand men for a mission many deemed hopeless. Together with Cavour, they plotted to dismantle the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies and unite it with the north. Although Cavour publicly distanced himself from Garibaldi, he covertly supported the endeavor, even encouraging others to join. This collaboration aimed to topple the Neapolitan and Sicilian monarchy, ultimately merging these territories with the northern lands.
summary_2: In 1854, Italian patriot Garibaldi moved to NYC after fleeing Austria, starting a thriving fruit business. After selling it, he returned to Italy in 1859, joining the fight against Austrians. Despite the subsequent peace treaty, he still pursued full Italian independence. By 1860, he led a group of 1,000 men to challenge the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, planning to merge it with the north. While maintaining public distance, Cavour secretly backed this effort, seeking to overthrow the Neapolitan and Sicilian monarchies and unify them with the north.
summary_3: In 1854, Garibaldi fled to NYC, started a successful fruit business, then sold it and returned to Italy in 1859 to fight Austrians, advocating for complete Italian independence; by 1860, he led 1,000 men, backed secretly by Cavour, to challenge the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, aiming to merge it with the north.

text: One of the most dramatic changes in priorities proposed by the City Council would shift $25.6 million from funding for court-appointed lawyers to the Legal Aid Society.In a document released yesterday to justify its reordered priorities, the Council contended that Legal Aid can achieve greater economies of scale than lawyers appointed pursuant to Article 18-B of the County Law.The Council document also noted that "inexplicably" 18-B lawyers are handling 50 percent of the indigent criminal cases in New York City, even though their mandate is to handle only multi-defendant cases where the Legal Aid Society had a conflict.In past years, the City Council had consistently added $5.6 million to the $54.7 million proposed for the Legal Aid Society by former Mayor Giuliani, bringing the total to just a shade over $60 million.But this year for the first time, the Council is proposing shifting more than $20 million in funds earmarked by the Mayor for 18-B lawyers to the Legal Aid Society, which would increase its total funding to $80.4 million.That would reflect a jump in its current finding of about one-third.Meantime, the City Council proposed slashing the Mayor's allocation of $62.8 million for 18-B lawyers by 66 percent, to $21.4 million.
summary_1: The City Council plans to transfer $25.6 million from financing for court-appointed attorneys to the Legal Aid Society, according to a new proposal. The Council argues that the Legal Aid Society can realize higher efficiency compared to individually assigned lawyers stipulated under Article 18-B of the County Law. Notably, these 18-B lawyers currently manage half of New York City's indigent criminal cases, despite their formal remit being limited to multi-defendant instances where the Legal Aid Society encounters conflicts. Previously, the City Council has regularly supplemented the $54.7 million initially allocated by former Mayor Giuliani for the Legal Aid Society, raising it to approximately $60 million. However, for the first time, the Council suggests redistributing over $20 million intended for 18-B lawyers to the Legal Aid Society, thereby increasing its budget to $80.4 million. Simultaneously, the Council proposes reducing the Mayor's $62.8 million provision for 18-B lawyers by nearly two-thirds, down to $21.4 million.
summary_2: City Council intends to shift $25.6m from 18-B lawyer funding to the Legal Aid Society, arguing for greater efficiency. The Legal Aid Society handles half of NYC's indigent criminal cases, though their role was originally restricted to managing multi-defendant instances with conflicts. The proposed change would increase the Legal Aid Society's budget to $80.4m, while cutting the Mayor's $62.8m provision for 18-B lawyers by nearly two-thirds, down to $21.4m.
summary_3: City Council plans to transfer $25.6m from 18-B lawyers' funding to the Legal Aid Society, potentially increasing the latter's budget to $80.4m, while reducing the Mayor's allocation for 18-B lawyers by nearly two-thirds.

text: Though prehistoric remains from the Paleolithic, Neolithic, and Bronze Ages have been unearthed in the Manzanares Valley, prior to Madrid's sudden elevation to capital city in 1561 its history was rather undistinguished.Over a period of many centuries crucial in Spanish history, Madrid's significance was negligible.The Romans built their most advanced outpost on the Iberian peninsula, but left nothing of consequence in Madrid.Armies of North African nomads, intent on disseminating Islam, invaded the peninsula in a.d.Within 10 years, they had overrun most of Spain.If Madrid played any role in these pivotal events, no record of it remains.The first solid references to this obscure settlement on the Castilian plateau, guarded by the looming Guadarrama mountain range, appear in the 9th century.The Arabic name for "place of many springs," variously recorded as Magerit, Mayrit or Magrit, eventually evolved into Madrid.The hamlet entered historical chronicles for its military significance; it was located near the main line of resistance to the Christian reconquest.Over centuries of struggle, the defending Moorish army built a full-scale fort, or Alcázar, on the heights of Madrid commanding the Manzanares valley.After several unsuccessful skirmishes, the Christian forces of Alfonso VI captured Madrid in 1083.The Alcázar became a fort of the crown of Castile.During a counter-offensive in 1109, the town was overrun by the Moors, but the Christianized fortress held.The Moors were expelled from the town, but they remained in control of southern Spain for almost four centuries.Meanwhile, Madrid enjoyed brief prominence in 1308 when king Ferdinand IV and his Cortes, an early version of parliament, held a formal meeting in the fledgling town.From then on, the kings of Spain began to visit Madrid, where the air was invigorating and the hunting excellent.Ferdinand and Isabella, the Catholic monarchs that united all the provinces of Spain, first visited Madrid in 1477.
summary_1: Madrid's historical significance was minimal until the 1500s, despite being inhabited since the Paleolithic, Neolithic, and Bronze Ages. The Romans and Islamic armies who later occupied the area left little trace in Madrid. The first notable mentions of Madrid, originally named 'Magerit', 'Mayrit', or 'Magrit' in Arabic, appeared in the 9th century as a strategic location during the Christian Reconquista. The Moors constructed a significant fort, the Alcázar, around the 11th century, which changed hands between Christians and Moors multiple times before finally becoming a royal fortress of Castile in 1083. Madrid gained some importance in 1308 when King Ferdinand IV and his Cortes convened there. Following this event, Spanish royals started visiting due to its refreshing climate and prime hunting opportunities. Notably, King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella, known for unifying Spain, made their first trip to Madrid in 1477.
summary_2: Originally called 'Magerit', 'Mayrit', or 'Magrit', Madrid emerged in the 9th century with a strategically important fort, the Alcázar. Initially built by the Moors, it switched hands frequently between Muslims and Christians. In 1083, it became a permanent royal fortress under Castile. Madrid gained prominence in 1308 when King Ferdinand IV held court here. Its pleasant climate and abundant hunting attracted Spanish rulers, including King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella in 1477. Despite earlier habitation and Roman/Islamic occupation, Madrid's historical relevance remained limited until the 1500s.
summary_3: Madrid rose to prominence as a permanent royal fortress for Castile around 1083 after changing hands multiple times between Muslims and Christians since its initial establishment as 'Magerit', 'Mayrit', or 'Magrit' in the 9th century; it wasn't until the early 16th century that it gained significant historical importance, particularly during King Ferdinand IV's reign in 1308 and later due to its appealing climate and ample hunting opportunities which attracted Spanish monarchs like King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella in 1477.

text: While this process moved along, diplomacy continued its rounds.Direct pressure on the Taliban had proved unsuccessful.As one NSC staff note put it, "Under the Taliban, Afghanistan is not so much a state sponsor of terrorism as it is a state sponsored by terrorists."In early 2000, the United States began a high-level effort to persuade Pakistan to use its influence over the Taliban.In January 2000, Assistant Secretary of State Karl Inderfurth and the State Department's counterterrorism coordinator, Michael Sheehan, met with General Musharraf in Islamabad, dangling before him the possibility of a presidential visit in March as a reward for Pakistani cooperation.Such a visit was coveted by Musharraf, partly as a sign of his government's legitimacy.He told the two envoys that he would meet with Mullah Omar and press him on  Bin Laden.They left, however, reporting to Washington that Pakistan was unlikely in fact to do anything," given what it sees as the benefits of Taliban control of Afghanistan."President Clinton was scheduled to travel to India.The State Department felt that he should not visit India without also visiting Pakistan.The Secret Service and the CIA, however, warned in the strongest terms that visiting Pakistan would risk the President's life.Counterterrorism officials also argued that Pakistan had not done enough to merit a presidential visit.But President Clinton insisted on including Pakistan in the itinerary for his trip to South Asia.His one-day stopover on March 25, 2000, was the first time a U.S. president had been there since 1969.At his meeting with Musharraf and others, President Clinton concentrated on tensions between Pakistan and India and the dangers of nuclear proliferation, but also discussed  Bin Laden.President Clinton told us that when he pulled Musharraf aside for a brief, one-on-one meeting, he pleaded with the general for help regarding  Bin Laden."I offered him the moon when I went to see him, in terms of better relations with the United States, if he'd help us get  Bin Laden and deal with another issue or two."The U.S. effort continued.
summary_1:
Efforts at diplomacy paralleled actions against Al Qaeda and the Taliban. Direct pressure on the Taliban yielded no success. The US turned to Pakistan, hoping to leverage its influence over the Taliban. In January 2000, Karl Inderfurth and Michael Sheehan met with General Musharraf, offering a potential presidential visit as incentive for Pakistani cooperation. Despite promises, they reported back that Pakistan was unlikely to act due to perceived benefits from Taliban control of Afghanistan. 

Despite warnings from security agencies about potential danger, President Clinton decided to include Pakistan in his March 2000 tour of South Asia, marking the first presidential visit since 1969. Discussions focused on Indo-Pakistan tensions and nuclear proliferation, but also touched upon Bin Laden. During a private meeting, Clinton implored Musharraf for assistance in dealing with Bin Laden, promising improved US relations in return. The efforts persisted beyond this encounter.
summary_2: In early 2000, U.S. diplomats attempted to persuade Pakistan to help combat Al Qaeda and the Taliban. Despite meetings with General Musharraf, Pakistan seemed uncooperative. Regardless, President Clinton visited Pakistan in March, discussing various issues including Bin Laden. Clinton urged Musharraf to assist in handling Bin Laden, offering better U.S.-Pakistan relations in return. Diplomatic efforts continued post-visit.
summary_3: U.S. diplomats, including President Clinton, tried convincing Pakistan's General Musharraf in 2000 to aid against Al Qaeda and the Taliban, specifically targeting Bin Laden, promising improved U.S.-Pakistan relations in exchange.

text: (CNN) -- Horror-meister, Stephen King calls George Pelecanos "perhaps the greatest living American crime writer."His stories are set in Pelecanos' hometown of Washington, D.C., but this is not the side of the U.S. capitol that you see portrayed on TV with white marble monuments, lawyers and lobbyists.Pelecanos is more interested in working families struggling to get by, the racial tensions in its ethnic neighborhoods and the low-lifes on the edges.His crime-writing peers call Pelecanos the "undisputed poet" of Washington's gritty side.The best-selling and award-winning author is out this week with his 17th and latest novel, "The Cut."It's the first in a new series featuring Iraq war veteran and private investigator Spero Lucas.When he's not working for a Washington defense attorney, Lucas recovers stolen property for a 40% cut.Now, a high-profile crime boss hires Lucas to find out who's been stealing from him, and it could turn out to be Lucas' biggest payday or an untimely end.While Pelecanos made his bones in the noir tradition, there's a definite "Western" feel to "The Cut."The new novel takes place in a morally gray and often violent world.It's peppered with pitch-perfect dialogue and captures the sights, sounds and taste of Washington in rich detail.In short, Pelecanos reads like the real deal.Pelecanos knows a thing or two about capturing the authenticity of urban America with an ethnically and socially diverse cast.In addition to his success as a novelist, Pelecanos is a producer and writer for HBO's New Orleans-set, "Treme."He was previously a producer and Emmy-nominated writer on the hit series "The Wire" and the miniseries "The Pacific."Read an excerpt from "The Cut" CNN recently spoke to Pelecanos about his new novel.The following is an edited transcript.CNN: Tell me more about your new character, Spero Lucas.
summary_1: Renowned horror author Stephen King has praised George Pelecanos as one of the finest contemporary American crime writers, particularly acclaimed for his vivid depictions of Washington D.C.'s less glamorous aspects. His novels delve into the lives of working-class families, racial strife in multicultural districts, and the city's criminal underbelly. Labeled the "poet laureate" of D.C.'s rougher quarters, Pelecanos has just released his newest book, "The Cut," introducing protagonist Spero Lucas. A former soldier turned private investigator, Lucas retrieves stolen goods for clients while also moonlighting for a lawyer. In "The Cut," Lucas is tasked with discovering a thief targeting a powerful mobster, potentially leading to a substantial fee or serious danger. While Pelecanos gained fame through hardboiled storytelling, "The Cut" incorporates elements reminiscent of Western narratives. It features graphic violence and raw dialogue, immersively describing Washington's atmosphere. Besides writing critically successful novels, Pelecanos boasts producing credits for television shows such as "Treme," "The Wire," and "The Pacific." He remains committed to accurately representing urban landscapes and their diverse inhabitants within his works. During a recent interview, Pelecanos elaborated on "The Cut" and Spero Lucas to CNN.
summary_2: George Pelecanos, hailed by Stephen King as a top crime writer, explores Washington D.C.'s gritty side in "The Cut". The novel follows ex-soldier turned PI, Spero Lucas, who recovers stolen goods and probes a theft targeting a dangerous mobster. With nods to Western narratives, "The Cut" contains violent scenes, raw dialogue, and an authentic portrayal of D.C. Known for TV hits like "The Wire", Pelecanos focuses on accurate representation of urban life.
summary_3: Crime author George Pelecanos delves into Washington D.C.'s underbelly in "The Cut," where ex-military investigator Spero Lucas retrieves stolen items and confronts a vicious criminal, featuring graphic violence, realistic dialogue, and a true-to-life depiction of D.C., consistent with Pelecanos' renowned TV shows.

text: Mr. Neville ( ( ( Anthony Higgins , a young and arrogant artist and something of a Byronic hero , is contracted to produce a series of 12 landscape drawings of an estate by Mrs. Virginia Herbert for her absent and estranged husband . Part of the contract is that Mrs. Herbert agrees `` to meet Mr. Neville in private and to comply with his requests concerning his pleasure with me . '' Several sexual encounters between them follow , each of them acted in such a way as to emphasise reluctance or distress on the part of Mrs Herbert and sexual aggression or insensitivity on the part of Mr Neville . Meanwhile , whilst living on the estate , Mr. Neville gains quite a reputation with its dwellers , especially with Mrs. Herbert's son-in-law , Mr. Talmann . Mrs. Herbert , wearied of meeting Mr. Neville for his pleasure , tries to terminate the contract before all of the drawings are completed and orders Mr. Neville to stop . But he refuses to void the contract and continues as before . Then Mrs. Herbert's married , but as yet childless , daughter , Mrs. Talmann , who has apparently become attracted to Mr. Neville , seems to blackmail him into making a second contract in Which he agrees to comply with what is described as her pleasure , rather than his a reversal of the position in regard to her mother . A number of curious objects appear in Neville's drawings , Which point ultimately to the murder of Mr. Herbert , whose body is discovered in the moat of the house . Mr. Neville completes his twelve drawings and leaves the house .
summary_1: Anthony Higgins, referred to as Mr. Neville, is commissioned by Mrs. Virginia Herbert to create 12 landscape drawings of her estate. The agreement includes private meetings between them, during which Mr. Neville exhibits sexual aggression while Mrs. Herbert displays reluctance. His reputation grows among the estate's inhabitants, particularly with Mrs. Herbert's son-in-law, Mr. Talmann. Tired of these encounters, Mrs. Herbert attempts to end the contract early, but Mr. Neville declines. Later, Mrs. Herbert's daughter, Mrs. Talmann, also seemingly infatuated with Mr. Neville, negotiates a new contract where Mr. Neville must comply with her desires instead. This change mirrors the initial arrangement between Mr. Neville and Mrs. Herbert. The landscapes Mr. Neville creates contain peculiar elements hinting at the future discovery of Mr. Herbert's corpse in the property's moat. After completing the 12 drawings, Mr. Neville departs from the estate. Throughout this process, both women experience discomfort and distress due to Mr. Neville's actions.
summary_2: Mr. Neville, hired by Mrs. Herbert to draw her estate, makes its inhabitants uncomfortable through his aggressive behavior towards both women. Despite their resistance, he persists until Mrs. Herbert tries to terminate the contract. Her daughter then takes over negotiations, leading to oddities in the finished artworks foreshadowing a grim find on the property. Eventually, Mr. Neville leaves after fulfilling his commission, leaving unease behind.
summary_3: Hired to illustrate Mrs. Herbert's estate, aloof artist Mr. Neville unsettles the family, resulting in strange artwork and lingering discomfort even after his departure.

text: To make certain the U.S. was aware of the danger, in July 1939, a few months before the beginning of World War II in Europe, Szilard and Wigner visited Einstein to explain the possibility of atomic bombs, which Einstein, a pacifist, said he had never considered.He was asked to lend his support by writing a letter, with Szilard, to President Roosevelt, recommending the U.S. pay attention and engage in its own nuclear weapons research.A secret German facility, apparently the largest of the Third Reich, covering 75 acres in an underground complex, was being re-excavated in Austria in December 2014 and may have been planned for use in nuclear research and development.The letter is believed to be "arguably the key stimulus for the U.S. adoption of serious investigations into nuclear weapons on the eve of the U.S. entry into World War II".In addition to the letter, Einstein used his connections with the Belgian Royal Family and the Belgian queen mother to get access with a personal envoy to the White House's Oval Office.President Roosevelt could not take the risk of allowing Hitler to possess atomic bombs first.As a result of Einstein's letter and his meetings with Roosevelt, the U.S. entered the "race" to develop the bomb, drawing on its "immense material, financial, and scientific resources" to initiate the Manhattan Project.It became the only country to successfully develop an atomic bomb during World War II.For Einstein, "war was a disease ... [and] he called for resistance to war."By signing the letter to Roosevelt he went against his pacifist principles.In 1954, a year before his death, Einstein said to his old friend, Linus Pauling, "I made one great mistake in my life--when I signed the letter to President Roosevelt recommending that atom bombs be made; but there was some justification--the danger that the Germans would make them ..."
summary_1:
In July 1939, Leo Szilard and Eugene Wigner approached Albert Einstein, a known pacifist, about the potential of atomic bombs, a concept previously unfamiliar to him. They urged him to write a letter to President Roosevelt advocating for U.S. engagement in nuclear weapons research due to this newfound threat. This letter, co-authored by Einstein and Szilard, is considered a significant catalyst for the U.S.'s subsequent focus on nuclear weapons research, leading up to their involvement in World War II.

Einstein, leveraging his relationships with the Belgian Royal Family and the Belgian queen mother, secured a meeting at the White House's Oval Office. His discussions with President Roosevelt led to the initiation of the Manhattan Project after Roosevelt recognized the potential danger of Germany developing atomic bombs first. The U.S., capitalizing on its substantial resources, became the sole nation to successfully create an atomic bomb during World War II.

Despite his pacifist beliefs, Einstein prioritized the prevention of Nazi possession of such weaponry over his opposition to violence. In 1954, nearing his death, Einstein confided in his friend Linus Pauling that signing the letter to Roosevelt was his greatest error, rationalizing it as a necessary response to the potential German development of atomic bombs.
summary_2: Albert Einstein, initially unaware of atomic bombs, learned of them from Leo Szilard and Eugene Wigner in 1939. Concerned about this potential threat, Einstein agreed to write a letter urging U.S. engagement in nuclear weapons research, which contributed to the creation of the Manhattan Project. Despite being a pacifist, Einstein deemed preventing Nazi acquisition of these weapons crucial, even though he later regretted his decision.
summary_3: In 1939, Albert Einstein wrote a letter urging U.S. involvement in nuclear weapons research after learning about atomic bombs from Leo Szilard and Eugene Wigner, despite his pacifism and subsequent regret, due to concerns over Nazi acquisition.

text: After the death of Spitamenes and his marriage to Roxana (Roshanak in Bactrian) to cement relations with his new satrapies, Alexander turned to the Indian subcontinent.He invited the chieftains of the former satrapy of Gandhara, in the north of what is now Pakistan, to come to him and submit to his authority.Omphis(Indian name Ambhi Kumar), the ruler of Taxila, whose kingdom extended from the Indus to the Hydaspes (Jhelum), complied, but the chieftains of some hill clans, including the Aspasioi and Assakenoi sections of the Kambojas (known in Indian texts also as Ashvayanas and Ashvakayanas), refused to submit.Ambhi hastened to relieve Alexander of his apprehension and met him with valuable presents, placing himself and all his forces at his disposal.Alexander not only returned Ambhi his title and the gifts but he also presented him with a wardrobe of "Persian robes, gold and silver ornaments, 30 horses and 1000 talents in gold".Alexander was emboldened to divide his forces, and Ambhi assisted Hephaestion and Perdiccas in constructing a bridge over the Indus where it bends at Hund (Fox 1973), supplied their troops with provisions, and received Alexander himself, and his whole army, in his capital city of Taxila, with every demonstration of friendship and the most liberal hospitality.On the subsequent advance of the Macedonian king, Taxiles accompanied him with a force of 5000 men and took part in the battle of the Hydaspes River.After that victory he was sent by Alexander in pursuit of Porus, to whom he was charged to offer favourable terms, but narrowly escaped losing his life at the hands of his old enemy.Subsequently, however, the two rivals were reconciled by the personal mediation of Alexander; and Taxiles, after having contributed zealously to the equipment of the fleet on the Hydaspes, was entrusted by the king with the government of the whole territory between that river and the Indus.A considerable accession of power was granted him after the death of Philip, son of Machatas; and he was allowed to retain his authority at the death of Alexander himself (323 BC), as well as in the subsequent partition of the provinces at Triparadisus, 321 BC.In the winter of 327/326 BC, Alexander personally led a campaign against these clans; the Aspasioi of Kunar valleys, the Guraeans of the Guraeus valley, and the Assakenoi of the Swat and Buner valleys.A fierce contest ensued with the Aspasioi in which Alexander was wounded in the shoulder by a dart, but eventually the Aspasioi lost.Alexander then faced the Assakenoi, who fought in the strongholds of Massaga, Ora and Aornos.The fort of Massaga was reduced only after days of bloody fighting, in which Alexander was wounded seriously in the ankle.According to Curtius, "Not only did Alexander slaughter the entire population of Massaga, but also did he reduce its buildings to rubble".A similar slaughter followed at Ora.In the aftermath of Massaga and Ora, numerous Assakenians fled to the fortress of Aornos.Alexander followed close behind and captured the strategic hill-fort after four bloody days.
summary_1: Alexander ventured into the Indian subcontinent upon Spitamenes' death and marrying Roxana. He summoned Gandhara chieftains to submit to his rule, which Omphis (Ambhi Kumar) of Taxila did, bringing gifts and allegiance. The chieftains of hill clans like the Aspasioi and Assakenoi sections of the Kambojas resisted. To reassure Alexander, Ambhi offered provisions, aid in building a bridge over the Indus, and joined Alexander's campaign. After victories, Ambhi helped govern territories up to the Indus. In winter 327/326 BC, Alexander targeted the Aspasioi, Guraeans, and Assakenoi for refusing submission. Despite being injured, Alexander defeated them, razed Massaga and Ora, and massacred many. Pursuing fugitive Assakenians to Aornos, he captured the fort after heavy casualties.
summary_2: Upon Spitamenes' death and marriage to Roxana, Alexander journeyed into India. Submitting to him, Omphis of Taxila brought gifts and loyalty. However, some mountain tribes resisted. To secure support, Ambhi supplied provisions, assisted with an Indus bridge, and accompanied Alexander's expedition. Victorious against those who refused surrender, including the Aspasioi, Guraeans, and Assakenoi, Alexander destroyed their cities and slaughtered numerous inhabitants. Continuing pursuit of fleeing Assakenians to Aornos, he seized the stronghold at high cost.
summary_3: After Spitamenes' death, Alexander married Roxana and invaded India, receiving tribute from Omphis of Taxila but facing resistance from mountain tribes until Ambhi's assistance secured victory, enabling Alexander to conquer defiant groups and seize Aornos after heavy losses.

text: I'm here to tell you the story of a robot named Carl.He came from a far away land known as Factory.Carl was sad because he was missing a part called a tire.He also needed a sun gatherer.But, the tire was more important.Once Carl got all these parts he could travel to his new home in the nation of Lab and the city of Office.It was a tricky thing to get there with missing parts.Just as he had given up hope Carl got a message from Mr. X saying the new parts were ready to be delivered.This made the robot very happy.The parts arrived a few days later and Carl put them in with 2 days of work.After this Carl began to travel the last bit of his goal to get to his new job.After this Carl took 10 days to get to Lab.
summary_1: Robot Carl hailed from Factory but found himself yearning for essential components to reach his destination: Lab, located in Office. Lacking both a tire and a sun gatherer, Carl faced significant challenges on his journey. The absence of a tire proved particularly problematic, hindering his progress significantly. However, when all seemed lost, Carl received word that his required parts would soon arrive, thanks to a timely message from Mr. X. This promising news rekindled Carl's determination, fueling him to press forward despite the obstacles before him. Upon receiving the eagerly awaited package, Carl diligently installed the much-needed tire and sun gatherer within two days. With renewed vigor, Carl embarked upon the final leg of his voyage, reaching his long-awaited destination after ten grueling yet triumphant days.
summary_2: Desiring crucial parts, Robot Carl journeys from Factory to Office's Lab. Initially lacking a tire and sunlight collector, he faces hurdles until hope arrives via Mr. X's message about imminent delivery. Bolstered, Carl installs these vital elements within two days. Reinvigorated, he finally reaches his goal after a strenuous yet victorious ten-day trek.
summary_3: Robot Carl overcomes obstacles to acquire necessary components, completing a ten-day journey from Factory to Office's Lab.

text: Callimaco is taken by the beauty of Lucrezia , but she is the loyal wife of Nicia , a rich and foolish lawyer . Callimaco hires the service of a shady ` fixer ' named Ligurio to aid in his quest to sleep with her . Lgurio informs Callimaco that Nicia and Lucrezia are anxious to have a child . With the fixer's help , . Callimaco masquerades as a doctor and convinces Nicia that the best way for Lucrezia to conceive a child is by her taking a potion made from the Mandrake Root . He lies and warns Nicia that the first man to sleep with Lucrezia after she has taken the potion will die within eight days . Together they devise a plan to kidnap a stranger to sleep with Lucrezia and draw out the poison . Callimaco then disguises himself and arranges to be the one who is kidnapped . Lucrezia is an honorable woman and does not at first agree to meet with the stranger . Nicia gets both Lucrezia's mother , a woman of ill repute , and her confessor Brother Timoteo , a priest of low morals , to aid in convincing Lucrezia of the necessity of the plan . After finally sleeping with Lucrezia , Callimaco confesses everything . Lucrezia gives thought to the duplicity of her husband , her mother , and her confessor , and decides that she now wants Callimaco as a lover forever . Callimaco gets what he had desired and everyone else continues to believe that each had outwitted the others .
summary_1: Callimaco desires Lucrezia, married to wealthy yet silly Nicia. Aiding him is sly fixer Ligurio. Informing them Nicia and Lucrezia long for a baby, Ligurio assists Callimaco in posing as a physician, prescribing a Mandrake Root elixir to induce pregnancy. Warning of death to the first male partner post-potion ingestion, they plot to lure a rando to replace the supposed victim. Disguised, Callimaco allows himself to be "kidnapped." Initially reluctant, Lucrezia eventually consents due to persuasion from her manipulative mother and corrupt priest, Brother Timoteo. Post-coitus, Callimaco admits his deceit. Pondering the dishonesty of her family, Lucrezia opts to keep Callimaco as a lover. Believing themselves victorious, all remain oblivious to their actual foolery.
summary_2: Callimaco seeks Lucrezia, wife of foolish rich man Nicia. With help from cunning Ligurio, he disguises as a doctor, recommends a mandrake root potion for conception. Claiming it could kill the first male after consumption, they trick another into replacing the assumed dead husband. Posing as a stranger, Callimaco gets 'captured.' Though hesitant initially, Lucrezia agrees due to her manipulative mom and crooked priest, Brother Timoteo. After sex, Callimaco confesses. Doubting her kin's honesty, Lucrezia decides to continue relationship with Callimaco. All are unaware of their folly.
summary_3: Callimaco, disguised as a doctor, tricks Lucrezia into having an affair by convincing her family to replace her supposedly deceased husband with him.

text: (CNN) -- Guatemala's government has declared a state of siege and sent hundreds of troops to a northern province where officials say a Mexican drug gang is overtaking towns and threatening residents.President Alvaro Colom announced the 30-day emergency rule in Alta Verapaz on Sunday.The rule allows the military to order anyone suspected of conspiring against the government to be arrested and imprisoned without a warrant, the state-run AGN news agency said."Starting today, combined forces will retake the streets of Alta Verapaz," a government statement released Sunday morning said.Government data shows cells of the drug gang known as Los Zetas are in the area to protect drug trafficking paths between Honduras and Mexico, "intimidating the population with their heavy weapons and threatening farmers to give up their land for criminal activities," AGN reported.The state of siege also allows the government to place greater restrictions on public gatherings, travel visas and gun licenses, among other things, according to AGN."The population should be calm.What we are doing is not intended to persecute honest, working people," Interior Minister Carlos Menocal told reporters.Menocal said operations in the coming days would aim to boost regional security, regain control of territory, identify criminal gangs and capture their members.In an interview with CNN en Espanol last month, Menocal said his country needed more help from the United States to combat cartels, which were increasingly carving out new drug transport paths."In the end, the large majority of drugs travel through Central America, and the assignment of resources or the financial support of the United States government is not the same as Colombia and Mexico receive," he said.Menocal said clashes between authorities and Los Zetas had notably increased.
summary_1: Guatemalan President Alvaro Colom has declared a 30-day state of siege in the northern province of Alta Verapaz due to threats from the Mexican drug gang, Los Zetas. The decree enables the military to arrest and detain suspects without a warrant, restrict public gatherings, tighten controls on travel visas and gun licenses, and enhance regional security. Los Zetas are reportedly present in Alta Verapaz, controlling drug trafficking routes and intimidating locals. Over 100 soldiers have been deployed to reclaim the region, ensure safety, and apprehend criminals. This move comes after increasing conflicts between authorities and Los Zetas. Guatemala seeks additional US aid to combat cartels, claiming that most drugs pass through Central America, unlike the higher levels of assistance provided to Colombia and Mexico. Despite these measures, Guatemala aims to avoid disrupting lawful citizens' lives while addressing this crisis.
summary_2: President Alvaro Colom declared a state of siege in Alta Verapaz over threats from Mexican gang, Los Zetas. Military can now arrest suspects without warrants, limit public gatherings, control travel visas/gun licenses, and boost regional security. Soldiers were sent to regain control, protect people, and capture criminals. Conflicts with Los Zetas led to this decision. Guatemala asked for increased U.S. aid to fight cartels, stating most drugs pass through Central America. Authorities aim to maintain normalcy for lawful citizens amidst this crisis.
summary_3: Guatemalan President Colom has declared a state of siege in Alta Verapaz due to threats from Mexican gang Los Zetas, allowing military to arrest suspects without warrants, restrict public gatherings, manage travel visas and gun licenses, and enhance regional security.

text: The cute red ball rolled over to the blue ball and said hello.The blue ball was scared and went to cry to the green ball.The green ball laughed at the blue ball.Then the green ball told the orange ball that blue ball was stupid.Most felt this was not good to do and so they punished the green ball by taking away all his air.From that day on everyone saw the air-less green ball and knew that they could not do or say any bad things.This is how the trouble started.The purple ball used the fear of everyone to become the leader that they all feared.The purple ball was mean to everyone.Until one day the red ball spoke up and got all the other colored balls together and they took the air from the purple ball and put it in the green ball.Sadly, the green ball had been without air for too long and was dead.
summary_1: A series of events unfolded when the red ball greeted the frightened blue ball, which then sought solace with the green ball. The green ball mocked the blue ball before informing the orange ball about the blue ball's perceived foolishness. This led to the green ball being deprived of air as punishment. Consequently, the purple ball exploited the general apprehension and assumed leadership through intimidation. However, the red ball eventually challenged the purple ball's authority, rallying the other balls against the oppressive regime. Regrettably, their actions proved futile as the green ball had already perished due to prolonged oxygen deprivation.
summary_2: The red ball meets a scared blue ball, who seeks comfort from the green one. Green mocks blue, telling orange about its supposed stupidity. Orange punishes Green by cutting off air, leading Purple to seize control via fear. Later, Red challenges Purple's rule, uniting the balls against it. Tragically, Green dies due to lack of oxygen.
summary_3: In a power struggle, Red leads other colored balls to overthrow Purple after Green dies from oxygen deprivation, caused by Orange mocking Blue and cutting off Green's air supply.

text: New Legitimacy: Organized crime was soon to have a formidable adversary in its bid to control Las Vegas — corporate cash.Though Las Vegas had developed a powerful local economy, few major outside investments were made in the city, due primarily to mob infiltration and its inherent ties to illegal activities.That would change dramatically with the 1966 arrival of billionaire Howard Hughes.A legitimate businessman, Hughes was nonetheless eccentric and dramatic, a style suited to the Las Vegas ethos.True to the myth, the reclusive Hughes immediately cloistered himself in the Desert Inn's penthouse.Several weeks later he was asked — then ordered — to vacate the room to make room for high rollers, whereupon he promptly bought the property and fired the management.Thus began Hughes' legendary three-year, $300-million Las Vegas buying spree.When it was over, Hughes owned six casinos, an airport, and an airline, along with numerous plots of land stretching from the Strip to the mountains.Hughes' actions would have beneficial repercussions, both immediate and lasting.Because of the new legitimacy Las Vegas acquired from Hughes' investments, established companies such as Hilton Hotels bought into the gaming business, and their influence helped draw a line in the desert sand between legitimate operations and mob casinos, where illegal skimming of profits was rampant.That, combined with the formation of the Nevada Gaming Control Board, would signal the beginning of the end for heavy mob influence in the city.Las Vegas with a Vision As corporations moved in and the mob was slowly pushed out, a new Las Vegas emerged.The legitimization of gambling led to its increased legalization across the US.What was once a sure thing became much more competitive.Casino operators had to reassess the nature of their business.The first to really do so was Steve Wynn, a Las Vegas resident and owner of the Golden Nugget.In the mid-1980s, Wynn began plans to reinvigorate Las Vegas with a new resort.He bought several Strip properties — the Silver Slipper and Castaways among them — and demolished them to make way for a new kind of resort — Mirage —  which became an instant success.
summary_1: Howard Hughes arrived in Las Vegas in 1966, marking a significant shift in the city's landscape. A billionaire known for his eccentricity, Hughes purchased the Desert Inn after being asked to vacate his penthouse suite. This was just the start of his three-year spending spree, during which he spent $300 million on various properties, including six casinos, an airport, an airline, and numerous plots of land. His legitimate business dealings brought corporate capital into Las Vegas, leading to the entry of other reputable companies like Hilton Hotels into the gaming industry. This influx of corporate investment marked the beginning of the end for organized crime's stronghold in the city. The Nevada Gaming Control Board also played a crucial role in this transition by drawing a clear line between legitimate businesses and mob-run casinos. Meanwhile, the gradual legitimization of gambling led to its expansion beyond Nevada, increasing competition in the industry. In response, casino operators like Steve Wynn had to innovate to stay ahead. Wynn's development of the Mirage resort in the mid-1980s set a precedent for future resorts, signaling a new era for Las Vegas.
summary_2: In 1966, Howard Hughes arrived in Las Vegas, initiating a transformation. Hughes, a billionaire known for eccentricity, bought the Desert Inn, sparking a three-year spending spree where he acquired six casinos, an airport, an airline, and land, investing $300 million. His legitimate deals attracted corporate capital, weakening organized crime's grip. The Nevada Gaming Control Board distinguished legal businesses from mob-run casinos, while gambling's legitimization expanded beyond Nevada, intensifying competition. Innovators like Steve Wynn responded by creating unique experiences, such as the Mirage resort, ushering in a new era for Las Vegas.
summary_3: Howard Hughes' 1966 arrival in Las Vegas initiated a transformation, as his acquisition of multiple properties weakened organized crime's hold, attracting corporate investment, leading innovators like Steve Wynn to create unique attractions that furthered gambling's expansion.

text: Surviving being shot and stabbed at the end of the previous film , the stepfather has been institutionalized in Puget Sound , Washington since , spending his time building model houses in the workshop .Assigned a new doctor named Joseph Danvers the stepfather begins confiding in him to gain his trust , ultimately murdering the doctor during a session by stabbing him in the neck with a blade smuggled out of the workshop .After killing Danvers the stepfather beats a suspicious guard named Ralph Smith to death with his own nightstick with only two strikes and takes his uniform , successfully sneaking out of the sanitarium .Checking into a hotel after robbing and murdering a traveling salesman the stepfather alters his appearance , takes the name Doctor Gene F. Clifford from the newspaper obituaries and travels to Palm Meadows , Los Angeles after seeing an ad for it on an episode of Dream House .Gene arrives in Palm Meadows and meets real estate agent Carol Grayland and leases a house just across the street from her and her son Todd .During a session with the wives of the neighborhood , Gene learns Carol 's dentist husband , Philip had absconded with his mistress the previous year .Gene begins courting Carol , eventually winning over her and Todd .Gene 's plan to marry Carol is soon complicated when Phil returns , wanting to reconcile with his wife .Needing Phil out of the way , Gene persuades Carol to send Phil over for a meeting , during which Gene kills him with a broken bottle , covering up Phil 's disappearance afterward by arranging it so that it looks as though he simply ran off again .
summary_1: The story follows a man, previously shot and stabbed, who now resides in a mental institution in Puget Sound, Washington. He spends his days constructing miniature homes in the workshop. A new doctor, Joseph Danvers, tends to him but falls victim to the patient's manipulations. The patient gains Dr. Danvers' trust, murders him during a session by stabbing him in the neck, and assumes his identity using a hidden knife and stolen guard uniform. After escaping, he checks into a hotel, disguises himself, and adopts the alias "Doctor Gene F. Clifford" from an obituary. His destination: Palm Meadows, Los Angeles, where he finds a home near realtor Carol Grayland and her son, Todd. During a gathering with local women, he discovers that Carol's dentist spouse, Philip, left with his lover a year prior. Gene starts romancing Carol, gradually gaining her affection and acceptance. However, complications arise when Philip resurfaces, seeking forgiveness and reunification with his wife. To remove this obstacle, Gene convinces Carol to invite Philip over, resulting in Gene ending Philip's life with a shattered bottle before staging a cover-up to make it appear as if Philip abandoned them once more.
summary_2: A man feigns recovery from injuries, deceives a doctor, and escapes a mental hospital. Assuming a false name, he befriends a woman whose husband deserted her. When the estranged husband returns, the deceiver kills him, making it seem like another abandonment.
summary_3: After faking his recovery and fleeing a mental institution, a man poses as someone new, bonds with an abandoned wife, then murders her returning spouse under false pretenses.

text: Search "Emiliano Malaquez" and you'll find he's a master of the "captured moment" school of sculpture.Even The Terran Times has only praise for his work.To compare his pieces to those of others is to compare mannequins to living models.He accents the illusion of reality --I paraphrase his entry in La Enciclopedia Humanica --by doing life-size scenes in "The full round," never the easier frontal or three-quarters view.Moreover, he never did portraits of famous people; his works were therefore the reality and could never be compared to it.As is typical of his school, his pieces are sealed in stopboxes.The shimmer of light on their surfaces always reminds us that we're looking at an instant snatched from under the hooves of time.They say the cubes will outlast planets and suns, that when the universe dies, the works of Malaquez and his followers will be the last things seen in the final wink of God's eye.Yes, Self, I am also bothered that this observation ignores half-eaten cheese sandwiches, incomplete insect collections, and locks of infants' hair, forgotten in closets, basements, and warehouses.You see the inspiration for my latest play, "Captured Moments."The mindwipe will take its creation from my future self --but time too often does that without aid.The play's second act concludes with the last fight between Tasha and me.I have disguised us in the play, and deleted one brief melodramatic interchange.Now I will mention it, in case I/You decide to restore it.Shortly before she left, Tasha said, "You steal from life for art, Bernardo.You'll impoverish yourself."I only snarled at her and -- My story leaps ahead of itself.Let me retreat and retrench: One night during N'apulco's mild winter, Tasha returned to The Flamingo, saying, "Nardo!Nardo!Guess what?"
summary_1:
Emiliano Malaquez is renowned for his hyper-realistic sculptures, capturing moments in time like nothing else. Acclaimed by The Terran Times, his life-sized, three-dimensional works stand out due to their intricate detail and unique perspective - they're never just frontal or three-quarter views. Instead, Malaquez prefers depicting everyday situations and common individuals rather than famous figures, enhancing the relatability of each piece.

His sculptures are preserved within special cases, reflecting the transient nature of existence. These stopboxes emphasize the fragility of life while highlighting the luminescent beauty found even in fleeting instances. It is believed that these artistic creations may endure long after celestial bodies cease to exist, potentially being among the very last remnants of our universe.

This concept inspired author Bernardo to write "Captured Moments", where characters grapple with themes of memory preservation and loss. In the story, Bernardo explores how memories shape personal growth through a dramatic confrontation between two main characters, Tasha and himself. Despite initial resistance, Tasha criticizes Bernardo’s tendency to draw inspiration from real-life experiences to fuel his creative process. She fears that prioritizing art over genuine connections might lead him down a path towards emotional isolation.
summary_2: Acclaimed artist Emiliano Malaquez creates striking hyper-realistic sculptures, focusing on everyday people and situations. His detailed, three-dimensional works capture life's ephemeral beauty within protective casings, suggesting their potential longevity beyond celestial existence. Author Bernardo was inspired by this concept, exploring memory preservation and loss in "Captured Moments". The narrative features character Tasha challenging Bernardo about prioritizing art over authentic relationships.
summary_3: Artist Emiliano Malaquez crafts hyper-realistic sculptures depicting everyday scenes, which author Bernardo draws upon for his novel "Captured Moments", exploring themes of memory preservation and loss, with a character questioning art's priority over real connections.

text: Before the establishment of the People's Republic, Albania's illiteracy rate was as high as 85%.Schools were scarce between World War I and World War II.When the People's Republic was established in 1945, the Party gave high priority to wiping out illiteracy.As part of a vast social campaign, anyone between the ages of 12 and 40 who could not read or write was mandated to attend classes to learn.By 1955, illiteracy was virtually eliminated among Albania's adult population.Today the overall literacy rate in Albania is 98.7%; the male literacy rate is 99.2% and female literacy rate is 98.3%.With large population movements in the 1990s to urban areas, the provision of education has undergone transformation as well.The University of Tirana is the oldest university in Albania, having been founded in October 1957.
summary_1: Albania had an illiteracy rate of up to 85% before the founding of the People's Republic. Limited schools existed between the two World Wars. Post-establishment of the People's Republic in 1945, eradicating illiteracy became a top priority for the ruling Party. A massive social campaign was launched, requiring anyone aged 12 to 40, unable to read or write, to attend educational programs. By 1955, illiteracy among adults was nearly eradicated. As of now, Albania boasts a 98.7% overall literacy rate, with males at 99.2% and females at 98.3%. The 1990s saw significant population shifts to urban areas, leading to changes in education provision. The University of Tirana, founded in October 1957, stands as Albania's first university.
summary_2: After the establishment of the People's Republic in 1945, Albania prioritized eliminating illiteracy, which affected up to 85% of the population pre-Republic. A large-scale campaign ensued, mandating that individuals aged 12-40, who were illiterate, attend educational programs. This successful initiative reduced adult illiteracy by the mid-1950s. Currently, Albania enjoys a high 98.7% literacy rate, with minimal differences between genders. The 1990s brought increased urbanization and alterations in education distribution, including the foundation of the University of Tirana in 1957.
summary_3: Since the founding of the People's Republic in 1945, Albania has substantially reduced illiteracy from approximately 85% to a current high literacy rate of 98.7%, primarily through mandatory education for those aged 12-40, resulting in significant improvements by the mid-1950s.

text: Renewable Energy Resource Sunlight Sunlight can be used to heat homes.It can also be used to produce electricity.This conversion is made possible by solar cells.However, solar energy may not always be practical.Some areas are just too cloudy.Example Solar panels on the roof of this house generate enough electricity to supply a familys needs.Moving Water Falling water can have a lot of energy.Its energy can be converted into kinetic energy.This energy can turn a turbine and generate electricity.The water may fall naturally over a waterfall or flow through a dam.A drawback of dams is that they flood land upstream.They can also reduce water flow downstream.Either effect may harm ecosystems.Wind Wind is moving air.It has kinetic energy that can do work.Wind turbines change the kinetic energy of the wind to electrical energy.Only certain areas of the world get enough steady wind.Many people also think that wind turbines are noisy and not very nice to look at.
summary_1: Sunlight and moving water are renewable energy resources. Sunlight can heat homes and generate electricity via solar cells, although it might not be feasible in overcast regions. A family residence equipped with solar panels can yield sufficient power for their consumption. Moving water, such as falling water from natural waterfalls or man-made dams, possesses substantial energy which can be transformed into mechanical energy using a turbine, subsequently generating electricity. However, constructing dams comes with environmental concerns like flooding nearby lands and disrupting aquatic ecosystems due to altered water flows. Lastly, wind, an abundant source of kinetic energy, can perform tasks when harnessed correctly. Wind turbines convert wind's kinetic energy into electrical energy; however, locations must experience consistent winds, and some individuals perceive these structures as visually unappealing and noisy.
summary_2: Solar and hydroelectric power, along with wind energy, offer sustainable energy solutions. Solar power, utilizing sunlight, generates electricity through solar cells but may not suit overcast areas. Hydroelectric power converts moving water's mechanical energy into electricity, though dam construction raises environmental concerns. Wind energy, derived from wind turbines, transforms wind's kinetic energy into electrical energy, yet requires constant winds and faces aesthetic opposition.
summary_3: Solar, hydroelectric, and wind energies provide sustainable power, each with limitations such as sunlight availability, environmental impact, and reliance on consistent winds and favorable aesthetics.

text: Representing yourself in court can be a tricky endeavor.There are confusing legal terms to learn, strict procedures to follow and volumes of case law that often need to be understood to prepare a case.Lake County officials and a private agency that assists indigent litigants in Illinois want to make the practice easier by creating a self-help center for people who choose to represent themselves in legal matters.The center, which will be housed in the law library at the main courthouse in Waukegan, could open later this summer."I think it's going to be extremely helpful," Court Administrator Bob Zastany said."There is a population out there that will take advantage of this resource."The self-help center will be the only one of its kind in the county.Only a few operate nationwide, officials said.The project is the work of Lake County circuit court officials and Prairie State Legal Services, a statewide agency with an office in Waukegan that provides information and legal assistance to poor and elderly Illinois residents.The organization has received a $25,000 grant from the Illinois Equal Justice Foundation, a nonprofit group that funds programs designed to increase access to legal information and assistance, to help pay for the effort.Prairie State will share the money with the county.The county's law library is on the first floor of the governmental center at 18 N. County St. The new self-help center will be designed to help litigants find the information they need to properly represent themselves in court, an undertaking that can be complicated and confusing."Some people can do OK on their own, and some people can do OK with some help," said Linda Rothnagel, the managing attorney for Prairie State Legal Services."But other people can't do it.It's not always easy."Self-representation is a right affirmed by the U.S. Supreme Court.The practice is far more common in civil matters than in criminal cases.In fact, self-represented litigants - formally called "pro se" in Latin, or "for oneself" - in criminal defenses are so rare that statistics about the practice generally are not kept, legal experts say.
summary_1: A self-help center is being established in Lake County, Illinois, aimed at assisting individuals representing themselves in legal proceedings. This initiative is a collaboration between local authorities and Prairie State Legal Services, utilizing a $25,000 grant from the Illinois Equal Justice Foundation. The center, situated in the main courthouse's law library, aims to provide resources for those navigating the complexities of self-representation. While some individuals may manage independently, others require assistance, emphasizes Linda Rothnagel, managing attorney for Prairie State Legal Services. Despite the rarity of pro se defendants in criminal cases, self-representation is significantly more prevalent in civil matters.
summary_2: Lake County, IL creates a self-help center for people handling their own legal affairs, supported by a $25,000 grant from the Illinois Equal Justice Foundation. Collaborators include local officials and Prairie State Legal Services. Located in the county courthouse law library, it offers help for those tackling self-representation. Although rare in criminal cases, self-representation is common in civil matters, stresses Linda Rothnagel, Prairie State Legal Services' managing attorney.
summary_3: Lake County establishes a self-help center, backed by a $25,000 grant, to assist individuals representing themselves in legal matters.

text: Sometimes traits can vary from parent to offspring.These changes are due to mutations.Mutations are a random change.Mutations are natural.Some mutations are harmful.In this case, the organism may not live to reproduce.The trait will not be passed onto offspring.Others variations in traits have no effect on survival.Can some mutations be good for a living thing?Other mutations can have great benefits.Imagine being the first moth that can blend into its background.It would have a better chance of survival.A living thing that survives is likely to have offspring.If it does, it may pass the new trait on to its offspring.Thats good news for the offspring.The offspring may be more likely to survive.Mutations are one way living things adapt to new conditions.
summary_1: Mutations, which are random changes, bring about differences between parents and their offspring. Some mutations might prove detrimental, potentially endangering the organism's ability to reproduce, thereby preventing the passing of such traits to future generations. Other mutations, however, bear no impact on an organism's chances of survival. In certain instances, though, mutations can offer significant advantages. Picture, if you will, the very first moth capable of blending seamlessly into its surroundings—its likelihood of survival would undoubtedly increase. A surviving organism typically reproduces, granting it the opportunity to transmit these advantageous genetic traits to its progeny. Consequently, descendants inheriting these favorable traits could enjoy improved odds of survival themselves. Mutations, therefore, represent but one means by which life forms adjust to shifting environmental circumstances.
summary_2: Mutations introduce variations among offspring, sometimes harmfully affecting reproduction. Many have no effect, while others enhance survival prospects. For instance, a well-camouflaged moth has better survival odds, passing this trait onto its descendants for enhanced survivability. Thus, mutations enable species adaptation to changing environments.
summary_3: Mutations cause genetic variation, some improving species' adaptability to environmental changes by enhancing their chances of survival.

text: The Venetian artist Jacopo de' Barbari, whom Durer had met in Venice, visited Nuremberg in 1500, and Durer said that he learned much about the new developments in perspective, anatomy, and proportion from him.De' Barbari was unwilling to explain everything he knew, so Durer began his own studies, which would become a lifelong preoccupation.A series of extant drawings show Durer's experiments in human proportion, leading to the famous engraving of Adam and Eve (1504), which shows his subtlety while using the burin in the texturing of flesh surfaces.This is the only existing engraving signed with his full name.Durer made large numbers of preparatory drawings, especially for his paintings and engravings, and many survive, most famously the Betende Hande (English: Praying Hands, c.1508 Albertina, Vienna), a study for an apostle in the Heller altarpiece.He also continued to make images in watercolour and bodycolour (usually combined), including a number of still lifes of meadow sections or animals, including his Young Hare (1502) and the Great Piece of Turf (1503, both also Albertina).
summary_1: In 1500, Venetian artist Jacopo de' Barbari visited Nuremberg, where he met Albrecht Dürer. Dürer acknowledged learning significantly from de' Barbari about advancements in perspective, anatomy, and proportion. However, de' Barbari was reluctant to share all his knowledge, prompting Dürer to embark on his own studies, which became a lifetime focus. A sequence of drawings illustrates Dürer's exploration of human proportion, culminating in his renowned engraving, 'Adam and Eve' (1504), the sole surviving engraving bearing his full signature. Dürer produced numerous preparatory sketches, particularly for his paintings and engravings, many of which have survived, such as the iconic 'Praying Hands' (c.1508, Albertina, Vienna). Additionally, Dürer created watercolor and bodycolor images, often featuring still lifes of meadows or animals, including the celebrated 'Young Hare' (1502) and 'Great Piece of Turf' (1503, both at the Albertina).
summary_2: Venetian artist Jacopo de' Barbari influenced Albrecht Dürer during their meeting in 1500, sparking Dürer's intense study of perspective, anatomy, and proportion. This led to Dürer's famous engraving, 'Adam and Eve', and detailed sketches like 'Praying Hands'. He also produced vibrant watercolors, like 'Young Hare' and 'Great Piece of Turf'. De' Barbari's influence made Dürer a master of various techniques, making him one of the most influential artists of his time.
summary_3: In 1500, Venetian artist Jacopo de' Barbari's meeting with Albrecht Dürer inspired Dürer's intensive study of anatomy, perspective, and proportion, leading to renowned works like 'Adam and Eve', 'Praying Hands', 'Young Hare', and 'Great Piece of Turf', establishing Dürer as a master of diverse techniques and significant influencer in art.

text: Do not look for the Danteum in the Eternal City.In true Dantean form, politics stood in the way of its construction in 1938.Ironically this literature-inspired building can itself most easily be found in book form.Reading this book I remembered Goethe's quote about frozen music.Did Terragni try to freeze Dante's medieval miracle of song?Certainly a cold-poem seems artistically repulsive.Unflattering comparisons to the lake of Cocytus spring to mind too.While I cannot read Italian, I can read some German.After locating the original quotation I discovered that 'frozen' is a problematic (though common) translation of Goethe's original 'erstarrte.'The verb 'erstarren' more properly means 'to solidify' or 'to stiffen.'This suggests a chemical reaction in which the art does not necessarily chill in the transformation.Nor can simple thawing yield the original work.Like a chemical reaction it requires an artistic catalyst, a muse.Indeed the Danteum is not a physical translation of the Poem.Terragni thought it inappropriate to translate the Comedy literally into a non-literary work.The Danteum would not be a stage set, rather Terragni generated his design from the Comedy's structure, not its finishes.
summary_1: The proposed Danteum, inspired by Dante's Divine Comedy, was intended for construction in Rome in 1938 but wasn't built due to political obstacles. The architect, Giuseppe Terragni, aimed to create a literary monument rather than a literal translation of the poem into architecture. He focused on the Comedy's structure instead of its finishes. The term 'frozen music', often used to describe the Danteum, may not be entirely accurate. The German word 'erstarren', which translates to 'freeze' in English, could also mean 'to solidify' or 'to stiffen'. This implies a transformation process where the original work isn't simply refrozen, but altered through an artistic reaction, requiring a creative catalyst or muse. Therefore, the Danteum is not a direct physical translation of the poem, but a unique interpretation of its structure.
summary_2: Designed by Giuseppe Terragni, the unbuilt Danteum project sought to translate Dante's Divine Comedy into architecture, emphasizing the poem's structure over finishes. The term 'frozen music,' though commonly applied, may not fully capture the essence of the Danteum. Instead, it might be seen as a transformation or 'stiffening' of the original work, indicative of a creative interpretation rather than a literal translation.
summary_3: The Danteum project aimed to interpret Dante's Divine Comedy structurally, not literally, emphasizing its design over finishes.

text: The French have always wanted to know what it means to be a French­man.Their history has been a constant quest for national identity: a conflict between strong regional loyalties and central authority.In about 2000 b.c.Celtic tribes — probably from eastern Europe — came looking for greener pastures in the areas that are now Franche-Comté, Alsace, and Bur­gundy.At the same time, migrants from the Mediterranean countries were trickling into the south.The first recorded settlement was the trading post set up by Phocaean Greeks from Asia Minor at Massalia (Mar­seilles) around 600 b.c., followed by other ports at Hyères, Antibes, and Nice.But the Greeks developed few contacts with the interior beyond a little commerce in olives and wine with the Celts of Burgundy.When their position was threatened by Ligurian pirates at sea and warlike tribes from inland, the merchants of Marseilles called on Rome for help.From Gaul to France In 125 b.c., the Romans came in force, conquered the
