text: The modern Republic of Turkey dates only from 1923, but the history of the land within its borders stretches back to the dawn of humanity.Widespread finds of Stone Age implements in cave excavations show that Anatolia was already inhabited during the Middle of the Palaeolithic period (about 200,000 to 40,000 years ago).By Neolithic times, organized communities had arisen, such as the one at Çatalhöyük, near Konya, Turkey's most important prehistoric site.This town, which flourished between 6500 and 5500 b.c., had flat-roofed houses of mud and timber decorated with wall-paintings, some of which show patterns that still appear on Anatolian kilims.The advent of the Bronze Age (about 3200 b.c.), and the spread of city-states ruled by kings, is marked by the appearance of royal tombs containing bronze objects in such places as Troy in the west, and Alacahöyük near Ankara.Around this time the Sumerian civilization living in Mesopotamia (the region between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers in present-day Iraq) founded and developed the cuneiform script, the world's oldest form of writing on record.The technique was introduced by Assyrian traders 1,000 years later in­to Anatolia, where it was qui­ck­ly adopted by the indigenous Hatti people, who, at this point, had already reached an ad­­vanced state of civilization.The Hittites: The capital of the Hatti was Kanesh (modern Kültepe, near Kayseri).Cuneiform tablets found here record the arrival in Anatolia of warlike invaders around the second mill­ennium b.c.Their origins remain a my­s­tery (their written language was finally deciphered in 1915), but they came from the direction of the Caucasus moun­tains, spreading destruction and disorder throughout Anatolia.It was two hundred years before they were firmly entrenched in their newly conquered empire.The newcomers were the Hittites, and their domination of Anatolia can be divided into three distinct periods: the Old Kingdom (c.1600–1450 b.c.), then the New or Empire Period (c.1450–1200 b.c.), and the Late Hittite Period (c.
summary_1:
Turkey's historical roots trace back to the earliest human inhabitants of Anatolia, evidenced by Stone Age artifacts discovered in cave excavations from the Middle Paleolithic era (around 200,000 to 40,000 years ago). Organized communities emerged by Neolithic times, exemplified by the settlement at Çatalhöyük, active between 6500 and 5500 B.C. This society featured mud and timber homes adorned with wall paintings, hinting at cultural continuity through similarities with current Anatolian kilims.

The Bronze Age began around 3200 B.C., characterized by city-states under monarchies, as seen in sites like Troy in the west and Alacahöyük near Ankara, identifiable by royal tombs containing bronze items. During this age, the Sumerians in Mesopotamia created cuneiform script - the first known form of writing. Around 2000 B.C., this system arrived in Anatolia via Assyrian traders and was embraced by the local Hatti populace, already possessing advanced civilizations.

The Hittites, originating from the Caucasus mountains, appeared in Anatolia around the second millennium B.C., causing chaos and ultimately establishing dominance over the region for centuries. Their reign in Anatolia consists of three main phases: the Old Kingdom (circa 1600-1450 B.C.), followed by the New or Empire Period (circa 1450-1200 B.C.), ending with the Late Hittite Period (circa).
summary_2: Anatolia's history begins with early humans in the Middle Paleolithic era, leading to organized societies by the Neolithic period, such as Çatalhöyük. The Bronze Age introduced city-states, writing from Sumeria, and the arrival of the Hatti civilization. The Hittites, from the Caucasus, dominated Anatolia in three periods until 1200 BC.
summary_3: The history of Anatolia spans from early human settlement during the Middle Paleolithic era to the Bronze Age emergence of city-states, writing, and the rise and fall of the Hatti and Hittite civilizations up to 1200 BC.

text: Life for the partners of Cates, Katalinic & Lund holds little of the glamour one might expect from a career in law.Instead of lunches at Lut��ce, they caucus at the Palace Diner in Queens.Wooing clients means passing out fliers on street corners, not securing box seats at Madison Square Garden.To make ends meet, one partner stacks pipe and cleans the yard at a plumbing warehouse.Another handles urine samples in a hospital lab.A sign of failure, of a feeble economy, perhaps?Hardly.They are heeding the call of a growing pool of law schools, which are for the first time pointing graduates in a new direction and teaching them how to get there.Forget the lure of large firms, the security of a government post.Here is how to grapple "in the service of justice," as many of the schools put it, instead.Convinced that corporate largess and government programs barely dent the nation's legal needs, the law schools are urging graduates to buck tradition, pass up big salaries and ignore mushrooming student debt to join tiny neighborhood practices or simply start their own, all with an eye toward charging no more than their clients can afford.This is not pro bono legal work; it is "low bono," a term the schools coined to define the atypical kind of law career they are training students for.While its practitioners do charge for their services, they are also dead set on turning no one away - or at least as few as possible."When you go into this kind of social justice law, it's really brutal and you're almost guaranteed to struggle for a couple of years before there's a light at the end of the tunnel," said Fred Rooney, director of the Community Legal Resource Network at City University of New York School of Law, from which the lawyers of the newly formed Cates, Katalinic & Lund graduated last May."But if our graduates don't do it, the millions of people who cannot access justice in this country will continue to soar."The movement, primly called the consortium, started four years ago by CUNY, Northeastern University, the University of Maryland and St. Mary's Law School in Texas.(St. Mary's later dropped out.) Since then, it has drawn seven additional law schools to its ranks: the University of Michigan, Rutgers and Syracuse Law Schools, New York Law School, University of New Mexico School of Law, Thomas M. Cooley Law School and Touro Law School.It has elicited at least initial interest from 19 more.
summary_1: Several law schools have begun encouraging graduates to shun traditional high-paying legal careers in favor of establishing small, affordable neighborhood practices, aiming to address the significant portion of the population unable to access legal services due to financial constraints. The law schools teach students to prioritize serving communities over personal gain, even if it means lower salaries and increased debt. This shift towards what these institutions refer to as 'low bono' law aims to provide accessible legal assistance to those who could otherwise not afford it. A collective effort, known as the consortium, consisting of nine law schools including CUNY, Northeastern University, University of Michigan, Rutgers, Syracuse Law Schools, New York Law School, University of New Mexico School of Law, Thomas M. Cooley Law School, and Touro Law School, promotes this innovative approach to practicing law.
summary_2: Nine U.S. law schools form a group called the consortium, promoting 'low bono' law. They encourage grads to start affordable neighborhood law practices, providing legal help to those previously priced out. It's about community service over profit, despite potential debt and lower wages for new lawyers.
summary_3: The Consortium, comprising nine American law schools, advocates for 'low bono' law, urging graduates to establish budget-friendly local legal services, extending aid to those unable to afford it before.

text: Low-income domestic violence victims may find long-term legal help -- representation in divorces or child-custody disputes -- hard to come by, if two organizations now providing such help can't replace their lost funding.The Legal Aid Society of Salt Lake and Utah Legal Services are already facing cutbacks after they were refused a federal grant of more than $450,000 in September.The board overseeing the state Office of Crime Victim Reparations [CVR] has voted to deny a stopgap funding request from the two organizations.While describing the request as a worthy cause, board members agreed Tuesday that funding divorces or custody disputes was outside their focus -- providing direct services for crime victims.The $175,000 requested would have allowed the legal aid groups to maintain a skeleton staff to continue providing help beyond emergency protective orders for victims, completing existing cases and offering services in limited cases.The groups also plan to enlist more pro bono attorneys through coordination with the Utah State Bar. "We don't have a lot more options," said Anne Milne, executive director of Utah Legal Services, after learning of the CVR refusal Wednesday.The organization has already lost some staff through attrition and has turned away some cases, she said.Milne said she may ask the board overseeing her organization to give her until November to seek funding from additional sources.Without additional funding, the outlook for longer-term legal help is unclear.For two years, the groups had received 18-month civil legal assistance grants from the U.S. Department of Justice and had used them to provide such assistance.But last month, a third request was denied.Funding used to help victims obtain emergency protective orders remains in place, said Milne and Stewart Ralphs, executive director of the Legal Aid Society of Salt Lake.Although an order's requirements that an abuser stay away from a victim may remain in effect for years, protective orders only settle issues such as child custody, child support, custody and property arrangements for 150 days.Many judges are reluctant to address those issues in emergency protective orders, since the decrees stay in effect for such a short time, Milne and Ralphs said."The likelihood a victim will return to her abuser increases if she cannot permanently sever the relationship and establish workable support, custody and property arrangements," the funding request to CVR said.The Department of Justice said it denied the grant application, in part, because evaluators did not see enough collaboration between the organizations and victims' advocates, Ralphs and Milne told CVR board members.While the two said they believe their organizations coordinate well, the organizations cannot appeal the grant denial.Although CVR board members considered giving the money as a loan, not a grant, their vote on the funding request -- taken after Milne and Ralphs left the meeting -- was unanimous.
summary_1: Two organizations assisting low-income domestic violence victims, The Legal Aid Society of Salt Lake and Utah Legal Services, face difficulties due to lost funding. They were denied a federal grant of over $450,000 in September and were recently refused stopgap funding by the Office of Crime Victim Reparations (CVR). This could result in reduced long-term legal help, including divorce and child-custody dispute representation. The requested $175,000 would allow these organizations to maintain minimal staff, complete ongoing cases, and offer limited new services. Both organizations aim to involve more pro bono attorneys via cooperation with the Utah State Bar. Losing funds means losing staff and turning away cases. Without alternative financing, future legal assistance prospects look uncertain. For two years, these groups received 18-month civil legal assistance grants from the U.S. Department of Justice, but recent requests have been declined. Funding still covers emergency protective orders; however, these orders only manage immediate concerns like child custody, child support, and property arrangements for 150 days. Long-term solutions require further financial commitment, which currently seems unlikely.
summary_2: Legal aid societies serving low-income domestic violence victims, The Legal Aid Society of Salt Lake and Utah Legal Services, encounter challenges after losing federal funding worth over $450,000 and being denied backup funds by the CVR. Refusal may lead to diminished extended legal assistance such as divorce and custody dispute representation. Requesting $175,000 ensures continued basic operations, case completion, and restricted new services. Both entities plan to engage more pro bono lawyers through collaboration with the Utah State Bar. Absence of additional finances might mean fewer employees and declining caseloads. Previous 18-month civil legal assistance grants expired, leaving solely emergency protective order coverage. Sustainable remedies need extra investment, presently appearing improbable.
summary_3: After losing significant federal funding, two Utah legal aid societies for low-income domestic violence victims risk reduced legal services without an additional $175,000, which could maintain basic operations, limited new services, and collaborations with the Utah State Bar for pro bono lawyer involvement; otherwise, they face potential staff cuts and decreased caseloads.

text: The CIA's senior management saw problems with the armed Predator as well, problems that Clarke and even Black and Allen were inclined to minimize.One (which also applied to reconnaissance flights) was money.A Predator cost about $3 million.If the CIA flew Predators for its own reconnaissance or covert action purposes, it might be able to borrow them from the Air Force, but it was not clear that the Air Force would bear the cost if a vehicle went down.Deputy Secretary of Defense Wolfowitz took the position that the CIA should have to pay for it; the CIA disagreed.Second, Tenet in particular questioned whether he, as Director of Central Intelligence, should operate an armed Predator."This was new ground,"he told us.Tenet ticked off key questions: What is the chain of command?Who takes the shot?Are America's leaders comfortable with the CIA doing this, going outside of normal military command and control?Charlie Allen told us that when these questions were discussed at the CIA, he and the Agency's executive director, A. B." Buzzy" Krongard, had said that either one of them would be happy to pull the trigger, but Tenet was appalled, telling them that they had no authority to do it, nor did he.Third, the Hellfire warhead carried by the Predator needed work.It had been built to hit tanks, not people.It needed to be designed to explode in a different way, and even then had to be targeted with extreme precision.In the configuration planned by the Air Force through mid-2001, the Predator's missile would not be able to hit a moving vehicle.White House officials had seen the Predator video of the "man in white."On July 11, Hadley tried to hurry along preparation of the armed system.He directed McLaughlin, Wolfowitz, and Joint Chiefs Vice Chairman Richard Myers to deploy Predators capable of being armed no later than September 1.
summary_1: The CIA identified issues with arming the Predator drone, including financial aspects. Each Predator cost around $3 million, leading to debates over funding between Deputy Secretary of Defense Wolfowitz and the CIA. The latter argued that the Air Force should cover costs if a drone crashed during CIA operations, while the former believed the CIA should foot the bill. Additionally, CIA Director George Tenet raised concerns regarding his role in authorizing strikes, questioning the chain of command and who would make the final decision to fire. Charlie Allen and Buzzy Krongard suggested they could authorize attacks, but Tenet rejected their proposal due to lack of authority. Furthermore, modifications were required for the Hellfire missiles, which were initially developed for tank destruction rather than targeting individuals. Initially, the missiles couldn't accurately strike moving vehicles. Following the observation of a man in white via Predator footage on July 11, White House official Stephen Hadley urged the deployment of armed Predators by September 1.
summary_2: The CIA faced controversy over financing Predator drones, with Deputy Secretary of Defense Wolfowitz and CIA disagreeing on payment for crashes. CIA Director Tenet questioned his authority to order strikes, causing debate over the chain of command. Officials proposed modifying Hellfire missiles for individual targets, addressing initial difficulties striking moving vehicles. Amidst these challenges, there was pressure to deploy armed Predators by September 1 after observing an individual on July 11.
summary_3: Amid debates over funding and command chains, officials raced to modify Hellfires for targeted Predator drone strikes against a specific individual by September 1, following disagreements about post-crash payments and strike authorization.

text: Two women trade houses without ever having met . They 're both looking for an escape from their problems , but by running away , both come to discover a great deal about themselves . Ria Lynch is married to Danny Lynch and they have a daughter and a son . Danny begins spending less and less time at home with his wife and children . Ria believes another baby is the solution , and is shocked to find out that indeed her husband is going to be a father - but to a child from an affair he has been having . Her husband's unfaithfulness is the event that leads Ria into her decision to switch homes with a woman from the US called Marilyn who lost her teenage son to a motorcycle accident on his birthday . Marilyn is struggling to come to terms with her son's death and has become estranged from her husband . She hopes her time in Dublin will cease her grief . Ria and Marilyn discover deep , dark secrets about the other during the summer . The two become close friends but do not reveal the secrets . { { Expand section } }
summary_1: Ria Lynch and Marilyn swap homes, seeking respite from personal issues. Ria, married to Danny Lynch with two kids, finds solace when she learns she's pregnant after Danny confesses to infidelity. Meanwhile, Marilyn, grieving over her teenage son's fatal motorcycle accident, becomes distant from her spouse. Hoping for healing, she moves to Dublin where Ria currently lives. Throughout their stay in each other's homes, Ria and Marilyn unearth shocking secrets about one another. Despite this knowledge, they form a bond yet decide to keep these revelations hidden. Their friendship blossoms despite the weighty secrets, offering them newfound understanding and self-discovery.
summary_2: Amidst personal crises, Ria and Marilyn exchange homes. Pregnant Ria seeks comfort from husband Danny's infidelity, while grieving Marilyn avoids her spouse post-son's death. Both hope for peace in unfamiliar surroundings. As they adjust, surprising truths emerge about both women, strengthening their connection. They choose not to expose these discoveries, fostering a deepened bond and fresh insights into themselves.
summary_3: Ria and Marilyn swap homes amid personal struggles, finding solace and forming a deeper bond as they uncover surprising truths about each other, deciding to keep them secret.

text: Have you ever seen an egg?Some animals do not have live births.Instead, they lay eggs.The eggs contain the embryo.The embryo matures in the egg.With time, it will hatch.Some animals hatch and do not need care from their parents.They are ready to live on their own.Other animals will still need the care of their parents.Sea turtles break out of their shells.They immediately walk to the ocean.They do this with no help from an adult.Birds stay in the nest for many weeks.They are cared for by their parents.They leave the nest when they are strong enough to fly.Some animals give birth to live offspring.Animals like horses, cows, and whales give live birth.Their offspring are born looking like mini adults.
summary_1: Certain creatures reproduce via eggs rather than giving live birth. These eggs encase an embryo that develops and hatches over time. Some species, such as sea turtles, become independent soon after hatching, venturing into their environment without parental assistance. Conversely, birds remain in their nests for extended periods, receiving care from their parents until they grow strong enough to fly and fend for themselves. Other animals deliver live young ones, including horses, cows, and whales, whose newborns emerge resembling smaller versions of the adults.
summary_2: Some animals lay eggs which hatch into offspring, while others give live birth. Newly hatched sea turtles are self-reliant, whereas baby birds need parental care before flying independently. Mammals like horses, cows, and whales bear live young, who appear miniature but similar to adult forms.
summary_3: Certain creatures hatch from eggs or are born alive, with varying levels of independence at birth differing among species.

text: LONDON, England -- Graffiti artist Banksy, famed for infiltrating museum collections without their knowledge and spray-painting public buildings around the world, is holding his first major exhibition in years.A Banksy painting of the British House of Commons at England's Bristol museum.This time, however, the anonymous artist worked in tandem with the director of Bristol museum in the UK.CNN's Max Foster got a preview of his largest project to date.The artist's anonymity gained him notoriety and he became one of the art world's biggest names with his works selling at auction for hundreds of thousands of dollars.The exhibition's range, while very varied, remained true to Banksy form with his usual unconventional take on art.See pictures from Banksy's exhibition » "I think we might have dragged them down to our level rather than being elevated to theirs" Banksy, who is thought to be from Bristol, said about the museum.He filled three stories of the building with his art in 36 hours under tight security, as only a few museum staff were aware of the shows' imminent arrival.His work is hidden among the museum's usual exhibits and is split into different rooms, including installations, paintings and sculptures.In one of the paintings, a character has been cut out and is instead sitting on the painting's frame, perhaps taking a break from posing?
summary_1: Banksy, the elusive graffiti artist known for covertly adding his work to museums and public spaces worldwide, is presenting his first significant exhibit in years, collaborating with Bristol museum's director. The enigmatic figure, renowned for his anonymity and controversial style, has created an array of artwork that aligns with his signature unorthodox approach. The display, which includes installations, paintings, and sculptures, was installed within 36 hours under strict secrecy, surprising even some museum employees. A notable piece features a character seemingly stepping away from the canvas to rest on its frame. Banksy humorously commented on the collaboration, stating it may have lowered the museum's standards rather than raising his own artistic level. Despite maintaining a low profile throughout his career, Banksy's creations consistently fetch high prices at auctions, solidifying his status in the contemporary art scene.
summary_2: Banksy, the anonymous street artist, teams up with Bristol Museum's director for his first major exhibit in years, showcasing installations, paintings, and sculptures reflecting his distinctive style. Notorious for clandestine installations, he assembled the collection in secret over 36 hours. A highlight shows a character leaving a painting to lean on its frame. Banksy quipped about potentially lowering the museum's standards instead of elevating his art. His works remain popular despite his reclusive nature, often selling for substantial sums in auctions.
summary_3: Banksy collaborates with Bristol Museum's director for a new exhibition, featuring installations, paintings, and sculptures, including a notable piece showing a character leaning against a painting's frame.

text: Let me begin again.I like life on the resort worlds -- always have and, after the upcoming mindwipe, always will.Last year, I rented a small house on Vega IV, a sea world, all islands and reefs and archipelagos, turquoise waters and aquamarine skies, sunrises like symphonies and sunsets like stars gone supernova.There's only one city: called Nuevo Acapulco in La Enciclopedia del Empirio de la Humanidad, it's N'apulco to the locals.The N'apulcans are mostly emigrants from Polaris II; the only difference between them and their Carribbean ancestors is that the ancestors fleeced NorAm tourists.Now the N'apulcans profit from their Hispanic siblings.I don't mean to sound cynical.I suppose I wish to show that I'm still capable of a certain authorial distance, a semblance of dispassionate observation.The following events may indicate otherwise.In fine tourist tradition, most homes on Vega IV are named.Mine was The Sleeping Flamingo, and its outer walls were coral pink.Were they mood-sensitive, they would have changed as I first viewed them.The rental agent, an attractive N'apulcan named Tasha Cortez, was not mood-sensitive either.She said, "It's beautiful, isn't it, Señor Flynn?"My instinct was to gesture curtly with a cupped hand that she lift the wind boat and take me elsewhere.But she was young and attractive (as I have said and may say again) and eager and so happy to be assisting the infamous Bernardo Flynn that I merely raised an eyebrow in mild scepticism.And then, because a playwright cannot resist a promising line, I said, "Your Sleeping Flamingo should be put to sleep."
summary_1: Bernardo Flynn, known for his love of resort worlds, shares his experience of staying at The Sleeping Flamingo, a coral pink house on Vega IV - a sea world filled with islands, reefs, and turquoise waters. The only city, Nuevo Acapulco or N'apulco, houses descendants of Polaris II immigrants who now profit from tourism, much like their Caribbean predecessors did. Despite being renters, the inhabitants often name their homes, and Flynn's rental home has a strong impact on him. Upon seeing The Sleeping Flamingo for the first time, he experiences mixed feelings but decides against voicing any concerns due to the youthful enthusiasm of the real estate agent, Tasha Cortez. Intrigued by her eagerness to help famous writer Bernardo Flynn, he holds back his initial skepticism about the property.
summary_2: Author Bernardo Flynn rents a house, "The Sleeping Flamingo," on Vega IV's vibrant Nuevo Acapulco. An ex-Polaris II immigrant hub, it thrives on tourism. Flynn, initially skeptical, is swayed by enthusiastic realtor Tasha Cortez. He appreciates the coral pink house despite initial mixed emotions.
summary_3: Bernardo Flynn, author, decides to rent a coral pink house named 'The Sleeping Flamingo' in lively Nuevo Acapulco, an erstwhile Polaris II immigrant hub turned tourist hotspot, after being persuaded by an enthusiastic realtor, Tasha Cortez.

text: You couldnt survive without your skin.It has many important functions.The main function of the skin is controlling what enters and leaves the body.It prevents the loss of too much water from the body.It also prevents bacteria and other microorganisms from entering the body.The skin helps maintain a constant body temperature.It keeps the body cool in two ways.Sweat from sweat glands in the skin evaporates to cool the body.Blood vessels in the skin dilate, or widen.This action increases blood flow to the body surface.This allows more heat to reach the surface.The heat is then able to radiate off the body.The opposite happens to retain body heat.Blood vessels in the skin constrict, or narrow.This decreases blood flow to the body surface.This reduces the amount of heat that reaches the surface.When this happens, less heat can be lost to the air.
summary_1: Skin serves crucial roles for survival. Its primary role involves regulating substances entering and exiting the body. It averts excessive water loss by acting as a barrier against water evaporation. Furthermore, it obstructs bacterial and other microorganism intrusion. Skin contributes to maintaining a stable internal environment through thermoregulation. To counteract overheating, sweat glands produce sweat which evaporates on the skin, cooling down the body. Additionally, dilation of blood vessels near the skin enhances blood flow towards the skin surface, facilitating heat radiation into the surroundings. Conversely, during cold environments, constriction of these blood vessels occurs, reducing blood flow close to the skin surface. This restricts heat dissipation, thus preserving core body warmth.
summary_2: Skin plays vital functions for survival. Mainly, it regulates substance entry/exit, preventing dehydration and infection. Thermoregulation is another key function; sweating cools the body, while blood vessel dilation/constriction helps maintain core temperature in hot/cold conditions.
summary_3: Skin regulates substances entering/exiting the body, prevents dehydration and infection, and controls temperature through thermoregulation.

text: The earliest signs of people on Jamaica are the remains of the Arawak, an AmerIndian society that originated on the north coast of South America.Arawak peoples migrated to various Caribbean islands, arriving in Jamaica by the beginning of the eighth century.They were peaceful and lived by "slash-and-burn" farming.For meat, they bred pigs and ate iguana, both native to the island.They were highly skilled in such manual activities as thatching and weaving.In fact, the hammock was an AmerIndian invention that remains with us today; it is an object which, more than any other, evokes an image of a warm sunny day on a tropical isle.The Arawak left a legacy of paintings in places such as Runaway Caves near Discovery Bay, and shards of pottery found at their settlements near Nueva Sevilla and Spanish Town have added a little to our knowledge about them.Over 200 Arawak sites have been identified, and it is said that when the Spanish arrived in Jamaica there were approximately 100,000 Arawak living on the island.They called Jamaica "Xaymaca" ("land of wood and water").Columbus and the Arrival of Europeans Columbus first arrived in Jamaica on 5 May 1494 at Discovery Bay, where there is now a small park in his honor.He stayed for only a few days but returned in 1502, landing here when the ships of his fleet became unserviceable; he waited at St. Ann's Bay for help to arrive from Cuba.After the death of Columbus in 1505, Jamaica became the property of his son Diego, who dispatched Don Juan de Esquivel to the island as Governor.Esquivel arrived in 1510 and created a base called Nueva Sevilla near St. Ann's Bay, from which he hoped to colonize the rest of the island.The Spanish immediately began subjugating the Arawak population, many of whom died under the yoke of oppression and of diseases carried by the Europeans.A number of them committed suicide rather than live the life created for them by the Spanish.The site of Nueva Sevilla proved to be unhealthy and mosquito-ridden, and in 1534 the Spanish founded Villa de la Vega, today known as Spanish Town.Pig breeding was the main occupation of these early settlers, but they also planted sugar cane and other crops that required large numbers of laborers.The number of Arawak had already fallen dramatically, so the Spanish began to import slaves from Africa to work the land; the first Africans arrived in 1517.
summary_1: Arriving around the start of the 8th century, the Arawaks, indigenous people from South America, inhabited Jamaica peacefully, practicing 'slash-and-burn' agriculture, rearing local animals like pigs and iguanas, and excelling in crafts like weaving and thatching. Their influence lingers through inventions like the hammock. Evidence of their existence includes remnants in caves like those in Runaway Caves near Discovery Bay and ceramic pieces unearthed close to Nueva Sevilla and Spanish Town. Initially estimated at 100,000 upon European arrival, their numbers rapidly declined due to Spanish enslavement, foreign illnesses, and suicides triggered by harsh conditions. Christopher Columbus made two visits - first in 1494 at Discovery Bay, then in 1502 at St. Ann's Bay while awaiting aid from Cuba after ship troubles. Following Columbus' demise in 1505, his son, Diego, took control over Jamaica via Governor Don Juan de Esquivel in 1510. Establishing Nueva Sevilla, the Spanish forced Arawaks into servitude until moving to healthier Spanish Town in 1534. With the decline in Arawak population, African slave labor emerged in 1517 to support pig breeding, sugar cultivation, and other crop production.
summary_2: The Arawaks, originally from South America, settled Jamaica around the 8th century, engaging in peaceful farming, animal husbandry, and skilled craftwork. Known for innovations like the hammock, they thrived until decimated by Spanish slavery, disease, and poor living conditions post-European contact. Remains in caves and archaeological sites attest to their legacy. After Columbus' exploratory visits in 1494 and 1502, his son, Diego, controlled Jamaica through Governor Esquivel in 1510. The Spanish established Nueva Sevilla, utilizing Arawak slaves until relocating to Spanish Town in 1534. As the Arawak population dwindled, African slave labor was introduced in 1517 for pig farming, sugar cultivation, and other crops.
summary_3: The Arawaks, indigenous to South America, inhabited Jamaica from the 8th century, excelling in agriculture, craftsmanship, and inventing the hammock, but were nearly wiped out due to Spanish exploitation, diseases, and harsh living conditions after European arrival; the Spanish, led by Columbus' son Diego, replaced them with African slaves for labor from 1517 onwards.

text: Bin Laden and his aides did not need a very large sum to finance their planned attack on America.The 9/11 plotters eventually spent somewhere between $400,000 and $500,000 to plan and conduct their attack.Consistent with the importance of the project, al Qaeda funded the plotters.KSM provided his operatives with nearly all the money they needed to travel to the United States, train, and live.The plotters' tradecraft was not especially sophisticated, but it was good enough.They moved, stored, and spent their money in ordinary ways, easily defeating the detection mechanisms in place at the time.The origin of the funds remains unknown, although we have a general idea of how al Qaeda financed itself during the period leading up to 9/11.General Financing As we explained in chapter 2,  Bin Laden did not fund al Qaeda through a personal fortune and a network of businesses in Sudan.Instead, al Qaeda relied primarily on a fund-raising network developed over time.The CIA now estimates that it cost al Qaeda about $30 million per year to sustain its activities before 9/11 and that this money was raised almost entirely through donations.For many years, the United States thought  Bin Laden financed al Qaeda's expenses through a vast personal inheritance. Bin Laden purportedly inherited approximately $300 million when his father died, and was rumored to have had access to these funds to wage jihad while in Sudan and Afghanistan and to secure his leadership position in al Qaeda.In early 2000, the U.S. government discovered a different reality: roughly from 1970 through 1994,  Bin Laden received about $1 million per year-a significant sum, to be sure, but not a $300 million fortune that could be used to fund jihad.Then, as part of a Saudi government crackdown early in the 1990s, the  Bin Laden family was forced to find a buyer for Usama's share of the family company in 1994.The Saudi government subsequently froze the proceeds of the sale.This action had the effect of divesting  Bin Laden of what otherwise might indeed have been a large fortune.Nor were  Bin Laden's assets in Sudan a source of money for al Qaeda.When  Bin Laden lived in Sudan from 1991 to 1996, he owned a number of businesses and other assets.
summary_1: Al-Qaeda financed the 9/11 attacks, which cost around $400,000-$500,000, mostly supplied by Khalid Sheikh Mohammed (KSM). The group's funding came primarily from donations, not from bin Laden's personal fortune or businesses. Al-Qaeda was estimated to spend about $30 million annually before 9/11, also from donations. Contrary to previous beliefs, bin Laden didn't have a $300 million inheritance; instead, he received about $1 million annually until 1994, when his assets were frozen by the Saudi government after being forced to sell his shares in the family business. In Sudan, where bin Laden resided from 1991 to 1996, his businesses and assets were not used to fund al-Qaeda.
summary_2: Al-Qaeda funded the 9/11 attacks, mainly through donations, contrary to assumptions that it stemmed from Osama bin Laden's wealth. Previously thought to have a $300 million inheritance, bin Laden actually received $1 million yearly until 1994. Before 9/11, al-Qaeda spent approximately $30 million per year, all from contributions. Bin Laden did not use his Sudanese businesses for financing during his residency there from 1991 to 1996.
summary_3: Al-Qaeda financed the 9/11 attacks primarily through donations, not Osama bin Laden's wealth, which was estimated at $1 million annually, not $300 million.

text: In October 1933 Einstein returned to the U.S. and took up a position at the Institute for Advanced Study (in Princeton, New Jersey), noted for having become a refuge for scientists fleeing Nazi Germany.At the time, most American universities, including Harvard, Princeton and Yale, had minimal or no Jewish faculty or students, as a result of their Jewish quota which lasted until the late 1940s.Einstein was still undecided on his future.He had offers from several European universities, including Oxford where he stayed for three short periods between May 1931 and June 1933, however in 1935 he arrived at the decision to remain permanently in the United States and apply for citizenship.Einstein's affiliation with the Institute for Advanced Study would last until his death in 1955.He was one of the four first selected (two of the others being John von Neumann and Kurt Godel) at the new Institute, where he soon developed a close friendship with Godel.The two would take long walks together discussing their work.Bruria Kaufman, his assistant, later became a physicist.During this period, Einstein tried to develop a unified field theory and to refute the accepted interpretation of quantum physics, both unsuccessfully.
summary_1: In October 1933, Albert Einstein joined the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, becoming part of a community of scholars escaping Nazi Germany. At the time, many American universities, including Harvard, Princeton, and Yale, had limited Jewish faculty and students due to Jewish quotas that persisted until the late 1940s. Initially uncertain about his plans, Einstein received offers from various European institutions, visiting Oxford for brief stays between May 1931 and June 1933. However, by 1935, he decided to settle permanently in the US and applied for citizenship, maintaining his association with the Institute until his demise in 1955. Chosen as one of its first members alongside John von Neumann and Kurt Gödel, Einstein formed a close bond with Gödel during their walks and discussions. Bruria Kaufman, his assistant, also pursued a career in physics. During this tenure, Einstein endeavored to construct a unified field theory and challenge the prevailing understanding of quantum physics, but without success.
summary_2: Albert Einstein moved to the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton in 1933 after leaving Nazi Germany. Many U.S. universities still had Jewish quotas at the time. After considering options in Europe, Einstein chose to stay in the U.S., applying for citizenship and joining the institute permanently. He became close friends with fellow physicist Kurt Gödel and assistant Bruria Kaufman. Despite efforts, Einstein failed to develop a unified field theory or change the dominant understanding of quantum physics.
summary_3: Einstein joined Princeton's Institute for Advanced Study in 1933 due to Jewish quotas in U.S. universities, befriended Kurt Gödel and Bruria Kaufman, but didn't succeed in creating a unified field theory or altering quantum physics understanding.

text: Roberta Adams skipped the thick how-to guide on child-custody forms and sat down at a computer at the Lamoreaux Justice Center in Orange on Wednesday.The Garden Grove woman answered a series of questions to create and print a form to file with the court."It's easy," said Adams, 25."I thought I'd have all kinds of questions and have to take the forms home."A University of California, Irvine, study released Wednesday found an interactive computer system effectively helps people fill out paperwork for restraining orders, eviction defense, small-claims cases and requests for filing-fee waivers.Not only does the system make life easier for people who can't afford a lawyer, but it also might improve efficiency in the courts because the forms, which are printed out when completed, are easy to read and are being filled out correctly, the study found.Since the program started in 2000, more than 6,000 people have used the free system, located in public buildings throughout Orange County.The system was developed by the Legal Aid Society of Orange County with about $800,000 in grants.The program avoids legal jargon, offers a courthouse video tour and sticks to a fifth-grade vocabulary.Users can choose English, Spanish or Vietnamese.Kiosks are in courthouses in Fullerton and Orange, the district attorney's family-support office, the Legal Aid Society in Santa Ana, Irvine City Hall and the San Juan Capistrano Library.The program is also available online.Bob Cohen, executive director of Legal Aid, said the study should clear the way for expansion throughout California.Locally, a program for divorce petitions will be added this summer.Cohen said the system proves the benefit of technology tailored to those who aren't computer-savvy.He said much of the technology now available requires Internet skills and access.Low-income people, however, have less access to computers and less experience using them."Our clients have to catch up, and they have to become a part of the mainstream," Cohen said.
summary_1: An interactive computer system has been shown to aid individuals in completing legal documents such as restraining orders, eviction defenses, small claims cases, and fee-waiver applications, according to a UC Irvine study. The system, operational since 2000, has assisted over 6,000 people in Orange County, many of whom cannot afford lawyers. Developed by the Legal Aid Society with approximately $800,000 in grants, the system simplifies language to a fifth-grade level, supports multiple languages, and avoids legal jargon. It currently operates in various public buildings and online. An example provided is Roberta Adams, who successfully created a child-custody form without needing to consult a guide. The study suggests that such systems could enhance court efficiency by ensuring accurately filled forms. Bob Cohen, Legal Aid's executive director, plans to expand the system statewide and introduce a divorce petition program locally. He emphasizes the importance of accessible technology for those with limited computer literacy and resources.
summary_2: A UC Irvine study reveals an interactive computer system, developed by the Legal Aid Society, helps users complete legal documents like restraining orders and petitions. Since 2000, it has assisted over 6,000 low-income individuals in Orange County, enabling them to navigate complex legal processes without lawyers. The system uses simple language, multi-language support, and avoids legal jargon, operating in public spaces and online. Success stories include Roberta Adams, who completed a child-custody form independently. This system aims to improve court efficiency and may expand statewide, offering a divorce petition program.
summary_3: The Legal Aid Society's interactive computer system has helped over 6,000 low-income individuals in Orange County complete legal documents since 2000, providing simple language, multilingual support, and avoiding legal jargon, potentially expanding statewide with a focus on improving court efficiency.

text: The Mummy 's Shroud is set in 1920 and tells the story of a team of archaeologists who come across the lost tomb of the boy Pharaoh Kah-To-Bey .The story begins with a flash back sequence to Ancient Egypt and we see the story of how Prem , a manservant of Kah-To-Bey , spirited away the boy when his father was killed in a palace coup and took him into the desert for protection .Unfortunately , the boy dies and is buried .The story then moves forward to 1920 and shows the expedition led by scientist Sir Basil Walden and business man Stanley Preston finding the tomb .They ignore the dire warning issued to them by Hasmid , a local Bedouin about the consequences for those that violate the tombs of Ancient Egypt and remove the bodies and the sacred shroud .Sir Basil is bitten by a snake just after finding the tomb .He recovers , but has a relapse after arriving back in Cairo .Preston takes advantage of this and commits him to an insane asylum , to take credit for finding the tomb and Prince 's mummy himself .Meanwhile , after being placed in the Cairo Museum , the mummy of Prem is revived when Hasmid chants the sacred oath on the shroud .The mummy then proceeds to go on a murderous rampage to kill off the members of the expedition , beginning with Sir Basil after he escapes from the asylum .One by one , those who assisted in removing the contents of the tomb to Cairo are eliminated by such grisly means as strangulation , being thrown out of windows , and having photographic acid thrown in their face .
summary_1: In "The Mummy's Shroud," set in 1920, a group of archaeologists discover the tomb of the boy Pharaoh Kah-To-Bey in Ancient Egypt. The tale starts with a flashback showing Prem, Kah-To-Bey's servant, saving the boy during a palace coup and burying him in the desert after his death. In 1920, an expedition led by Sir Basil Walden and Stanley Preston unearths the tomb but disregards a grave warning from a local Bedouin named Hasmid. They remove the bodies and the sacred shroud despite Hasmid's caution about disturbing ancient Egyptian tombs. Sir Basil gets bitten by a snake at the site but recovers, only to be committed to an asylum by Preston upon returning to Cairo. Preston seeks recognition for discovering the tomb and its artifacts. Meanwhile, Prem's mummy comes alive in the museum when Hasmid chants over the shroud. Prem embarks on a killing spree, targeting the expedition members responsible for desecrating the tomb. Victims meet gruesome ends—strangulation, falling from windows, and even facial burns from photographic acid.
summary_2: "The Mummy's Shroud" follows 1920s archaeologists uncovering a boy Pharaoh's tomb, ignoring a local's warning. A servant's mummy revives, seeking vengeance on those who disturbed the tomb, resulting in grisly deaths.
summary_3: In "The Mummy's Shroud," 1920s archaeologists disregard a local's warning, unearthing a boy Pharaoh's tomb, leading to a mummy's revenge and gruesome deaths.

text: Dirk Diggler was born as Steven Samuel Adams on April 15 , 1961 outside of Saint Paul , Minnesota .His parents were a construction worker and a boutique shop owner who attended church every Sunday and believed in God .Looking for a career as a male model , Diggler dropped out of school at age 16 and left home .He was discovered at a falafel stand by Jack Horner .Diggler met his friend , Reed Rothchild , through Horner in 1979 while working on a film .Horner slowly introduced Diggler to the business until he became noticeable within the industry .Diggler became a prominent model and began appearing in pornographic films , after Which his career took off .He had critical and box office hits Which led him to stardom .The hits and publicity led to fame and money Which led Diggler to the world of drugs .With the amount of money Diggler was making he was able to support both his and Rothchild's addictions .The drugs eventually caused a breakup between Diggler and Horner since Diggler was having issues with his performance on set .After the breakup Diggler tried to make a film himself but the film was never completed .He then attempted a music career Which was also successful but led him deeper into drugs because of the amount of money he was making .He then starred in a TV show Which was a failure both critically and commercially .Having failed and with no work , Diggler returned to the porn industry taking roles in low-budget homosexual films to help support his habit .
summary_1: Born on April 15, 1961, Dirk Diggler, originally named Steven Samuel Adams, hailed from a religious family near Saint Paul, Minnesota. His parents, a construction worker and a boutique shop owner, regularly attended church and held faith in God. At 16, Diggler abandoned high school and his family in pursuit of a modeling career. He was discovered at a falafel stand by Jack Horner, who later introduced him to Reed Rothchild. Under Horner's guidance, Diggler ventured further into the adult entertainment industry, first gaining recognition as a model before transitioning to explicit films. Critical and commercial success followed, accompanied by wealth and drug addiction. The latter ultimately resulted in strained relations with Horner due to Diggler's struggles with substance abuse affecting his performances. Post-breakup, Diggler embarked on various projects including attempting to produce his own film, pursuing a music career, and even featuring in a television series. However, these endeavors either flopped or exacerbated his drug problem. Ultimately, Diggler found himself back in the porn industry, settling for lower-budget, gay films to sustain his escalating habits.
summary_2: Dirk Diggler, born Steven Samuel Adams in 1961, left home aged 16 for a modeling career. Discovered by Jack Horner, he entered the adult film industry, achieving fame and wealth but also drug addiction. His substance abuse led to strained relations with Horner and failed attempts at music and TV careers. Eventually, Diggler returned to low-budget, gay films to fuel his habit.
summary_3: Dirk Diggler, real name Steven Samuel Adams, became a wealthy porn star under Jack Horner, but drugs derailed his mainstream success, leading him back into low-budget gay films.

text: A government-sponsored coup last year made Bruce Iwasaki and Neal Dudovitz the kings of Los Angeles County's federally funded legal aid community.The two men emerged atop a changed landscape that resulted from a decade of begging for a share of shrinking public dollars doled out by an unsympathetic GOP-controlled Congress.That era was capped in 1998, when the Legal Services Corp. forced 275 legal aid providers nationwide to combine into 179.To comply with the orders from their main funding source, a new species of poverty lawyer emerged - a tech-savvy and button-down breed who swapped neighborhood walkin offices for toll-free phone lines, self-help kiosks and Internet access to legal advice.While some organizations made the dramatic change look effortless, for others, it did not come easy.And few programs provide more dramatic illustrations of the promise and pitfalls of government-funded legal services than Los Angeles County's two largest providers of federally funded services - Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles and Pacoima-based Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County.From his offices in Koreatown, Iwasaki, a soft-spoken former O'Melveny & Myers attorney, quietly engineered a merger between a much smaller Legal Aid Society of Long Beach and his program, the Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles.The merger was completed peacefully within a year of the federal order.Today, the programs operate seamlessly, offering new innovations - including toll-free multilingual phone advisers, expanded hours for domestic-violence clinics, and renewed immigration and consumer aid - built on the foundations of the old program.The organization is Los Angeles' largest government-funded group, with a budget of $11 million leveraged into $40 million in legal services to the poor.
summary_1: Last year, due to a government-backed coup, Bruce Iwasaki and Neal Dudovitz became the rulers of Los Angeles County's federally funded legal aid sector. This shift occurred after a decade of pleading for a portion of diminishing public funds from an unresponsive Republican-dominated Congress. The period culminated in 1998 when the Legal Services Corp. mandated the amalgamation of 275 legal aid providers into 179. To adhere to the directives from their primary financier, a fresh kind of poverty lawyer surfaced - one proficient in technology and business attire, trading local drop-in offices for toll-free numbers, self-help kiosks, and internet access to legal guidance. While certain entities transitioned smoothly, others faced challenges. Two prominent examples of this transformation are Los Angeles County's leading government-funded service providers - Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles and Pacoima-based Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County. Iwasaki, a tranquil ex-O'Melveny & Myers attorney based in Koreatown, orchestrated a merge between a smaller Legal Aid Society of Long Beach and his program, the Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles. The merger concluded harmoniously within a year of the federal decree. Now, both programs function cohesively, introducing advancements such as multilingual toll-free counselors, extended hours for domestic violence consultations, and revitalized immigration and consumer assistance. Established on established structures, these improvements have created Los Angeles' most extensive government-supported organization, boasting an $11 million budget amplified to $40 million in legal services for the underprivileged.
summary_2: Bruce Iwasaki and Neal Dudovitz took charge of LA County's federally funded legal aid sector after a 1998 coup backed by the government. Facing decreased public funds, the Legal Services Corp. ordered the consolidation of 275 legal aid providers into 179. This led to a new breed of poverty lawyers who were tech-savvy and donned business attire, replacing local offices with virtual ones. Notable examples include Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles and Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County. Iwasaki, a former O'Melveny & Myers attorney, merged Legal Aid Society of Long Beach with his program, forming a unified entity that now offers multilingual toll-free counselling, longer domestic violence consultation hours, and improved immigration/consumer assistance. These changes have resulted in Los Angeles' largest government-supported organization, with a $40 million budget for legal services.
summary_3: After a 1998 coup supported by the government, Bruce Iwasaki and Neal Dudovitz led LA County's federally funded legal aid sector, merging 275 providers into 179 due to reduced funding, creating a new generation of tech-savvy, business-attired poverty lawyers who replaced physical offices with virtual ones, leading to the formation of large organizations like Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles and Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County, resulting in Los Angeles' largest government-supported legal service organization with a $40 million budget.

text: (CNN) -- A Christian evangelical group said Thursday that a Bible school -- backed by American evangelist Franklin Graham -- was destroyed in the latest bombing raid to hit South Kordofan, an oil-rich Sudanese province that borders the newly created independent country of South Sudan.At least eight bombs were dropped in the area Wednesday during the school's first day of classes, according to a statement by Samaritan's Purse, Graham's Christian humanitarian group, which supports the school.Two bombs landed inside the compound -- located in the region's Nuba Mountains -- destroying two Heiban Bible College buildings and igniting grass fires across the area, the group said in a statement No injuries were reported."It was a miracle that no one was injured," the statement added.Graham, who has called on the international community to take out Sudan's air assets and establish a no-fly zone in the region, said in a statement Thursday that he blamed Sudan's air force for the strike.At least four churches have been destroyed since August, the group said."We are deeply concerned for the welfare and lives of the people of South Kordofan and we condemn the bombing of churches and Christian facilities," added Graham, son of the famed Rev. Billy Graham.More than 78,000 people have fled South Kordofan and Blue Nile states since August of last year after an armed rebellion took root, the United Nations reported.The Sudanese government is thought to have responded to the rebellion by conducting sustained air raids with the use of Russian-made Antonov bombers, which have raised concerns over civilian casualties.Decades of civil war between the north and south, costing as many as 2 million lives, formally ended with a U.S.-brokered peace treaty in 2005.
summary_1: A Christian evangelical organization reports that a Bible school supported by Franklin Graham was ruined in a recent bombing in South Kordofan, Sudan. The attack occurred on the first day of classes at Heiban Bible College, resulting in damage to college structures and setting off grass fires. Despite this, there were fortunately no reported injuries. According to Samaritan's Purse, Graham's Christian aid group, Sudan's air force is responsible for the incident. This event marks the fourth church destruction since August, raising concerns about religious freedom and civilian safety. Since last August, more than 78,000 individuals have left their homes in South Kordofan and Blue Nile states due to ongoing violence. Decades of conflict between the north and south resulted in approximately 2 million fatalities before reaching a U.S.-mediated peace agreement in 2005. Graham has urged the global community to neutralize Sudan's aircraft capabilities and enforce a no-fly zone in response to these attacks.
summary_2: Franklin Graham's Bible school in Sudan was bombed, causing damage but no injuries. The Sudanese air force is suspected. It's the fourth such incident since August, sparking worries about religious freedom and safety. Over 78,000 people have fled their homes due to ongoing violence. Graham's Christian aid group, Samaritan's Purse, reported the incident. Graham calls for disabling Sudan's aircraft capabilities and imposing a no-fly zone.
summary_3: Bible school run by Franklin Graham in Sudan bombed for fourth time, prompting concerns over religious freedom and displacement of thousands; Graham urges disabling Sudan's aircraft capabilities.

text: Billy and Sally are brother and sister.Billy is seven and Sally is eight.Their mother, Deborah, likes to have Billy and Sally dress up in costumes and play a game where they are answering the telephone.Usually when they play the game, Billy answers the telephone in a loud voice, and Sally answers the telephone in a quiet voice.On Tuesdays, Billy answers in a quiet voice, and Sally answers in a loud voice.On Fridays, Billy answers in a loud voice and Sally in a quiet voice.Billy has blonde hair.Sally has brown hair.Deborah has blonde hair, and Billy and Sally's father, Bob, has brown hair.He tells them to eat lettuce every time that he sees them, so that they grow big and strong like he is.Deborah likes to add some sugar with the lettuce so that Billy and Sally know what it is like to have sweet tastes in their life.One day, a Wednesday, Billy throws some lettuce into Sally's hair.Deborah laughs an grabs some straw from their farm and puts it in Billy's hair.Billy and Sally live on a farm.They have a goat, named Joey, and a duck, named Quack.They sometimes play a game with the goat where they chase him around the farm.Other times, they play a game with Quack where they wave at Quack and laugh.They have a fun life growing up on the farm.
summary_1: Billy and Sally are siblings, aged seven and eight respectively. Their mother, Deborah, enjoys dressing them up and having them role-play answering phone calls. The children take turns answering loudly or softly depending on the day - Billy speaks quietly on Tuesdays and loudly on other days, while Sally does the opposite. Their parents have contrasting hair colors; Deborah has blonde hair, and Bob, their father, has brown hair, a trait shared by Sally. Bob encourages his children to consume lettuce for growth, and Deborah occasionally adds sugar to make it more appealing. A humorous incident occurred one Wednesday when Billy tossed lettuce into Sally's hair, prompting Deborah to retaliate by placing straw in Billy's hair. The family resides on a farm, tending to a goat named Joey and a duck called Quack. They engage in various activities with these animals, such as chasing Joey and waving at Quack. Their upbringing on the farm is filled with joy and laughter.
summary_2: Siblings Billy and Sally, aged seven and eight, live on a farm with parents Deborah (blonde) and Bob (brunette). Role-playing phone call scenarios is part of their routine, with volume preferences alternating daily. Parents encourage vegetable intake, adding sweeteners to enhance taste. One amusing episode involved salad tossing and subsequent pranks. Farm life includes caring for a goat named Joey and a duck known as Quack, resulting in delightful experiences.
summary_3: Billy and Sally, aged seven and eight, enjoy role-playing phone calls and helping with chores on their family farm, where they care for a goat named Joey and a duck called Quack, while their blonde mother Deborah and brunette father Bob encourage healthy eating habits by adding sweeteners to vegetables.

text: And William Martinez, 28, who cut his medical school studies short because he couldn't afford the $39,000 in loans after two years of graduate school and four years of college.Martinez works two jobs as a physician's assistant and supports his elderly parents and 8-year-old son.Uncommon Good has a 22-member board of doctors, lawyers and representatives of Christian groups and is recruiting mentors.One goal is to get the state Legislature to pass a law to provide loan forgiveness to medical professionals and lawyers who work with the poor.Mintie said she hopes her organization can be a national model for other professions.She is trying to bring legal aid services to the Inland Valley -- the closest legal aid office is in El Monte and represents 700,000 poor people throughout the San Fernando, San Gabriel and Inland valleys."Unless the legal aid is in the community, you can't say you are serving the poor," Mintie said.Neal Dudovitz is the executive director of Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County, the legal aid office in El Monte.He sees attorneys new to poverty law leave all the time because they can't afford the salary with their law school debt."She's really opened a lot of eyes in terms of having people understand how the educational debt is limiting and reducing the services that are available to low-income communities," Dudovitz said."Nancy is light years ahead of the curve on this stuff.Very little is being done practically to solve it."Mintie, her colleagues say, could have made a lot of money in private practice."She's very kind and pleasant," said Julius Thompson, 45, an attorney at Inner City Law Center and an Uncommon Good recipient."But she's also a woman on a mission.When she sets her sights on something, she's a formidable force."
summary_1: William Martinez had to abandon his medical education due to financial constraints from accrued student loans. He now holds down two jobs as a physician's assistant while supporting his aged parents and young son. A nonprofit group named Uncommon Good exists, comprising 22 members from various backgrounds including medicine, law, and Christianity. The aim of this organization is to secure legislative approval for a bill that would absolve medical professionals and lawyers working with underprivileged individuals of their educational debts. Nancy Mintie, founder of Uncommon Good, seeks to establish localized legal aid services within the Inland Valley region, which currently lacks such facilities. The nearest legal aid center is situated in El Monte, catering to approximately 700,000 impoverished residents across the San Fernando, San Gabriel, and Inland Valleys. Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County Executive Director Neal Dudovitz acknowledges Mintie's efforts towards raising awareness about the restrictive impact of educational debt on service provision for disadvantaged communities. Despite possessing the potential to earn substantial income through private practice, Mintie remains steadfastly committed to her cause.
summary_2: Medical graduate William Martinez left school due to loan issues, now works two jobs, supports family, and has educational debt. Nonprofit "Uncommon Good" aims to pass a bill forgiving educational debt for public interest workers. Founder Nancy Mintie wants localized legal aid in Inland Valley, where the closest facility is in El Monte, serving hundreds of thousands of poor people. Mintie's commitment to helping underserved areas remains strong despite potential high earnings elsewhere.
summary_3: Medical graduate William Martinez works two jobs to support his family and pay off educational debt, while Nancy Mintie of Uncommon Good advocates for a bill to forgive such debts, particularly aiming to provide localized legal aid in Inland Valley.

text: The documentary portrays a behind-the-scenes look at the poor state of Argentina's civil aviation , and puts the blame on the Argentine Air Force .The Air Force has been in control of air traffic operations since the military takeover of General Juan Carlos Ongan a in 1966 .The producer/director , Enrique Pi eyro , claims Argentina and Nigeria are the only countries whose air force controls and regulates the airline industry .Pi eyro , a former Argentine airline pilot , makes his case in the documentary using diagrams , 3D animations , interviews , hidden cameras in the control tower , and a few props .For example , at one point he spills out a bag of plastic airplanes and equates it to the number of planes the air force has lost due to negligence .The film is heavily based on the Austral L neas A reas Flight 2553 plane crash .Enrique Pi eyro takes his camera , secretly , into the control tower of the Ministro Pistarini International Airport also-known-as Ezeiza , the international airport at Buenos Aires .
summary_1: "Argentina's civil aviation conditions are critically examined in a documentary that attributes the issues to the Argentine Air Force. The Air Force has overseen air traffic operations since General Juan Carlos Onganía's military takeover in 1966, making Argentina one of two nations, alongside Nigeria, where the air force governs the aviation industry. Documentary maker Enrique Pi eyro, a former airline pilot from Argentina, presents his argument through diagrams, 3D animations, interviews, covert footage from the control tower, and visual aids like a bag of model airplanes representing aircraft losses caused by neglect. The documentary primarily focuses on the Austral Líneas Aéreas Flight 2553 accident. Pi eyro films surreptitiously inside the Ministro Pistarini International Airport (Ezeiza) control tower, Buenos Aires' international hub."
summary_2: A revealing documentary scrutinizes Argentina's aviation problems, blaming the Air Force for poor conditions. Since the 1966 military coup, Argentina is one of two countries where the air force controls aviation, the other being Nigeria. Ex-pilot Enrique Pi eyro's film explores these concerns using graphics, animations, interviews, hidden airport tower footage, and visual props, focusing on Austral Líneas Aéreas Flight 2553 crash.
summary_3: The documentary "Argentina's Aviation Crisis" by ex-pilot Enrique Pi eyro criticizes Argentina's air force for poor aviation conditions, highlighted by the Austral Líneas Aéreas Flight 2553 crash.

text: It is almost summer time.Spring has been very long and very rainy.Winter was very warm and very long.In the winter the snows falls on the ground.It covers all the grass.It covers all the trees.It covers all the flowers.In the winter, the chipmunk goes to sleep.The chipmunk works all summer long to gather enough food for the winter.The chipmunk gathers berries.The chipmunk gathers pine cones.The chipmunk drops the pine cones off our roof and rolls them to her favorite hiding place.Boom!Boom!Boom!The pine cones sound so loud when they drop off the roof!The snow melts away in the spring.It is off the ground in our yard by the month of May.In June, there is still snow on the mountains.The snow on the mountains is still there until July.In May the grass starts to grow.In June, the flowers bloom again.In July, we go swimming in the lake.We get to play all summer.We do not have to go to school.We do not have to gather pine cones for food.We get to play outside and we get to have cook outs.We are not chipmunks.We are children.Our mom makes us lemonade in the summer time.Our mom takes us to the beach.Our mom lets us have a lot of campfires.Our mom mows the lawn.It is summer time and now we play for 90 days and the chipmunk works for 90 days.In the winter we work and go to school and the chipmunk gets to sleep.I am glad it is summer and I am glad that I am a human child and not a chipmunk.I am glad that we get to be awake through all the seasons.I like spring.I like fall.I like winter.My favorite time of all is, for sure, summer!
summary_1: Summer approaches after an extended wet spring, which followed an unusually mild and lengthy winter. Winter brought heavy snowfall, blanketing the landscape—grass, trees, and flowers alike. During this season, chipmunks retreat into hibernation, having spent the previous months gathering food supplies such as berries and pinecones, the latter often dropped from rooftops to hidden caches. As spring unfolds, snow recedes from the yard typically by May, although mountainous areas retain their snow cover until July. Summer triggers growth spurts in grass and blossoms, permitting outdoor activities like swimming in lakes and enjoying barbecues. Unlike chipmunks who labor throughout these warmer months storing sustenance, humans revel in leisure pastimes, indulging in homemade lemonades, trips to the beach, and frequent campfires. Parents undertake chores like mowing lawns while kids enjoy three uninterrupted months free from academic responsibilities. The cycle concludes with autumn and returns to winter, marking a stark contrast between species—one working tirelessly to endure the cold, the other embracing each new season with joyful anticipation.
summary_2: After a harsh winter, spring arrives, leading to summer. Heavy snowfall marked winter, causing animals like chipmunks to hibernate. Spring sees melting snow, replaced by growing plants and blooming flowers. Humans engage in leisurely pursuits during summer, unlike chipmunks that continue preparing for winter. Autumn follows, heralding another winter. Two different responses to changing seasons emerge - one of survival, the other of celebration.
summary_3: Different seasonal responses appear among species, with humans celebrating summer while animals prepare for winter.

text: One evening , Felix serves as a conductor to four singing cats .Meanwhile at a house only a few yards away , a hefty man is napping on a chair but gets awakened by their act .To silence them , the man grabs and rolls out bowling ball , knocking Felix and the other cats off their feet .Felix , however , still insist to go on performing as he plays a flute and his friends dance .Awakened once more , the man takes out an ether sprayer and showers its contents onto the cats .While his friends fall into a snooze , Felix decides to have his sleep at home .Felix enters his apartment , and lies on the sofa .But before he can rest long enough , his dwarf master calls him over .Felix comes in and hears about the dwarf's complaint about an insomnia problem .To assist his master , the cat offers a glass of warm milk but to no effect .The dwarf is still unable to sleep , and therefore craves for some entertainment instead .Felix then plays a clarinet , and the toy soldiers start dancing to his music .After moving around for a few moments , one of the little soldiers fires a small cannon , piercing a picture on a wall with its projectile .The dwarf was amazed by the presentation , and asks Felix to handover the cannon .When Felix gives it and suddenly turns around , the hostile dwarf aims the small weapon at him and fires .Felix was struck at the back and frightenedly flees the apartment .Out in the streets , Felix looks for suitable resting places .He then climbs up a telephone pole , and lies down on a set of pants hanging on one of the lines .
summary_1: Felix, a cat, conducts a musical performance with four feline companions, much to the dismay of a nearby resident who becomes annoyed and attempts to stop them. Initially, the man uses a bowling ball to disrupt the performance, causing Felix and the others to stumble. Undeterred, Felix continues playing a flute while his fellow performers dance. The man responds by using an ether sprayer, which puts the animals to sleep except for Felix, who retreats to his apartment. Upon arriving home, Felix finds that his dwarf master is experiencing insomnia. In an attempt to help, Felix provides warm milk, but this doesn't alleviate the issue. Seeking alternative relief, the dwarf requests entertainment from Felix, who performs on a clarinet. As the toy soldiers begin to dance, one accidentally shoots a small cannonball through a painting. Amazed, the dwarf demands the cannon, only to aim and fire it at Felix, striking him and prompting the cat to run from the apartment in fear. Outdoors, Felix searches for a safe place to rest and eventually settles on lying down on a pair of trousers hung between two telephone wires.
summary_2: Felix, a performing cat, faces opposition from a grumpy neighbor who tries to halt his concert with a bowling ball and ether sprayer, putting the other cats to sleep. Returning home, Felix cheers up his sleepless dwarf master with music until a rogue cannonball shot sends him fleeing onto hanging trousers.
summary_3: Despite interference from an ill-tempered neighbor armed with a bowling ball and ether, Felix serenades his dwarf master awake, but must seek refuge on laundry after a cannonball disrupts his performance.

text: Ace , a wannabe rock star , is on his way to a concert of the band Guitar Wolf when space aliens invade the Earth . As a result the dead rise to their feet in the countryside setting of Asahi , Japan , with an appetite for flesh . Enlisting the help of his rock 'n roll blood brother Guitar Wolf , Ace and the members of the band get entangled in many misadventures with crazy rock managers in very tight shorts , transsexuals , naked women shooting guns in the shower , and bloodthirsty zombies ready to tear them apart . Leather jackets , loud over-modulated music , laser guitar picks , motorcycles , guns , muscle cars , and fire abound . Guitar Wolf , a Japanese trio signed to Matador Records in the US and self-proclaimed coolest rock band in the world star as the well-coiffed heroes . It is also a love story , between Ace and Tobio , a trans woman . The music , in a garage punk vein , plays an important role in the film . It features music from Greg Cartwright of Reigning Sound and The Oblivians . His 1997 song `` Twice as Deep '' by Greg Oblivian & the Tip Tops is featured . This film is similar to another movie by a Spanish punk group , La matanza can bal de los garrulos lis rgicos produced by Siniestro Total
summary_1: "Guitar Wolf, a Japanese trio known for being cool and sporting leather jackets, find themselves at the center of an alien invasion in rural Japan. Amidst the chaos, they encounter various eccentric characters such as flamboyant rock managers in skintight shorts, gun-toting women in showers, and trans individuals including Tobio, who becomes intertwined in a romantic narrative with protagonist Ace, an aspiring musician. Zombies roam freely, adding to the danger and excitement. Musical elements play a significant role throughout the film, featuring songs like "Twice as Deep" by Greg Oblivian & the Tip Tops. The overall atmosphere is filled with adrenaline-pumping action sequences, intense music, and dark humor."
summary_2: Japanese band Guitar Wolf confront aliens in their native countryside, meeting quirky figures like shower-dwelling weapon-wielding ladies and romancing musicians. Zombie attacks spur on thrilling scenes while musical numbers enhance the wild ride, exemplified by tracks like "Twice As Deep". Dark comedy permeates this energetic tale.
summary_3: In Japan, Guitar Wolf battles aliens with eccentric allies amidst zombies, set to raucous tunes, underscored by dark humor.

text: Tommy and Suzy (brother and sister) went to the playground one afternoon with their mom and dad, Jan and Dean.They were playing a game of tag and having the best time ever running after each other and laughing.They liked to play tag instead of building sandcastles or swinging.They liked tag because they liked to run.They like to play hopscotch or jump rope but that day they wanted to play tag.Other games aren't as fun.They met Tony and Ally (who are best friends) and invited them to play tag too.Tony and Ally like to play other games like hopscotch or jump rope but that day they joined the game of tag.Making new friends is important.Tony and Ally would rather make friends than play their favorite games.
summary_1: Siblings Tommy and Suzy, accompanied by parents Jan and Dean, spent an enjoyable afternoon at the park playing tag. The brother and sister duo preferred tag over activities such as constructing sandcastles or swinging due to their love for running. They also expressed disinterest towards hopscotch and jump rope on this particular day. During their game, they encountered fellow youngsters Tony and Ally, who happened to be best friends. Invited to join the tag match, Tony and Ally agreed despite preferring alternative pastimes like hopscotch and jump rope. This interaction emphasized the importance of forming friendships over engaging solely in favored pursuits.
summary_2: Tommy and Suzy, along with parents Jan and Dean, enjoyed a family day at the park playing tag. Meeting Tony and Ally, they invited them to play despite differing preferences. This gathering highlighted the value of friendship over individual interests.
summary_3: The families of Tommy, Suzy, Jan, Dean, Tony, and Ally prioritized friendship by uniting for a fun game of tag at the park, disregarding personal preferences.
