Despite extending services and increasing the budget, tensions rose among personnel, resulting in animosity and unclear objectives. This led to lawsuits and lingering bitterness. An observer noted that personal conflicts negatively impacted the process. While both mergers aimed to improve access to legal assistance for low-income communities, their approaches yielded vastly different outcomes.
summary_2: Iwasaki smoothly merged Long Beach's program, maintaining jobs and services, thanks to his thoughtful method and political support. Conversely, Dudovitz encountered issues integrating the San Gabriel-Pomona Valleys area, leading to strife, lawsuits, and resentment despite extended services and increased funding. Both sought to enhance legal aid access, but results varied greatly due to differing strategies.
summary_3: Iwasaki successfully integrated Long Beach with minimal disruption, while Dudovitz faced challenges merging the San Gabriel-Pomona Valleys, resulting in conflict and varying outcomes for both.

text: The letterhead on correspondence still bears the Bexar County Legal Aid name, even though the organization is no longer.Texas Rural Legal Aid - known for its fearless and sometimes controversial advocacy of the poorest of the poor - last week took over four other corporations serving the legal needs of the indigent in Southwest Texas, including the one in Bexar County.The new 68-county legal aid organization has yet to be named and stretches from El Paso to Corpus Christi, Harlingen to Austin.The leader for the super-sized law firm has big plans."I'm more interested in looking at what we as advocates can do to address the serious problems of poverty than the number of cases we close," said David Hall, the TRLA executive director.In the Rio Grande Valley, Hall's attorneys set up separate groups to assist small-business owners and residents with low-interest loans and legal representation.They also operate a legal arm that assists migrant workers from Texas to Kentucky.Now, Hall said, he wants to make services to the poor more efficient by working with law students who will handle less complicated legal matters, allowing licensed attorneys to take more "high impact" cases to court."What we need to do is handle cases as efficiently as we can, leveraging the amount of time of the lawyer that goes in there and maximizing the number of people that they can help at one time," Hall said.His plan is to place the 110 attorneys on staff in teams working on specialized legal issues.He wants to expand the law clinic it already has with St. Mary's University Law School to involve students at the University of Texas Law School.The law students at St. Mary's interview potential clients, assist them with filling out legal documents and answer the telephones for the legal hotline, freeing up TRLA lawyers to handle the complicated cases, Hall said.By the end of September, Hall said all the attorneys working with the poor in the 68county area will be placed on the same computer network so they can pass cases to the best available attorneys.Last year, board members on the former Legal Aid of Central Texas and Bexar County Legal Aid resisted the merger, saying that the mergers were done illegally and without the input of board members.They also argued that Hall's litigious style hampered their ability to garner funds from Congress.TRLA generated controversy in 1996, when its attorneys challenged the rights of 800 military personnel to vote in Val Verde County elections by absentee ballot after a former Ku Klux Klan member won a county commissioner post.Brendan Gill, the former executive director of the Bexar County group, said he has since come to see the merger as a positive move for South Texas."I always knew there were good points to merging, just as I knew that there were bad points," Gill said.
summary_1:
Texas Rural Legal Aid (TRLA), recognized for its bold advocacy for impoverished individuals, recently amalgamated four organizations in Southwest Texas, including Bexar County Legal Aid. The newly formed entity, yet to be officially named, spans 68 counties from El Paso to Corpus Christi, Harlingen to Austin. 

David Hall, TRLA's executive director, aims to enhance efficiency in serving the underprivileged, focusing on problem resolution rather than case numbers. In the Rio Grande Valley, TRLA has established units supporting small business owners and residents with low-interest loans and legal assistance. They also provide aid to migrant workers across Texas and Kentucky.

Hall intends to improve service efficiency by having law students manage less complex legal matters, enabling licensed attorneys to tackle high-impact cases. His vision includes organizing the 110 attorneys into specialized teams addressing specific legal issues. He also plans to collaborate with the University of Texas Law School, similar to the existing partnership with St. Mary's University Law School. Here, law students conduct client interviews, assist with paperwork, and manage the legal hotline, thereby liberating TRLA lawyers to focus on intricate cases.

By the end of September, all attorneys serving the underprivileged in the 68-county region will share a unified computer network, facilitating the transfer of cases to the most suitable attorneys. Despite past resistance to the merger from certain board members due to alleged illegal procedures and funding concerns, Brendan Gill, ex-executive director of Bexar County group, now views the merger positively. However, TRLA faced criticism in 1996 when its attorneys contested the voting rights of 800 military personnel in Val Verde County elections, following a former Ku Klux Klan member's election as county commissioner.
summary_2: Texas Rural Legal Aid (TRLA) combines forces with three other groups in Southwest Texas, creating a larger organization covering 68 counties. This new entity, led by Executive Director David Hall, seeks to boost efficiency in helping disadvantaged people through effective issue resolution instead of just increasing case numbers. Plans include law students handling simpler tasks while experienced attorneys take critical cases. Specialized teams will address particular legal problems, and collaboration with universities will free up TRLA lawyers for complex cases. By late September, a shared computer system will connect all attorneys serving the expanded area. Past controversies involved allegations of improper merger methods and backlash over contesting military voters' rights in an election.
summary_3: TRLA partners with three organizations to form a bigger group spanning 68 Texas counties, aiming to enhance efficiency in assisting marginalized individuals via strategic case management, specialized teams, and academic collaborations, set to implement a unified IT system by late September, despite past disputes over merging tactics and voting rights issues.

text: IBM opened a sprawling and sophisticated semiconductor factory here on Wednesday that cost more than $2.5 billion to build and equip, the largest single capital investment the company has ever made.The factory, which opens as the computer chip business is in a slump, is a costly and risky move for IBM.But it is also an expression of confidence by the company that it can remain a technology leader in the highly competitive global semiconductor industry, and a commitment that the best place to execute that strategy is in upstate New York.IBM is an exception among computer makers in that it still invests heavily in research to advance the design, manufacture and materials used in semiconductor chips.It is spending more than $500 million a year on semiconductor research and development.The factory will produce a wide range of specialized semiconductors used in everything from the largest mainframe computers to cell phones and video-game consoles.The new plant is part of IBM's push to gain a strong lead in chip-making beyond the personal computer business, where Intel and East Asian chip producers hold the advantage."The core of our strategy is to lead in technology and attack the high-performance segments of the market," said John Kelly, senior vice president in charge of IBM's technology group.An advantage to having the semiconductor fabricating factory here, Kelly explained, was that it was very close to its research laboratories in nearby Westchester County, N.Y. To stay ahead in advanced chip technology, he said, moving innovations out of the labs and into the factory as fast as possible is crucial."What we call the lab-to-fab time should be as close to zero as possible," Kelly said."If our strategy were anything but to be on the leading edge, we'd have put the plant in Asia."The new factory, which will begin normal production early next year, will employ about 1,000 people.
summary_1: IBM recently established a state-of-the-art semiconductor factory, representing a $2.5 billion investment, marking their most substantial single capital expenditure. Despite the current downturn in the chip industry, this venture signifies IBM's faith in its capacity to maintain technological leadership and presence in the worldwide semiconductor sector. Distinctive amongst computer manufacturers, IBM continues to heavily fund research aimed at advancing semiconductor chip design, manufacturing processes, and materials. Annually, they allocate over $500 million towards semiconductor research and development. The facility will generate a diverse assortment of specialized semiconductors utilized in various products ranging from large mainframe computers to mobile devices and gaming consoles. This initiative forms part of IBM's endeavor to secure dominance in chip-manufacturing beyond the personal computer domain, where Intel and Eastern Asian chip producers dominate. According to John Kelly, Senior Vice President of IBM's technology division, proximity between the new plant and nearby research facilities in Westchester County, NY, accelerates innovation transfer from laboratory to factory, enabling IBM to sustain a competitive edge. Once operational in early 2023, the plant will provide employment for approximately 1,000 individuals.
summary_2: IBM has invested $2.5 billion in a cutting-edge semiconductor factory, their largest single capital expense. This move, despite the chip industry slump, shows IBM's confidence in maintaining global semiconductor leadership. IBM annually invests over $500 million in related research, producing a variety of chips used in everything from mainframes to mobiles. Set to open in 2023, the factory aims to create advanced chips, securing IBM's influence in sectors outside personal computing. It also promises jobs for around 1,000 people and faster tech transfer due to its location near research facilities.
summary_3: IBM invests $2.5B in new semiconductor factory, demonstrating commitment to global chip leadership and job creation.

text: Temperate climates have moderate temperatures.These climates vary in how much rain they get and when the rain falls.You can see different types of temperate climates in Figure 2.40.Mediterranean climates are found on the western coasts of continents.The coast of California has a Mediterranean climate.Temperatures are mild and rainfall is moderate.Most of the rain falls in the winter, and summers are dry.To make it through the dry summers, short woody plants are common.Marine west coast climates are also found on the western coasts of continents.The coast of Washington State has this type of climate.Temperatures are mild and theres plenty of rainfall all year round.Dense fir forests grow in this climate.Humid subtropical climates are found on the eastern sides of continents.The southeastern U.S. has this type of climate.Summers are hot and humid, but winters are chilly.There is moderate rainfall throughout the year.Pine and oak forests grow in this climate.
summary_1: Temperate climates are characterized by moderate temperatures, with variations in precipitation and seasonal distribution. Four distinct temperate climate categories exist, each differing geographically and meteorologically. Mediterranean climates occur along western coastal regions, such as California, featuring mild temperatures and moderate rainfall, primarily during winter months, fostering growth of drought-tolerant vegetation. Marine west coast climates, like those in Washington State, exhibit similar temperature moderation yet maintain consistent rainfall year-round, promoting dense forestation of coniferous trees. Humid subtropical climates, found in the southeastern United States, experience warm, moist summers and cooler winters, accompanied by evenly distributed annual precipitation, enabling pine and oak ecosystems to thrive.
summary_2: Temperate climates have four types based on location and weather patterns. Mediterranean climates, like California, have mild temps and most rain in winter, favoring drought-resistant plants. Marine west coast climates, e.g., Washington State, keep moderate temps but get steady rain all year, nurturing conifers. Southeast US has humid subtropical climates with warm, wet summers; cool winters; and balanced annual rain, allowing pines and oaks to flourish.
summary_3: Different temperate climates exist based on location, each having distinct temperature and precipitation patterns that support specific plant growth.

text: (Financial Times) -- The increasing amount of personal information that can been gleaned by computer programs that track how people use Facebook has been revealed by an extensive academic study.Such programmes can discern undisclosed private information such as Facebook users' sexuality, drug-use habits and even whether their parents separated when they were young, according to the study by Cambridge university academics.In one of the biggest studies of its kind, scientists from the university's psychometrics team and a Microsoft-funded research centre analysed data from 58,000 Facebook users to predict traits and other information that were not provided in their profiles.The algorithms were 88 per cent accurate in predicting male sexual orientation, 95 per cent for race and 80 per cent for religion and political leanings.Personality types and emotional stability were also predicted with accuracy ranging from 62-75 per cent.Facebook declined to comment.The study highlights growing concerns about social networks and how data trails can be mined for sensitive information, even when people attempt to keep information about themselves private.Less than 5 per cent of users predicted to be gay, for example, were connected with explicitly gay groups.Michal Kosinksi, one of the report's authors, told the Financial Times that the university's techniques could easily be replicated by companies to infer personal attributes a person did not wish to share, such as sexual orientation or political views: "We used very simple and generic methods.Marketing companies and internet companies could spend much more time and resources, and hence get much higher accuracy than we did."Last week , the EU agreed to water down proposals for a radical overhaul of data privacy regulation.The move reflects governments' reluctance to impede internet businesses that might spur economic growth, and follows fierce lobbying from technology companies including Facebook and Google.Personal data has become big business.Wonga, the UK online lender, makes credit judgments within seconds based on thousands of pieces of information, including an applicant's Facebook profile.Tesco, the supermarket chain, this month started to use its customers' shopping histories to sell targeted online advertising.The report also revealed some unexpected correlations -- such as people who liked 'curly fries' having higher IQs, while those who like Facebook's "Sliding on Floors With Your Socks On" page were unlikely to use drugs.
summary_1: A study conducted by Cambridge University researchers, in conjunction with a Microsoft-funded research center, analyzed data from 58,000 Facebook users. The aim was to predict various aspects and traits of these users, even if the information wasn't disclosed in their profiles. The results showed that the algorithms were 88% accurate in predicting male sexual orientation, 95% for race, and 80% for religion and political leanings. Personality types and emotional stability were accurately predicted within a range of 62-75%. Despite attempts to maintain privacy, less than 5% of users predicted to be gay were associated with explicitly gay groups. This study underscores rising concerns about social networks and the mining of sensitive information through data trails. Researchers emphasized that similar techniques could be easily replicated by corporations to infer personal details individuals may not wish to share, such as sexual orientation or political views. The European Union recently softened proposed updates to data privacy regulations due to government hesitancy towards stifling potential internet-based economic growth and pressure from tech giants like Facebook and Google. Personal data usage is becoming increasingly prevalent; Wonga, a UK online lender, determines creditworthiness using thousands of data points, including an individual's Facebook profile. Tesco now uses customer purchasing patterns to deliver tailored online advertisements. Interestingly, the study found unusual correlations - for instance, individuals who preferred curly fries tended to have higher IQ scores, whereas fans of Facebook's "Sliding on Floors With Your Socks On" page were statistically less likely to engage in drug use.
summary_2: Cambridge/Microsoft researchers used Facebook data from 58k users to predict personality traits, achieving 88% accuracy for male sexuality, 95% for race, and 80% for religion/political views. They also determined personality types (62-75%) and emotional stability. Privacy efforts failed, as under 5% of those identified as gay joined related groups. Tech companies might exploit this method to access private info, like sexuality or politics. A UK lender already assesses creditworthiness via Facebook data, while supermarkets analyze consumer habits for targeted ads. Surprising links emerged, e.g., high IQ linked to preference for curly fries, low drug use tied to liking "Sliding on Floors With Your Socks On". EU relaxed data privacy rules despite growing concerns over misuse.
summary_3: Researchers accurately predicted sensitive personal details using Facebook data, including sexuality, ethnicity, beliefs, and emotions, with varying success rates; tech firms could potentially abuse this technique for unauthorized data collection.

text: If you have a mass of 50 kg on Earth, what is your weight in newtons?An object with more mass is pulled by gravity with greater force.Mass and weight are closely related.However, the weight of an object can change if the force of gravity changes.On Earth, the force of gravity is the same everywhere.So how does the force of gravity change?It doesnt if you stay on Earth.What if we travel to another planet or moon in our solar system?Look at the photo of astronaut Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. taken by fellow astronaut Neil Armstrong in the Figure.They were the first humans to walk on the moon.An astronaut weighs less on the moon than he would on Earth.This is because the moons gravity is weaker than Earths.The astronauts mass, on the other hand, did not change.He still contained the same amount of matter on the moon as he did on Earth.If the astronaut weighed 175 pounds on Earth, he would have weighed only 29 pounds on the moon.If his mass on Earth was 80 kg, what would his mass have been on the moon?[Figure 3]
summary_1: Weight is determined by the gravitational pull of an object, while mass remains constant regardless of location. On Earth, gravity pulls objects with a consistent force, causing them to have weight. However, this force varies depending on the celestial body. For instance, Earth's gravity is stronger than that of the Moon. Therefore, an object's weight differs based on where it is. To illustrate, an astronaut weighing 175 lbs (approximately 78.47 kg) on Earth would weigh about 29 lbs (around 13.15 kg) on the Moon due to its weaker gravitational pull. Despite the difference in weight, the astronaut's mass—the quantity of matter in an object—remains unchanged at 80 kg both on Earth and the Moon. In conclusion, an object's mass stays constant despite varying weights caused by different gravitational forces across various celestial bodies.
summary_2: Mass, the amount of matter in an object, is constant regardless of location. Weight, influenced by gravity, changes based on celestial bodies. An object's weight varies - for example, an astronaut weighing 175 lbs on Earth becomes 29 lbs on the Moon due to weaker gravity, although their mass remains constant at 80 kg. Thus, mass stays constant despite changing weights from diverse gravitational forces.
summary_3: Although weight fluctuates with varying gravitational forces, an object's mass remains constant regardless of location.

text: In chapters 3 and 4 we described how the U.S. government adjusted its existing agencies and capacities to address the emerging threat from Usama  Bin Laden and his associates.After the August 1998 bombings of the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, President Bill Clinton and his chief aides explored ways of getting  Bin Laden expelled from Afghanistan or possibly capturing or even killing him.Although disruption efforts around the world had achieved some successes, the core of  Bin Laden's organization remained intact.President Clinton was deeply concerned about  Bin Laden.He and his national security advisor, Samuel "Sandy" Berger, ensured they had a special daily pipeline of reports feeding them the latest updates on  Bin Laden's reported location.In public, President Clinton spoke repeatedly about the threat of terrorism, referring to terrorist training camps but saying little about  Bin Laden and nothing about al Qaeda.He explained to us that this was deliberate-intended to avoid enhancing  Bin Laden's stature by giving him unnecessary publicity.His speeches focused especially on the danger of nonstate actors and of chemical and biological weapons.As the millennium approached, the most publicized worries were not about terrorism but about computer breakdowns-the Y2K scare.Some government officials were concerned that terrorists would take advantage of such breakdowns.On November 30, 1999, Jordanian intelligence intercepted a telephone call between Abu Zubaydah, a longtime ally of  Bin Laden, and Khadr Abu Hoshar, a Palestinian extremist.Abu Zubaydah said, "The time for training is over."Suspecting that this was a signal for Abu Hoshar to commence a terrorist operation, Jordanian police arrested Abu Hoshar and 15 others and informed Washington.One of the 16, Raed Hijazi, had been born in California to Palestinian parents; after spending his childhood in the Middle East, he had returned to northern California, taken refuge in extremist Islamist beliefs, and then made his way to Abu Zubaydah's Khaldan camp in Afghanistan, where he learned the fundamentals of guerrilla warfare.He and his younger brother had been recruited by Abu Hoshar into a loosely knit plot to attack Jewish and American targets in Jordan.After late 1996, when Abu Hoshar was arrested and jailed, Hijazi moved back to the United States, worked as a cabdriver in Boston, and sent money back to his fellow plotters.After Abu Hoshar's release, Hijazi shuttled between Boston and Jordan gathering money and supplies.With Abu Hoshar, he recruited inTurkey and Syria as well as Jordan; with Abu Zubaydah's assistance, Abu Hoshar sent these recruits to Afghanistan for training.
summary_1: Post-August 1998 embassy bombings, President Bill Clinton and his administration sought to tackle the growing threat of Usama Bin Laden and his associates. Concerns were raised about Bin Laden's operations in Afghanistan, leading to discussions on extradition, capture, or elimination. Daily briefings on Bin Laden's whereabouts were provided to the president and his team. Public statements regarding the threats posed by terrorism increased, focusing on non-state actors and unconventional weaponry. As the new millennium approached, concerns shifted towards potential computer failures (Y2K) and their possible exploitation by terrorists. In November 1999, Jordanian intelligence intercepted communications suggesting an imminent terrorist operation. The chatter pointed to a group led by Abu Zubaydah, who had links to Bin Laden. A cell member, Raed Hijazi, originally from California, joined the network after being exposed to extremist ideologies during his stay at an Afghan training camp. Following arrests in Jordan, it was discovered that Hijazi had traveled between the US and Jordan, raising funds and procuring materials for attacks against Jewish and American interests.
summary_2: After August '98 embassy bombings, President Clinton focused on Usama Bin Laden. Concerns grew over Bin Laden's activities in Afghanistan, leading to discussions on capturing or eliminating him. Daily updates on Bin Laden's location were given to the President. Statements about dangers of terrorism increased, emphasizing non-state actors and unconventional weapons. As the new millennium neared, worries about Y2K and its use by terrorists emerged. In Nov '99, Jordanian intel intercepted comms indicating an upcoming attack. The plot involved Abu Zubaydah, linked to Bin Laden, and Raed Hijazi, a Californian exposed to extremist views in Afghanistan. After raids in Jordan, it was found that Hijazi moved between the US and Jordan, raising funds and obtaining supplies for assaults on Jewish and American targets.
summary_3: Following the '98 embassy bombings, daily tracking of Usama Bin Laden intensified due to his suspected involvement in planning attacks with Abu Zubaydah and Raed Hijazi, who had ties to extremist groups in Afghanistan and California, prompting concerns over potential terrorist threats using unconventional weapons as the year 2000 approached.

text: You may be wondering, how can a glacier get so big?Why does it move?These are both good questions.In the winter months, precipitation falls as snow.This solid form of water builds up on the ground as long as the temperatures stay cold enough.As the temperature rises, the snow starts to melt.The frozen water changes state back into a liquid state.Nearer the poles, summer does not last very long.If the summer is long enough and warm enough, all the snow may melt.This is what typically happens now.The earth was a little cooler 12,000 years ago.As a result, during the summer months, that amount of snow did not melt.It may have only been an inch or so of snow that melted.The following winter, snow fell on top of this left-over snow.This next winters snowfall had a head start.Year after year, the snow that did not melt became thicker and thicker.Inch by inch the snow started to build up.Over many years, layer upon layer of snow compacted and turned to ice.
summary_1: Glaciers grow large due to layers of unmelting snow transforming into ice over thousands of years. During colder periods, such as winter, snow accumulates; however, when warmer weather arrives, some of this snow melts into liquid water. In regions closer to the Earth's poles, summers tend to be shorter, allowing for less time to melt the built-up snow. Around 12,000 years ago, global temperatures were slightly lower than they are today. Consequently, even though some snow would still liquefy during the summer season, there wouldn't be sufficient warmth to entirely eradicate the previous winter's snowfall. As each subsequent winter arrived, new snowflakes would land on existing remnants from prior years, gradually increasing its depth. Over numerous seasons, these incremental layers of snow eventually condense under their immense weight, turning into dense ice sheets. This gradual process forms the expansive masses known as glaciers we observe today.
summary_2: Around 12,000 years ago, during cooler times, less summer heat led to insufficient melting of accumulated snow. New snow added onto old layers, compacted by weight, transformed into thick ice sheets. This formed the extensive glaciers seen today.
summary_3: About 12,000 years ago, reduced summer heat caused incomplete melting of snow, resulting in the formation of today's expansive glaciers due to new snow compressing into thick ice sheets over time.

text: Hannah Harvey was a ten year old that had many friends in school.She lived in New York and enjoyed doing gymnastics and playing soccer.One day, Hannah came home from school and her parents greeted her.She knew that something was different by the expressions on their faces.Even Jackson, Hannah's dog, was acting different.Hannah asked why everyone was being so strange.Hannah's father, who was known as Pop, explained to Hannah that his job was forcing him to move.Hannah did not seem to think this was too big of a deal.Then, Hannah's mother explained that they were moving to Kenya.Kenya, she explained, was a place in Africa and life would be very different there.As Hannah began to cry thinking about all of her friends at home, Hannah's mother calmed her with a gentle touch.Jackson began howling as Hannah cried, but was also calmed by Hannah's mother.Hannah spent the next two weeks visiting her friends and saying her goodbyes.She did not know the next time she would be home.She cried very hard when she said goodbye to her best friend, Susan.Susan did not quite understand where Kenya was, but promised to visit Hannah.The next day, Hannah boarded a plane with her family.At first, they thought that Jackson could not come with them.However, Hannah worked hard and helped make sure that he had all of his shots so that he could come.After he had them all, the airport said it was OK for Jackson to come!The Harvey family left and off they went across the ocean to begin their new life in Kenya.
summary_1: Ten-year-old Hannah Harvey, a popular student living in New York, was shocked when her parents told her they were moving to Kenya due to her father's job relocation. Initially, Hannah didn't grasp the gravity of the situation, viewing the move as an adventure. However, her understanding deepened when her mother clarified that Kenya was located in Africa, implying a significant change in lifestyle. Despite initial shock, Hannah bravely bid farewell to her friends over two weeks, promising to stay in touch despite uncertainty about future visits. She shed tears while parting with her closest companion, Susan. The following day, Hannah, along with her family and pet dog, Jackson, embarked on a journey towards their new life in Kenya after ensuring Jackson received necessary vaccinations.
summary_2: Hannah Harvey, aged ten, must leave NY for Kenya due to her dad's work. At first, she sees it as exciting, but learns Kenya is in Africa, signaling big changes. Though upset, she courageously says goodbye to pals, especially best friend Susan, before leaving with her family and dog Jackson, who had his shots.
summary_3: Ten-year-old Hannah Harvey leaves New York for Kenya due to her father's job, bravely adjusting to major changes after initially viewing the move as an adventure.

text: What if two children push a swing at the same time?Would the swing go higher?Yes, together their force would be more.It is common for forces to be combined.Most objects on Earth have at least two forces acting on them.Do you know what one of them is?Of course, that force is gravity.How many forces do you have on you right now?Gravity pulls you down toward the center of Earth.Your legs exert a downward force.They hold you up against the pull of gravity.Consider the example in Figure 1.3.A book is resting on a table.Gravity pulls the book downward.It has a force of 20 newtons.At the same time, the table pushes the book upward.Its force is also 20 newtons.The table opposes the pull of gravity.
summary_1: Two individuals pushing a swing concurrently will indeed result in a greater height due to the increased force generated by both parties. Most physical entities on Earth experience multiple forces simultaneously; an archetypal instance being gravity. The human body, specifically, is subjected to various forces, such as gravity pulling it towards the Earth's core and the counteracting force from the ground via leg muscles maintaining an upright position. To illustrate this concept, consider a book positioned on a table. Gravity exerts a downward force of twenty newtons onto the book, while the table counters with an equal force of twenty newtons, effectively neutralizing the gravitational pull.
summary_2: Two people pushing a swing together create more force, leading to higher swings. Similarly, objects like humans face multiple forces daily, for example, gravity pulling us down and our legs fighting back. An object on a table receives two forces - gravity pulling it down and the table pushing up equally, balancing out the gravity.
summary_3: Different forces acting upon an object, such as gravity and resistance, determine its motion; when balanced, there's no net motion, like an object on a table experiencing equal upward push from the surface and downward pull from gravity.

text: Boone, Ia.-Poor and elderly people may soon go without legal representation in Boone County.Boone County Legal Aid, which for 31 years has provided legal services to those who couldn't afford them, will close in February if a $10,000 grant from Prairie Meadows Racetrack and Casino is not awarded.The legal service is one of the few programs in Iowa that offers legal representation to those who qualify without turning to the state for its services."It is a very sad situation, but that's the fact," said Alan Schroeder, city attorney and supervisor of Boone County Legal Aid.For the past two years using money mostly from the city and county, Schroeder has upheld the outfit alone, taking on about 60 clients a year, and settling cases that range from domestic abuse to bankruptcy.He also has a private practice.If the legal service closes, he's unsure where his clients will go.The city of Boone gave Schroeder $6,300 in July to resolve pending cases, said Kathy Berg, Boone's finance officer.Without that, the program might already be closed."All governments are having problems with finances," Boone Mayor George Maybee said."No one else stepped in.The county didn't.The state didn't."Donovan Olson, chairman of the county Board of Supervisors, said the board quit funding the legal service in July because it felt the county didn't need it.Drake University ended its funding after the 2000 spring semester "for a variety of reasons," Suzanne Levitt, the law professor who oversaw the program, said via e-mail.Olson said Schroeder must prove Prairie Meadows is the primary money source for the board to grant the program any more money.Schroeder ran the program without the help of law students or Drake, which had provided as much as two-thirds of the money in some years.
summary_1: Boone County Legal Aid, a 31-year-old service providing free legal assistance to low-income individuals, faces closure due to lack of funds. The service, which assists approximately 60 clients annually with cases ranging from domestic abuse to bankruptcy, could shut down in February unless a $10,000 grant from Prairie Meadows Racetrack and Casino is received. The potential closing is attributed to financial strain, with the city and county being unable to fully fund the service. City Attorney Alan Schroeder, who currently manages the service, expresses uncertainty regarding where his clients would seek legal aid should the service close. The city of Boone granted $6,300 in July to settle pending cases, preventing an earlier closure. However, both the county and state have withdrawn their support. Donovan Olson, Chairman of the county Board of Supervisors, stated the board ceased funding due to belief that the service was no longer necessary. Drake University also discontinued its contribution post-2000. For the program to secure future county funding, Schroeder must demonstrate Prairie Meadows as the primary sponsor.
summary_2: Boone County Legal Aid, offering free help since 1991, may close due to insufficient funds, potentially leaving around 60 annual clients without aid. The service needs a $10,000 grant from Prairie Meadows by Feb or it will likely shut down. Financial difficulties led to reduced city and county contributions, causing uncertainty about clients' future options for legal assistance. If the grant isn't obtained, the city attorney expects challenges finding alternative resources for those needing legal aid.
summary_3: Boone County Legal Aid risks closure if it doesn't secure a $10,000 grant from Prairie Meadows by February, which could leave approximately 60 clients annually without legal aid.

text: For thousands of years, people have found fossils.The fossils caused curiosity about Earths past.How did these organisms live?What type of world did they live in?Fossils can tell us a lot about Earths history.In ancient times, fossils inspired myths and stories.These stories included tales of monsters and other incredible creatures.What type of creature do you know that could inspire such stories?Of course, dinosaur fossils were once mistaken for dragons bones.Two thousand years ago, people discovered fossils in China.At the time, they were thought to be dragon bones.We know now that these were not bones, but fossils.So what is the difference?
summary_1: Fossils have sparked human curiosity about Earth's past for millennia. They provide valuable insights into the lives of ancient organisms and the nature of their habitats. A fossil can reveal a wealth of information about a bygone era. In antiquity, fossils often fueled myths and narratives about extraordinary creatures, even being misidentified as dragon bones. For instance, two thousand years ago in China, what we now recognize as fossils were then considered dragon bones. The distinction between fossils and actual animal remains lies in their formation process. Fossils are mineralized remnants or impressions of prehistoric life, while bones are organic materials from present-day animals.
summary_2: Fossils offer crucial insights on ancient organisms and environments, though they've also ignited imaginative tales throughout history. Often mistaken for dragon bones, these mineralized leftovers differ from contemporary animal remains due to distinct formation processes.
summary_3: Fossils provide valuable information about past life and environments, but their unique formation differentiates them from modern animal remains.

text: (CNN) -- Cuba will pardon more than 2,900 prisoners, the government said Friday, though U.S. subcontractor Alan Gross is not among those who will be freed.The decision to release the prisoners follows "numerous requests" from their family members and religious institutions, and is a humanitarian gesture, said Cuban President Raul Castro.Among those who might be freed are prisoners over the age of 60, along with those who are sick, female or young with no previous criminal record.With some exceptions, prisoners convicted of spying, terrorism, murder and drug trafficking will not be released.Those who will be freed have already served a "important" part of their sentences and exhibited good behavior, according to an official statement published on the state-run website Cubadebate.The jailed American, Gross, will not be among those pardoned, the Cuban Interests Section in Washington said.Gross was jailed in December 2009, when he was working as a subcontractor on a U.S. Agency for International Development project aimed at spreading democracy.Castro has accused him of importing satellite equipment to connect dissidents to the Internet, and this year Cuba's highest court upheld the 15-year sentence imposed on Gross for committing crimes against the security of the state.He has maintained his innocence and said he was trying to help connect the Jewish community to the Internet.Castro, speaking to the National Assembly, said that 86 prisoners from 25 countries would be among those released in coming days.He cited the upcoming visit of Pope Benedict XVI as one of the motivations behind the move, which he said showed the "generosity and strength of the revolution."The pope has said he plans to visit Mexico and Cuba before Easter.
summary_1: Cuba announced it will free over 2,900 prisoners, excluding US subcontractor Alan Gross, as a humanitarian gesture. The release comes in response to numerous appeals from families and religious groups. Prisoners eligible for freedom include the elderly, ill, women, and youth without prior records. Those guilty of espionage, terrorism, murder, and drug trafficking won't be released. Freed prisoners have served significant portions of their terms and shown good conduct. Gross, detained since 2009 while working on a USAID project promoting democracy, remains incarcerated. He denies charges of endangering national security by providing satellite equipment to dissidents. His 15-year sentence was upheld this year. Castro mentioned releasing 86 foreign prisoners ahead of Pope Benedict XVI's planned visit to Cuba and Mexico around Easter.
summary_2: Cuba plans to free over 2,900 prisoners, not including American contractor Alan Gross, due to family and religious group appeals. Eligible prisoners are elderly, sick, female, young, and without prior records; those guilty of serious crimes aren't included. Gross, jailed since 2009 for supplying satellite gear to dissidents, still serves his 15-year term after denying charges of threatening Cuban security. Ahead of Pope Benedict XVI's visit, 86 foreign prisoners might also be freed.
summary_3: Cuba will release around 2,900 prisoners, excluding Alan Gross, based on various appeals, with an additional 86 foreign prisoners potentially freed before the Pope's visit.

text: "The impact of her interest and work on the provision of legal services in the state of California is immeasurable," said Patricia Philips, senior of-counsel for Los Angeles' Morrison & Foerster."Its value is felt every day by someone who would otherwise be floundering around in the legal system yet dealing with very serious problems."Zelon's public-interest work has not gone unnoticed.Several organizations that share her commitment to public service - including the National Legal Aid & Defender Association and the State Bar of California - have honored her.Two years ago, Zelon received the Laurie D. Zelon Pro Bono Award, which had been named for her one year earlier by the Law Firm Pro Bono Project, which she'd helped found."I didn't find out until I was standing in the great hall of the Supreme Court, surrounded by 300 people who were there, that the award had been named for me and was thereafter going to be given in my name.It's very hard to believe, for anyone who knows me well, but I was actually speechless for a period," Zelon said.Zelon faced one of the greatest challenges of her legal career, she said, when her appointment to the bench forced her to switch gears from civil litigation to criminal law."It was a steep learning curve for me," she said."It's a whole different set of processes.The rules are different.The case law is a whole body unto itself."Attorneys praise Zelon for her thorough understanding of the law."She's extremely well-versed in the law," Leon said."She's very thorough in her research," Wong said.Of course, not all attorneys concur with every decision Zelon makes in court.Some city attorneys disagree with her interpretation of evidentiary statutes when Zelon puts limits on their use of hearsay testimony.But lawyers who have appeared before her say that they appreciate her intelligent interpretation of the law.
summary_1: Justice Laurie Zelon has made significant contributions to California's legal landscape through her dedication to public-interest work. Her influence extends to daily life, providing assistance to those navigating complex legal issues. Recognized by various organizations such as the National Legal Aid & Defender Association and the State Bar of California, Zelon even has an eponymous award presented annually by the Law Firm Pro Bono Project. In 2019, she became its first recipient. Appointment to the bench led to a shift from civil litigation to criminal law, presenting new challenges due to distinct procedures and case laws. Despite differing opinions regarding some decisions, particularly concerning evidentiary statute interpretations, Zelon remains respected among peers for her comprehensive knowledge and thoughtful application of the law.
summary_2: Justice Laurie Zelon, known for public-interest work, impacts Californian lives via legal aid. Honored by groups like NLADA and SBC, she received an annual award named after herself in 2019. Moving from civil to criminal law upon joining the bench brought fresh challenges, but respect persists for her thorough understanding and careful use of law despite varying views on certain rulings.
summary_3: Justice Laurie Zelon, honored by organizations like NLADA and SBC, is recognized for impacting Californians through legal aid, receiving an annual award in her name since 2019, while maintaining respect for her deep understanding and careful application of law, despite differing opinions on specific rulings.

text: These incoherent words threw the first glimpse of light on the meaning of her distress and penitence. I doubt if the best woman in Christendom would so reproach and abase herself, if convicted of even a worse sin than the secret use of those stimulants for which the "charny" is a Martial equivalent. No Martialist would dream of poisoning his blood and besotting his brain with alcohol in any form. But their opiates affect a race addicted to physical repose, to sensuous enjoyment rather than to sensual excitement, and to lucid intellectual contemplation, with a sense of serene delight as supremely delicious to their temperament as the dreamy illusions of haschisch to the Turk, the fierce frenzy of bhang to the Malay, or the wild excitement of brandy or Geneva to the races of Northern Europe. But as with the luxury of intoxication in Europe, so in Mars indulgence in these drugs, freely permitted to the one sex, is strictly forbidden by opinion and domestic rule to the other. A lady discovered in the use of "charny" is as deeply disgraced as an European matron detected in the secret enjoyment of spirits and cigars; and her lord and master takes care to render her sufficiently conscious of her fault.
summary_1: The passage sheds light on the reason behind her regret and remorse. The narrator suggests that even the most virtuous woman in Christian society wouldn't humble herself as much if found guilty of a more serious sin than privately using 'charny', a Martian equivalent for a certain type of stimulant. Unlike Martialists who don't use alcohol or similar substances, the people of Mars, particularly women, consume opiates due to their preference for relaxation, sensory pleasure, and calm intellectual appreciation over intense sensual excitement. This habit among Mars inhabitants is likened to the luxury of intoxication in Europe, where it's allowed for one gender but restricted for another. If a woman from Mars is caught using 'charny', she faces severe social stigma, comparable to an European wife being caught consuming spirits and cigarettes secretly. Her partner ensures she fully understands her mistake.
summary_2: The text discusses a woman's guilt after using 'charny', a Martian relaxant. While Martians prefer relaxed pleasures, using 'charny' brings shame, especially for women. It's compared to European wives covertly drinking and smoking, frowned upon despite male privilege. Severe societal judgment follows discovery, causing deep regret.
summary_3: After using the Martian relaxant 'charny', a woman feels intense guilt due to societal stigma, similar to European wives discreetly consuming alcohol and tobacco, an act frowned upon despite male privilege, leading to severe judgment and remorse if discovered.

text: Alexis-Charles-Henri Clerel de Tocqueville (French: [aleksi SaRl aRi kleRel d@ tokvil]; 29 July 1805 - 16 April 1859) was a French political thinker and historian best known for his works Democracy in America (appearing in two volumes: 1835 and 1840) and The Old Regime and the Revolution (1856).In both of these, he analyzed the improved living standards and social conditions of individuals, as well as their relationship to the market and state in Western societies.Democracy in America was published after Tocqueville's travels in the United States, and is today considered an early work of sociology and political science.Tocqueville was active in French politics, first under the July Monarchy (1830-1848) and then during the Second Republic (1849-1851) which succeeded the February 1848 Revolution.He retired from political life after Louis Napoleon Bonaparte's 2 December 1851 coup, and thereafter began work on The Old Regime and the Revolution.He argued that the importance of the French Revolution was to continue the process of modernizing and centralizing the French state which had begun under King Louis XIV.The failure of the Revolution came from the inexperience of the deputies who were too wedded to abstract Enlightenment ideals.Tocqueville was a classical liberal who advocated parliamentary government, but was skeptical of the extremes of democracy.
summary_1: Alexis de Tocqueville was a renowned French political scientist and historian, remembered particularly for "Democracy in America" and "The Old Regime and the Revolution". His writings delved into societal advancements, individual welfare, and relationships between society, the market, and the state in Western civilizations. Published in two parts in 1835 and 1840 respectively, "Democracy in America" encapsulated Tocqueville's observations from his U.S exploration, making it one of the earliest pieces of sociological and political research. Active in French politics during the July Monarchy (1830-1848) and the Second Republic (1849-1851), post the February 1848 Revolution, Tocqueville withdrew from politics after Louis Napoleon Bonaparte's coup on 2 December 1851. This led him to focus on "The Old Regime and the Revolution", where he posited that the significance of the French Revolution lay in its role of furthering the modernization and centralization of the French administration, initially instigated by King Louis XIV. However, according to Tocqueville, the revolution stumbled due to the lack of experience among the representatives, who remained rigidly committed to the absolute principles of the Enlightenment era. A proponent of classical liberalism, Tocqueville endorsed parliamentarianism while being cautious about extreme democratic tendencies.
summary_2: Renowned French thinker Alexis de Tocqueville wrote "Democracy in America," analyzing American democracy, and "The Old Regime and the Revolution." He studied societal progress, individual wellbeing, and links between society, markets, and states in Western societies. The first part of "Democracy in America" appeared in 1835, sharing insights from his US travels. After active involvement in French politics, including under the July Monarchy and the Second Republic, Tocqueville left politics after Louis Napoleon Bonaparte's coup in 1851. In "The Old Regime and the Revolution," published later, Tocqueville argued that the French Revolution advanced France's modernization and centralization but failed due to inflexible adherence to Enlightenment ideals. As a classic liberal, Tocqueville advocated parliamentarianism with caution against excessive democratization.
summary_3: Alexis de Tocqueville, known for "Democracy in America" and "The Old Regime and the Revolution," was a French thinker who analyzed democratic systems, societal advancements, and market/state dynamics; he served in French politics before leaving post-coup, arguing that the French Revolution spurred modernization despite failing due to rigid Enlightenment views, while favoring cautious democratization.

text: Rakal, her first officer, was staring pensively at his panel.He was what this was all about.She watched his graceful fingers ending in thick black claws tap out calculations on the panel.His pointed ears swiveled back and forth, catching every sound from the bridge, while his long tail swished to the rhythm of his thoughts.Only those of the Arrallin Insurrection inner team knew he was no common 'beta furry'.His silken fur, which would be tawny golden and striped with jet black bands, was dyed perfectly to a pure black, and his mane trimmed and thinned as to be indistinguishable from the rest of his coat.His eyes had been treated and darkened to a rich purple to disguise the brilliant golden yellow color that would mark him as an Alpha Arrallin, and leader of his hive.Right now, he looked like an overgrown wolf who'd learned touch-typing.The scout ship re-emerged from the hole - a brilliant speck emerging from a sphere of velvety blackness.It's hail crackled across the comm, and Tara spun to retake her seat at the helm."Launch the second probe.Won't Central be crushed to learn that another gateway has yielded little more than a class F planet and a white dwarf system.Level 1 and 2 staffers should prepare to be briefed and move out.This sounds like it's the one."The distinctive whuffle of pleasure rippled through the betas on the bridge, and Rakal let loose a small growl, as if to caution his charges against false hope.They'd scouted twenty-seven gates so far, and none had turned up anything worth the Insurrection's time.Tara would not let giddy hopes drag them onto a rock that would spell the end for the project, and the Arrallin species.
summary_1: Rakal, seemingly a regular beta furry, is actually a high-ranking Alpha Arrallin, masked by dye and treatment to blend in with the crew. His true identity is known only to the insurrection's core members. His striking gold eyes have been altered to a deep purple, and his silver fur dyed black, making him appear as an oversized wolf. He's currently serving as the first officer aboard their scout ship. The crew has surveyed 27 gates thus far, finding nothing significant until now. A new gateway has revealed a Class F planet accompanied by a white dwarf star system. Despite the promising discovery, Rakal remains cautious, remembering the disappointment after investigating previous gates. The crew prepares to gather data and present findings to Level 1 and 2 personnel, but they remain wary due to past experiences.
summary_2: Rakal, disguised as a wolf, is an important Alpha on a mission, leading a team that discovered a potential Class F planet near a white dwarf star. Known as a beta, he hides his gold eyes and silver fur for safety. After surveying 27 gates, this is the first hint at something useful. Though excited, Rakal urges caution from past disappointments. They plan to collect data and report to higher authorities while staying vigilant.
summary_3: Wolf-disguised Alpha Rakal leads a team that found a promising Class F planet after scouting 27 gates, urging caution due to previous setbacks, planning to gather data before reporting to superiors.

text: Alexander earned the epithet "The Great" due to his unparalleled success as a military commander.He never lost a battle, despite typically being outnumbered.This was due to use of terrain, phalanx and cavalry tactics, bold strategy, and the fierce loyalty of his troops.The Macedonian phalanx, armed with the sarissa, a spear 6 metres (20 ft) long, had been developed and perfected by Philip II through rigorous training, and Alexander used its speed and maneuverability to great effect against larger but more disparate Persian forces.Alexander also recognized the potential for disunity among his diverse army, which employed various languages and weapons.He overcame this by being personally involved in battle, in the manner of a Macedonian king.In his first battle in Asia, at Granicus, Alexander used only a small part of his forces, perhaps 13,000 infantry with 5,000 cavalry, against a much larger Persian force of 40,000.Alexander placed the phalanx at the center and cavalry and archers on the wings, so that his line matched the length of the Persian cavalry line, about 3 km (1.86 mi).By contrast, the Persian infantry was stationed behind its cavalry.This ensured that Alexander would not be outflanked, while his phalanx, armed with long pikes, had a considerable advantage over the Persian's scimitars and javelins.Macedonian losses were negligible compared to those of the Persians.At Issus in 333 BC, his first confrontation with Darius, he used the same deployment, and again the central phalanx pushed through.Alexander personally led the charge in the center, routing the opposing army.At the decisive encounter with Darius at Gaugamela, Darius equipped his chariots with scythes on the wheels to break up the phalanx and equipped his cavalry with pikes.Alexander arranged a double phalanx, with the center advancing at an angle, parting when the chariots bore down and then reforming.The advance was successful and broke Darius' center, causing the latter to flee once again.When faced with opponents who used unfamiliar fighting techniques, such as in Central Asia and India, Alexander adapted his forces to his opponents' style.Thus, in Bactria and Sogdiana, Alexander successfully used his javelin throwers and archers to prevent outflanking movements, while massing his cavalry at the center.
summary_1: Known as "The Great," Alexander achieved remarkable feats as a military leader, remaining undefeated throughout his career. His triumphs resulted from strategic use of terrain, innovative tactics, and strong soldier loyalty. The Macedonian phalanx, armed with a 6-meter spear called the sarissa, proved crucial to his victories. Having honed their skills under Phillip II, these soldiers excelled at maneuvers, enabling them to outperform larger yet less organized enemy forces. Aware of linguistic and weapon diversity within his army, Alexander actively participated in battles, fostering unity. In his initial Asian battle at Granicus, he commanded approximately 13,000 infantry and 5,000 cavalry against a 40,000-strong Persian force. Positioning the phalanx centrally and placing cavalry and archers on the flanks allowed him to match the length of the Persian cavalry line. This tactic minimized casualties amongst his troops while maximizing damage to enemies. Similar strategies emerged during his encounters with Darius at Issus and Gaugamela, resulting in victory each time. When battling opponents employing distinct combat styles, such as in Central Asia and India, Alexander adjusted his approach accordingly. For instance, utilizing javelin throwers and archers effectively counterbalanced threats posed by outflanking adversaries, ultimately securing victory across numerous frontiers.
summary_2: Alexander III of Macedonia, known as 'The Great,' was an invincible military commander celebrated for his strategic genius and loyal soldiers wielding 6-meter sarissas. He utilized clever formations like positioning the phalanx centrally, surrounding it with cavalry and archers, which led to decisive wins over larger but disorganized foes. Adapting to diverse fighting techniques, Alexander triumphed everywhere, including Central Asia and India, thanks to versatile tactics that balanced various threats.
summary_3: Alexander the Great won numerous battles by skillfully arranging his disciplined troops, using long spears and adapting to different combat styles.

text: In his 1847 Report on Algeria, Tocqueville declared that Europe should avoid making the same mistake they made with the European colonization of the Americas in order to avoid the bloody consequences.More particularly he reminds his countrymen of a solemn caution whereby he warns them that if the methods used towards the Algerian people remain unchanged, colonization will end in a blood bath.Tocqueville includes in his report on Algeria that the fate of their soldiers and finances depended on how the French government treats the various native populations of Algeria, including the various Arab tribes, independent Kabyles living in the Atlas Mountains, and the powerful political leader Abd-el-Kader.In his various letters and essays on Algeria, Tocqueville discusses contrasting strategies by which a European country can approach imperialism.In particular, the author differentiates between what he terms 'dominance' and a particular version of 'colonization'.The latter stresses the obtainment and protection of land and passageways that promise commercial wealth.In the case of Algeria, the Port of Algiers, and the control over the Strait of Gibraltar, were considered by Tocqueville to be particular valuable.Direct control of the political operations of the entirety of Algeria, however, was not.Thus the author stresses domination over only certain points of political influence as a means to colonization of commercially valuable areas.Tocqueville argued that domination via violent means, though unpleasant, is necessary for colonization and justified by the laws of war.Such laws are not discussed in detail; however, given that the goal of the French mission in Algeria was to obtain commercial and military interest as opposed to self-defense, it can be deduced that Tocqueville would not concur with Just war theory's jus ad bellum criteria of just cause.Further, given that Tocqueville approved of the use of force to eliminate civilian housing in enemy territory, his approach does not accord with Just War Theory's jus in bellow criteria of proportionality and discrimination.
summary_1: Tocqueville's 1847 Report on Algeria warned against repeating past mistakes in colonial efforts, emphasizing the risk of a bloody outcome if treatment of the local population didn't change. He highlighted the importance of the Algerian people, including various Arab tribes, the independent Kabyles, and leader Abd-el-Kader, for the success of French soldiers and finances. In his writings, Tocqueville compared two approaches to imperialism: 'dominance' and a specific form of 'colonization.' The latter focused on securing commercially valuable territories and routes, such as the Port of Algiers and the Strait of Gibraltar, rather than complete political control. While direct governance was seen as unnecessary, strategic political influence was deemed crucial. Although Tocqueville acknowledged the necessity of force in some instances, he did not fully align with Just War Theory's principles of just cause, proportionality, and discrimination.
summary_2: In his 1847 report, Tocqueville advised against repeating past errors in colonization, highlighting the dangers of maltreating Algerians. He distinguished between 'domination' and a unique 'colonization,' favoring the latter, which prioritized commercial interests over absolute power. Despite acknowledging the need for force at times, Tocqueville didn't adhere strictly to Just War Theory's principles. His work underscored the significance of understanding diverse groups like the Kabyles and Abd-el-Kader, advocating strategic political influence instead of full control.
summary_3: Tocqueville's 1847 report recommended a non-oppressive colonization approach in Algeria, emphasizing trade, respect for locals, and strategic influence over brute force, while discouraging past colonial mistakes.

text: Once upon a time I had a dog named Toodles.He was black and white and had long floppy ears.He also had very short legs, but really big paws.Every Saturday we would go to the park and play Toodles' favorite game.Toodles loved playing fetch.One Saturday, Toodles ran over to the pond because he saw ducks swimming there.He ran all around the pond, barking at the ducks.The ducks ignored him, and kept swimming.Toodles wasn't having it!He jumped into the pond and started swimming toward the ducks, chasing around his new playmates.One of the ducks, braver than the others, poked Toodles with his beak - and then bit him right on one of his floppy ears!Toodles barked and ran out of the pond because the duck hurt his ear.Soaking wet, he ran toward where I was eating a sandwich on the grass and curled right up in my lap so I could make him feel better.After that, whenever he would see a duck, Toodles would run the other way.
summary_1: Toodles was a black and white dog with long floppy ears and large paws, who enjoyed playing fetch every Saturday at the park. One day, while they were there, Toodles noticed some ducks swimming in the pond. He became excited and began running around the pond, barking at them. The ducks didn't pay much attention to him until one particularly brave duck decided to confront Toodles. It first poked him with its beak, followed by a bite on one of his floppy ears. This encounter prompted Toodles to quickly exit the pond due to the pain inflicted by the duck. As a result, Toodles ended up soaked and sought comfort from his owner, who happened to be enjoying a sandwich nearby. After this incident, Toodles developed an instinctive fear of ducks; each time he spotted one, he made sure to keep his distance.
summary_2: Toodles, a dog who loves fetch, meets a bossy duck that bites his ear, causing Toodles to avoid ducks henceforth.
summary_3: After meeting a bossy duck that bit its ear, Toodles, a fetch-loving dog, develops an aversion to ducks.

text: Bin Laden reportedly discussed the planes operation with KSM and Atef in a series of meetings in the spring of 1999 at the al Matar complex near Kandahar.KSM's original concept of using one of the hijacked planes to make a media statement was scrapped, but  Bin Laden considered the basic idea feasible. Bin Laden, Atef, and KSM developed an initial list of targets.These included the White House, the U.S. Capitol, the Pentagon, and the World Trade Center.According to KSM,  Bin Laden wanted to destroy the White House and the Pentagon, KSM wanted to strike the World Trade Center, and all of them wanted to hit the Capitol.No one else was involved in the initial selection of targets. Bin Laden also soon selected four individuals to serve as suicide operatives: Khalid al Mihdhar, Nawaf al Hazmi, Khallad, and Abu Bara al Yemeni.During the al Matar meetings,  Bin Laden told KSM that Mihdhar and Hazmi were so eager to participate in an operation against the United States that they had already obtained U.S. visas.KSM states that they had done so on their own after the suicide of their friend Azzam (Nashiri's cousin) in carrying out the Nairobi bombing.KSM had not met them.His only guidance from  Bin Laden was that the two should eventually go to the United States for pilot training.Hazmi and Mihdhar were Saudi nationals, born in Mecca.Like the others in this initial group of selectees, they were already experienced mujahideen.They had traveled together to fight in Bosnia in a group that journeyed to the Balkans in 1995.By the time Hazmi and Mihdhar were assigned to the planes operation in early 1999, they had visited Afghanistan on several occasions.Khallad was another veteran mujahid, like much of his family.His father had been expelled from Yemen because of his extremist views.Khallad had grown up in Saudi Arabia, where his father knew  Bin Laden, Abdullah Azzam, and Omar Abdel Rahman (the "Blind Sheikh").
summary_1: In Spring 1999, at the al Matar complex near Kandahar, Osama bin Laden, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed (KSM), and Mohammad Atef held discussions about what would become the 9/11 attacks. The initial plan, suggested by KSM, was to use a hijacked plane for a media statement, which was later abandoned. However, the core concept was deemed feasible. The trio initially shortlisted the White House, US Capitol, Pentagon, and World Trade Center as potential targets. Bin Laden aimed to demolish the White House and Pentagon, while KSM favored striking the World Trade Center; all agreed on targeting the Capitol. No other parties were involved in selecting these targets. Soon, Bin Laden chose four men - Khalid al Mihdhar, Nawaf al Hazmi, Khallad, and Abu Bara al Yemeni - to be suicide operatives. Bin Laden revealed that Mihdhar and Hazmi, both Saudi nationals who fought in Bosnia in 1995, possessed valid US visas, having procured them independently after their friend Azzam's death during the Nairobi bombing. They were tasked with undergoing pilot training in the US upon receiving instructions from Bin Laden via KSM.
summary_2: In spring 1999, Osama bin Laden, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, and Mohammad Atef discussed the 9/11 attacks at al Matar complex, Kandahar. Initial plan, suggested by KSM, used a hijacked plane for a media statement, but was dropped. Target selection included White House, US Capitol, Pentagon, and WTC, with final agreement on all except White House. Four suicide operatives were chosen, including Khalid al Mihdhar and Nawaf al Hazmi, who had valid US visas and were tasked with pilot training in the US.
summary_3: In early 1999, Osama bin Laden, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, and Mohammad Atef decided on the 9/11 targets at the al Matar complex, Kandahar, selecting the Pentagon, US Capitol, and World Trade Center, excluding the White House. Khalid al Mihdhar and Nawaf al Hazmi, both with valid U.S. visas, were assigned to train as pilots in the U.S. after an initial plan involving a hijacked plane for a media statement was abandoned.

text: The rally took place on October 17, the shooting on February 29.Again, standard filmmaking techniques are interpreted as smooth distortion: "Moore works by depriving you of context and guiding your mind to fill the vacuum -- with completely false ideas.It is brilliantly, if unethically, done."As noted above, the "from my cold dead hands" part is simply Moore's way to introduce Heston.Did anyone but Moore's critics view it as anything else?He certainly does not "attribute it to a speech where it was not uttered" and, as noted above, doing so twice would make no sense whatsoever if Moore was the mastermind deceiver that his critics claim he is.Concerning the Georgetown Hoya interview where Heston was asked about Rolland, you write: "There is no indication that [Heston] recognized Kayla Rolland's case."This is naive to the extreme -- Heston would not be president of the NRA if he was not kept up to date on the most prominent cases of gun violence.Even if he did not respond to that part of the interview, he certainly knew about the case at that point.Regarding the NRA website excerpt about the case and the highlighting of the phrase "48 hours after Kayla Rolland is pronounced dead": This is one valid criticism, but far from the deliberate distortion you make it out to be; rather, it is an example for how the facts can sometimes be easy to miss with Moore's fast pace editing.The reason the sentence is highlighted is not to deceive the viewer into believing that Heston hurried to Flint to immediately hold a rally there (as will become quite obvious), but simply to highlight the first mention of the name "Kayla Rolland" in the text, which is in this paragraph.
summary_1: On October 17, Michael Moore's documentary "Bowling for Columbine" was released, featuring Charlton Heston. The film contains a scene where Heston holds a rally in Flint, Michigan, just 48 hours after the death of six-year-old Kayla Rolland, who was fatally shot. Critics accuse Moore of manipulative editing, suggesting that Heston rushed to Flint immediately after hearing about the incident. However, the highlighted phrase "48 hours after Kayla Rolland is pronounced dead" merely marks the first mention of her name in the text, not an attempt to mislead viewers about Heston's timing. Moreover, Heston's famous quote, "from my cold dead hands," though associated with this event, was actually said at a different time and place. Despite claims that Moore attributes this quote to the Flint rally, there's no evidence to support this. Heston, then-president of the NRA, was likely aware of the Kayla Rolland case, regardless of whether he addressed it directly in interviews. Overall, while Moore's editing style may create impressions that some find misleading, closer examination reveals these interpretations might be overly critical.
summary_2: Michael Moore's "Bowling for Columbine" debuted on Oct 17, featuring Charlton Heston. The film includes a Flint, MI rally, 48 hours after six-year-old Kayla Rolland's death. Critics allege manipulative editing, implying Heston hurried to Flint post-incident. However, the text doesn't suggest immediate response; instead, it mentions Rolland's death before introducing Heston. Also, Heston's renowned quote wasn't from this event but elsewhere. While Moore's editing could imply otherwise, scrutiny suggests criticism may be too harsh.
summary_3: Critics accuse Michael Moore of manipulating footage in "Bowling for Columbine," particularly regarding Charlton Heston's appearance soon after a child's death, but closer examination suggests their reactions might be overly critical.

text: Tokhtakhounov, whose age was given by Comey as 53 or 62, is a "major figure in international Eurasian organized crime," Comey said.Born in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, and now a Russian citizen, he is known as Taivanchik, or Little Taiwanese, for his Central Asian ethnic background.Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, he has been implicated in arms trading and Russian art smuggling, and in the Russian news media he was accused of complicity in a plot to extort $10 million from the head of a Russian sports foundation.He appears to have moved to France in 1989, according to news media reports, and is reported to have Israeli citizenship also.Comey said Tokhtakhounov had three residences in Italy: Forte dei Marmi, Rome and Milan.The complaint against Tokhtakhounov's traces his contact with figure skating to 2000, when he proposed to Gailhaguet the creation of a professional hockey team in Paris that would provide revenue for the French Skating Federation.( Gailhaguet and Anissina are not referred to by name in an accompanying FBI agent's affidavit, but by their descriptions their identities are obvious.) In return, Gailhaguet told the FBI on Feb. 23 as the Olympics were taking place, Tokhtakhounov asked for Gailhaguet's help in renewing his French visa, which was about to expire.But when Gailhaguet sought guidance from a French government official, he was told that "Tokhtakhounov's money is bad," the affidavit said.The federal complaint offers many details of the alleged conspiracy, including excerpts from a transcript of the Italian wiretaps.later suspended Le Gougne and Gailhaguet for three years.The federal complaint did not describe the possibility of a wider conspiracy or any contact between Tokhtakhounov, or his unnamed co-conspirators, with Le Gougne."We have alleged no connection between this man with any officials other than with Russian federation officials," James B. Comey, the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, said at a news conference.He said that Tokhtakhounov "reached out to a co-conspirator, somebody connected to the Russian Skating Federation, who did the legwork for him."
summary_1:
Alleged mobster Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov, also known as Taivanchik, is a significant player in global Eurasian criminal circles, born in Uzbekistan and currently a Russian national. He has lived in France since 1989 and holds Israeli citizenship too. His connections span across arms dealing, Russian artwork trafficking, and accusations of involvement in a $10 million blackmail scheme targeting a Russian sports foundation leader. The US Attorney, James B. Comey, identified three Italian addresses tied to Tokhtakhounov - Forte dei Marmi, Rome, and Milan.

In 2000, Tokhtakhounov approached Didier Gailhaguet, former president of the French Figure Skating Federation, suggesting they establish a professional ice hockey team under the Federation umbrella to generate income. This proposition came with a request for assistance in extending Tokhtakhounov's soon-to-expire French visa. However, after consulting a French authority, Gailhaguet learned that accepting Tokhtakhounov's funds could be problematic due to their dubious nature.

An Italian wiretap transcript forms part of the evidence presented in the federal complaint. Following Marina Anissina's controversial disqualification during the Salt Lake City Winter Games, both she and her coach, Nikolai Morozov, faced suspensions of three years. Although the complaint does not explicitly link Tokhtakhounov or his unknown accomplices to Le Gougne, it confirms communication between Tokhtakhounov and someone linked to the Russian Skating Federation. No further links to Olympic officials beyond Russia have been established. Comey clarified that there is no proof connecting Tokhtakhounov directly to any officials outside the Russian Skating Federation.
summary_2: Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov, aka Taivanchik, is a prominent figure in international crime, hailing from Uzbekistan but now a Russian citizen with Israeli citizenship and residences in France. Accused of arms trading, art smuggling, and a $10M blackmail plot against a Russian sports official, he proposed creating an ice hockey team through the French Figure Skating Federation (FSF) in exchange for renewing his expiring French visa. In 2000, FSF head Didier Gailhaguet declined due to suspected illicit origins of Tokhtakhounov's money. A 2002 Italian wiretap connects him to Marina Anissina's suspension; however, no solid ties to non-Russian skating officials exist.
summary_3: Uzbeki-born, Russian-Israeli criminal Alimzhan Tokhtakhounov, known as Taivanchik, attempted to create an ice hockey team via the French Figure Skating Federation using alleged illicit funds, but was denied by its president, Didier Gailhaguet, leading to suspicions about his involvement in a skater's suspension.

text: The dermis is the inner layer of skin.The dermis has blood vessels and nerve endings.The nerve endings explain why your skin is sensitive.You can sense pain, pressure, and temperature.You cut your finger and it starts to bleed.What has happened?If your skin bleeds, it means you have cut the dermis layer and damaged blood vessels.The cut really hurts.It hurts because of the nerve endings in this skin layer.The dermis also contains hair follicles and two types of glands.Hair follicles are structures where hairs originate.Each hair grows out of a follicle.Hair passes up through the epidermis.It then extends above the skin surface.Oil glands produce an oily substance.The oil is secreted into hair follicles.
summary_1: The dermis, the inner layer of skin, houses blood vessels and nerve endings, making skin sensitive to touch, pressure, and temperature changes. When you cut your finger, it may start bleeding due to severed blood vessels from damaging the dermis. The resulting pain originates from nerve endings in that skin layer. Hair follicles and two kinds of glands are also present in the dermis. Hair sprouts from follicles, growing through the epidermis and extending beyond the skin surface. Oil glands secrete an oily substance into these follicles, which plays a role in maintaining healthy skin and hair.
summary_2: Skin's inner layer, the dermis, contains blood vessels and nerves, causing sensitivity to touch and temperature changes.
