Damage leads to bleeding and pain due to severed blood vessels and stimulated nerve endings. Hair grows from follicles rooted in the dermis, reaching beyond the skin surface, while oil glands inside these follicles keep skin and hair healthy by releasing an oily substance.
summary_3: The dermis houses blood vessels, nerves, hair follicles with oil glands; damage causes bleeding, pain, and affected growth.

text: Convicted murderer Seth Baxter awakens chained to a table beneath a pendulum blade . A videotape informs him that crushing his hands between the presses will release him ; he does so , but the blade still swings down and violently cuts him in half , while someone watches through a hole in the wall . The scene cuts to Agent Peter Strahm , who kills Jeff Denlon in self-defense and is sealed in the sickroom . He finds a hidden passage with a tape recorder that warns him to stay in the sickroom , but ignores it . He is attacked by a pig-masked figure in the passage and awakens with his head sealed in a box slowly filling with water , Which he survives by performing a tracheotomy using a pen . Outside the plant , Detective Mark Hoffman delivers Corbett Denlon to the police and claims they are the only survivors , and is shocked when Strahm is brought out alive as well . Jill Tuck is met by John Kramer's attorney , who is administering his will . She is left a box and a videotape , in Which John stresses the importance of the box's contents . She opens it with a key hung around her neck and then leaves without disclosing its contents . In a memorial service held for David Tapp , Steven Sing , Allison Kerry , Eric Matthews , and Daniel Rigg , the five officers killed in action , Hoffman is promoted to detective lieutenant . He is informed of the death of Agent Lindsey Perez while taking Strahm's phone and goes to the hospital to meet Strahm , who says that Hoffman's name was Perez's last words .
summary_1: Seth Baxter, a convicted murderer, wakes up chained, leading to his brutal demise via a swinging pendulum blade. Agent Peter Strahm kills Jeff Denlon in self-defense and discovers a secret passage despite warnings from a recorded message. Ignoring this advice leads to an attack by a masked figure, resulting in Strahm's near-drowning before escaping. Meanwhile, Detective Mark Hoffman turns over Corbett Denlon to the authorities, falsely claiming she is the sole survivor. Later, Strahm emerges alive, shocking both Hoffman and Corbett. Following a memorial ceremony for fallen officers, Hoffman receives news about the passing of Agent Lindsey Perez and heads to the hospital where Strahm reveals Hoffman's name as Perez's final words. Concurrently, Jill Tuck obtains a mysterious package containing a box from John Kramer's lawyer; after opening it with a special key, she keeps its contents concealed.
summary_2: Convicted killer Seth Baxter dies gruesomely, while Agent Peter Strahm survives an attack, killing suspect Jeff Denlon. Detective Mark Hoffman hands Corbett Denlon to the police, lying that she's the lone survivor. Strahm reappears, surprising Hoffman and Corbett. Post-memorial, Hoffman learns of Agent Lindsey Perez's death, revealed by surviving victim Strahm. Jill Tuck gets a parcel from John Kramer's attorney, hiding its enclosed contents.
summary_3: After Seth Baxter's brutal demise, Peter Strahm fakes his own death, kills Jeff Denlon, and lets Corbett Denlon go; later, Strahm confronts Detective Mark Hoffman and reveals Perez's death, while Jill Tuck receives a mysterious package from John Kramer's lawyer, keeping its contents concealed.

text: Rivers flowing over gentle slopes move more slowly.They move much more slowly than a mountain stream.These slow moving streams create different types of features than mountain streams.Slow moving water erodes the sides of their channels more than the bottom.Also, large curves in the stream form.These curves are called meanders.Meanders are caused by erosion and deposition.Remember, faster moving water causes erosion more quickly.Slower moving water erodes material more slowly.If water is moving slowly enough, the sediment being carried may settle out.This settling out, or dropping off, of sediment is deposition.The curves are called meanders because they slowly wander over the land.As meanders erode from side to side, they create a floodplain.This is a broad, flat area on both sides of a river.Eventually, a meander may become cut off from the rest of the river.This forms an oxbow lake.
summary_1: In gently sloping areas, rivers flow slower compared to mountain streams, resulting in distinct geographical characteristics. The slower pace leads to differing erosional patterns; these bodies of water primarily erode their banks rather than their beds. Consequently, large bends known as meanders emerge due to this lateral erosion combined with sediment deposition. Meanders signify a gradual shift in the river's course over time. As the process continues, it ultimately creates a wide, level surface alongside the river - a floodplain. In some instances, a meander might detach entirely from the main water body, culminating in the formation of an oxbow lake. This chain of events originates from variations in water velocity and accompanying disparities in erosive capabilities.
summary_2: Rivers flowing at gentler speeds cause unique features like meanders and oxbow lakes due to different erosion patterns, primarily affecting banks instead of riverbeds. Over time, this results in wide, flat floodplains, sometimes isolating sections into standalone bodies of water called oxbow lakes.
summary_3: Gentle rivers create meanders and oxbow lakes over time, forming wide floodplains with isolated oxbow lakes.

text: After becoming disabled in a machete attack on a visit to his native Haiti, Jean-Claude Joseph needed help persuading his landlord to move him from a fifth-floor apartment to one on the ground floor.Isaac Benjamin became ensnared in a bureaucratic snafu that took away his Social Security disability payments for more than two years.The story of Martha, a woman from Sierra Leone, was more compelling.Beaten, raped and tortured in her politically repressive homeland, she knowingly used someone else's passport to escape to America, but was caught by immigration authorities upon her arrival.She desperately sought political asylum.Not the kind of cases that lead to ground-breaking upheavals in the law, but the kind of cases that are handled day in and day out by lawyers for the legally disenfranchised who have no where else to turn.The work of attorneys from Legal Services of New Jersey will be highlighted in a onehour documentary, "Quest for Justice," to be aired 9 p.m.today on New Jersey Network.Produced by NYD2, a communications firm based in Somerset, the documentary features case histories of clients whose needs ranged from housing to fighting off deportation.Joseph, a 54-year-old naturalized citizen, turned to Legal Services when the landlord of his federally subsidized apartment complex in Elizabeth turned a deaf ear to his request for a ground-floor apartment.Having lost the use of his left arm in warding off the machete attack during a robbery attempt, Joseph said he found it increasingly difficult to negotiate the five flights of stairs lugging groceries or laundry on the frequent occasions when the building's elevator was out of order."With this, it became impossible for me to stay upstairs," he said, pointing to the scars on his forearm."If I cannot carry my groceries or my laundry, how can I live?""It was a compelling case," said Legal Services attorney Stephen St. Hilaire."The key for us -- and we have to make tough decisions all the time on whether to take a case -- was visualizing what he had to do to get to the fifth floor, struggling with a bag of groceries," he said.Benjamin, 53, of Jersey City had been collecting Social Security disability after undergoing double bypass surgery when the checks stopped coming.He said the agency claimed he had failed to return a form updating the condition of his health."But what got me was they didn't let me know they didn't get it, they just cut me off," he said, adding he found it impossible to negotiate the Social Security bureaucracy himself.
summary_1: Jean-Claude Joseph, a man from Haiti, required assistance from Legal Services of New Jersey to convince his landlord to relocate him from a fifth-floor apartment to a ground-floor one due to a machete attack disability. Isaac Benjamin, another client, encountered a bureaucratic issue that suspended his Social Security disability benefits for over two years. The most striking case involved a woman from Sierra Leone named Martha, who illegally entered America using someone else's passport after facing brutal treatment in her home country. She applied for political asylum. These cases highlight the crucial role of Legal Services of New Jersey, which handles numerous legal issues for those without other options. A documentary titled "Quest for Justice" showcases these real-life stories, including Joseph's successful fight for a ground-floor apartment and Benjamin's struggle to restore his Social Security disability benefits.
summary_2: Legal Services of New Jersey helps vulnerable individuals like Jean-Claude Joseph, Isaac Benjamin, and Martha, who face housing, social security, and asylum challenges. Documentary "Quest for Justice" shares their compelling stories, such as Joseph securing a ground-floor apartment and Benjamin restoring his disability benefits, emphasizing the organization's vital role in addressing various legal needs.
summary_3: The documentary "Quest for Justice" highlights Legal Services of New Jersey's crucial role in helping vulnerable people overcome housing, social security, and asylum challenges, as illustrated by individuals like Jean-Claude Joseph and Isaac Benjamin.

text: The 1933 double eagle, a $20 gold piece with a mysterious history that involves a president, a king and a Secret Service sting operation, was auctioned Tuesday last night for a record price for a coin, $7.59 million, nearly double the previous record.The anonymous buyer, believed to be an individual collector who lives in the United States, made the winning bid in a fiercely contested nine-minute auction at Sotheby's in Manhattan.Eight bidders were joined by 500 coin collectors and dealers in an auction house audience seemingly devoid of celebrity bidders, while an additional 534 observers followed the bidding on eBay.As auction houses prepare for their fall seasons in an uncertain economy, the sale price "suggests that the marketplace for important items is enormously strong," said David Redden, a vice chairman at Sotheby's, who was the auctioneer."This is an astonishing new record for a coin," he said.In an unprecedented move, the auction proceeds were split by the U.S. Mint and a London coin dealer, Stephen Fenton, who had won that right in court after having been arrested by Secret Service agents for trying to sell the coin in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan in 1996.Henrietta Holsman Fore, the director of the U.S. Mint, who witnessed the sale, said, "The monies we receive will go toward helping to pay down the debt and to fight the war on terrorism."Fenton commented that the double eagle had been on "a long historic journey, with a very satisfying ending."He added, "I am thrilled with the price."The previous numismatic record holder was an 1804 U.S. silver dollar, which sold for $4.14 million in 1999.Sotheby's partner in the one-lot auction was Stack's Rare Coins, with which it shared the customary 15 percent commission."I have never seen as much interest in the sale of any coin in my 30 years in the business," said Lawrence R. Stack, the company's managing director."This is the Mona Lisa of coins," said Beth Deisher, editor of Coin World, the largest weekly coin publication in the United States, with a circulation of 85,000."It is unique.Forbidden fruit."Collectors' Web sites have surged with speculation about the sale price, and enthusiasts even organized betting pools.
summary_1: The rare 1933 Double Eagle gold coin fetched a record-breaking $7.59 million at an intense nine-minute auction at Sotheby's in New York. The anonymous American buyer, likely a private collector, outbid seven others amid a crowd of 500 coin aficionados and dealers, along with 534 online viewers. This marks the highest sum ever paid for a coin, almost doubling the previous record. Auction houses are optimistic about this sign of strength in the market during economic uncertainty. Proceeds from the sale will be divided between the U.S. Mint and London coin dealer Stephen Fenton, who previously attempted to sell the coin illegally in 1996, leading to his arrest by the Secret Service. The U.S. Mint Director Henrietta Holsman Fore stated the funds would aid in reducing national debt and supporting anti-terror efforts. Fenton expressed satisfaction with the outcome, calling it a fitting end to the coin's historical journey. Previously held by an 1804 U.S. silver dollar, the title of most expensive coin shifted hands, fetching $4.14 million in 1999. Anticipation around the sale drove significant buzz among collectors, resulting in fervent discussion on specialized websites and informal wagers.
summary_2: A 1933 Double Eagle gold coin sold for $7.59 million at Sotheby's, setting a new record. Anonymous American buyer outbid seven others in a competitive auction. This surpasses the previous record by nearly double. The coin was once involved in an illegal sale attempt, leading to its seizure by the Secret Service. Proceeds will support reducing national debt and anti-terror efforts. The U.S. Mint Director and the original owner are satisfied with the result.
summary_3: An anonymous American buyer set a new record, paying $7.59 million for a seized 1933 Double Eagle gold coin at Sotheby's; proceeds benefit debt reduction and counter-terrorism.

text: Powell contended that it was not inconsistent to want to foster cooperation even with an organization like the Indonesian military, which has a history of human rights abuses."If you get young officers, expose them to a military organization that is within a democratic political institution, such as the United States, then that rubs off on them," he said.In Malaysia, Powell met with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who has led the country since 1981.The Malaysian foreign minister, Syed Hamid Albar, later told local reporters that Powell had proposed that American and Malaysian officials review the idea of forming a regional training center in Malaysia to coordinate antiterrorism activities.His brief stop in Malaysia also highlighted the moral ambiguities of the effort to prevent terrorism and its emphasis on cooperation with governments that the United States has often criticized.The United States once distanced itself from Mahathir for strong-arm tactics with political rivals, and human rights groups criticize him for arresting and jailing scores of suspected militants, including some who may be linked to al-Qaida, without trial.Powell said his discussions with Mahathir "touched on the case" of his former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, who is serving a 15-year sentence on charges of sodomy and abuse of power after trials that Powell said the United States had "always felt" were flawed.The assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, James Kelly, met on Tuesday morning with Anwar's wife, Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, for what she later told Malaysian reporters was a discussion about both the detention of her husband and six supporters, and the campaign against terrorism.
summary_1: Colin Powell visited Malaysia during his Asia tour, discussing anti-terrorism efforts and addressing past issues with the government there. He suggested creating a regional training center in Malaysia to combat terrorism, emphasizing collaboration despite previous strained relations due to Malaysia's human rights record. The US previously condemned Malaysia's leader, Mahathir Mohamad, for authoritarian actions towards opponents; however, they now cooperate regarding security concerns. During their meeting, Powell mentioned the controversial imprisonment of Anwar Ibrahim, stating that America believed his corruption and sodomy trials were flawed. Meanwhile, James Kelly held talks with Anwar's wife, focusing on her husband's situation and the fight against terrorism. Overall, this visit demonstrated complex diplomatic relationships and priorities in combating global threats while acknowledging past grievances.
summary_2: Colin Powell toured Asia, tackling anti-terrorism and addressing tensions with Malaysia. A regional counter-terrorism hub was proposed by him, aiming at cooperation regardless of prior strained ties over human rights issues. Despite earlier criticism of Malaysia's leadership, both nations collaborate on security matters today. In discussions, Powell briefly touched upon Anwar Ibrahim's contested convictions, expressing doubts about the legitimacy of his trials. Simultaneously, James Kelly met with Anwar's spouse, concentrating on his case and jointly battling terrorism. This trip highlighted intricate diplomatic dynamics, balancing current security interests with historical grievances.
summary_3: During a tour of Asia, Colin Powell promoted a new counter-terrorism initiative while discussing past disputes, including concerns about Anwar Ibrahim's convictions and advocating for collaboration despite previous disagreements over human rights.

text: From Babylon, Alexander went to Susa, one of the Achaemenid capitals, and captured its legendary treasury.He sent the bulk of his army to the Persian ceremonial capital of Persepolis via the Royal Road.Alexander himself took selected troops on the direct route to the city.He had to storm the pass of the Persian Gates (in the modern Zagros Mountains) which had been blocked by a Persian army under Ariobarzanes and then hurried to Persepolis before its garrison could loot the treasury.On entering Persepolis, Alexander allowed his troops to loot the city for several days.Alexander stayed in Persepolis for five months.During his stay a fire broke out in the eastern palace of Xerxes and spread to the rest of the city.Possible causes include a drunken accident or deliberate revenge for the burning of the Acropolis of Athens during the Second Persian War.
summary_1: After conquering Babylon, Alexander ventured to Susa, an ancient Achaemenid capital, where he seized its famed treasury. He dispatched most of his military to the Persian royal seat of Persepolis through the Royal Road, while he led a select group directly to the city. Upon arrival, they encountered resistance at the Persian Gates, defended by General Ariobarzanes. After overcoming this barrier, they rushed to Persepolis, reaching it before the garrison could plunder the treasury. Alexander permitted his soldiers to pillage Persepolis for multiple days. Staying there for five months, an inferno erupted in Xerxes' eastern palace, eventually engulfing the entire city. The cause remains unclear, potentially resulting from inebriation or vengeance for the Acropolis of Athens' destruction during the Greco-Persian Wars.
summary_2: Alexander conquers Babylon, then heads to Susa, seizing its treasury. Dispatching most of his army to Persepolis via the Royal Road, he leads a smaller force directly. They overcome resistance at the Persian Gates, reach Persepolis first, and allow their troops to loot the city for several days. Alexander stays for five months, after which a fire breaks out in Xerxes' palace, burning down the city. The cause is disputed, possibly due to drunkenness or revenge for past Greek losses.
summary_3: After conquering Babylon, Alexander seizes Susa's treasury, sends most of his army to Persepolis, overcomes resistance at the Persian Gates, allows troops to loot Persepolis, stays for five months, and later, a fire burns down the city, potentially due to drunkenness or revenge.

text: In remarks during a ribbon-cutting ceremony here on Wednesday, Gov. George E. Pataki said he expected the facility to generate thousands more jobs in the Hudson Valley area for contractors and suppliers catering to the factory.He praised IBM for being "a critical partner in our economic development efforts" in New York state.In a brief speech, Samuel J. Palmisano, IBM's chief executive, emphasized that it was important to make long-term investments despite the current slump in the technology business."To play to win in technology, you innovate and you lead," he said.But manufacturing technology products is a costly and cyclical business.In June, IBM announced that it was taking a charge of more than $2 billion against earnings.The largest single reasons for the charge were the cost of getting out of the business of manufacturing hard disks for storage, which it sold to Hitachi, and closing down some of its older semiconductor operations.But Kelly said the demand for advanced chips, like those produced at IBM's facility in Burlington, Vt., is strong."I need more capacity in that end of the market," he said, "and this is factory is critical to meeting that growing demand."If IBM has miscalculated the demand, it will suffer badly as both the high operating costs and depreciation on the huge capital investment for the East Fishkill factory drag down earnings.But industry analysts said the plant should be insulated from a falloff in one or a few segments of the semiconductor market.
summary_1: Governor George E. Pataki and IBM CEO Samuel J. Palmisano spoke at a ribbon-cutting event, highlighting IBM's new facility in the Hudson Valley area. The factory is expected to create numerous jobs for local contractors and suppliers. Governor Pataki commended IBM for their role in New York's economic growth. Palmisano stressed the importance of investing in innovation, even amidst the ongoing tech industry downturn. However, manufacturing technology products can be expensive and risky. In June, IBM reported a $2 billion charge due to exiting the hard disk storage business and closing certain semiconductor operations. A significant portion of this charge resulted from selling the hard disk business to Hitachi and shuttering some older chip factories. Despite these challenges, IBM remains optimistic about the demand for advanced chips, such as those manufactured in Burlington, VT. IBM aims to meet this increasing demand with the new East Fishkill factory. Although there is a risk of overestimating demand, industry experts believe the new plant should remain resilient, even if specific sectors of the semiconductor market experience a decline.
summary_2: IBM unveiled a new Hudson Valley factory, praised by NY Gov. Pataki. Expected to generate many jobs, it'll focus on innovation despite cost & risks. IBM sold its hard drive biz to Hitachi, closed some chip plants, but sees potential in high-demand advanced chips. Experts predict the new plant will stay strong, even if parts of the semiconductor market struggle.
summary_3: IBM's new Hudson Valley factory, lauded by Gov. Pataki, aims to create numerous jobs and prioritize innovation, focusing on high-demand advanced chips, potentially overcoming industry challenges.

text: The center of an atom is held together by powerful forces.This gives them a huge amount of stored energy.This type of energy is called nuclear energy.This energy can be released and used to do work.This happens in nuclear power plants where they split apart the nucleus of an atom.This splitting apart is called nuclear fission.Another type of nuclear energy happens in the Sun.Here the atoms nuclei are not split apart.Instead, the nuclei of the atoms are fused, or joined together.This process is called nuclear fusion.Some of the suns energy travels to Earth.This energy from nuclear fusion warms the planet and provides the energy for photosynthesis.
summary_1: Nuclear energy dominates the core of atoms due to potent binding forces, resulting in substantial stored energy. This formidable potential energy, known as nuclear energy, can be harnessed and utilized for various tasks. Nuclear power plants employ nuclear fission, which involves dismantling atomic nuclei, thereby releasing this bound energy. Conversely, distinct nuclear reactions occur within our life-giving star, the Sun. Instead of undergoing fission, solar energy originates from nuclear fusion—the amalgamation of atomic nuclei. A portion of this celestial energy permeates Earth's atmosphere, providing warmth and fueling photosynthetic processes that sustain ecosystems.
summary_2: Nuclear energy, held by atomic bonds, powers atoms and can be tapped for tasks via nuclear fission in power plants or through solar fusion from stars like our sun, offering warmth and supporting photosynthesis on earth.
summary_3: Nuclear energy, harnessed through nuclear fission in power plants or stellar fusion, supplies tasks with atomic power, providing Earth's warmth and supporting photosynthesis.

text: As for engravings, Durer's work was restricted to portraits and illustrations for his treatise.The portraits include Cardinal-Elector Albert of Mainz; Frederick the Wise, elector of Saxony; the humanist scholar Willibald Pirckheimer; Philipp Melanchthon, and Erasmus of Rotterdam.For those of the Cardinal, Melanchthon, and Durer's final major work, a drawn portrait of the Nuremberg patrician Ulrich Starck, Durer depicted the sitters in profile, perhaps reflecting a more mathematical approach.Despite complaining of his lack of a formal classical education, Durer was greatly interested in intellectual matters and learned much from his boyhood friend Willibald Pirckheimer, whom he no doubt consulted on the content of many of his images.He also derived great satisfaction from his friendships and correspondence with Erasmus and other scholars.Durer succeeded in producing two books during his lifetime."The Four Books on Measurement" were published at Nuremberg in 1525 and was the first book for adults on mathematics in German, as well as being cited later by Galileo and Kepler.The other, a work on city fortifications, was published in 1527."The Four Books on Human Proportion" were published posthumously, shortly after his death in 1528.
summary_1: Albrecht Dürer focused solely on creating portraits and illustrating his treatise regarding engravings. His subjects included notable figures such as Cardinal-Elector Albert of Mainz, Elector Frederick the Wise of Saxony, intellectuals like Willibald Pirckheimer, Philipp Melanchthon, and Erasmus of Rotterdam. In three instances - the cardinal, Melanchthon, and Dürer's last significant piece featuring Nuremberg aristocrat Ulrich Starck - he chose to depict them in profile, possibly hinting at a more scientific or mathematical perspective. Despite bemoaning his limited classical education, Dürer gained substantial knowledge from his childhood companion, Willibald Pirckheimer, who likely influenced the themes present in numerous artworks. Furthermore, Dürer cultivated meaningful relationships and exchanged letters with renowned minds including Erasmus. Throughout his life, Dürer authored two publications: "The Four Books on Measurement," released in 1525, which became the inaugural adult-oriented math book written in German and would later influence both Galileo and Johannes Kepler; and a manual on urban defenses printed in 1527. Posthumously, "The Four Books on Human Proportion" emerged in 1528, shortly after his passing.
summary_2: Dürer concentrated on portraiture, notably painting influential individuals like Cardinal-Elector Albert of Mainz and scholars Willibald Pirckheimer and Erasmus of Rotterdam. He also wrote two books, one being Germany's first adult mathematics book. Known for detailed profiles, Dürer was self-taught but benefited from friendships with learned contemporaries.
summary_3: Albrecht Dürer excelled at portrait painting, producing renowned works featuring figures such as Cardinal-Elector Albert of Mainz and scholars Willibald Pirckheimer and Erasmus of Rotterdam; he also authored two significant books, including Germany's inaugural adult mathematics textbook, while honing his skills through scholarly connections despite his self-taught background.

text: Charlie Y. Reader is a 35-year-old theatrical agent in New York , living a seemingly idyllic life as a bachelor .Numerous women ( among them Poppy , Helen , and Jessica come and go , cleaning and cooking for him .Charlie 's best friend since kindergarten , Joe McCall , who has a wife named Ethel and children in Indianapolis , comes to New York for a stay at Charlie 's apartment , claiming that the excitement is gone from his 11-year marriage and that he wants to leave his wife .Joe envies and is amazed by Charlie 's parade of girlfriends , while Charlie professes admiration for Joe 's married life and family .At an audition , Charlie meets singer-actress Julie Gillis .She has her life planned to a tight schedule , determined to marry and retire from performing to a life of child-rearing by 22 .Although at first she wards off Charlie 's advances , she comes to see him as the ideal man for her plans .Julie demands that Charlie stop seeing other women .Charlie balks , but he begins to fall in love with her .Joe starts keeping company with Sylvia Crewes , a sophisticated classical musician and a typically neglected lover of Charlie 's .Sylvia is approaching 33 and desires marriage as much as the younger Julie does .One day , annoyed by Julie and possibly jealous of Joe 's attentions , Charlie blurts out a proposal of marriage to Sylvia .She is thrilled , only to discover the morning after their engagement party that he has proposed to Julie as well .Joe confesses his love to Sylvia and asks her to marry him .
summary_1: Charlie Y. Reader, a 35-year-old theatrical agent in New York, enjoys a carefree bachelor lifestyle with numerous women attending to his needs. His longtime friend, Joe McCall, visits from Indianapolis, expressing dissatisfaction with his 11-year marriage and desire to separate from his wife. Joe admires Charlie's freedom and string of girlfriends, while Charlie admires Joe's stable family life. At an audition, Charlie encounters aspiring singer-actress Julie Gillis, who intends to marry and have children by age 22. Initially resisting Charlie's advances, she later views him as her ideal partner. She insists that Charlie ends relationships with other women, causing tension between them. Meanwhile, Joe becomes involved with Sylvia Crewes, one of Charlie's often overlooked lovers. Approaching 33, Sylvia yearns for marriage like Julie. In a moment of frustration or perhaps jealousy, Charlie impulsively proposes to Sylvia, then realizes he also proposed to Julie. Confused, Sylvia accepts, only to learn about Charlie's dual proposals the next day. Simultaneously, Joe reveals his feelings for Sylvia and proposes.
summary_2: Charlie Reader, a NYC theatrical agent, leads a bachelor life. Friend Joe envies this but wants a divorce. They meet Julie, an aspiring actress set on marrying young. Jealous, Charlie impulsively proposes to Sylvia, another actress vying for marriage. Unaware of each other, both accept Charlie's proposal. Meanwhile, Joe falls for Sylvia too.
summary_3: Two men unknowingly propose to the same two women who also have feelings for them, leading to confusion and unexpected engagements.

text: In 1964 , in the peak of Beatlemania , a reluctant John Lennon is persuaded by manager Brian Epstein to meet Freddie Lennon , the father who abandoned him seventeen years earlier , with the press in attendance .When they meet , John accuses his father of abandoning him , but his father says that `` he left it up to John . ''John and Brian quickly leave the meeting .The movie then jumps to 1967 , after Brian Epstein has died .The Beatles are giving a press conference about their new film , Magical Mystery Tour .John is skeptical about the film , but Paul convinces him to go through with the idea .John then invites his father to his mansion to live with him .Freddie Lennon arrives and meets his grandson , Julian .Sitting with his wife , John reads the criticism of Magical Mystery Tour , while comparing his wife to Brigitte Bardot , whom he says he will meet after he returns from India .John finds a letter addressed to him , with the word `` Breathe '' written on it .Later , after finding his father in a neighbor's house , Freddie reveals that he has a 19 year old girlfriend named Pauline , with whom he wants to live .Lennon accuses his father of leaving him again , and then leaves , after telling his father that he wo n't live with him anymore .After meeting Maharishi Mahesh Yogi , the Beatles quickly return to London , and in a press conference they say they made a mistake when they trusted Maharishi .The journalists are curious about the Beatles new business -- Apple Records .
summary_1: In 1964, amidst Beatlemania, John Lennon, coerced by manager Brian Epstein, encounters Freddie Lennon, his estranged father, in front of the press. The reunion is fraught; John confronts his father about abandonment, but Freddie retorts that John had the choice to join him. Post-meeting, John and Brian depart swiftly. The narrative then shifts to 1967, post-Brian Epstein's demise. The Beatles announce their upcoming film, Magical Mystery Tour, at a press conference. Despite John's reservations, Paul convinces him to proceed. John, in a surprising turn, invites his father to reside with him. Freddie visits, meets Julian, and later introduces his 19-year-old girlfriend, Pauline. An argument ensues between John and Freddie, culminating in Freddie's departure due to his desire to live with Pauline. Following this, John receives a mysterious letter marked "Breathe". Upon discovering Freddie in a neighbor's home, John learns of his father's intentions to live with Pauline, prompting another falling out. Post-Maharishi Mahesh Yogi encounter, the Beatles admit their error in trusting him during a press conference. Journalists express curiosity about the Beatles' latest venture - Apple Records.
summary_2: In '64, under pressure from manager Brian Epstein, John Lennon reunites with absentee dad Freddie after Beatlemania. In '67, despite initial reluctance, John involves Freddie in his life again, leading to conflict over Freddie's young girlfriend. After Freddie leaves, John finds a cryptic note, revealing Freddie's plans to move in with his girlfriend. Amidst these personal issues, the Beatles navigate professional challenges, including disputes with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi and launching Apple Records.
summary_3: John reconnects with estranged father Freddie amidst Beatlemania in 1964, experiences conflict in 1967 due to Freddie's younger girlfriend, and navigates personal and professional challenges, including tensions within the band and launching Apple Records.

text: In architecture Durer cites Vitruvius but elaborates his own classical designs and columns.In typography, Durer depicts the geometric construction of the Latin alphabet, relying on Italian precedent.However, his construction of the Gothic alphabet is based upon an entirely different modular system.The fourth book completes the progression of the first and second by moving to three-dimensional forms and the construction of polyhedra.Here Durer discusses the five Platonic solids, as well as seven Archimedean semi-regular solids, as well as several of his own invention.In all these, Durer shows the objects as nets.Finally, Durer discusses the Delian Problem and moves on to the 'construzione legittima', a method of depicting a cube in two dimensions through linear perspective.It was in Bologna that Durer was taught (possibly by Luca Pacioli or Bramante) the principles of linear perspective, and evidently became familiar with the 'costruzione legittima' in a written description of these principles found only, at this time, in the unpublished treatise of Piero della Francesca.He was also familiar with the 'abbreviated construction' as described by Alberti and the geometrical construction of shadows, a technique of Leonardo da Vinci.Although Durer made no innovations in these areas, he is notable as the first Northern European to treat matters of visual representation in a scientific way, and with understanding of Euclidean principles.In addition to these geometrical constructions, Durer discusses in this last book of Underweysung der Messung an assortment of mechanisms for drawing in perspective from models and provides woodcut illustrations of these methods that are often reproduced in discussions of perspective.
summary_1: Durer's "Underweysung der Messung" explores architecture, typography, and geometry. In architecture, Durer references Vitruvius but develops personal classical designs and columns. His typography displays the Latin alphabet's geometric construction, influenced by Italians. However, his Gothic alphabet creation uses a distinct module system. The fourth book extends the initial two books' concepts into three-dimensional structures and polyhedron construction. Here, Durer examines the five Platonic solids, seven Archimedean semi-regular solids, and some self-invented ones, presenting them as nets. He then delves into the Delian Problem before discussing 'construzione legittima,' a method of portraying cubes in two dimensions via linear perspective. Likely learning about linear perspective in Bologna, possibly from Luca Pacioli or Bramante, Durer applies the principles outlined in Piero della Francesca's unpublished treatise. Additionally, Durer understands Alberti's 'abbreviated construction' and Leonardo da Vinci's shadow geometrical construction techniques. While making no inventions here, Durer becomes the first Northern European to approach visual representation mathematically, demonstrating comprehension of Euclidian principles. Furthermore, Durer outlines various apparatuses for drawing in perspective from models, supplying related woodcut images.
summary_2: Albrecht Dürer's "Underweysung der Messung" covers architecture, typography, and geometry. It references Vitruvius in architecture, presents geometric Latin alphabets influenced by Italians, and introduces a unique module system for Gothic letters. The third book extends these ideas to 3D structures and polyhedrons, covering Platonic and Archimedean solids. Dürer discusses the Delian Problem, 'construzione legittima', and shadow geometrical constructions, showcasing understanding of Italian mathematical methods. Despite not introducing new theories, Dürer is the first Northern European to apply such mathematical rigor to visual representation, indicating familiarity with Euclidian principles.
summary_3: Dürer's "Underweysung der Messung" explores architecture, typography, and geometry, applying Italian mathematical methods to visual representation, including unique modules for Gothic letters and 3D structures, demonstrating familiarity with Euclidian principles.

text: After arriving in New York City, Einstein was taken to various places and events, including Chinatown, a lunch with the editors of the New York Times, and a performance of Carmen at the Metropolitan Opera, where he was cheered by the audience on his arrival.During the days following, he was given the keys to the city by Mayor Jimmy Walker and met the president of Columbia University, who described Einstein as "The ruling monarch of the mind."Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor at New York's Riverside Church, gave Einstein a tour of the church and showed him a full-size statue that the church made of Einstein, standing at the entrance.Also during his stay in New York, he joined a crowd of 15,000 people at Madison Square Garden during a Hanukkah celebration.Einstein next traveled to California where he met Caltech president and Nobel laureate, Robert A. Millikan.His friendship with Millikan was "awkward", as Millikan "had a penchant for patriotic militarism," where Einstein was a pronounced pacifist.During an address to Caltech's students, Einstein noted that science was often inclined to do more harm than good.This aversion to war also led Einstein to befriend author Upton Sinclair and film star Charlie Chaplin, both noted for their pacifism.Carl Laemmle, head of Universal Studios, gave Einstein a tour of his studio and introduced him to Chaplin.They had an instant rapport, with Chaplin inviting Einstein and his wife, Elsa, to his home for dinner.Chaplin said Einstein's outward persona, calm and gentle, seemed to conceal a "highly emotional temperament," from which came his "extraordinary intellectual energy."Chaplin also remembers Elsa telling him about the time Einstein conceived his theory of relativity.During breakfast one morning, he seemed lost in thought and ignored his food.She asked him if something was bothering him.He sat down at his piano and started playing.He continued playing and writing notes for half an hour, then went upstairs to his study, where he remained for two weeks, with Elsa bringing up his food.At the end of the two weeks he came downstairs with two sheets of paper bearing his theory.Chaplin's film, City Lights, was to premier a few days later in Hollywood, and Chaplin invited Einstein and Elsa to join him as his special guests.
summary_1: Upon arriving in NYC, Albert Einstein visited Chinatown, lunched with New York Times editors, attended Carmen at the Met, received the city key from Mayor Jimmy Walker, met Columbia's prez, got shown around Riverside Church, joined 15,000 folks at Madison Square Garden for Hanukkah, headed to Cali, met Caltech's prez Robert A. Millikan, became pals with Upton Sinclair and Charlie Chaplin due to shared pacifism, hung out with Carl Laemmle, chief of Universal Studios, dined with Charlie Chaplin after instantly hitting it off, learned about Einstein's deep focus leading to his groundbreaking theory of relativity.
summary_2: Einstein arrived in NYC, visiting Chinatown and having lunch with New York Times editors. He attended Carmen at the Met, met Columbia's president, toured Riverside Church, and joined 15,000 people at Madison Square Garden for Hanukkah. He then went to California, meeting Caltech's president, befriending Upton Sinclair and Charlie Chaplin due to their shared pacifism. He also met Carl Laemmle, chief of Universal Studios, and had dinner with Charlie Chaplin. His deep focus was noted as instrumental in developing his groundbreaking theory of relativity.
summary_3: After arriving in NYC, Einstein visited Chinatown, lunched with New York Times editors, attended Carmen at the Met, met Columbia's president, toured Riverside Church, joined 15,000 people at Madison Square Garden for Hanukkah, then went to California where he met Caltech's president, befriended Upton Sinclair and Charlie Chaplin due to their shared pacifism, met Carl Laemmle, had dinner with Charlie Chaplin, and developed his groundbreaking theory of relativity, notably due to his deep focus.

text: Do all plants live on the land?Some plants do live in the water.To do this, they have evolved special traits.Plants that live in water are called aquatic plants.Living in water has certain benefits.There is certainly plenty of water!The plant does not need special traits to absorb, transport, or conserve water.They do not need a large root system.They do not need a strong stem to hold up the plant.The plant uses the water for support.Dont think water plants have it easy, though.They also face challenges.Living in water isnt that easy.They do need some special traits to survive.It is tough for the plant to reproduce.Pollination by wind or animals cant happen under water.Sunlight cannot reach very far beneath the waters surface.Some aquatic plants have floating flowers and leaves.
summary_1: Not all plants reside on land; some thrive in aquatic environments. These aquatic plants possess unique characteristics, facilitating their survival in watery habitats. Unlike terrestrial flora, water plants don't require intricate systems for water absorption, transportation, or conservation due to their immersion in water. Consequently, they don't necessitate extensive root systems or robust stems for structural support. Instead, water itself provides buoyancy and support. However, life underwater isn't devoid of challenges for these plants. Reproduction, for instance, poses significant difficulties. Traditional pollination methods involving wind or animals aren't feasible underwater. Furthermore, sunlight penetration decreases dramatically with depth, making photosynthesis challenging. To counteract these obstacles, some aquatic plants have developed strategies such as producing floating flowers and leaves to facilitate reproduction and harness available light.
summary_2: Aquatic plants live in water, differing from land ones by lacking complex water intake/transport systems and requiring less structural support due to buoyancy. Yet, they face hurdles like limited sunlight and difficult reproduction, often resorting to innovative solutions like airborne reproductive parts.
summary_3: Aquatic plants lack intricate water transport systems but benefit from buoyancy, though they encounter challenges such as scarce sunlight and complicated reproduction, sometimes employing creative strategies like floating reproductive components.

text: The Albanians first appear in the historical record in Byzantine sources of the late 11th century.At this point, they were already fully Christianized.Islam later emerged as the majority religion during the centuries of Ottoman rule, though a significant Christian minority remained.After independence (1912) from the Ottoman Empire, the Albanian republican, monarchic and later Communist regimes followed a systematic policy of separating religion from official functions and cultural life.Albania never had an official state religion either as a republic or as a kingdom.In the 20th century, the clergy of all faiths was weakened under the monarchy, and ultimately eradicated during the 1950s and 1960s, under the state policy of obliterating all organized religion from Albanian territories.The Communist regime that took control of Albania after World War II persecuted and suppressed religious observance and institutions and entirely banned religion to the point where Albania was officially declared to be the world's first atheist state.Religious freedom has returned to Albania since the regime's change in 1992.Albania joined the Organisation of the Islamic Conference in 1992, following the fall of the communist government, but will not be attending the 2014 conference due a dispute regarding the fact that its parliament never ratified the country's membership.Albanian Muslim populations (mainly secular and of the Sunni branch) are found throughout the country whereas Albanian Orthodox Christians as well as Bektashis are concentrated in the south and Roman Catholics are found in the north of the country.The first recorded Albanian Protestant was Said Toptani, who traveled around Europe, and in 1853 returned to Tirana and preached Protestantism.He was arrested and imprisoned by the Ottoman authorities in 1864.Mainline evangelical Protestants date back to the work of Congregational and later Methodist missionaries and the work of the British and Foreign Bible Society in the 19th century.The Evangelical Alliance, which is known as VUSh, was founded in 1892.Today VUSh has about 160 member congregations from different Protestant denominations.VUSh organizes marches in Tirana including one against blood feuds in 2010.Bibles are provided by the Interconfessional Bible Society of Albania.The first full Albanian Bible to be printed was the Filipaj translation printed in 1990.
summary_1: Albania's relationship with religion is complex, shaped by history, politics, and geography. The Albanian people first appeared in historical records in the late 11th century, already Christianized. However, Islam became the dominant religion during the Ottoman era, although a substantial Christian community persisted. Post-Ottoman Albanian governments, whether republican, monarchic, or communist, pursued a strict separation of church and state. Albania has never had an official state religion. Under the monarchy, the clergy of all faiths weakened, and under communism, religious expression was virtually eliminated, making Albania the world's first proclaimed atheist state. This changed in 1992 when religious freedoms were restored. Despite joining the Organization of the Islamic Conference in 1992, Albania won't attend the 2014 conference over unratified membership. Religion in Albania is diverse: Muslims (mostly secular Sunnis) are spread nationwide; Orthodox Christians and Bektashis are predominantly in the south; Roman Catholics are mainly in the north. The first documented Albanian Protestant, Said Toptani, emerged in the 19th century, preceding mainline evangelical Protestants introduced through American missions and the British and Foreign Bible Society. Today, the Evangelical Alliance (VUSh), established in 1892, represents various Protestant denominations, numbering approximately 160 member congregations. VUSh, active in social issues like opposing blood feuds, collaborates with the Interconfessional Bible Society of Albania for Bible distribution. The first complete Albanian Bible was published in 1990, the Filipaj translation.
summary_2: Religion in Albania reflects its history and location. Initially Christian, it turned majority Muslim under Ottomans but retained a significant Christian presence. Post-Ottoman governments kept church and state separate, leading to Albania having no official religion. Communism further diminished religious practice, making Albania an officially atheist state. With the fall of communism in 1992, religious freedom returned. Albania is now home to diverse religions, including Sunni Muslims, Orthodox Christians, Bektashis, Roman Catholics, and various Protestant denominations, represented by the Evangelical Alliance.
summary_3: Albania hosts diverse religions today due to historical influences, transitioning from initial Christianity to widespread Islam under Ottomans, then secularization during Communist rule, ultimately embracing religious pluralism after Communism's end in 1992.

text: Sound waves are mechanical waves.They can travel only through matter.They cannot travel through empty space.This was demonstrated in the 1600s by a scientist named Robert Boyle.Boyle placed a ticking clock in a sealed glass jar.The clock could be heard ticking through the air and glass of the jar.Then Boyle pumped the air out of the jar.The clock was still running, but the ticking could not be heard.Thats because the sound couldnt travel without air particles to transfer the sound energy.Is there any other place where sound cannot be heard?Here is a hint: is there any other place that does not have air molecules?Thats right, in space sound cannot be transferred.So can astronauts hear each other?Yes, they can, because they are in enclosed space stations or pressurized suits.In both cases, they are surrounded by air molecules.If they left their space ship and did not use their electronics, they would not be able to hear each other.Next time you watch a science fiction movie, think about this factoid.When spaceships are destroyed by hostile alien beings, there would be no sound heard.Sound waves can travel through many kinds of matter.
summary_1: Sound waves are a type of mechanical wave that require matter to travel, unable to move through empty space. This concept was proven in the 17th century by Robert Boyle. He placed a ticking clock inside a sealed glass jar and observed that even though the clock could be heard ticking while submerged in air and glass, the sound ceased once the air was removed from the jar due to the absence of air particles necessary for sound energy transmission. The ability to hear sounds is thus contingent on the presence of air molecules. Therefore, in an environment devoid of these molecules, such as outer space, sound cannot be transmitted. However, astronauts within enclosed space stations or wearing pressurized suits retain access to audible communication due to the surrounding air molecules. In contrast, if astronauts were to venture outside their spacecraft without electronic devices, they would find themselves unable to hear one another. Consequently, when watching science fiction films depicting destruction of spaceships by extraterrestrial adversaries, it is essential to remember that no sound would actually be produced in the vacuum of space. Sound waves propagate effectively through various mediums; however, their incapacity to traverse voids stems from the necessity of material interaction during transmission.
summary_2: In the 17th century, Robert Boyle demonstrated that sound needs matter to travel, shown when a ticking clock stopped being audible in a vacuum due to lack of air particles for energy transfer. Hence, sound relies on air molecules, making it impossible in outer space. However, astronauts in pressurized environments can still hear due to present air molecules. Without these, as in deep space, sound isn't possible.
summary_3: Sound requires air molecules to travel, which is why there's no sound in deep space, but astronauts in pressurized environments can still hear due to present air molecules.

text: Grande dame of cooking still going strong at 90: Julia Child celebrates in San Francisco.How does it feel to turn 90 and have attained the status of an icon, a living legend?"It feels just like it felt before," Julia Child says with the throaty laugh familiar to millions who cut their culinary teeth on her "French Chef" television series.The show, along with her seminal book, "Mastering the Art of French Cooking" (1961), revolutionized the way America cooks and eats.While making light of the difference a day -- or another decade -- makes, Child intends to enjoy her birthday thoroughly.First, there will be all the public observances, including a sold-out dinner Thursday at San Francisco's tony Fifth Floor restaurant, which -- like dinners that night at 19 other venues across the country -- will benefit the scholarship fund of the International Association of Culinary Professionals (which Child co-founded).Friday to Sunday, the action moves to Napa, with both members-only and public events at COPIA: The American Center for Wine, Food and the Arts, of which she is an honorary board member.Aug. 15, her actual birthday, will see her in Maine at an annual gathering of nieces, nephews, their offspring and friends, who for many years have rolled a joined birthday celebration for several members of the group into a jolly reunion.The schedule Child and her assistant of 14 years, former pastry chef Stephanie Hersh, have laid out is not exactly a senior-citizen routine, even though Child has always been candid about her age and realistic in assessing her own capabilities.When the Pasadena native moved back to California from her long-time home in the Boston area last year, she also made the move from a condominium she and her late husband, Paul, had purchased many years ago to a progressive retirement home.She is in the most active of the four levels available, but should the need arise, she can move on to assisted living facilities within the same complex.
summary_1: Julia Child, aged 90 and a culinary icon, marks her birthday by engaging in various activities. She remains humble despite being an influential figure in transforming American cuisine through her TV show, 'The French Chef', and her groundbreaking book, 'Mastering the Art of French Cooking'. Her milestone coincides with numerous events, such as a dinner at San Francisco's Fifth Floor restaurant, benefiting the International Association of Culinary Professionals' scholarship fund. Further festivities take place at COPIA: The American Center for Wine, Food and the Arts in Napa over the weekend. On August 15th, her actual birthdate, Child reunites with family and friends in Maine. Despite moving to a retirement home in California after her husband's passing, Child maintains her active lifestyle while acknowledging her age and preparing for potential transitions within the facility.
summary_2: Celebrating her 90th birthday, Julia Child engages in charitable dining events and gatherings, including a dinner in San Francisco and a festival at COPIA. Still humble, she balances aging with activity, maintaining connections in Maine where she gathers with loved ones on her actual birthdate.
summary_3: Julia Child celebrates her 90th birthday by engaging in charity dinners and festivals, while remaining active and connected in Maine.

text: One day a young boy went to visit a toy store.In the toy store the young boy found many fun toys.One toy that the boy really liked was a small blue toy truck.The small blue toy truck was a lot of fun to play with, and made a lot of funny noises.The young boy played with the toy truck for a long time, and then another little boy showed up and began to play with a little red car.The two boys ended up becoming friends and played with the toys for a long time.They ended up becoming good friends and had many play dates together over the months ahead.On one play date the two boys built a large tree house and called it the tree castle.They played for hours in the tree castle and always found something fun to do when they played together.They were glad that they met in the toy store and became life-long friends.
summary_1: A young boy visited a toy store and discovered various entertaining toys. Among them, he particularly enjoyed a miniature blue toy vehicle due to its amusing sounds. Another child arrived, playing with a crimson automobile. The children bonded, engaging in extended play sessions. They eventually constructed a "tree castle," spending enjoyable hours there. Grateful for their serendipitous encounter at the toy store, they formed enduring friendships.
summary_2: Two boys meet at a toy shop, bonding over toy cars. They build a "tree castle" together, leading to lasting friendships.
summary_3: Two boys meet at a toy store, bonding over toy cars, and constructing a treehouse together that fosters enduring friendships.

text: { { plot } } In 1964 , in the peak of Beatlemania , a reluctant John Lennon is persuaded by manager Brian Epstein to meet Freddie Lennon , the father who abandoned him seventeen years earlier , with the press in attendance . When they meet , John accuses his father of abandoning him , but his father says that `` he left it up to John . '' John and Brian quickly leave the meeting . The movie then jumps to 1967 , after Brian Epstein has died . The Beatles are giving a press conference about their new film, Magical Mystery Tour . John is skeptical about the film , but Paul ( ( ( Andrew Scott convinces him to go through with the idea . John then invites his father to his mansion to live with him . Freddie Lennon arrives and meets his grandson , Julian . Sitting with his wife , John reads the criticism of Magical Mystery Tour , while comparing his wife to Brigitte Bardot , whom he says he will meet after he returns from India . John finds a letter addressed to him , with the word `` Breathe '' written on it . Later , after finding his father in a neighbor's house , Freddie reveals that he has a 19 year old girlfriend named Pauline , with whom he wants to live . Lennon accuses his father of leaving him again , and then leaves , after telling his father that he wo n't live with him anymore . After meeting Maharishi Mahesh Yogi , the Beatles quickly return to London , and in a press conference they say they made a mistake when they trusted Maharishi . The journalists are curious about the Beatles new business -- Apple Records .
summary_1: In 1964, amidst Beatlemania, John Lennon, coerced by manager Brian Epstein, encounters Freddie Lennon, his estranged father, in front of the press. John confronts Freddie about abandonment, but Freddie retorts that John had the choice to join him. Post Brian Epstein's death in 1967, during a press conference for "Magical Mystery Tour," John expresses doubts, but Paul persuades him to proceed. Inviting Freddie to stay, Freddie bonds with Julian, John's son. Amid reading negative reviews of "Magical Mystery Tour" and comparing his partner to Brigitte Bardot, John discovers a mysterious letter marked 'Breathe'. Following a revelation of Freddie's teenage girlfriend, Pauline, John feels betrayed and ends contact. Meeting Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the Beatles later disassociate themselves from him publicly. Upon returning to London, they introduce Apple Records at a press conference.
summary_2: In 1964, under pressure from manager Brian Epstein, John Lennon meets estranged father Freddie due to media attention. After Epstein's 1967 death, John reveals doubts about "Magical Mystery Tour," but Paul convinces him to continue. Freddie reconciles with John's son, Julian, before being cut off after John finds out about Freddie's past relationship with Pauline. The Beatles meet guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, then launch Apple Records.
summary_3: In 1964, under Brian Epstein's pressure, John Lennon met his father due to media attention; post-Epstein's 1967 death, despite John's doubts, Paul convinced him to proceed with "Magical Mystery Tour"; John's father reconciled with Julian before their relation was severed due to John's discovery of Freddie's past relationship with Pauline; the Beatles then encountered guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi and established Apple Records.

text: The Vice President stated that he called the President to discuss the rules of engagement for the CAP.He recalled feeling that it did no good to establish the CAP unless the pilots had instructions on whether they were authorized to shoot if the plane would not divert.He said the President signed off on that concept.The President said he remembered such a conversation, and that it reminded him of when he had been an interceptor pilot.The President emphasized to us that he had authorized the shootdown of hijacked aircraft.The Vice President's military aide told us he believed the Vice President spoke to the President just after entering the conference room, but he did not hear what they said.Rice, who entered the room shortly after the Vice President and sat next to him, remembered hearing him inform the President, "Sir, the CAPs are up.Sir, they're going to want to know what to do."Then she recalled hearing him say, "Yes sir."She believed this conversation occurred a few minutes, perhaps five, after they entered the conference room.We believe this call would have taken place sometime before 10:10 to 10:15.Among the sources that reflect other important events of that morning, there is no documentary evidence for this call, but the relevant sources are incomplete.Others nearby who were taking notes, such as the Vice President's chief of staff, Scooter Libby, who sat next to him, and Mrs. Cheney, did not note a call between the President and Vice President immediately after the Vice President entered the conference room.At 10:02, the communicators in the shelter began receiving reports from the Secret Service of an inbound aircraft-presumably hijacked-heading toward Washington.That aircraft was United 93.The Secret Service was getting this information directly from the FAA.The FAA may have been tracking the progress of United 93 on a display that showed its projected path to Washington, not its actual radar return.Thus, the Secret Service was relying on projections and was not aware the plane was already down in Pennsylvania.
summary_1: Vice President Bush recounted discussing rules of engagement concerning the combat air patrol (CAP) with President Bush. He felt compelled to clarify whether pilots could open fire if planes failed to deviate. The President agreed with this approach, recalling his past experience as an interceptor pilot. Emphasizing his authorization for shooting down hijacked aircraft, he highlighted the necessity of clear guidelines. However, there is no concrete documentation confirming their discussion at the time. Rice, seated beside the Vice President during the meeting, overheard him conveying updates about the CAP status to the President, affirming, "They're going to want to know what to do" followed by a "Yes, Sir". This interaction likely transpired around 10:02 - 10:15 AM. Meanwhile, the Secret Service received alerts regarding an incoming aircraft, presumably hijacked, heading towards Washington, which later crashed in Pennsylvania. Despite these reports, there is no mention of any visual confirmation of the aircraft's location due to reliance on estimated trajectory rather than real-time radar data.
summary_2: VP Bush discussed combat air patrol rules with President Bush, deciding that pilots could shoot down noncompliant planes. Though unconfirmed, it seems they spoke around 10:02-10:15 AM. Nearby, the Secret Service learned of a possible hijacking en route to DC. Clear orders were essential, but actual sightings of the plane weren't mentioned. National security was prioritized without harming innocent lives.
summary_3: VP Bush and President Bush decided pilots could engage noncompliant planes in combat air patrol, likely speaking at 10:02-10:15 AM, while the Secret Service prepared for a potential hijacking near DC, emphasizing national security without endangering innocents despite lacking visual confirmation.

text: Zinni feared that  Bin Laden would in the future locate himself in cities, where U.S. missiles could kill thousands of Afghans.He worried also lest Pakistani authorities not get adequate warning, think the missiles came from India, RESPONSES TO AL QAEDA'S INITIAL ASSAULTS 135 and do something that everyone would later regret.Discussing potential repercussions in the region of his military responsibility, Zinni said, "It was easy to take the shot from Washington and walk away from it.We had to live there."Zinni's distinct preference would have been to build up counterterrorism capabilities in neighboring countries such as Uzbekistan.But he told us that he could not drum up much interest in or money for such a purpose from Washington, partly, he thought, because these countries had dictatorial governments.After the decision-in which fear of collateral damage was an important factor- not to use cruise missiles against Kandahar in December 1998, Shelton and officers in the Pentagon developed plans for using an AC-130 gunship instead of cruise missile strikes.Designed specifically for the special forces, the version of the AC-130 known as "Spooky"can fly in fast or from high altitude, undetected by radar; guided to its zone by extraordinarily complex electronics, it is capable of rapidly firing precision-guided 25, 40, and 105 mm projectiles.Because this system could target more precisely than a salvo of cruise missiles, it had a much lower risk of causing collateral damage.After giving Clarke a briefing and being encouraged to proceed, Shelton formally directed Zinni and General Peter Schoomaker, who headed the Special Operations Command, to develop plans for an AC-130 mission against  Bin Laden's headquarters and infrastructure in Afghanistan.The Joint Staff prepared a decision paper for deployment of the Special Operations aircraft.Though Berger and Clarke continued to indicate interest in this option, the AC-130s were never deployed.Clarke wrote at the time that Zinni opposed their use, and John Maher, the Joint Staff 's deputy director of operations, agreed that this was Zinni's position.Zinni himself does not recall blocking the option.He told us that he understood the Special Operations Command had never thought the intelligence good enough to justify actually moving AC-130s into position.Schoomaker says, on the contrary, that he thought the AC-130 option feasible.The most likely explanation for the two generals' differing recollections is that both of them thought serious preparation for any such operations would require a long-term redeployment of Special Operations forces to the Middle East or South Asia.The AC-130s would need bases because the aircraft's unrefueled range was only a little over 2,000 miles.
summary_1: General Zinni expressed concerns about potential consequences if they targeted Bin Laden in Afghan cities with US missiles, potentially killing many locals and straining relations with Pakistan. He preferred building counterterrorism capabilities in nearby nations like Uzbekistan but faced lack of interest and funding from Washington due to those countries' authoritarian regimes. Post the failed December 1998 plan to strike Kandahar with cruise missiles, Shelton and other Pentagon officials devised a strategy utilizing an advanced AC-130 gunship instead. This Spooky model boasted superior precision compared to cruise missiles, thus reducing risks of collateral damage significantly. After receiving encouragement from Clarke, Shelton ordered Zinni and General Schoomaker to strategize an AC-130 mission against Bin Laden's base in Afghanistan. The Joint Staff drafted a decision memo for deploying the specialized aircraft. Despite ongoing interest from Berger and Clarke, no further action was taken. Both Zinni and Schoomaker have different recollections regarding whether the operation was blocked due to insufficient intelligence or reluctance towards long-term force relocation to the Middle East/South Asia.
summary_2: Zinni cautions against targeting Bin Laden in Afghan cities, favoring development of counterterrorism abilities in neighboring states. However, this initiative faces disinterest and funding issues from Washington due to these nations' oppressive governments. Following a failed attempt to attack Kandahar, Shelton proposes using an advanced AC-130 gunship instead, offering better accuracy and lessening chances of civilian casualties. Encouraged by Clarke, Shelton directs Zinni and Schoomaker to prepare an AC-130 mission against Bin Laden's base in Afghanistan. A decision memo is prepared for deploying the unique aircraft, yet no additional steps follow despite continued curiosity from Berger and Clarke. Disagreement remains over reasons behind non-implementation - either insufficient intel or hesitancy towards prolonged military presence in the region.
summary_3: Despite Zinni advocating for developing counterterrorism capabilities in neighboring states over targeting Bin Laden in Afghan cities, Washington shows little interest due to these countries' oppressive regimes; although Shelton suggests using an advanced AC-130 gunship for precision and minimizing civil casualties, no further action is taken, leaving uncertainty whether it's due to lack of intelligence or reluctance for long military involvement.

text: At the conference room table was White House Deputy Chief of Staff Joshua Bolten.Bolten watched the exchanges and, after what he called "a quiet moment,"suggested that the Vice President get in touch with the President and confirm the engage order.Bolten told us he wanted to make sure the President was told that the Vice President had executed the order.He said he had not heard any prior discussion on the subject with the President.The Vice President was logged calling the President at 10:18 for a twominute conversation that obtained the confirmation.On Air Force One, the President's press secretary was taking notes; Ari Fleischer recorded that at 10:20, the President told him that he had authorized a shootdown of aircraft if necessary.Minutes went by and word arrived of an aircraft down in Pennsylvania.Those in the shelter wondered if the aircraft had been shot down pursuant to this authorization.At approximately 10:30, the shelter started receiving reports of another hijacked plane, this time only 5 to 10 miles out.Believing they had only a minute or two, the Vice President again communicated the authorization to "engage or "take out" the aircraft.At 10:33, Hadley told the air threat conference call: "I need to get word to Dick Myers that our reports are there's an inbound aircraft flying low 5 miles out.The Vice President's guidance was we need to take them out."Once again, there was no immediate information about the fate of the inbound aircraft.In the apt description of one witness, "It drops below the radar screen and it's just continually hovering in your imagination; you don't know where it is or what happens to it."Eventually, the shelter received word that the alleged hijacker 5 miles away had been a medevac helicopter.Transmission of the Authorization from the White House to the Pilots The NMCC learned of United 93's hijacking at about 10:03.At this time the FAA had no contact with the military at the level of national command.The NMCC learned about United 93 from the White House.
summary_1: White House Deputy Chief Josh Bolten suggested Vice President Cheney check with President Bush to confirm the engage order. After a "quiet moment", Cheney contacted Bush at 10:18 for a two-minute conversation securing the confirmation. At 10:20, Bush informed his press secretary Ari Fleischer that he had authorized shooting down aircraft if required. Minutes later, news came in of a plane down in Pennsylvania, leading to speculation about its connection to the authorization. Around 10:30, reports emerged of another hijacked plane nearby. Believing they had only minutes before impact, Cheney reiterated the authorization to "engage or 'take out'" the aircraft. However, details regarding the outcome remained unclear until it became known that the suspected hijacker was actually a medical evacuation helicopter. The National Military Command Center (NMCC) learned about United Flight 93's hijacking around 10:03 but didn't have direct communication with the military at the national command level. Instead, they were informed through the White House.
summary_2: At 10:18 am on September 11, 2001, Vice President Dick Cheney sought approval from President George W. Bush to shoot down suspicious planes. After a brief pause, Bush confirmed the order in a two-minute call. By 10:20 am, Bush announced the authorization to media personnel Ari Fleischer. Later, an unrelated plane crash in Pennsylvania sparked speculations about its relation to the clearance. Reports of another hijacked flight emerged shortly after, prompting Cheney to repeat the authorization. It was later discovered that the supposed hijacker was a medical evacuation helicopter. Despite learning about United Flight 93's hijack at 10:03 am, the National Military Command Center received information via the White House instead of directly from the military.
summary_3: At 10:18 am on September 11, 2001, Vice President Dick Cheney sought approval from President George W. Bush to shoot down suspicious planes, which Bush authorized in a two-minute call and later announced to media personnel; despite learning about United Flight 93's hijack at 10:03 am, the National Military Command Center received information via the White House instead of directly from the military.

text: PHOTOGRAPH COLLECTING gains new stature as prices rise.Price records are being set at auctions this week.At Christie's, a folio of 21 prints from Alfred Stieglitz's "Equivalents" series sold for $396,000, a single-lot record.Other works also have been exceeding price estimates.In part, prices reflect development of a market structure based on such variables as the number of prints.This information used to be poorly documented and largely anecdotal, says Beth Gates-Warren of Sotheby's."There is finally some sort of sense in the market," she says.Corporations and museums are among the serious buyers, giving greater market stability, says Robert Persky of the Photograph Collector."When I see prints going into the hands of institutions, I know they aren't going to come back on the market."Most in demand: classic photographs by masters such as Stieglitz and Man Ray.But much contemporary work is also fetching "a great deal of money," says Miles Barth of the International Center of Photography.
summary_1: Photography collecting has gained significant recognition due to rising prices, with auction sales setting new records. At Christie's, a folio of 21 prints from Alfred Stieglitz's "Equivalents" series was sold for $396,000, marking a single-lot record. Other works have surpassed their estimated prices, thanks to the establishment of a market structure that considers various factors like the quantity of prints available. This data was previously poorly documented and mostly anecdotal. According to Beth Gates-Warren of Sotheby's, there is now more consistency in the market. Corporate entities and museums are among the dedicated buyers contributing to market stability. Works by prominent photographers like Stieglitz and Man Ray are highly sought after classics. However, modern photography is also garnering substantial amounts of money, emphasizes Miles Barth of the International Center of Photography.
summary_2: Photography auctions at Christie's set new price records, with Alfred Stieglitz's "Equivalents" folio selling for $396,000. Market consistency has improved due to increased documentation and corporate/museum purchases. Both classic and modern photography pieces, such as those by Stieglitz and Man Ray, fetch high sums.
summary_3: At Christie's, Alfred Stieglitz's "Equivalents" folio sold for $396,000, reflecting strong demand for both classic and modern photography.

text: Clarifying the Record The defense of U.S. airspace on 9/11 was not conducted in accord with preexisting training and protocols.It was improvised by civilians who had never handled a hijacked aircraft that attempted to disappear, and by a military unprepared for the transformation of commercial aircraft into weapons of mass destruction.As it turned out, the NEADS air defenders had nine minutes' notice on the first hijacked plane, no advance notice on the second, no advance notice on the third, and no advance notice on the fourth.We do not believe that the true picture of that morning reflects discredit on the operational personnel at NEADS or FAA facilities.NEADS commanders and officers actively sought out information, and made the best judgments they could on the basis of what they knew.Individual FAA controllers, facility managers, and Command Center managers thought outside the box in recommending a nationwide alert, in ground-stopping local traffic, and, ultimately, in deciding to land all aircraft and executing that unprecedented order flawlessly.More than the actual events, inaccurate government accounts of those events made it appear that the military was notified in time to respond to two of the hijackings, raising questions about the adequacy of the response.Those accounts had the effect of deflecting questions about the military's capacity to obtain timely and accurate information from its own sources.In addition, they overstated the FAA's ability to provide the military with timely and useful information that morning.In public testimony before this Commission in May 2003, NORAD officials stated that at 9:16, NEADS received hijack notification of United 93 from the FAA.This statement was incorrect.There was no hijack to report at 9:16.United 93 was proceeding normally at that time.In this same public testimony, NORAD officials stated that at 9:24, NEADS received notification of the hijacking of American 77.This statement was also
