text: (CNN) -- Shain Gandee, one of the stars of the MTV reality show "Buckwild," has been found dead along with two other people in Kanawha County, West Virginia, authorities said Monday."This is a very sad and tragic event," Kanawha County Commissioner Kent Carper said."We live in a very small community.Our thoughts and prayers are with the Gandee family."Gandee, 21, was found dead in a vehicle along with his uncle, David Dwight Gandee, 48, and Donald Robert Myers, 27, authorities said.'Buckwild' producer talks about the show "Earlier this day after releasing information Shain Gandee was missing, the Kanawha County Sheriff's Office received word of a disabled vehicle in a wooded area near Thaxton Hollow, Sissonville, Kanawha County WV," said a statement from the Sheriff's Office."Deputies and members of the Sissonville Volunteer Fire Department used all terrain vehicles to access that vehicle, a 1984 Ford Bronco belonging to the Gandee family.The vehicle was in a muddy area along a worn path.Inside were the bodies of three people."In a subsequent release, the Sheriff's Office said the vehicle was partially submerged in mud.It was uneven but upright; its muffler was below the surface.Mud covered the lower part of the Bronco's passenger side door, but the driver's side, where the younger Gandee sat, was free, the Sheriff's Office said.Gandee was happy with life before death He was one of the nine cast members of "Buckwild."The show follows a group of young adults trying to have fun in Sissonville, West Virginia, pulling stunts such as turning a dump truck into a swimming pool or just riding around the woods on their all-terrain vehicles.Gandee was billed as a former high school prom king who had done "every job from coal mining to being a garbage man."
summary_1: Shain Gandee, a star of MTV's "Buckwild," was discovered deceased in Kanawha County, West Virginia, alongside his uncle, David Dwight Gandee, and Donald Robert Myers. The trio was found inside a 1984 Ford Bronco in a muddy, wooded region known as Thaxton Hollow, Sissonville. Authorities believe they died due to carbon monoxide poisoning caused by the vehicle's exhaust filling the enclosed space. Gandee, 21, gained fame for his role on "Buckwild," which featured a group of young adults enjoying their lives in rural West Virginia through various antics. Known for his charm and friendly demeanor, he was once a local high school prom king and held several jobs, including coal mining and waste disposal duties. Officials expressed their condolences to the Gandee family, emphasizing the close-knit nature of their community during this difficult time.
summary_2: MTV's "Buckwild" star Shain Gandee, 21, was found dead in West Virginia with two others, due to suspected carbon monoxide poisoning from a running car in an enclosed area. He was popular for his charm and roles in "Buckwild." Found in a muddy hollow, officials suspect death occurred after the car engine filled the space with toxic fumes. Gandee, former local high school prom king, had also worked as a miner and garbage collector. His loss deeply affects the tight-knit community, who share their sympathies with the Gandee family.
summary_3: Shain Gandee, 21, a star of MTV's "Buckwild," was found dead in West Virginia from apparent carbon monoxide poisoning, causing grief in his close-knit community.

text: The film is set in Igloolik in the Eastern Arctic wilderness at the dawn of the first millennium . http://atanarjuat.com/legend/legend_film.php The wind is blowing over a bleak snowy landscape while a man tries to herd away some marauding dogs . We hear the voice of an old man singing a childish song . Inside a stone house a strange shaman by the name of Tungajuaq , who comes from up north , is singing playfully to the gathered community and camp leader Kumaglak . But among the spectators there are some mistrustful faces . Flash forward to another day . Qulitalik is bidding goodbye to his sister Panikpak , wife of Kumaglak , promising to come if she calls for help in her heart . She gives him her husband's rabbit's foot for spiritual power . Qulitalik tells his sister , `` Tulimaq is the one they 'll go after now . '' It seems that Qulitalik is leaving to escape a threat , and the hope is that one day he will return to help . As Panikpak watches him leave , we hear a voice-over from a woman : `` We never knew what he was or why it happened . Evil came to us like Death . It just happened and we had to live with it . '' Flash back to the original scene in the stone house . The visitor and the camp leader Kumaglak are in a `` friendly '' spiritual duel involving binding in leather thongs . But Panikpak is startled when the stone lamp in front of her breaks in half , and , to the horror of those present , Kumaglak falls over dead . The visitor removes the leader's walrus-tooth necklace from Kumaglak's body , and , passing by Tulimaq , he puts the necklace around the neck of Sauri , the son of the murdered leader Kumaglak , saying , `` Be careful what you wish for '' .
summary_1: In the opening scene of "Atanarjuat," a blizzard sweeps across Igloolik, a desolate area in the Eastern Arctic during the first millennium. A man struggles to control a pack of aggressive dogs amidst this barren terrain. An elderly man sings a nursery rhyme as background narration. In a communal dwelling, a mystical figure named Tungajuaq entertains the crowd, including chief Kumaglak, with whimsical songs. However, not everyone appears comfortable with his presence. Later, Qulitalik parts ways with his sister Panikpak, spouse of Kumaglak, gifting her late husband's rabbit talisman for protection. He departs, intending to avoid danger but hopes to aid them someday. Panikpak tearfully observes his departure, interjected with a flashback narrative from an anonymous female speaker recounting their misfortune - evil befell them without warning, causing suffering. Returning to the initial scene, Tungajuaq engages in a spiritual battle with Kumaglak using leather bindings. When a nearby oil lamp suddenly splits, Kumaglak collapses, marking his untimely death. After removing Kumaglak's neckpiece, Tungajuaq places it on young Sauri, the deceased leader's offspring, whispering, "Beware of what you desire."
summary_2: A blizzard strikes Igloolik, where a man restrains vicious dogs while an elder sings a lullaby. Entertainer Tungajuaq performs at a gathering, though some seem uneasy around him. Husbandless Panikpak receives her late spouse's talisman from brother Qulitalik before he leaves, fearful of impending doom. Flashbacks reveal past calamity. As Tungajuaq duels spiritually with Chief Kumaglak, an oil lamp shatters, killing Kumaglak instantly. Posthumously adorning son Sauri with Kumaglak's amulet, Tungajuaq warns, "Fear your desires."
summary_3: During a storm in Igloolik, a man controls dangerous dogs while an elder sings; entertainer Tungajuaq performs amidst discomfort, later engaging in spiritual combat with Chief Kumaglak, who dies when an oil lamp breaks; his final words advise his son to fear his desires, foreshadowing danger.

text: Reducing resource use means just what it says using fewer resources.There are lots of ways to reduce our use of resources.Buy durable goods.Choose items that are well made so they will last longer.Youll buy fewer items in the long run, so youll save money as well as resources.Thats a win-win!Repair rather than replace.Fix your bike rather than buying a new one.Sew on a button instead of buying a new shirt.Youll use fewer resources and save money.Buy only what you need.Dont buy a gallon of milk if you can only drink half of it before it spoils.Instead, buy a half gallon and drink all of it.You wont be wasting resources (or money!) Buy local.For example, buy local produce at a farmers market, like the one in Figure 2.20.A lot of resources are saved by not shipping goods long distances.Products bought at farmers markets use less packaging, too!About a third of what we throw out is packaging.
summary_1: The crux of reducing resource usage lies in minimizing consumption of resources through various strategies. One effective approach involves purchasing high-quality, durable goods designed to endure, thereby extending their lifespan and reducing overall expenditures. This tactic also contributes to conserving resources, making it a financially beneficial choice. Another recommended practice entails repairing damaged items instead of replacing them entirely. For instance, mending a torn piece of clothing or fixing a punctured bicycle tire can significantly cut down on both material waste and financial costs. Additionally, practicing mindful consumption plays a crucial role; this includes purchasing only necessary items and avoiding unnecessary waste. For example, buying locally sourced products from venues such as farmers' markets helps conserve energy spent on transportation while simultaneously decreasing packaging waste. Approximately one-third of discarded materials comprise packaging materials, which underscores the importance of curtailing excessive packaging.
summary_2: Purchasing long-lasting goods, repairing items, and mindful consumption reduce resource use and save money. Buying quality items that last, fixing things rather than replacing, and being thoughtful about purchases minimize waste and expenses. Locally sourcing products saves transport energy and reduces packaging waste.
summary_3: Mindfully buying durable goods, repairing instead of replacing, locally sourcing products conserves resources and cuts costs.

text: Once upon a time Jimmy had a mother who told him that he was good at music.Jimmy wanted to play music.He did not know which instrument to play, so he tried a piano first.The piano went like a sound.Then he tried a guitar.The guitar played.His brother told him that the piano was better to start, so Jimmy played the piano.He hammered on the keys.Jimmy's brother liked this, but mom did not like this.Jimmy tried playing very quiet.Jimmy's mom liked this, but Jimmy's brother did not like this.Jimmy tried playing in the middle.Jimmy liked this, and Jimmy's mom liked this, and Jimmy's brother liked this.It was great.
summary_1:
Jimmy received encouragement from his mother about his musical abilities. Intrigued by music, Jimmy decided to learn an instrument, initially trying out the piano. He found that he could make sounds with it, albeit somewhat crudely. Following this, he experimented with a guitar, producing noises that were pleasing to his ear. His brother suggested that starting with the piano would be more beneficial for Jimmy. As Jimmy began to enthusiastically strike the piano keys, his mother expressed her disapproval due to the noise level. Seeking a compromise, Jimmy attempted to play softly, managing to satisfy both his own desire for volume and his mother's preference for lower decibels. This balanced approach proved agreeable to all parties involved.
</details>
summary_2: Jimmy tried the piano, then guitar, before settling on the piano, practicing quietly to please his mom.
summary_3: After trying both instruments, Jimmy chose the piano, playing softly to keep his mother happy.

text: We waited for half an hour, watching the smoke curling over the house, and then, judging that the Indians had made off for fear of being ambushed, we crossed the clearing. It took but a glance to read the story. The women had been washing by the little brook before the cabin, with the children playing about them, when the Indians had come up and with a single volley killed them all except the child we had heard crying. They had swooped down upon their victims, torn the scalps from their heads, looted the house, and set fire to it. We dragged out the body of the woman which had been thrown within, in the hope that a spark of life might yet remain, but she was quite dead. Beneath the warrior Spiltdorph had shot we found the child. It was a boy of some six or seven years, and so covered with blood that it seemed it must be dead. But we stripped it and washed it in the brook, and found no wounds upon it except in the head, where it had been struck with a hatchet before its scalp had been stripped off. The cold water brought it back to life and it began to cry again, whereat Spiltdorph took off his coat and wrapped it tenderly about it.
summary_1: A group of individuals ventured across a clearing after waiting thirty minutes, observing smoke rising from a nearby house. Upon closer examination, they discovered evidence of a recent attack by Native Americans. Women washing by a stream, along with their children, were targeted; a single gunshot ended most of their lives. Subsequently, the assailants plundered the residence and set it ablaze. Amongst the casualties was a woman who had been tossed inside the dwelling, presumably deceased due to multiple injuries. However, her demise was confirmed only after attempts to resuscitate her proved futile. Nearby lay a young boy, approximately six or seven years old, drenched in blood. Although initially feared dead, he exhibited signs of life post-washing – the result of a head injury inflicted by a hatchet prior to losing his scalp. Revived by the coolness of the water, he recommenced crying, prompting one individual to compassionately swaddle him in his own jacket for warmth.
summary_2: A party found devastation at a home, seeing women and kids attacked, houses looted, structures burned, and bodies harmed. They discovered a badly injured little boy near his presumed-dead mom. Washed in cold water, the child regained consciousness, resuming tears. An onlooker gently wrapped him in a coat.
summary_3: After finding a severely injured young boy beside his apparently deceased mother amidst destruction and chaos, the rescuer cleaned him up with cold water, reviving the child who then wept while being comfortingly swathed in a warm coat.

text: Rock layers extend laterally, or out to the sides.They may cover very large areas.This is especially true if they formed at the bottom of ancient seas.Seas are very large areas of water.Over time, sediment builds up on the seabed.They will be covered with the same types of material.As rocks form out of this sediment it will all be the same type.The rocks may be forced up above the water as Earths plates move.Rivers may eventually run across this area.The river will cut into the rock and erode it away.The layers of exposed rock on either side of the river will still match up.Look at the Grand Canyon in Figure 2.27.Its a good example of lateral continuity.You can clearly see the same rock layers on opposite sides of the canyon.The matching rock layers were deposited at the same time.They are the same age.
summary_1: Lateral continuity refers to the consistent nature of rock layers that stretch outwards, often spanning vast distances. This phenomenon is particularly prevalent in regions once occupied by ancient seabeds, given their expansive sizes. As sediment accumulates over time on these ocean floors, homogenous strata emerge from the consolidation process. The resulting uniform layers can subsequently be elevated above sea level due to tectonic plate movements. Subsequent riverine activity may then carve through these elevated structures, revealing identical rock strata on both banks. Consequently, observing corresponding rock layers on opposing sides of rivers or valleys serves as evidence of simultaneous deposition during a common geological era, thereby indicating their equivalent ages. A prime illustration of lateral continuity can be discerned in the iconic Grand Canyon, where visibly parallel rock strata extend across both flanks of the chasm.
summary_2: "Lateral continuity" describes how rock layers maintain consistency over distance, notably in former seabed areas. Sediments form homogeneous strata over time, which can be raised above sea level by tectonic shifts. When rivers cut through these structures, they reveal matching rock strata on opposite banks, signifying simultaneous deposition and equal age. An example is the Grand Canyon, showcasing parallel rock strata on either side.
summary_3: Rock layers called "lateral continuity" display consistent sediment composition across distances, with identical strata on opposing sides of river cuts indicating simultaneous deposition and equal age, exemplified by the Grand Canyon's parallel strata.

text: An insect can have one of three types of change in its life.A metamorphosis describes how insects change.Some insects do not go through a change.Instead, the young look like small versions of adults.The only change between young and mature is size.Other types of insects go through a change in physical appearance.There are two types of this type of change.Some insects change only slightly during their change.This type is called incomplete metamorphosis.Other types of insects go through a major change.They don't look at all like the adult when they are born.This type of change is called complete metamorphosis.Occurs in the most primitive insects.Newborn insect looks like a tiny version of the adult.Incomplete Three stages: egg, nymph, and adult.Young, called nymphs, usually similar to adult.Growth occurs during the nymph stage.
summary_1: Insects undergo one of three kinds of transformations in their lives, known as metamorphosis. Some insects exhibit no changes, with young ones resembling miniature adults, differing only in size upon maturity. Other insects experience physical alterations, categorized into two groups. The first group experiences slight modifications, termed incomplete metamorphosis. These insects don't resemble adults at birth but gradually evolve into them. The second group undergoes a significant transformation, referred to as complete metamorphosis. In this case, newborns bear no resemblance to adults. This phenomenon is prevalent in more ancient insect species. Complete metamorphosis comprises three stages: egg, nymph, and adult. During the nymph phase, youthful insects, often similar to adults, grow and develop.
summary_2: There are three types of insect metamorphoses: none, incomplete, and complete. No change occurs in the first type, while minor adjustments define the second, where juveniles gradually become adults. The third, complete metamorphosis, involves a radical transformation seen in older insect species, divided into three stages: egg, nymph, and adult. Here, baby insects, distinct from adults, morph over time.
summary_3: Insect metamorphoses come in three forms - no change, gradual changes, and radical transformations into eggs, nymphs, then adults, typically in older species.

text: We do not know exactly how the hijackers gained access to the cockpit; FAA rules required that the doors remain closed and locked during flight.Ong speculated that they had "jammed their way" in.Perhaps the terrorists stabbed the flight attendants to get a cockpit key, to force one of them to open the cockpit door, or to lure the captain or first officer out of the cockpit.Or the flight attendants may just have been in their way.At the same time or shortly thereafter, Atta-the only terrorist on board trained to fly a jet-would have moved to the cockpit from his business-class seat, possibly accompanied by Omari.As this was happening, passenger Daniel Lewin, who was seated in the row just behind Atta and Omari, was stabbed by one of the hijackers-probably Satam al Suqami, who was seated directly behind Lewin.Lewin had served four years as an officer in the Israeli military.He may have made an attempt to stop the hijackers in front of him, not realizing that another was sitting behind him.The hijackers quickly gained control and sprayed Mace, pepper spray, or some other irritant in the first-class cabin, in order to force the passengers and flight attendants toward the rear of the plane.They claimed they had a bomb.About five minutes after the hijacking began, Betty Ong contacted the American Airlines Southeastern Reservations Office in Cary, North Carolina, via an AT&T airphone to report an emergency aboard the flight.This was the first of several occasions on 9/11 when flight attendants took action outside the scope of their training, which emphasized that in a hijacking, they were to communicate with the cockpit crew.The emergency call lasted approximately 25 minutes, as Ong calmly and professionally relayed information about events taking place aboard the airplane to authorities on the ground.At 8:19, Ong reported:"The cockpit is not answering, somebody's stabbed in business class-and I think there's Mace-that we can't breathe-I don't know, I think we're getting hijacked."She then told of the stabbings of the two flight attendants.At 8:21, one of the American employees receiving Ong's call in North Carolina, Nydia Gonzalez, alerted the American Airlines operations center in Fort Worth, Texas, reaching Craig Marquis, the manager on duty.Marquis soon realized this was an emergency and instructed the airline's dispatcher responsible for the flight to contact the cockpit.At 8:23, the dispatcher tried unsuccessfully to contact the aircraft.
summary_1: On September 11, the hijackers likely forced their way into the cockpit, potentially injuring flight attendants to obtain a cockpit key or coerce someone to open the door. The attack occurred simultaneously or soon after passenger Daniel Lewin, a former Israeli military officer, was stabbed, presumably by terrorist Satam al Suqami. To control the situation, the hijackers released an irritant, probably Mace or pepper spray, and declared possession of a bomb. At around 8:14 AM ET, flight attendant Betty Ong used an Airfone to inform the American Airlines Southeastern Reservations Office in Cary, North Carolina, about the unfolding crisis. Over a 25-minute period, she communicated crucial updates regarding injuries and the absence of communication from the cockpit. By 8:21 AM ET, word reached the American Airlines operations center in Fort Worth, Texas, leading to attempts to establish contact with the cockpit, but without success until 8:23 AM ET.
summary_2: Hijackers stormed Flight 11's cockpit on September 11, possibly harming crew members for access. A passenger was stabbed, and an irritant was released to control the cabin. Flight attendant Betty Ong alerted authorities via Airfone, sharing vital information about injuries and lost contact with the cockpit. This news reached American Airlines operations at 8:21 AM ET, with unsuccessful attempts made to connect with the cockpit until 8:23 AM ET.
summary_3: On September 11, hijackers took over Flight 11, injuring passengers and seizing the cockpit, while flight attendant Betty Ong informed American Airlines operations about the situation before losing contact with the cockpit.

text: (CNN) -- A federal court jury in Florida convicted seven people of participating in a global child pornography trafficking enterprise, according to the Department of Justice.Jurors convicted the seven Wednesday of multiple counts of child exploitation, pornography and obstruction of justice.Members of the organization used Internet news groups to swap and share "illegal images and videos depicting prepubescent children, including toddlers, engaged in various sexual and sadistic acts," prosecutors said.An indictment filed in the case detailed interactions between group members as they swapped and commented on images."My thanks to you and all the others that together make this the greatest group of pedos to ever gather in one place," Freeman wrote in response to one posting, according to the indictment.And a posting from Castleman, cited in the indictment, read, "Thanks to all for the wonderful material that has been posted."An Australian constable who infiltrated the group in August 2006 was among 50 witnesses testifying at trial.He told the jury that the group traded more than 400,000 images and videos of child sexual abuse before being dismantled by law enforcement, according to the Justice Department statement.Each defendant faces a sentence of 20 years to life in prison, fines and the possibility of supervised release for the rest of their lives, authorities said.The seven will be sentenced April 14.During the six-day trial, evidence showed the seven participated in what prosecutors called a "well-organized criminal enterprise whose purpose was to proliferate child sex abuse images to its membership during a two-year period.""This was a wide-scale, high-volume, international trafficking enterprise that used sophisticated computer encryption technology and file-sharing techniques," Matthew Friedrich, acting assistant attorney general, said in the statement.The seven defendants were James Freeman of Santa Rosa Beach, Florida; Gary Lakey of Anderson, Indiana; Marvin Lambert of Indianapolis, Indiana; Neville McGarity of Medina, Texas; Warren Mumpower of Spokane, Washington; Daniel Castleman of Lubbock, Texas; and Ronald White of Burlington, North Carolina, according to the Department of Justice.
summary_1: A federal court jury in Florida convicted seven individuals of involvement in a worldwide child pornography trading operation, as announced by the Department of Justice. The accused faced charges of child exploitation, pornography distribution, and obstruction of justice, and were found guilty on multiple counts. Group members utilized internet newsgroups to exchange and comment on illegal images and videos featuring young children in explicit situations. An undercover Australian police officer infiltrated the group in August 2006 and shared details about over 400,000 abusive image and video exchanges prior to the group's disbandment by law enforcement. Each convict faces 20 years to life imprisonment, fines, and potential lifetime supervision upon release. Sentencing is scheduled for April 14. Prosecutors referred to the network as a "well-organized criminal enterprise" that distributed child sex abuse content using advanced computer encryption and sharing technologies. Those charged include James Freeman (Santa Rosa Beach, FL), Gary Lakey (Anderson, IN), Marvin Lambert (Indianapolis, IN), Neville McGarity (Medina, TX), Warren Mumpower (Spokane, WA), Daniel Castleman (Lubbock, TX), and Ronald White (Burlington, NC).
summary_2: In Florida, a federal court convicted seven people for participating in a global child pornography ring, involving child exploitation, distribution, and obstruction charges. They used online newsgroups to trade and discuss illegal content, with an undercover cop discovering over 400,000 such exchanges. Convicts face 20 years to life imprisonment, fines, and possible lifelong supervision. Sentencing is set for April 14. The group is described as a sophisticated criminal enterprise distributing child sexual abuse material via advanced tech.
summary_3: Seven individuals were found guilty in Florida for running a complex child pornography operation using online newsgroups, facing prison terms, fines, and potential lifetime monitoring; sentencing is scheduled for mid-April.

text: Imagine a glass of your favorite drink that never became empty.Now think about what really happens.You take a drink and there is less in the glass.You keep drinking and soon it is all gone.Good thing you have more to refill your glass.What if there would never be any more of your favorite drink.What would you do?Now you know the difference between renewable and non-renewable.Its too bad that many things here on Earth will run out.This includes some of our natural resources we depend on.Things like oil will not last forever.There is a limited supply.Someday, we will run out, so then what?At current rates of use, coal will last about 300 years.Petroleum will be used up in just a few decades.
summary_1: The provided text contrasts renewable versus non-renewable resources using the analogy of an everlasting drink. The focus shifts towards Earth's finite natural resources, primarily oil and coal. These non-renewable resources face depletion at current usage rates, with petroleum projected to last for merely a few more decades, while coal could endure approximately three centuries. This underscores the urgency to address resource management sustainably.
summary_2: Earth has limited fossil fuels like oil and coal, which may run out soon—oil within decades, coal in around 300 years. Renewables offer a sustainable alternative due to their continuous supply. It's crucial to manage these resources wisely.
summary_3: It's essential to transition from finite fossil fuels to renewable energy sources to ensure long-term sustainability.

text: The second major point on which the principals had agreed on March 10 was the need to crack down on terrorist organizations and curtail their fund-raising.The embassy bombings of 1998 had focused attention on al Qaeda's finances.One result had been the creation of an NSC-led interagency committee on terrorist financing.On its recommendation, the President had designated  Bin Laden and al Qaeda as subject to sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.This gave theTreasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) the ability to search for and freeze any  Bin Laden or al Qaeda assets that reached the U.S. financial system.But since OFAC had little information to go on, few funds were frozen.In July 1999, the President applied the same designation to the Taliban for harboring  Bin Laden.Here, OFAC had more success.It blocked more than $34 million in Taliban assets held in U.S. banks.Another $215 million in gold and $2 million in demand deposits, all belonging to the Afghan central bank and held by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, were also frozen.After October 1999, when the State Department formally designated al Qaeda a "foreign terrorist organization," it became the duty of U.S. banks to block its transactions and seize its funds.Neither this designation nor UN sanctions had much additional practical effect; the sanctions were easily circumvented, and there were no multilateral mechanisms to ensure that other countries' financial systems were not used as conduits for terrorist funding.Attacking the funds of an institution, even the Taliban, was easier than finding and seizing the funds of a clandestine worldwide organization like al Qaeda.Although the CIA's  Bin Laden unit had originally been inspired by the idea of studying terrorist financial links, few personnel assigned to it had any experience in financial investigations.Any terrorist-financing intelligence appeared to have been collected collaterally, as a consequence of gathering other intelligence.This attitude may have stemmed in large part from the chief of this unit, who did not believe that simply following the money from point A to point B revealed much about the terrorists' plans and intentions.As a result, the CIA placed little emphasis on terrorist financing.Nevertheless, the CIA obtained a general understanding of how al Qaeda raised money.
summary_1: Agreement was reached on March 10 to target terrorist organizations and restrict their financing. The 1998 embassy bombings led to focus on Al Qaeda's finances, resulting in an NSC-led interagency group on terrorist financing. This group recommended that Bin Laden and Al Qaeda be subject to sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, allowing the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) to locate and freeze any Al Qaeda assets within the US financial system. However, limited information resulted in minimal seized funds. Post-July 1999, the President designated the Taliban for harboring Bin Laden, leading to over $34 million in Taliban assets frozen in US banks, along with $215 million in gold and $2 million in demand deposits owned by Afghanistan's central bank at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Following October 1999, US banks were required to halt Al Qaeda transactions and confiscate their funds due to Al Qaeda being officially recognized as a 'foreign terrorist organization'. Yet, these actions and UN sanctions proved insufficient as they could be easily bypassed, without global measures ensuring prevention of utilizing foreign financial systems for terrorist funding. Despite challenges, the CIA managed to gain a broad comprehension of Al Qaeda's fundraising methods. While initially keen on exploring terrorist financial connections, the CIA allocated few experts proficient in financial investigations to the task. Intelligence regarding terrorist financing seemed gathered passively during pursuit of other intel. Consequently, the CIA didn’t prioritize tracking terrorist financing extensively. Nevertheless, the CIA gained a holistic view of Al Qaeda's monetary practices.
summary_2: On March 10, an agreement targeted terrorist financing and sanctioned organizations like Al Qaeda. After the 1998 bombings, an interagency group focused on Al Qaeda's finances, leading to OFAC freezing some US-based Al Qaeda assets. Post-1999, the President designated the Taliban, freezing $34 million in Taliban assets in US banks. In October 1999, US banks stopped Al Qaeda transactions and seized their funds. These efforts, however, proved insufficient due to global loopholes. Despite challenges, the CIA understood Al Qaeda's fundraising methods but lacked dedicated experts, suggesting passive data collection rather than proactive investigation. Nonetheless, the CIA obtained a comprehensive understanding of Al Qaeda's financial strategies.
summary_3: In response to the 1998 bombings, the U.S. began targeting terrorist financing by freezing assets of groups like Al Qaeda and the Taliban, but struggled due to global loopholes, eventually gaining a comprehensive understanding of Al Qaeda's financial strategies despite lacking dedicated experts at the CIA.

text: Breathing is the process of moving air into and out of the lungs.The process depends on a muscle called the diaphragm.This is a large, sheet-like muscle below the lungs.Inhaling, or breathing in, occurs when the diaphragm muscle tightens.This increases the size of the chest.This too decreases air pressure inside the lungs.This action allows air and gases to enter the lungs.Exhaling, or breathing out, occurs when the diaphragm muscle relaxes.This decreases the size of the chest.This increases air pressure inside the lungs.This action allows for air to leave the lungs.When you inhale, air enters the respiratory system through your nose and ends up in your lungs, where gas exchange with the blood takes place.What happens to the air along the way?In the nose, mucus and hairs trap any dust or other particles in the air.The air is also warmed and moistened.Next, air passes through a passageway that is connected to the windpipe.The air then finds its way to the lungs.In the chest, the windpipe splits so that air enters both the right and left lung.
summary_1: Breathing involves two main actions - inhaling and exhaling - which occur due to the contraction and relaxation of the diaphragm, a large muscle located beneath the lungs. During inhalation, the diaphragm contracts and expands the chest cavity, reducing air pressure within the lungs and allowing air to enter. This air moves from the nostrils, through the nasal passages where it gets warmed, moisturized, and filtered by mucus and hair, before proceeding towards the lungs via the windpipe. The windpipe further divides into two bronchi, one leading to each lung. Exhalation follows once the diaphragm relaxes, causing the chest cavity to shrink, increasing air pressure within the lungs, and pushing the air back out through the same pathway. Gas exchange between this inhaled air and the bloodstream occurs within the alveoli in the lungs.
summary_2: Breathing consists of inhaling and exhaling, caused by the diaphragm contracting and relaxing. Inhaling enlarges the chest cavity, decreasing air pressure, drawing air in through the nose, warming, moistening, filtering it, then directing it to the lungs via the windpipe and bronchi. Exhaling reverses this process when the diaphragm relaxes, raising air pressure and pushing air back out. Air and blood exchange gases in the alveoli during both stages.
summary_3: In breathing, the diaphragm's contraction and relaxation cause inhalation and exhalation, facilitating gas exchange between air and blood in the lungs.

text: The Glory of Melaka: In the early days, if you were not a pirate or a mosquito, Melaka was not much of a place to live.The land was infertile, just a swampy plain, the river small and sluggish.But it had a sheltered harbor, protected from the monsoons by neighboring Sumatra.Later, the strategic location and deep-water channel close to the coast brought in the bigger vessels of the trade-wind traffic crossing the Indian Ocean.The first to realize the larger commercial potential, as so often throughout the country's subsequent history, were the Chinese.In 1409, under a new directive from Emperor Chu Ti to pursue trade in the South Seas and the Indian Ocean, a Chinese fleet of 50 ships headed by Admiral Cheng Ho called in at Melaka.They made Parameswara an offer he could not refuse: port facilities and an annual financial tribute in exchange for Chinese protection against the marauding Thais.In 1411, Parameswara took the money to Beijing himself, and the emperor gratefully made him a vassal king.Twenty years later, the Chinese withdrew again from the South Seas trade.The new ruler of Melaka, Sri Maharajah, switched his allegiance to the Muslim trading fraternity by marrying into the Muslim faith, wedding the daughter of a sultan in Sumatra.Islam won its place in Malaya not by conquest — as had been the case in North Africa and Europe — but by trade, dynastic alliances, and peaceful preaching.Bengali peddlers had already brought the faith to the east coast.In Melaka and throughout the peninsula, Islam thrived as a strong, male-dominated religion of individuality, offering dynamic leadership and preaching brotherhood and self-reliance — all qualities ideally suited to the coastal trade.At the same time, Sufi mystics synthesized Islamic teaching with local Malay traditions of animistic magic and charisma, though Islam did not become the state religion until Muzaffar Shah became sultan of Melaka (1446–1459).But the key figure in the sultanate was Tun Perak, bendahara (prime minister) and military commander.He expanded Melaka's power along the west coast and down to Singapore and the neighboring Bintan islands.He also had orang laut pirates patrolling the seas to extort tribute from passing ships.After Ailied district chiefs had repelled assaults from Thai-controlled armies from Pahang, Tun Perak personally led a famous victory over a Thai fleet off Batu Pahat in 1456.
summary_1: Melaka started as an unremarkable area but gained significance due to its sheltered harbor, which attracted traders. The region's fortunes changed when Chinese Admiral Cheng Ho arrived in 1409, offering Parameswara a deal: Chinese protection and port facilities in return for loyalty. Impressed, Parameswara accepted and even visited China, becoming a vassal king. However, when the Chinese left the South Seas trade two decades later, Melaka shifted its allegiance to the Muslim trading community by embracing Islam through marriage ties. This marked Islam's arrival via Bengali peddlers and Sufi missionaries who blended Islamic teachings with local customs. Under Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Islam became the official religion. Meanwhile, Tun Perak, prime minister and military chief, played a pivotal role. He extended Melaka's influence along the west coast, controlled piracy, and famously defeated a Thai fleet in 1456, solidifying Melaka's reputation and power.
summary_2: In the fifteenth century, Melaka transformed from an insignificant region into a significant trading hub due to its strategic harbor. It initially allied with China after Admiral Cheng Ho offered protection and resources in exchange for loyalty. When China withdrew from the South Seas trade, Melaka turned to Islam, adopting it through marital and religious connections. This shift was influenced by Bengali merchants and Sufi missionaries who integrated Islamic beliefs with local traditions. Under Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Islam became the state religion. Tun Perak, the influential prime minister and military leader, expanded Melaka's control over the western coast, curbed piracy, and secured Melaka's reputation by defeating a Thai naval force in 1456.
summary_3: In the 15th century, Melaka evolved into a major trading hub due to its strategic harbor, first allying with China before turning to Islam, influenced by Bengali merchants and Sufi missionaries, and later adopted as the state religion under Sultan Muzaffar Shah; Tun Perak further strengthened Melaka's influence.

text: When you get sick, your body springs to action.Your body starts to fight the illness.Thats why you want to eat right and get plenty of sleep.You need a strong immune system to fight off illness.Plants dont have an immune system.That does not mean they do not get sick.Plants are affected by disease just like us.Typically, their first line of defense is the death of part of the plant.This prevents the infection from spreading.Many plants also produce special chemicals to fight disease.For example, willow trees produce a chemical to kill the bacteria.The same compound is used in many acne products.You can see a picture of a willow tree in Figure Plants may be smarter than we think.No, they cannot talk to each other.They may be able to send messages, though.
summary_1: Sickness prompts the human body to counteract the affliction due to its inherent immune system. A robust immune system is crucial for combatting illnesses. Contrarily, plants lack an immune system but are still susceptible to diseases. When attacked, initial plant defense often involves sacrificing a section to halt the spread of infection. Additionally, certain plants generate specific compounds to combat diseases. For instance, willow trees yield a bacteriocidal substance, identical to components found in numerous acne treatments. Therefore, it could be posited that plants possess intellectual capabilities beyond our current understanding, even if they cannot verbally communicate. They might transmit signals instead.
summary_2: Plants, unlike humans, don't have an immune system to fight off sickness. Instead, when attacked, they may sacrifice parts to stop disease spread. Some plants produce disease-fighting compounds, like willows' bacteriocidal substances used in acne treatments. This suggests plants might have complex abilities we don't yet grasp, communicating through signals rather than speech.
summary_3: Some plants lack human-like immunity, but can use chemical defenses and self-destructive tactics to combat diseases, hinting at intricate capabilities remaining undiscovered.

text: Albrecht Durer (/'dU@r@r, 'djU@r@r/; German: ['albRect 'dy:Ra]; 21 May 1471 - 6 April 1528) was a painter, printmaker and theorist of the German Renaissance.Born in Nuremberg, Durer established his reputation and influence across Europe when he was still in his twenties, due to his high-quality woodcut prints.He was in communication with the major Italian artists of his time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini and Leonardo da Vinci, and from 1512 he was patronized by emperor Maximilian I. His vast body of work includes engravings, his preferred technique in his later prints, altarpieces, portraits and self-portraits, watercolours and books.The woodcuts, such as the Apocalypse series (1498), retain a more Gothic flavour than the rest of his work.His well-known engravings include the Knight, Death, and the Devil (1513), Saint Jerome in his Study (1514) and Melencolia I (1514), which has been the subject of extensive analysis and interpretation.His watercolours also mark him as one of the first European landscape artists, while his ambitious woodcuts revolutionized the potential of that medium.Durer's introduction of classical motifs into Northern art, through his knowledge of Italian artists and German humanists, has secured his reputation as one of the most important figures of the Northern Renaissance.This is reinforced by his theoretical treatises, which involve principles of mathematics, perspective and ideal proportions.
summary_1:
Albrecht Dürer (1471-1528) was a renowned German painter, printmaker, and theorist of the Renaissance era. Born in Nuremberg, Dürer gained early recognition for his high-quality woodcut prints, leading to an influential career across Europe even before reaching thirty years of age. He corresponded with prominent Italian artists like Raphael, Giovanni Bellini, and Leonardo da Vinci, receiving patronage from Emperor Maximilian I from 1512 onwards.

Dürer's expansive oeuvre spans engravings, altarpieces, portraits, self-portraits, watercolors, and written works. Although some of his earlier woodcuts reflect a more Gothic style, as seen in the Apocalypse series (1498), his distinctive engravings display mastery over various themes—such as the iconic Knight, Death, and the Devil (1513); Saint Jerome in his Study (1514); and Melencolia I (1514). These pieces have sparked substantial scholarly discussion and interpretations.

As a pioneering artist, Dürer made significant contributions to landscape art via his expressive watercolor creations. Moreover, his innovative large-scale woodcuts expanded the artistic possibilities of this particular medium. By integrating classical elements from Italian masters and German humanists into his work, Dürer played a pivotal role in shaping the Northern Renaissance movement. This impact can be further attributed to his theoretical writings concerning mathematics, perspective, and ideal proportions.
summary_2: German Renaissance artist Albrecht Dürer (1471-1528) was celebrated for his painting, printmaking, and theories. Recognized early for high-quality woodcut prints, he corresponded with Italian greats like Raphael and Leonardo da Vinci. His diverse body of work includes engravings, altarpieces, portraits, and watercolors, showcasing mastery over themes like religion and melancholy. Known for landscapes and large-scale woodcuts, Dürer combined Italian and German influences, contributing significantly to the Northern Renaissance through both practical artwork and theoretical writings.
summary_3: Albrecht Dürer, a renowned German Renaissance artist, excelled in painting, printmaking, and art theory, exchanging ideas with Italian masters while creating diverse works reflecting religious themes and melancholy, thereby greatly influencing the Northern Renaissance.

text: Alexander married twice: Roxana, daughter of the Bactrian nobleman Oxyartes, out of love; and Stateira II, a Persian princess and daughter of Darius III of Persia, for political reasons.He apparently had two sons, Alexander IV of Macedon of Roxana and, possibly, Heracles of Macedon from his mistress Barsine.He lost another child when Roxana miscarried at Babylon.Alexander also had a close relationship with his friend, general, and bodyguard Hephaestion, the son of a Macedonian noble.Hephaestion's death devastated Alexander.This event may have contributed to Alexander's failing health and detached mental state during his final months.Alexander's sexuality has been the subject of speculation and controversy.No ancient sources stated that Alexander had homosexual relationships, or that Alexander's relationship with Hephaestion was sexual.Aelian, however, writes of Alexander's visit to Troy where "Alexander garlanded the tomb of Achilles and Hephaestion that of Patroclus, the latter riddling that he was a beloved of Alexander, in just the same way as Patroclus was of Achilles".Noting that the word eromenos (ancient Greek for beloved) does not necessarily bear sexual meaning, Alexander may have been bisexual, which in his time was not controversial.Green argues that there is little evidence in ancient sources that Alexander had much carnal interest in women; he did not produce an heir until the very end of his life.However, he was relatively young when he died, and Ogden suggests that Alexander's matrimonial record is more impressive than his father's at the same age.Apart from wives, Alexander had many more female companions.Alexander accumulated a harem in the style of Persian kings, but he used it rather sparingly; showing great self-control in "pleasures of the body".Nevertheless, Plutarch described how Alexander was infatuated by Roxana while complimenting him on not forcing himself on her.Green suggested that, in the context of the period, Alexander formed quite strong friendships with women, including Ada of Caria, who adopted him, and even Darius's mother Sisygambis, who supposedly died from grief upon hearing of Alexander's death.
summary_1: Alexander the Great had two marriages - one to Roxana, whom he loved deeply, and another to Stateira II due to political motives. He likely sired two sons - Alexander IV of Macedon with Roxana, and potentially Heracles of Macedon with Barsine. Sadly, a miscarriage occurred in Babylon resulting in the loss of another child. His closest companion was Hephaestion, who was both his friend, general, and bodyguard. The sudden demise of Hephaestion greatly affected Alexander, potentially contributing to his deteriorating health and emotional withdrawal towards the end of his life. Speculations about Alexander's sexual orientation vary, given the lack of explicit accounts in historical records. Ancient texts do not explicitly confirm any homosexual relations between Alexander and others, nor do they definitively label his bond with Hephaestion as romantic. However, certain passages suggest a deep connection between them. Some historians propose that Alexander might have been bisexual, pointing to his relationship with Hephaestion and limited interaction with women beyond marriage. Despite having multiple female partners, Alexander seemed to display restraint in physical intimacy. Nevertheless, he developed meaningful connections with various women such as Ada of Caria and Darius's mother Sisygambis, demonstrating respectable self-restraint regarding sensual indulgences.
summary_2: Alexander the Great married twice, to Roxana and Stateira II, possibly fathering Alexander IV and maybe Heracles. Close friend Hephaestion, described as friend, general, and bodyguard, died suddenly, affecting Alexander negatively. Sexuality speculation exists; ancient texts don't clarify if Alexander had male lovers or if his bond with Hephaestion was romantic. Historians consider him possibly bisexual, citing few relationships with women but strong bonds with men. Regardless, Alexander respected many women like Ada of Caria and Sisygambis, showing self-control around them.
summary_3: Alexander the Great married Roxana and Stateira II, possibly fathering two sons, while having close relationships with both genders, including best friend Hephaestion.

text: ATLANTA, Georgia (CNN) -- On a plot of soil, nestled against the backdrop of skyscrapers in downtown Atlanta, Georgia, a group of residents are turning a lack of access to fresh produce into a revival of old traditions and self-empowerment.Urban farming is a way for African-Americans to connect with the earth, says Cashawn Myers of HABESHA.HABESHA Gardens is one of many urban gardens sprouting up around the country.Fruits and vegetables are thriving in this community garden located in an economically depressed area of the city known as Mechanicsville.But the garden serves an even greater purpose.The harvest helps feed some of the neediest members of the neighborhood."It's a reawakening going on.It's almost like it's a renaissance," says Cashawn Myers, director of HABESHA Inc. "There's a Ghanaian proverb that says Sankofa.Sankofa means return to your past so you can move forward.Even if you look at coming over here during our enslavement, we were brought here to cultivate the land because that's something we did on the continent.So really, that's what many of the people are doing now," he said.Myers believes urban farming is a way for many African-Americans to reconnect with their past.iReport.com: Show us your urban farm "They are going through a process of Sankofa and going to what they traditionally did, which is connect to the Earth so they can move forward and grow," he says.But HABESHA Gardens isn't unique.Former pro basketball player Will Allen, who is considered to be one of the nation's leading urban farmers and founder of Growing Power Inc., estimates that there are hundreds of thousands of urban gardens in inner cities across America.Urban farms help feed people, sustain neighorhoods » "It's beyond a movement at this point.Its more like a revolution," says Allen.
summary_1: In Atlanta, Georgia, urban gardening has become a significant development, particularly among African-American communities. Cashawn Myers from HABESHA Gardens sees this as a means for these individuals to reconnect with the earth and their heritage. Located in a low-income district named Mechanicsville, HABESHA Gardens is just one example of numerous urban gardens springing up nationwide. These gardens serve not only as sources of fresh fruits and vegetables but also as symbols of empowerment and cultural reconnection. The practice harks back to the time when Africans were brought to America as slaves and made to work the land. Today, urban farming allows them to reclaim this lost connection with the earth, thereby moving forward while honoring their past - a concept encapsulated by the Ghanaian proverb 'Sankofa'. This revival extends beyond Atlanta, with former professional basketball player Will Allen estimating hundreds of thousands of similar initiatives across American inner cities. For Allen, this phenomenon represents a revolutionary shift in how urban spaces are utilized for food production and community building.
summary_2: Urban gardening thrives in Atlanta, especially in African-American communities, via projects like HABESHA Gardens in Mechanicsville. These gardens provide fresh produce and symbolize cultural reconnection and empowerment, echoing the Ghanaian principle 'Sankofa', which encourages learning from the past. This trend, estimated to include hundreds of thousands of initiatives nationwide, signifies a transformative use of urban spaces for both agriculture and community growth.
summary_3: African-American neighborhoods in Atlanta see urban farming growth, notably at HABESHA Gardens, symbolizing cultural connection and empowerment, part of an estimated hundreds-of-thousands-strong national movement.

text: The Washington Supreme Court is asking the Legislature to approve a $90 surcharge on a court filing fee to help provide legal help for the poor in civil cases, Chief Justice Gerry Alexander said Wednesday."Some might say, why should we support this when we face tough financial times?"Alexander asked in his State of the Judiciary address to a joint session of the Legislature."It seems to me in America, where we rejoice in the fact that we are a nation devoted to the rule of law, we should not ration access to justice."The recommendation comes from the court's Task Force on Civil Equal Justice Funding, created in 2001 to look for ways to cope with the sparse amount of money available for such cases.As the task force was studying the issue, $900,000 was cut from state support for civil equal justice services.That prompted the state's two main legal services providers - Columbia Legal Services and Northwest Justice Project - to cut their staffs, Alexander said.The change would increase the cost of filing a lawsuit in Superior Court to $200.The total fee would be split, with 54 percent going to counties and 46 percent going to the state for a newly created equal justice account.Alexander also requested money for five additional Superior Court judgeships and one additional District Court judgeships, arguing that increased caseloads require more judges.Two of the Superior Court judges and the District Court judge would be in Clark County, with one Superior Court judge added in the joint district that serves Benton and Franklin counties and one each in Kittitas and Kitsap counties.
summary_1: Chief Justice Gerry Alexander urged the Washington Legislature to approve a $90 surcharge on court filing fees to aid those unable to afford legal help in civil cases. The proposal originates from the court's Task Force on Civil Equal Justice Funding, established in 2001 due to insufficient funds for these matters. Following a $900,000 reduction in state support for civil equal justice services, the state's primary legal service providers, Columbia Legal Services and Northwest Justice Project, reduced their workforces. If implemented, the new fee would raise the Superior Court filing fee to $200, allocating 54% to counties and 46% to a newly formed equal justice fund at the state level. Additionally, Alexander sought funding for five extra Superior Court judgeships and one District Court judgeship across several counties to manage increasing caseloads.
summary_2: Justice Alexander asks Washington legislators to back a $90 charge on court filings to assist people struggling with civil case costs. This stems from the court's 2001 task force recommendation due to inadequate funds. After a $900,000 cut in state aid, main legal service providers, Columbia Legal Services and Northwest Justice Project, trimmed staff. If passed, the increased fee would hike Superior Court filing fee to $200, dividing revenue between counties and a new state equal justice fund. Furthermore, Alexander requests additional funds for five Superior Court and one District Court judge positions in various counties grappling with rising caseloads.
summary_3: Judge Alexander proposes a $90 increase in court filing fees to help those facing high civil case costs, directing part of the proceeds towards an equal justice fund and extra judges in busy courts.

text: Also on Feb. 12, a week before the ice dancing finals, Tokhtakhounov told Anissina's mother in a telephone call that the Russian federation official "had called me from America" to assure that "we are going to make" Anissina "an Olympic champion."He told her that the Russian skating federation official "will help -- he has two or three judges."On or about March 7, in a conversation between Tokhtakhounov and Anissina, she said she would have won the event without his assistance because the Russian judge did not vote for her and her partner.She also apologized for not calling to thank him earlier, but that Gailhaguet had forbidden her.She told Tokhtakhounov that she knew the FBI had interviewed Gailhaguet because of information that Tokhtakhounov "was involved with the results" of the ice dancing.He assured her that it was nonsense, but that Gailhaguet "knows my name very well -- he tried to help me, and later he made stuff up to scare you so you would not connect me to him even more."The conversations seem to indicate a familiarity between Tokhtakhounov and Anissina.Tass, the official Russian news agency, reported that Anissina attended a ceremony in 1999 at a Paris hotel honoring Tokhtakhounov for his philanthropy.That Russian organized crime may have infiltrated international sport at the Olympics stunned Phyllis Howard, president of the U.S. Figure Skating Association."This is a criminal act and it certainly puts things in a different league," Howard said.Lloyd Ward, chief executive officer of the U.S. Olympic Committee, said in a statement, "Competitors from all nations must be assured that they compete on a level playing field."
summary_1: Tokhtakhounov claimed to Anissina's mother that he could ensure Anissina's victory in the ice dancing event at the Olympics, stating that a Russian skating federation official would assist due to having two or three judges on their side. This conversation took place a week prior to the finals on February 12. Post-competition, Anissina informed Tokhtakhounov that she would have still won without his aid, as the Russian judge didn't vote for her. She expressed regret for not contacting him sooner to express gratitude; however, she mentioned that Gailhaguet had prohibited such communication. The reason being, Gailhaguet allegedly warned Anissina about suspicions surrounding Tokhtakhounov's involvement in the competition results. Despite this, Tokhtakhounov downplayed these concerns during their discussion. A relationship appears to exist between Tokhtakhounov and Anissina, supported by her presence at an event honoring Tokhtakhounov's philanthropic efforts in 1999. Reactions poured in from officials like Phyllis Howard, President of the US Figure Skating Association, who described the situation as a criminal act threatening fair play. Lloyd Ward, CEO of the US Olympic Committee, echoed similar sentiments, emphasizing the necessity of ensuring equal opportunities for athletes across all nations.
summary_2: Allegations claim Tokhtakhounov promised Anissina's victory in the Olympics, backed by a Russian skating federation official. However, post-competition, Anissina stated she'd have won regardless, implying the Russian judge hadn't voted for her. Anissina regretted not thanking Tokhtakhounov earlier due to Gailhaguet's warning about suspected interference. Officials reacted strongly, viewing it as a criminal threat to fair play and equality among athletes.
summary_3: Tokhtakhounov was accused of promising an Olympic win for Anissina, but she claimed it wouldn't have changed her result; Anissina regretted not thanking him earlier due to warned suspicions, sparking officials' outrage at the perceived threat to sport equity.

text: Federal health authorities Monday added 58 types of cancer to the list of covered illnesses for people who were exposed to toxins at the site of the World Trade Center in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks.The addition finalizes a recommendation from Dr. John Howard, administrator of the World Trade Center Health Program.Howard proposed in June that the program accept the recommendations of its Science/Technical Advisory Committee and add some cancers to the coverage list -- 14 categories in all.Firefighters responding to 9/11 at increased cancer risk The advisory committee review called for expanded "coverage for certain types of cancer resulting from exposure to toxins released at Ground Zero.""The publication of this final rule marks an important step in the effort to provide needed treatment and care to 9/11 responders and survivors through the WTC Health Program," Howard said in a statement Monday.The rule is expected to be published Wednesday in the Federal Register, and will take effect 30 days after its publication, Howard said.9/11 detective dies after battle with lung cancer First responders, volunteers, survivors of the attacks and residents near the site who meet specific qualifications will be eligible for coverage, according to the World Trade Center Health Program.According to the proposed rule, an estimated 950 to 2,150 people would take advantage of the additional coverage.The estimated cost for the total cancer treatment ranges between $14.5 million and $33 million, the proposal said.
summary_1: On Monday, federal health officials approved adding 58 kinds of cancer to the list of diseases covered by the World Trade Center Health Program for individuals exposed to toxic substances post-September 11 attacks. This decision aligns with Dr. John Howard's recommendation made in June, based on the advice of the Science/Technical Advisory Committee. The new ruling expands coverage to include 14 categories of cancer. Eligible recipients encompass first responders, volunteers, survivors, and nearby residents meeting specified criteria. An estimate suggests that around 950 to 2,150 individuals might utilize these extended healthcare benefits. Projected costs range from $14.5 million to $33 million for comprehensive cancer treatments under this scheme. The updated rules are set to be officially published on Wednesday in the Federal Register and become effective 30 days thereafter.
summary_2: Federal authorities have okayed expanding WTC Health Program coverage to 58 types of cancer, affecting those exposed to hazardous materials after 9/11. Based on expert recommendations, eligibility extends to specific groups who meet certain conditions. Estimated costs could reach up to $33 million, benefiting approximately 2,150 people. New guidelines will appear in the Federal Register soon.
summary_3: The WTC Health Program will start covering 58 new cancer types for those exposed to toxic substances post-9/11, potentially helping around 2,150 individuals at an estimated cost of $33 million.

text: At length, as I entered the pass, the huge rocks began to close around in all their wild, mysterious impressiveness, when suddenly, as I was gazing eagerly about me, a drove of gray hairy beings came in sight, lumbering toward me with a kind of boneless, wallowing motion like bears. I never turn back, though often so inclined, and in this particular instance, amid such surroundings, everything seemed singularly unfavorable for the calm acceptance of so grim a company. Suppressing my fears, I soon discovered that although as hairy as bears and as crooked as summit pines, the strange creatures were sufficiently erect to belong to our own species. They proved to be nothing more formidable than Mono Indians dressed in the skins of sage-rabbits. Both the men and the women begged persistently for whisky and tobacco, and seemed so accustomed to denials that I found it impossible to convince them that I had none to give. Excepting the names of these two products of civilization, they seemed to understand not a word of English; but I afterward learned that they were on their way to Yosemite Valley to feast awhile on trout and procure a load of acorns to carry back through the pass to their huts on the shore of Mono Lake.
summary_1: The explorer encountered a group of furry humanoid figures while traversing a mountain pass. Initially fearful due to their bear-like appearance and movements, he realized upon closer inspection that they were actually Native Americans from the Mono tribe. Dressed in rabbit pelts, both male and female members approached him, asking for alcohol and tobacco. Despite using English words, the individuals didn't comprehend any other part of the language. The traveler later understood they journeyed to Yosemite Valley to catch fish and gather acorns before returning home near Mono Lake.
summary_2: Exploring a mountain pass, an explorer met what seemed like bear people but turned out to be Mono Tribe natives dressed in rabbit skins. Speaking broken English, they asked for alcohol and tobacco, failing to understand further conversation. They had come from Yosemite Valley, catching fish and gathering acorns, then heading back to Mono Lake.
summary_3: An explorer encountered Mono Tribe members, mistaken for bear people, who requested alcohol and tobacco before returning to Mono Lake after fishing and gathering acorns in Yosemite Valley.

text: Neighborhood Legal Services, which provides free legal services to the poor, has expanded into the San Gabriel and Pomona valleys, areas with large Asian populations, many of whom speak limited or no English.Language is their biggest obstacle, but the Asian communities' cultural isolation and service providers' lack of cultural expertise also play a part, said NLS executive director Neal Dubovitz.And with 13 percent to 15 percent of the Asian population in the U.S. living below the poverty line, NLS services are badly needed, Dubovitz said."Although it is a significant part of the poverty population, Asians historically have not been able to participate in the services and programs available to the poor," he said.From simple telephone advice to complete legal representation in court, the agency provides free consumer, health, family, immigration, housing, public benefits and labor legal services to people who earn under $1,380 per month.Legal service providers have long served large Latino populations, who have cultural diversity but share a common language."I remember the days when there were only a handful of people in the legal offices who spoke Spanish," Dudovitz said."Now Spanish and English are interchangeable.Our goal is to have that for the major Asian languages as well."Before the expansion, only a few NLS lawyers spoke Asian languages, said attorney Rebecca Yee, who was hired by NLS in April 2002 to design and head the project."Now we have people speaking Cantonese, Mandarin, Thai, Khmer (from Cambodia), Korean, Vietnamese, Japanese and Tagalog," Yee said.One of the 13 attorneys hired to work with the program is Irene Mak, a family law attorney who speaks Cantonese, Mandarin and Thai.Mak was a partner at a private law firm before she went to work for NLS two years ago, earning up to $20,000 less a year working on domestic violence cases."The job is more satisfying than the money," said Mak, who grew up in Hong Kong and Thailand before coming to the United States."I could use my language skills and wanted to give back to the Asian community."NLS expanded when Legal Services Corp., the federal agency that funds providers of free legal services nationwide, reduced the number of grantees in the Los Angeles area from five to three, Dudovitz said.NLS won the competitive grant over the Legal Services Program for Pasadena, San Gabriel-Pomona valleys.That boosted its client base from 16,000 to around 25,000, and NLS opened an office in El Monte.
summary_1: Neighborhood Legal Services (NLS) has broadened its reach to include the San Gabriel and Pomona Valleys, home to sizable Asian communities with many non-English speakers. Cultural barriers and insufficient linguistic competence present substantial challenges, according to NLS executive director Neal Dubovitz. He highlights that while 13% to 15% of Asian Americans live below the poverty line, they have traditionally been underserved due to language barriers and cultural disparities. NLS offers comprehensive legal assistance spanning consumer, health, family, immigration, housing, public benefits, and labor matters, catering to individuals earning under $1,380 monthly. Although legal aid organizations have effectively assisted large Latino demographraphics, NLS aims to replicate this success for major Asian languages. Prior to expansion, few NLS lawyers commanded Asian languages; however, current staff includes professionals fluent in Cantonese, Mandarin, Thai, Khmer, Korean, Vietnamese, Japanese, and Tagalog. For instance, Irene Mak, a family law specialist proficient in Cantonese, Mandarin, and Thai, joined NLS after transitioning from a private practice where she earned significantly more. She cites her bilingual abilities and commitment to serving the Asian community as motivations for joining NLS. The organization's growth resulted from winning a competitive federal grant, increasing clients from 16,000 to approximately 25,000 and necessitating a new location in El Monte.
summary_2: Legal aid group, Neighborhood Legal Services (NLS), now serves the San Gabriel and Pomona Valleys, areas with significant Asian populations and language barriers. Previously underserved due to linguistic and cultural differences, these communities will now access NLS's services in various fields such as consumer rights, health, family, immigration, housing, public benefits, and labor. With a new location in El Monte, NLS aims to mirror past successful outreach efforts among Latinos but now targets major Asian languages like Cantonese, Mandarin, Thai, Khmer, Korean, Vietnamese, Japanese, and Tagalog. A recent influx of multilingual professionals allows NLS to better serve their diverse clientele, including Irene Mak, who specializes in family law and speaks multiple Asian languages. This expansion follows NLS securing a competitive federal grant, which increased their client base by nearly 9,000 people.
summary_3: Neighborhood Legal Services expands to San Gabriel and Pomona Valleys, offering legal assistance in various fields to Asian communities in several languages, thanks to a secured federal grant and addition of multilingual staff.

text: Catherine V. "Ginny" Kilgore of Oxford, an attorney with North Mississippi Rural Legal Services, has been recognized for her dedication to serving the indigent.Kilgore - who oversees delivering legal services to the disabled and elderly in 39 north Mississippi counties - is recipient of the University of Mississippi School of Law's 2002 Public Service Award.The award was announced recently at a dinne r, held in Kilgore's honor and hosted by law school Dean Samuel M. Davis, who presented her with an engraved plaque."Ginny Kilgore is a public servant in the truest sense," said Davis."Her selection continues the tradition of this award in recognizing those who have labored in the trenches, with little or no compensation but with great professional and personal satisfaction in helping to bring justice and equality to those who need it most.""This award means a great deal to me," Kilgore said, pointing to others so honored."The work of those who received the award before me has been so important; I feel very honored."After earning bachelor's and master's degrees in education and a few years teaching, Kilgore enrolled at the UM law school.Upon graduation in 1975, she entered private law practice in Oxford, joining NMRLS in 1978.Since then, she has earned promotions from managing attorney, senior attorney, then director of the Council on Aging project.Since 1990, she has worked in the Administrative Law Unit and Resource Development, and directed the Elder Law Project, serving the northern half of the state.She also is an adjunct professor in the UM law school's Civil Law Clinic.She held a similar post a few years ago in the school's Elder Law Clinic.Kilgore says she's found her niche."I've always thought it was important to do work to help people.I really enjoy it.The issues I've dealt with through the years have been on the side of helping people maintain the basics of life - home, healt h care, jobs and family."She says her desire to serve others was sparked early, growing up in a single-parent home, aware that her widowed mother faced certain challenges as she supported her four children through public school and college.
summary_1: Ginny Kilgore, an attorney at North Mississippi Rural Legal Services (NMRLS), has been honored with the University of Mississippi School of Law's 2002 Public Service Award. Kilgore, who manages the delivery of legal services to the disabled and elderly in 39 northern Mississippi counties, received the accolade for her commitment to serving the underprivileged. The award, which acknowledges lawyers who have served the underserved with minimal compensation, was presented by law school Dean Samuel M. Davis. Kilgore expressed her gratitude and humility, highlighting the significant contributions of past recipients. After obtaining her bachelor's and master's degrees in education, Kilgore attended the UM law school, later joining a private law firm in Oxford and subsequently NMRLS in 1978. She progressed from managing attorney to senior attorney, then director of the Council on Aging project. Since 1990, she has managed the Administrative Law Unit and Resource Development, leading the Elder Law Project in the northern part of the state. Additionally, Kilgore serves as an adjunct professor in the UM law school's Civil Law Clinic, contributing to both the Civil Law and Elder Law Clinics. Her passion for service began in her childhood, influenced by her mother's struggles as a single parent supporting four children. This experience ignited her commitment to assisting individuals in securing basic needs such as healthcare, employment, and familial support.
summary_2: Ginny Kilgore, an NMRLS lawyer, won the 2002 Public Service Award from the University of Mississippi School of Law. Kilgore, handling legal aid for the disabled and elderly in 39 northern MS counties since joining NMRLS in 1978, was recognized for her dedication to helping the disadvantaged. The award, given by Dean Samuel M. Davis, celebrates lawyers serving low-income clients. Grateful, Kilgore acknowledged past winners' impact. With a background in education, Kilgore became a lawyer, working in private practice before joining NMRLS. There, she advanced to lead various projects and now heads the Administrative Law Unit and Resource Development, overseeing the Elder Law Project. As an adjunct professor, she supports the Civil Law and Elder Law Clinics. Inspired by her mom's struggles, Kilgore champions those seeking life essentials like healthcare, jobs, and family assistance.
summary_3: Lawyer Ginny Kilgore, who advocates for the disabled and elderly at NMRLS, received the 2002 Public Service Award from the University of Mississippi School of Law for her commitment to assisting low-income clients.

text: As where to guard the walls, full many a foss Begirds some stately castle, sure defence Affording to the space within, so here Were model'd these; and as like fortresses E'en from their threshold to the brink without, Are flank'd with bridges; from the rock's low base Thus flinty paths advanc'd, that 'cross the moles And dikes, struck onward far as to the gulf, That in one bound collected cuts them off. Such was the place, wherein we found ourselves From Geryon's back dislodg'd. The bard to left Held on his way, and I behind him mov'd. On our right hand new misery I saw, New pains, new executioners of wrath, That swarming peopled the first chasm. Below Were naked sinners. Hitherward they came, Meeting our faces from the middle point, With us beyond but with a larger stride. E'en thus the Romans, when the year returns Of Jubilee, with better speed to rid The thronging multitudes, their means devise For such as pass the bridge; that on one side All front toward the castle, and approach Saint Peter's fane, on th' other towards the mount.
summary_1: The setting is a location surrounded by high stone walls, likened to the protective structures around grand castles. These walls have pathways leading up to them, extending from the base of the rocks all the way to the edge of a deep abyss. The speaker and the poet have just dismounted from Geryon and are now proceeding forward, with the poet taking the lead. On their right, they witness a crowd of suffering souls emerging from a chasm, moving towards them. This scene mirrors the Roman practice during the Jubilee year, where people hasten across the bridge, half heading towards the castle and St. Peter's church, while the others move towards the mountain. Beneath them, sinners emerge naked, drawing closer from the midpoint of the chasm, striding past the speakers with longer steps.
summary_2: In a walled area, resembling a fortress, paths lead to an abyss. Dismounted from Geryon, the speaker and poet advance, with the poet in front. To their right, tormented souls ascend from a fissure, echoing Jubilee crowds crossing a bridge towards St. Peter's church and a mountain. Naked sinners rise beneath them, passing swiftly from the chasm's center.
summary_3: The speaker and poet pass dismounted through a fortress-like enclosure, observing tortured spirits rising like jubilant crowds toward a mountain from a crack on the side.

text: 863.
