INGREDIENTS.--The remains of a boiled calf's head, 1-1/2 pint of the liquor in which the head was boiled, 1 blade of pounded mace, 1 onion minced, a bunch of savoury herbs, salt and white pepper to taste, thickening of butter and flour, the yolks of 2 eggs, 1 tablespoonful of lemon-juice, forcemeat balls. _Mode_.--Remove all the bones from the head, and cut the meat into nice square pieces. Put 1-1/2 pint of the liquor it was boiled in into a saucepan, with mace, onion, herbs, and seasoning in the above proportion; let this simmer gently for 3/4 hour, then strain it and put in the meat. When quite hot through, thicken the gravy with a little butter rolled in flour, and, just before dishing the fricassee, put in the beaten yolks of eggs and lemon-juice; but be particular, after these two latter ingredients are added, that the sauce does not boil, or it will curdle. Garnish with forcemeat balls and curled slices of broiled bacon. To insure the sauce being smooth, it is a good plan to dish the meat first, and then to add the eggs to the gravy: when these are set, the sauce may be poured over the meat.
summary_1: This recipe makes use of a cooked calf's head. First, debone the head and cut the meat into even squares. Use 1-1/2 pints of the cooking liquid, adding mace, minced onion, a bundle of flavorful herbs, and appropriate amounts of salt and white pepper. Simmer this mixture for 45 minutes, then strain it and combine it with the meat. Once heated through, thicken the gravy by stirring in a mix of butter and flour. Just prior to serving, incorporate beaten egg yolks and lemon juice into the gravy, ensuring it doesn't reach a boiling point to prevent curdling. Serve the dish garnished with forcemeat balls and curly strips of broiled bacon. For a smoother sauce, plate the meat first, then blend in the eggs before pouring the sauce over the meat.
summary_2: This recipe uses a cooked calf's head, cooked and cut into equal pieces. A broth is made from the cooking liquid, spices, and seasonings, simmered and strained. The meat is added back, and a thickened gravy formed using butter, flour, and an egg-lemon mixture. It's served with forcemeat balls and bacon, with the option to blend eggs into the sauce.
summary_3: This recipe makes a stew by boiling a calf's head, thickening the resulting broth with butter, flour, and an egg-lemon mixture, then serving it with forcemeat balls, bacon, and optional blended eggs.

text: Einstein was displeased with quantum theory and mechanics (the very theory he helped create), despite its acceptance by other physicists, stating that God "is not playing at dice."Einstein continued to maintain his disbelief in the theory, and attempted unsuccessfully to disprove it until he died at the age of 76.In 1917, at the height of his work on relativity, Einstein published an article in Physikalische Zeitschrift that proposed the possibility of stimulated emission, the physical process that makes possible the maser and the laser.This article showed that the statistics of absorption and emission of light would only be consistent with Planck's distribution law if the emission of light into a mode with n photons would be enhanced statistically compared to the emission of light into an empty mode.This paper was enormously influential in the later development of quantum mechanics, because it was the first paper to show that the statistics of atomic transitions had simple laws.Einstein discovered Louis de Broglie's work, and supported his ideas, which were received skeptically at first.In another major paper from this era, Einstein gave a wave equation for de Broglie waves, which Einstein suggested was the Hamilton-Jacobi equation of mechanics.This paper would inspire Schrodinger's work of 1926.
summary_1: Einstein expressed dissatisfaction with quantum theory and mechanics, famously stating that 'God does not play dice.' Despite widespread acceptance among other physicists, he persisted in challenging the theory without success until his death at 76. In 1917, during his relativity work, Einstein published an article suggesting stimulated emission, a concept fundamental to masers and lasers. The article highlighted the statistical enhancement of light emission into modes with n photons versus empty ones. This work significantly influenced quantum mechanics, being the first to demonstrate straightforward atomic transition statistic rules. Separately, Einstein endorsed French physicist Louis de Broglie's work, then met with skepticism. Following de Broglie's theories, Einstein introduced a wave equation, proposing it as the Hamilton-Jacobi equation of mechanics. This work laid the groundwork for Schrödinger's 1926 achievements.
summary_2: In 1917, while working on relativity, Einstein proposed stimulated emission, a concept key to masers and lasers. He also supported French physicist Louis de Broglie's unpopular ideas, leading to a wave equation. These contributions significantly influenced quantum mechanics, paving the way for Schrödinger's 1926 breakthrough. Despite disagreements, Einstein's work was instrumental in shaping quantum theory.
summary_3: Einstein's proposal of stimulated emission in 1917 greatly contributed to quantum mechanics, notably influencing Schrödinger's 1926 breakthrough, despite some disagreements.

text: Static electricity is like a teeter-totter.What happens if a teeter-totter is balanced?Correct!It does not move.What about when its not balanced?Yes, it will now begin to move.Charges move when they are not balanced.Charges can build up by friction.Maybe you rub your feet on a wool mat or carpet.Rubber soled shoes readily gain charges.The wool carpet easily gives up charges.The two items become unbalanced.One item has a positive charge.The other has a negative charge.The difference in charge is called static electricity.Just like the teeter-totter, something is going to move.Positive charges build up on the mat.Negative charges build up on you.
summary_1: Static electricity is similar to a seesaw at rest. When a seesaw is balanced, it remains stationary. Once it becomes imbalanced, movement occurs. Static electricity operates under a comparable principle; charges must be unbalanced for motion to take place. This imbalance can develop through friction between certain materials. For instance, when one walks across a carpet while wearing rubber-soled shoes, electrons may transfer from their footwear to the carpet fibers due to friction. Consequently, an excess of negative charges accumulates on the individual, while the carpet retains an abundance of positive charges. The resulting disparity generates static electricity.
summary_2: Walking on carpets in rubber soles can generate static electricity by transferring electrons via friction, creating an imbalance of charges that builds up negatively on individuals and positively on carpets.
summary_3: Walking in rubber soles on carpets generates static electricity due to electron transfer causing positive charge buildup on carpets and negative charge on individuals.

text: When American 11 struck the World Trade Center at 8:46, no one in the White House or traveling with the President knew that it had been hijacked.While that information circulated within the FAA, we found no evidence that the hijacking was reported to any other agency in Washington before 8:46.Most federal agencies learned about the crash in New York from CNN.Within the FAA, the administrator, Jane Garvey, and her acting deputy, Monte Belger, had not been told of a confirmed hijacking before they learned from television that a plane had crashed.Others in the agency were aware of it, as we explained earlier in this chapter.Inside the National Military Command Center, the deputy director of operations and his assistant began notifying senior Pentagon officials of the incident.At about 9:00, the senior NMCC operations officer reached out to the FAA operations center for information.Although the NMCC was advised of the hijacking of American 11, the scrambling of jets was not discussed.In Sarasota, Florida, the presidential motorcade was arriving at the Emma E. Booker Elementary School, where President Bush was to read to a class and talk about education.White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card told us he was standing with the President outside the classroom when Senior Advisor to the President Karl Rove first informed them that a small, twin-engine plane had crashed into the World Trade Center.The President's reaction was that the incident must have been caused by pilot error.At 8:55, before entering the classroom, the President spoke to National Security Advisor Condoleezza Rice, who was at the White House.She recalled first telling the President it was a twin-engine aircraft-and then a commercial aircraft-that had struck the World Trade Center, adding "that's all we know right now, Mr. President."At the White House, Vice President Dick Cheney had just sat down for a meeting when his assistant told him to turn on his television because a plane had struck the NorthTower of the World Trade Center.The Vice President was wondering "How the hell could a plane hit the World Trade Center" when he saw the second aircraft strike the South Tower.Elsewhere in the White House, a series of 9:00 meetings was about to begin.In the absence of information that the crash was anything other than an accident, the White House staff monitored the news as they went ahead with their regular schedules.
summary_1: On September 11, 2001, American Airlines Flight 11 crashed into the World Trade Center. Neither the White House nor the President were initially aware of the hijacking. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) had knowledge of the hijacking but did not report it to other agencies prior to the impact. Most federal agencies, including the White House, learned about the crash from CNN. Inside the FAA, Administrator Jane Garvey and Deputy Monte Belger were unaware of the confirmed hijacking until they saw it on TV. The National Military Command Center started notifying senior Pentagon officials about the incident around 9:00 am. However, there was no discussion about scrambling jets. At 8:55 am, before entering a classroom to read to students, President Bush was informed by his advisor that a 'twin-engine aircraft' had crashed into the WTC; he assumed it was pilot error. Upon seeing the second plane hit the South Tower, Vice President Cheney wondered how a plane could hit the building. With no information suggesting otherwise, White House staff continued with their regular schedules while monitoring the news.
summary_2: On September 11, 2001, American Airlines Flight 11 hit the World Trade Center. Initially, the White House and President were unaware. The FAA knew of the hijacking but didn't inform others before the impact. Most federal agencies, including the White House, learned about the crash from CNN. Inside the FAA, administrators weren't aware of the confirmed hijacking until seeing it on TV. The National Military Command Center began notifying senior Pentagon officials, but there was no discussion about scrambling jets. Before reading to students at 8:55 am, President Bush was told of a 'twin-engine aircraft' crashing into the WTC, assuming pilot error. Despite the second plane hitting the South Tower, White House staff carried on with their routines while monitoring the news.
summary_3: On September 11, 2001, despite the FAA being aware of American Airlines Flight 11's hijacking, they failed to inform others prior to its impact with the World Trade Center; subsequent notifications to federal agencies came primarily from CNN broadcasts, leading to delayed responses, including no immediate jet scrambles by the National Military Command Center.

text: His famous series of sixteen great designs for the Apocalypse is dated 1498, as is his engraving of St. Michael Fighting the Dragon.He made the first seven scenes of the Great Passion in the same year, and a little later, a series of eleven on the Holy Family and saints.The Seven Sorrows Polyptych, commissioned by Frederick III of Saxony in 1496, was executed by Durer and his assistants c.Around 1503-1505 he produced the first seventeen of a set illustrating the Life of the Virgin, which he did not finish for some years.Neither these, nor the Great Passion, were published as sets until several years later, but prints were sold individually in considerable numbers.During the same period Durer trained himself in the difficult art of using the burin to make engravings.It is possible he had begun learning this skill during his early training with his father, as it was also an essential skill of the goldsmith.In 1496 he executed the Prodigal Son, which the Italian Renaissance art historian Giorgio Vasari singled out for praise some decades later, noting its Germanic quality.He was soon producing some spectacular and original images, notably Nemesis (1502), The Sea Monster (1498), and Saint Eustace (c.1501), with a highly detailed landscape background and animals.His landscapes of this period, such as Pond in the Woods and Willow Mill, are quite different from his earlier watercolours.There is a much greater emphasis on capturing atmosphere, rather than depicting topography.He made a number of Madonnas, single religious figures, and small scenes with comic peasant figures.Prints are highly portable and these works made Durer famous throughout the main artistic centres of Europe within a very few years.
summary_1: Albrecht Dürer, a renowned artist, created a notable series of designs for the Apocalypse in 1498, along with an engraving of St. Michael Fighting the Dragon. In the same year, he crafted the initial seven scenes of the Great Passion and a series of eleven on the Holy Family and saints. The Seven Sorrows Polyptych, commissioned by Frederick III of Saxony in 1496, was completed by Dürer and his team around the same time. Between 1503 and 1505, he started working on the first seventeen of a series illustrating the Life of the Virgin, finishing it several years later. Neither of these were published as complete sets immediately; however, individual prints were widely circulated. During this period, Dürer mastered the use of the burin for engravings, possibly starting his training during his early years with his goldsmith father. His work from this era includes the Prodigal Son, praised by Italian Renaissance art historian Giorgio Vasari for its Germanic qualities. He subsequently produced striking images like Nemesis (1502), The Sea Monster (1498), and Saint Eustace (circa 1501). Landscapes from this period, including Pond in the Woods and Willow Mill, showcase atmospheric elements instead of precise topographical details. Dürer's prints gained immense popularity across major European artistic hubs within just a few years.
summary_2: Renowned artist Albrecht Dürer produced significant works between 1496 and 1505, including the Apocalypse series, the Great Passion, and the Holy Family series. He also worked on the Seven Sorrows Polyptych, the Life of the Virgin series, and various standalone pieces. Known for his innovative burin engravings, Dürer's popular prints often featured landscapes and religious themes, gaining wide circulation in Europe.
summary_3: Albrecht Dürer created notable print series like the Apocalypse series and the Great Passion from 1496 to 1505, known for intricate burin engravings reflecting religious themes with European distribution.

text: Tom plays pool in a deserted pool hall , pocketing two balls by lowdown means and then wakes Jerry up by shooting the 10-ball into the pocket where he is sleeping .Jerry awakes just in time to avoid the 10-ball and is carried out to the ball return , where the 10 and the 13 smash the mouse between each other .Jerry is mad and walks up through the pocket , first sees nothing , but after a few steps back to the pocket , he spots Tom perched behind it .Jerry tries to jump into another corner pocket , but Tom aims a cue ball with so much force that it roll's into the pocket , and spins back out of it and it rolls Jerry backwards to Tom , who has made a ramp with his cue stick for the mouse to slide up .Jerry stops at the top of the stick and is then blown down by Tom , who then shoots a stream of balls to make the mouse flat .The whole train rebounds back towards the cat and the balls stack up at Tom's end of the table .Tom shoots all the balls in succession with his cue , and then tries to shoot Jerry , but the mouse hangs onto the cue tip .The cat , as if he were saying `` Have it your way '' , chalks up and shoots the 8-ball using Jerry .The mouse drops off the cue tip and then is upended by the 8-ball rolling in circles , and Tom forces Jerry to jump through the ball rack as if he were a circus performer .Tom then sets it on fire to add an additional level of torment , and when Jerry accomplishes this with poise , Tom discards the flaming rack and shoots the 8-ball across the table and back .
summary_1: In a solitary pool hall, Tom engages in unsportsmanlike conduct, sinking two balls via deceitful methods before rousing Jerry from slumber by propelling the 10-ball into the pocket where he dozes. As Jerry stirs just in time to dodge the 10-ball, he is swept to the ball return, where the 10 and 13 collide, trapping him between them. Enraged, Jerry ascends from the pocket, initially spotting no sign of Tom. However, upon retracing his steps, he detects Tom balanced behind the pocket. Jerry attempts to leap into another corner pocket, but Tom hurls a cue ball with such force that it ricochets into the pocket, rebounding back and pushing Jerry towards Tom. Perched atop a makeshift ramp crafted from Tom's cue stick, Jerry teeters on the edge before being propelled airborne by Tom, who subsequently bombards him with a barrage of balls, causing Jerry to somersault backwards. Undeterred, Tom lines up shots, aiming to squash Jerry beneath the balls. Despite Jerry clinging to the cue tip for safety, Tom persists, ultimately launching the 8-ball with Jerry attached, which rolls in circles until Jerry tumbles off, only to be thrust through a fiery ball rack, culminating in Tom hurling the flaming apparatus across the table, followed by a final shot of the 8-ball.
summary_2: Tom plays unfairly, waking Jerry by shooting the 10-ball near him. Trapped between balls, Jerry escapes, only to be sent flying by a thrown cue ball. Balancing on a ramp, Jerry's launched into the air, dodging several hurtling balls. Tom then shoots an 8-ball with Jerry attached, sending him rolling through a flaming ball rack, concluding with Tom tossing the burning assembly across the table, ending with the 8-ball.
summary_3: Jerry narrowly avoids being hit by various pool balls shot by Tom, ultimately getting launched across a flaming ball rack after being tied to an 8-ball which Tom throws across the table.

text: Michigan will lose $2 million in federal funding and $600,000 in state funding to provide legal aid to the poor in 2003, according to Deierdre L. Weir, executive director of the Legal Aid and Defender Association, Inc., the state's largest provider of legal services to the poor.Current federal funds of nearly $10.7 million from the Legal Services Corporation (LSC) will drop to $8.7 million for next year, according to Weir.She said that the reductions reflect a decline in the number of persons in the state who are living in poverty, according to the U.S. Census Bureau's 2000 census.LSC uses census data to determine funding across the nation, and according to the census, the state's poverty population fell from an estimated 1.2 million in 1990 to an estimated 968,000 in 2000.The state's legal aid agencies are also bracing for yet another cut in 2003 of some $600,000 of state funding.A portion of filing fees paid by litigants in the state's circuit courts, and a portion of interest on lawyers trust accounts (IOLTA) are earmarked for Michigan legal aid programs.These funds are expected to drop from currently $7.5 million in 2002 to $6.9 million when the Michigan State Bar Foundation makes distributions next year.Most of the decrease is attributed to the past year's low interest rates."The irony of these funding cuts is that while there may be fewer poor people in Michigan today, the demand for service will not change because the poverty population remains so large and the legal aid funding so little that local providers will never able to serve all who need our service," said Weir."It's as if the poor will be victimized twice-once for being poor and again as victims of these funding cuts."The U.S. Census Bureau, in spite of its best efforts, cannot locate every poor person living in a census tract, therefore the poor are also undercounted, added Weir.The brunt of these cuts will be felt most in Wayne County where according to the census some 333,000 poor people live, the largest concentration of poverty in the state.LAD will lose more than $870,000 for legal aid in Wayne County, nearly half of the state's total loss, said Weir.While difficult to measure, the loss of funds will mean that several thousand of Michigan's poor in need of legal service will not receive it, or they will receive significantly limited service.Cutbacks will include service in such civil legal matters as landlord-tenant, bankruptcy, consumer, child custody, predatory lending, mortgage foreclosure, utility shutoffs, social security, wills, and probate."Local providers will have to work harder and smarter and use more technology instead of staff to provide as much service as we can with fewer dollars," said Weir."We will be providing more selfhelp training to clients enabling them to navigate the legal system on their own in routine matters, more assistance on the telephone, and less direct representation by attorneys in specific, high impact matters.Currently, Michigan has 13 legal aid agencies covering the state's 83 counties.
summary_1:
In 2003, Michigan's legal aid services face significant funding cuts, resulting in a combined loss of $2.6 million from both federal and state sources. The Legal Services Corporation (LSC) will reduce its funding from approximately $10.7 million to $8.7 million due to a reported decrease in the state's poverty population. This decrease is based on the 2000 U.S. Census Bureau data, which shows a reduction in the poverty population from 1.2 million in 1990 to 968,000 in 2000. 

Additionally, Michigan's legal aid programs anticipate a further reduction of $600,000 in state funding in 2003. This decrease is primarily attributed to lower interest rates affecting portions of filing fees and interest on lawyers' trust accounts (IOLTA), which support Michigan's legal aid programs. These funds are projected to decrease from $7.5 million in 2002 to $6.9 million in 2003.

Deirdre L. Weir, executive director of the Legal Aid and Defender Association, Inc., emphasizes that despite a potential decrease in the poverty population, the demand for legal aid services will remain high. She warns of the detrimental impact of these funding cuts, particularly in Wayne County, home to an estimated 333,000 impoverished individuals - the highest concentration of poverty in the state. As a result, the Legal Aid and Defender Association stands to lose over $870,000 for legal aid in Wayne County, nearly half of the state's total anticipated losses.

Ultimately, these funding cuts could deny several thousand disadvantaged Michiganders access to necessary legal services, forcing legal aid organizations to rely more heavily on technology and self-help resources to meet community needs with reduced financial means.
summary_2: Michigan's legal aid services faced significant funding cuts in 2003, with a combined loss of $2.6 million from federal and state sources. The Legal Services Corporation reduced its funding by $2 million, attributing it to a decreased poverty population based on 2000 census data. State funding was also expected to drop by $600,000 due to lower interest rates. Deirdre L. Weir highlighted that despite possible reductions in the poverty population, demand for legal aid would stay high, especially in Wayne County where an estimated 333,000 people lived in poverty. Losing over $870,000 for legal aid, the area would struggle to provide essential legal services without adequate financing.
summary_3: Legal aid services in Michigan suffered a $2.6 million funding cut in 2003 due to a $2 million reduction from the Legal Services Corporation and a projected $600,000 decrease in state funding, impacting primarily Wayne County where an estimated 333,000 people live in poverty, causing concern for providing necessary legal services amidst these financial constraints.

text: LONDON, England (CNN) -- The most eagerly anticipated animated film this year hits big screens this weekend, as "The Simpsons Movie" opens worldwide.The Screening Room spoke to creator Matt Groening and writer Al Jean in London about everyone's favorite two-dimensional yellow family.Simpsons supremo Matt Groening with his creations at the film's premiere in Springfield, Vermont Matt Groening told the Screening Room that fans had driven the demand for the movie."We've had fans clamoring for a movie for the past 18 years," he said.The film has taken four years to come to fruition, as writer Al Jean explained."What really held us up for a long time was to have enough people to do the show and the movie," he said."We talked for a while about doing the movie after the show is done, but the show is never done!So it really started in earnest in 2003, when we started working on this story that became the movie."Technology has also played its part.Jean continued, "The technology to do this film really wasn't even around five years ago.For example, there was this joke I once pitched and David Silverman, the director, started drawing and as I was pitching it, it went into the film and it was cut a day later.To go from pitch to cut in two days is pretty impressive."Its creators hope that "The Simpsons Movie" will both satisfy long-term fans and bring Homer and Marge's family to a new audience.Groening told the Screening Room, "This movie is designed to both honor the people who have loved the show all this time, so there's lots of little details for them in the movie, little characters and stuff who they know and love, but we also want people who don't know the family to not be completely confused.It is a complete movie experience, but again, we have a lot of little details that only the really, true die-hard fans are going to get."And fans can expect to be entertained by plenty of cartoon mishaps.Groening said, "When you see somebody fall off the roof in a live-action film, it's funny -- we all love it.But it's not as funny as when Homer falls off the roof.
summary_1: "The Simpsons Movie," an animated feature about the beloved two-dimensional yellow family, debuts globally this week, marking the culmination of 18 years of fan anticipation. Creator Matt Groening attributes the film's realization to persistent fan demand. Four years were spent bringing the project to life due to scheduling constraints; initially, the team considered completing the movie post-series conclusion. However, given the show's perpetual production, work began in earnest in 2003. Technological advancements facilitated the process—a joke conceived and drawn within two days exemplifies the expediency enabled by modern tools. Hoping to appeal to both dedicated followers and novice audiences, the creators incorporated intricate details for devoted fans while ensuring accessibility for newcomers. A blend of classic humor and novel animation techniques promises entertainment value for viewers.
summary_2: "The Simpsons Movie", featuring the iconic yellow cartoon family, launches worldwide after 18 years of fan expectation. Creator Matt Groening credits consistent fan interest for its creation. Despite initial plans to complete it after the series ended, work started in 2003 due to ongoing production. The four-year development was eased by technological advances. Balancing fan service with accessibility, the creators aim to please both long-term fans and newcomers with detailed references and broad humor.
summary_3: "The Simpsons Movie," starring the famous yellow cartoon family, debuts globally after 18 years of anticipation, offering balanced appeal to dedicated followers and new viewers through intricate references and universal comedy.

text: On a day it celebrated 50 years of giving free legal advice, Southern Arizona Legal Aid announced it has received two grants totaling more than $7 million.One of the grants includes the creation of a Web site with legal advice for the poor.A three-year grant worth $6.6 million and a separate technology grant were announced at a press conference and dinner held Thursday at Evo.A. DeConcini Federal Courthouse, 405 W. Congress St. Deconcini was one of the organization's early board members.Thursday's celebration was the first public even held at the courthouse.About 100 members of the legal community attended, including state Attorney General Janet Napolitano and Arizona Supreme Court Justice Thomas Zlaket.Both grants come from the Legal Services., a private, nonprofit corporation established by Congress in 1974 to offer poor people equal access to the justice system.It's funded through congressional appropriation.The $6.6 million grant will pay for staffing operations.The Web site, which will be created with a $50,000 grant, is intended to offer legal advice to poor people across Arizona, said Paul Julian, chief executive officer of Southern Arizona Legal Aid.He said he wants every poor person in Arizona to have legal help."This is another step in trying to realize that.We feel like we do a pretty good job of helping people who find us," Julian said.Julian said that though most people do not own computers, they can still access them at libraries, schools, and courthouses.He said the Web site will help bridge the "digital divide" that keeps the poor from using the Internet as a resource.Southern Arizona Legal Aid was founded in 1951 as the Legal Aid Society of the Pima County Bar Association.It offered free legal advice on civil matters including disputes in small claims court, divorce proceedings and obtaining Social Security benefits.Charles Ares, a member of the board of directors in the 1950s, said the office was kind of a charity operation.
summary_1: Southern Arizona Legal Aid (SALA) marked its 50th anniversary of providing free legal advice by announcing it had received grants amounting to over $7 million. The grants include a three-year grant of $6.6 million and a separate technology grant, both awarded at a press conference and dinner held at the Evo.A. DeConcini Federal Courthouse. SALA plans to use part of the funds to create a website offering legal advice to low-income Arizona residents. This initiative aims to address the digital divide that prevents many poor individuals from utilizing the internet as a resource. The web platform will provide guidance on various legal issues, accessible at libraries, schools, and courthouses. Founded in 1951, SALA initially focused on offering complimentary counsel for civil matters such as small claims court disputes, divorces, and Social Security benefit applications. Initially operating as a charitable endeavor, SALA has since evolved into an essential resource for disadvantaged communities seeking legal support.
summary_2: SALA celebrates 50 years with new grants totaling over $7M, including one for $6.6M and a tech grant, announced at a ceremony. Funds aid creation of a website offering free legal advice to low-income Arizonans via libraries, schools, and courthouses, addressing the digital divide. Established in 1951, SALA began as charity offering free help for civil cases like divorces and benefits; now, it's crucial for underserved communities needing legal assistance.
summary_3: At its 50th anniversary celebration, SALA announces over $7M in new grants, notably a $6.6M award funding a website providing free legal advice to underprivileged Arizonans through libraries, schools, and courthouses, expanding on its initial mission started in 1951.

text: The Principals Committee had its first meeting on al Qaeda on September 4.On the day of the meeting, Clarke sent Rice an impassioned personal note.He criticized U.S. counterterrorism efforts past and present.The "real question" before the principals, he wrote, was "are we serious about dealing with the al Qida threat?Is al Qida a big deal?Decision makers should imagine themselves on a future day when the CSG has not succeeded in stopping al Qida attacks and hundreds of Americans lay dead in several countries, including the US," Clarke wrote."What would those decision makers wish that they had done earlier?That future day could happen at any time."Clarke then turned to the Cole."The fact that the USS Cole was attacked during the last Administration does not absolve us of responding for the attack," he wrote."Many in al Qida and the Taliban may have drawn the wrong lesson from the Cole: that they can kill Americans without there being a US response, without there being a price."
summary_1: The initial meeting of the Principals Committee regarding al Qaeda took place on September 4. Prior to this gathering, Clarke penned a fervent letter to Rice, expressing his concerns about U.S. counterterrorism strategies. He critiqued both past and present efforts, posing two crucial questions: Is al Qaeda a significant threat? Are we genuinely committed to addressing this threat? Clarke urged decision-makers to envision a hypothetical scenario where the Counterterrorism Security Group fails to prevent al Qaeda attacks, resulting in numerous American casualties across various nations, including the U.S. He stressed that this catastrophic day could unfold at any given moment. Furthermore, Clarke emphasized that the unanswered repercussions from the USS Cole attack might lead certain elements within al Qaeda and the Taliban to believe they can assault Americans without facing consequences.
summary_2: Clarke wrote to Rice before a Principals Committee meeting on Sept 4, voicing concerns about US counterterrorism. He questioned if al Qaeda was a major threat and if there was real commitment to tackle it. He painted a grim picture of potential large-scale attacks causing many American casualties, linking it to unresolved issues post-USS Cole attack and possible misconceptions among al Qaeda and the Taliban about impunity for attacking Americans.
summary_3: Clarke warned Rice before a meeting that US counterterrorism efforts might be underestimating Al-Qaeda's threat, pointing to potential mass casualty attacks due to unresolved USS Cole issues and perceived American impunity.

text: Porky is looking all over the big city for a hotel room , but due to a convention there are no vacancies .Porky takes the only available vacancy at one hotel , but will have to share with Daffy Duck , who is a very loud , obnoxious and annoying sort .Daffy introduces his invisible kangaroo friend `` Hymie '' , but Porky wo n't believe that .Daffy spends the rest of the night annoying Porky : pestering him with questions , shaking the bed , spilling water from a glass , hogging the blanket and finally literally sending the both of them flying off the bed when Daffy kicks , and startles , Porky with his literally frozen feet .Fed up with his antics , Porky stuffs Daffy in a pillow case and drops him out of the window .As Porky goes back to bed , Daffy returns bandaged , but shakes them off and prepares to get revenge .Daffy tricks the half-asleep pig into stepping out of a window thinking he 's boarding a train .Daffy hides the window saying it 's `` too gruesome '' to watch .Suddenly he hears train noises , and behind the shade , sees the still-drowsy Porky pulling away on an actual train and waving at Daffy .Daffy finds this silly .Then he bounces all around the room , `` Hoo-Hoo ! ''- ing wildly .
summary_1: Porky, seeking a hotel room amidst a city convention crunch, reluctantly shares a space with boisterous Daffy Duck. The duo's tumultuous cohabitation involves Daffy's invisible companion, "Hymie," which Porky doubts exists. Annoyances escalate; Daffy badgers Porky with queries, drenches him while sleeping, steals blankets, and eventually propels them off the bed using frosty toes. Frustrated, Porky encases Daffy in a pillowcase and tosses him outside before resuming slumber. Resurfacing, Daffy reenters the room wrapped, ready for payback. He hoodwinks Porky into exiting a window by pretending they're aboard a train. Concealing the window, Daffy listens for reactions, then witnesses Porky nonchalantly pulling away on a real train, amusing himself with playful "hoo-hoos."
summary_2: Porky and Daffy share a chaotic hotel stay, feuding over an imaginary friend, Hymie. Daffy provokes Porky with endless questions, soaks him during sleep, robs his blanket, and finally ejects both from their shared bed. In retaliation, Porky traps Daffy in a pillowcase and discards him outdoors. Upon return, Daffy dupes Porky into stepping out a window, convincing him it's just another train ride. Unbeknownst to Daffy, he watches Porky happily pull away on a genuine train, oblivious to any deception.
summary_3: Porky and Daffy engage in a playful yet mischievous prank war at a hotel, ultimately leading to Daffy tricking Porky onto a real train and waving goodbye.

text: The properties of matter depend on the types of atoms that matter is made of.Matter can exist in two forms.It can be a pure substance.This means it is not mixed with anything.It can also be a combination of different substances.This means it can be a mix of different types of atoms.You may recall that atoms differ based on the numbers of protons they contain.Some atoms contain only one proton such as Hydrogen.Other atoms contain many protons.There are many types of atoms.For example, Helium has two protons.An Oxygen atom has eight.Water is composed of a two types of atoms.Water is made of two Hydrogen atoms and one Oxygen atoms.There are only so many types of atoms.These atoms can be mixed into an almost limitless amount of substances.So what do we call a substance that has only a single type of atom?
summary_1: Matter exists in two states: pure substances and combinations of various substances, which are essentially mixtures of diverse atomic structures. Atoms, the basic units of matter, vary depending on their proton count. For instance, hydrogen atoms have a single proton, while helium atoms possess two, and oxygen atoms boast eight. The number of protons in an atom determines its uniqueness. Water, a common compound, consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. Despite the vast array of possible combinations, there remains a finite number of distinct atom varieties. A term for a substance comprised of a singular atom type does not seem to have been established in this text.
summary_2: The text discusses matter's dual nature as pure substances or mixtures of different atomic structures. Atoms, the building blocks of matter, differ based on proton counts. For example, hydrogen has one proton, helium has two, and oxygen has eight. An atom's unique proton count defines it. Water, a typical compound, combines two hydrogens and one oxygen atom. Despite countless potential combinations, distinct atom types are limited. No specific term for a single-atom-type substance is mentioned.
summary_3: Matter consists of various atoms with unique proton counts defining each type, like water combining two hydrogens and an oxygen atom.

text: Tocqueville thought the conquest of Algeria was important for two reasons: first, his understanding of the international situation and France's position in the world, and, second, changes in French society.Tocqueville believed that war and colonization would "restore national pride, threatened", he believed, by "The gradual softening of social mores" in the middle classes.Their taste for "material pleasures" was spreading to the whole of society, giving it "an example of weakness and egotism".Applauding the methods of General Bugeaud, Tocqueville went so far to claim that "war in Africa is a science.Everyone is familiar with its rules and everyone can apply those rules with almost complete certainty of success.One of the greatest services that Field Marshal Bugeaud has rendered his country is to have spread, perfected and made everyone aware of this new science."Tocqueville advocated racial segregation in Algeria with two distinct legislations, one for European colonists and one for the Arab population.Such a two-tier arrangement would be fully realised with the 1870 Cremieux decree and the Indigenousness Code, which extended French citizenship to European settlers and Algerian Jews, whereas Muslim Algerians would be governed by Muslim law and restricted to a second-class citizenship.
summary_1: Alexis de Tocqueville supported France's conquest of Algeria due to his analysis of global politics and societal shifts within France. He saw military action and colonization as a means to rejuvenate national pride, which he felt was being eroded by the increasing materialism and self-interest permeating society. Tocqueville admired General Bugeaud's strategies, likening the conduct of war in Africa to a precise science, applicable by anyone who understands its principles. In terms of governance, Tocqueville proposed separate legal systems for different groups in Algeria - one for European colonizers and another for the local Arab populace. This bifurcation became reality through the 1870 Cremieux Decree and the Indigenousness Code, extending French citizenship rights to Jewish and European inhabitants while subjecting Muslim Algerians to Islamic law and inferior civil status.
summary_2: Tocqueville backed France's invasion of Algeria, viewing it as a solution to declining national pride and growing materialism. He endorsed General Bugeaud's tactics and suggested distinct legal systems for various groups. This led to differential treatment under the Cremieux Decree and Indigenousness Code, granting Jews and Europeans French citizenship but subjugating Muslims to Islamic law and lower civil standing.
summary_3: Tocqueville supported France's Algerian invasion, advocating for General Bugeaud's tactics and separate legal systems, leading to different rights for Jews, Europeans, and Muslims.

text: Although  Bin Laden, Atef, and KSM initially contemplated using established al Qaeda members to execute the planes operation, the late 1999 arrival in Kandahar of four aspiring jihadists from Germany suddenly presented a more attractive alternative.The Hamburg group shared the anti-U.S. fervor of the other candidates for the operation, but added the enormous advantages of fluency in English and familiarity with life in the West, based on years that each member of the group had spent living in Germany.Not surprisingly, Mohamed Atta, Ramzi Binalshibh, Marwan al Shehhi, and Ziad Jarrah would all become key players in the 9/11 conspiracy.Mohamed Atta was born on September 1, 1968, in Kafr el Sheikh, Egypt, to a middle-class family headed by his father, an attorney.After graduating from Cairo University with a degree in architectural engineering in 1990, Atta worked as an urban planner in Cairo for a couple of years.In the fall of 1991, he asked a German family he had met in Cairo to help him continue his education in Germany.They suggested he come to Hamburg and invited him to live with them there, at least initially.After completing a course in German, Atta traveled to Germany for the first time in July 1992.He resided briefly in Stuttgart and then, in the fall of 1992, moved to Hamburg to live with his host family.After enrolling at the University of Hamburg, he promptly transferred into the city engineering and planning course at the Technical University of Hamburg-Harburg, where he would remain registered as a student until the fall of 1999.He appears to have applied himself fairly seriously to his studies (at least in comparison to his jihadist friends) and actually received his degree shortly before traveling to Afghanistan.In school, Atta came across as very intelligent and reasonably pleasant, with an excellent command of the German language.When Atta arrived in Germany, he appeared religious, but not fanatically so.This would change, especially as his tendency to assert leadership became increasingly pronounced.According to Binalshibh, as early as 1995 Atta sought to organize a Muslim student association in Hamburg.In the fall of 1997, he joined a working group at the Quds mosque in Hamburg, a group designed to bridge the gap between Muslims and Christians.Atta proved a poor bridge, however, because of his abrasive and increasingly dogmatic personality.But among those who shared his beliefs, Atta stood out as a decisionmaker.
summary_1:
Four young men from Germany, known as the Hamburg Group, played crucial roles in the 9/11 attacks. They were fluent in English and familiar with Western culture due to their upbringing in Germany. The group consisted of Mohamed Atta, Ramzi Binalshibh, Marwan al Shehhi, and Ziad Jarrah. 

Mohamed Atta, born in Egypt, graduated from Cairo University in 1990 with a degree in architectural engineering. He moved to Germany in 1992 after being invited by a German family he had met in Cairo. Atta studied at the University of Hamburg before transferring to the Technical University of Hamburg-Harburg, where he pursued a degree in city engineering and planning. He was known for his intelligence and good command of German. Initially appearing religious but not excessively pious, Atta's demeanor changed over time, becoming more authoritative and divisive. By 1995, he attempted to establish a Muslim student association in Hamburg. In 1997, he participated in a working group at the Quds mosque aimed at fostering understanding between Muslims and Christians; however, his rigid views created discord rather than unity. Despite this, Atta emerged as a decisive figure among like-minded individuals.
summary_2: The Hamburg Group, four German-based terrorists, led key roles in 9/11. Members included Mohamed Atta, an Egyptian architect who grew radicalized while studying in Hamburg. Fluent in English and German, Atta co-piloted one of the planes on September 11th. His strict beliefs strained relationships, even within extremist circles.
summary_3: The Hamburg Group, including lead terrorist Mohamed Atta, played crucial roles in 9/11; Atta, fluent in English and German, co-piloted a plane.

text: When single father Thurman Williams needed help filling out papers in a custody suit recently, he didn't look to his lawyer for help.He walked to a computerized kiosk at the Lamoreaux Justice Center in Orange and started tapping the keys.As part of a legal experiment, litigants without lawyers across California are using computerized video kiosks to prepare common court filings and seek basic legal advice.The kiosk used by Williams is part of a statewide effort to cope with a flood of litigants who cannot afford or refuse to hire lawyers.Court officials statewide fear the number of self-represented litigants has reached crisis levels and threatens to clog court calendars.Like Williams, more than 6,000 Orange County litigants have initiated court actions on I-CAN!kiosks or accessed the programs on the Internet, using home computers.Similar programs are operating in Sacramento, San Diego and Ventura.A recent study of the kiosks' first 18 months of operation concluded it is too soon to tell if the system will relieve pressure on court calendars.But the report, by UC Irvine's School of Social Ecology, said users were overwhelmingly positive about the free legal assistance."It's made life a lot easier for me," Williams said."It's helped keep me from going to the poorhouse."The 29-year-old Orange resident was directed to a kiosk in the Lamoreaux Justice Center by court staff.After putting on headphones and following the directions of a videotaped instructor, Williams filled out a quarter-inch stack of paternity and custody documents.The exercise took 20 minutes; it would have cost him about $800 if he had relied on a lawyer, he said."It was a lot easier than I thought."Whether they can't afford a lawyer or just want to save money, more Californians are going to court without a lawyer."I'm just amazed at the numbers," said Commissioner Salvador Sarmiento, who hears between 40 and 90 child-support cases a day in Lamoreaux Justice Center.
summary_1: Thurman Williams, a single father, utilized an automated kiosk at the Lamoreaux Justice Center in Orange to complete paperwork for a custody case. This kiosk is part of a broader initiative to assist the increasing number of unrepresented litigants in California courts. The kiosks allow individuals to prepare standard court filings and access fundamental legal guidance. Over 6,000 Orange County residents have employed these kiosks or their online counterparts since their inception. Similar initiatives are underway in Sacramento, San Diego, and Ventura counties. A two-year review of the program by UC Irvine's School of Social Ecology reported that while it's early to determine if this approach alleviates court calendar congestion, users express high satisfaction with the complimentary legal aid. For instance, Williams, a 29-year-old man from Orange, successfully completed a pile of paternity and custody forms in 20 minutes through the kiosk, saving approximately $800 compared to hiring a lawyer.
summary_2: Single dad Thurman Williams used a courthouse kiosk to file custody papers, one of many across California helping unrepresented people navigate the system. Users like Williams save time and money; he finished his paperwork quickly and affordably via the machine. Known as "self-help" centers, they offer form completion and basic legal advice. While long-term impact on court schedules isn't clear yet, initial feedback shows high user satisfaction.
summary_3: Self-help kiosks at courthouses assist unrepresented individuals, like single father Thurman Williams, in completing legal paperwork swiftly and affordably, leading to high user satisfaction.

text: My parents, Kelly and Kelley, said that it was that time of year to take a family vacation.We've been to big ride parks that have hotels with large pools.This year my parents wanted to do something different.They wanted to take us all to Elk River Castle.After lots of planning we hit the road for our trip.My Brother Kelsey and I enjoyed the long car ride there.Once we arrive, the castle looked much bigger than we had imagined.There was so much to see and so much to do.There was a swimming pool, movie theater and an elevator to take us from floor to floor.What a magical place!I was so excited because we had the whole place to our family!We spent our vacation playing around the huge castle and finding small mysterious places.There was even a tiny room in the back of one of the closets.My brother, Kelsey, and I played hide and go seek for hours, watched movies and swam until the sun went down.It was sad when our vacation finally came to an end but we made some amazing memories.We'll never forget our trip to Elk River Castle!
summary_1: The family, including parents Kelly and Kelley, decided to forego their usual theme park vacation for something new: Elk River Castle. After meticulous planning, they embarked on their journey, with kids Kelsey and the narrator looking forward to the change. The castle turned out to be more magnificent than anticipated, boasting a swimming pool, a movie theater, and elevators. The siblings found endless entertainment exploring the vast castle, discovering hidden nooks and crannies, and even a secret room tucked away in a closet. They spent their days playing hide and seek, watching films, and swimming until sunset. Despite the inevitable end of their vacation, they left with cherished memories of their unique family adventure at Elk River Castle.
summary_2: The family swaps their regular theme park holiday for an extraordinary trip to Elk River Castle. Kids Kelsey and the narrator eagerly anticipate this novel experience. The castle surpasses expectations, offering amenities like a pool, cinema, and elevators. Siblings explore its expanse, uncovering concealed alcoves and a covert chamber within a wardrobe. Their days pass joyfully partaking in hide and seek, film screenings, and swimming till dusk. Though aware of their impending departure, they depart having created precious memories from their special family escapade at Elk River Castle.
summary_3: The family enjoys a memorable vacation at Elk River Castle, exploring hidden spaces and creating cherished memories together before sadly leaving.

text: Mike and Jeff are close friends.Their school is having a guessing game to guess how many gumballs are in a box.If they get the right amount they win $100.If they get close they get a $20 gift card.The box looks like it is missing some gumballs.It turns out some people are eating them when they place their guess.100 people guessed and took a piece of candy.The box is 10" by 10" by 10".Each gumball is 1" each.Mike guessed 500.Jeff guessed 800.They both said they would split their money they win, if they win.
summary_1: Mike and Jeff, good pals, learn about a guessing game at their school where participants estimate the number of gumballs in a cube-shaped box measuring 10" x 10" x 10", with each gumball being an inch wide. The prize for correctly guessing the exact number of gumballs is $100, while a near-accurate guess earns a $20 gift card. However, there seems to be a twist - after every participant makes their guess, they take a piece of candy from the box, which has led to some gumballs disappearing. Despite this, Mike estimates 500 gumballs, and Jeff bets on 800; they agree to share their winnings equally, should either of them win.
summary_2: Mike and Jeff, friends, hear of a guessing game awarding $100 for accurately estimating gumballs in a 10”x10”x10” container. A correct guess gets $20 for close attempts. Post-guess, players snag a sweet. Some gummies vanish due to this rule. Regardless, Mike assumes 500 gummies, and Jeff bets on 800, deciding to split any earnings.
summary_3: Mike and Jeff, friends, estimate the number of gumballs in a container to win money; Mike guesses 500, Jeff bets 800, with winners splitting earnings and receiving a gummy post-game.

text: Roma captain Francesco Totti set a new Serie A scoring record on Saturday as his side demolished Cesena 5-1.Two early goals from the 35-year-old striker saw him reach a total of 211 goals for Roma, which means he has scored more goals for one club than any other player in Serie A history.His tally sees him surpass the previous record of 210 set by the prolific Swedish striker Gunnar Nordahl who played for AC Milan in the 1950s."It's what I've always wanted, to wear this shirt and beat one record after another," said Totti, AFP reported."I've overtaken Nordahl and I'm proud of that.Now I'm aiming for Altafini," he added, AFP reported.Brazilian Jose Altafini is the joint third highest scorer (along with Giuseppe Meazza) in Serie A history with 216 goals.Totti's early brace and a goal from Fabio Borini put Roma 3-0 up with only eight minutes played.Juan and Miralem Pjanic added further goals in the second half after CM Eder had pulled a goal back for Cesena on the hour mark.The win lifts Roma to sixth -- although Napoli will overtake them again if they win at Siena on Sunday -- and boosts their chances of qualifying for European football next season.Cesena, however, remain mired in trouble hovering just above the foot of the table in 18th place with 15 points.
summary_1: On Saturday, Roma captain Francesco Totti broke the all-time Serie A scoring record for a single club, netting twice against Cesena in a match that ended 5-1. This achievement pushed Totti's career tally for Roma to 211 goals, surpassing the previous record of 210 held by Gunnar Nordahl, a prolific Swedish striker who played for AC Milan in the 1950s. An excited Totti expressed his delight, stating it was his dream to break records while donning the Roma jersey. He also revealed his intention to target Brazilian Jose Altafini's joint third-highest tally of 216 goals. The two early goals from Totti and a strike from Fabio Borini gave Roma an impressive 3-0 lead within the first eight minutes. Juan and Miralem Pjanic later contributed additional goals in the second half, despite Cesena's Eder managing to score once for his team. With this victory, Roma climbed to sixth place in the league standings, increasing their chances of playing European football next season. On the other hand, Cesena remained in 18th place, barely staying clear of relegation zone.
summary_2: Roma captain Francesco Totti breaks Serie A scoring record with two goals against Cesena, taking his total for Roma to 211, overtaking Gunnar Nordahl's record of 210. Excited Totti aims for third-highest tally of 216. Roma wins 5-1, climbing to sixth place, while Cesena stays just above relegation zone.
summary_3: Francesco Totti scores twice against Cesena, setting a new Serie A goalscoring record for Roma at 211, surpassing Gunnar Nordahl's previous record of 210.

text: The film begins with members of the Catholic Church digging up the body of a 19th century church official , whose casket has a box-shaped urn chained to it .Inside the box they discover artifacts belonging to Mater Lachrymarum , the last surviving member of the Three Mothers ; an ancient trio of powerful black witches .In particular , the box contains a magic cloak that , when worn by Mater Lachrymarum , increases her powers significantly .The urn is shipped to the Museum of Ancient Art in Rome , where Sarah Mandy , an American studying art restorationworks .Sarah is dating the curator Michael Pierce , a single father who is away from the museum that night .With help from the assistant curator , Sarah opens the box and finds the cloak , a dagger , and three statues representing the three witches .Sending Sarah to her office to retrieve tools to help her translate the text on the artifacts , the curator is promptly attacked by the demonic agents of Mater Lachrymarum .Sarah arrives too late to save her boss and starts to flee the museum .Unfortunately , she is pursued by Mater Lachrymarum 's familiar and is only able to escape when a disembodied voice magically throws open a series of locked doors keeping her trapped inside the museum .Sarah tells the police what happened as she spends the night with Michael and his son .Michael visits the Cardinal who sent him the urn only to find out that , shortly after mailing the urn to him , he had a severe stroke and is now in a coma .
summary_1:
A religious artifact related to Mater Lachrymarum, one of the Three Mothers, is unearthed, tied to a 19th-century cleric's remains. The artifact includes a potent cloak, a dagger, and statuettes signifying the three sorceresses. Initially stored at the Museum of Ancient Art in Rome, this relic falls into the hands of Sarah Mandy, an American restorer working there. Simultaneously, Sarah is romantically involved with Michael Pierce, the museum's curator and a single parent.

As Sarah prepares to decipher the artifact's engravings, demons linked to Mater Lachrymarum ambush her superior. Regrettably, Sarah returns to find her boss under attack and unable to rescue him. She manages to elude pursuit by Mater Lachrymarum's minion through magical intervention, which unlocks various barriers within the museum. Following these events, Sarah recounts the incident to law enforcement while spending the night with Michael and his child. Meanwhile, Michael learns about the cardinal responsible for sending the urn; however, the sender suffers a stroke right after dispatching the package and lapses into a coma.
summary_2: An ancient artifact connected to Mater Lachrymarum emerges, bound to a 19th-century priest's remains. It contains powerful items like a cloak, a dagger, and figurines symbolizing the Three Mothers. Initially kept at Rome's Museum of Ancient Art, it ends up with Sarah, an American restorer, who also happens to be dating Michael, the museum's curator and a single father. When preparing to decode the artifact's markings, supernatural forces strike her superior, but she fails to save him despite attempts. Afterward, Sarah shares details with authorities, spends time with Michael and his kid, and discovers that the cardinal behind the shipment has had a stroke and fallen into a coma.
summary_3: After discovering an ancient relic tied to Mater Lachrymarum, containing valuable items and once held at Rome's Museum of Ancient Art, restorer Sarah - involved with the museum's curator, Michael - reveals its existence to authorities when her superior gets struck down by supernatural forces; meanwhile, the shipping cardinal falls into a coma.

text: Madrid, Spain (CNN) -- Relatives of a woman killed in a Spanish airline crash were erroneously given the remains of another victim, and then were asked by authorities to return them, CNN partner network CNN+ reported Thursday.The victims of the crash were first laid out at a Madria convention center.A Madrid judge has opened an investigation into the error, and judicial sources say the initial indication is that the mixup occurred not in the proper identification of the victim, but in delivering the wrong remains to the family in question, CNN+ reported.The family Wednesday received an urn numbered 104, and were told it contained the ashes of their loved one, Pilar Gonzalez Ferreira, who died in the crash.But as the family was preparing to leave Madrid, officials called to tell them about the error and asked for the return of urn 104, CNN+ reported.Instead of urn 104, the family was supposed to have received urn 134, which actually contains the remains of Pilar Gonzalez, CNN+ reported, citing judicial sources and another family which also lost a relative in the crash.The Spanair MD82 jet crashed last week at Madrid's airport as the plane was trying to take off, killing 154 people.The aircraft, bound for Spain's Canary Islands, managed to rise only slightly before coming down quickly to the right of the runway, its tail section hitting the ground first, just off the asphalt.Then the out-of-control plane skidded and bounced at least three times as it careered 1,200 meters (3,840 feet) across uneven terrain and exploded, coming to rest in a gully, a top official of the investigative commission told a news conference in Madrid on Tuesday.Many of the bodies were badly charred from the fire, and authorities have used DNA samples to carry out numerous identifications.
summary_1: A family was mistakenly handed the wrong remains of a loved one after a deadly plane crash in Madrid, Spain. The actual remains belonged to Pilar Gonzalez Ferreira, one of the 154 victims of the Spanair MD82 jet crash at Madrid's airport. The mistake was discovered when authorities realized the incorrect delivery of urn 104 to the relatives. Officials contacted the family and requested the return of the urn, revealing the error. Instead, they should have been given urn 134, containing the correct remains of Pilar Gonzalez. The error is believed to have happened during the distribution process rather than the identification stage. Many victims suffered severe burns due to the post-crash fire, requiring DNA analysis for positive identification. A judge has initiated an investigation into this unfortunate incident.
summary_2: After a Madrid plane crash, a family received the wrong remains; the rightful owner was Pilar Gonzalez Ferreira. The error, discovered during urn distribution, likely occurred during distribution, not identification. Most victims had severe burns, necessitating DNA tests. The family was informed, and the mix-up is under investigation.
summary_3: Following a Madrid plane crash, it was determined that a family mistakenly received another person's remains instead of their loved one's, an issue believed to have arisen during the distribution process, with many victims having sustained severe burns requiring DNA tests for identification.

text: Moscow (CNN) -- Divers have completed their search of a Russian cruise ship that sank last weekend with the loss of many lives, the Emergency Situations Ministry told CNN Friday.The official death toll has reached 114 -- including 66 women, 28 children and 20 men, the ministry said.The bodies of 15 people are still missing.There were 208 people on the "Bulgaria" at the time of the accident Sunday, of whom 79 were rescued.Divers have checked all the boat's compartments, the ministry said, and are now looking for more bodies around the boat as well downstream on the Volga River, where they could have been carried by the current.The area where search efforts continue has been enlarged to 200 kilometers (125 miles) from the scene, Russian Transport Minister Igor Levitin said at a briefing Friday.Preparations are under way for the cruise ship to be raised from the river bottom in the coming days.Two large boat cranes, one from Moscow and another one from Volgograd, which will be used for the lifting, are on the way to the accident site."We have asked the Emergency Situations Ministry to keep 23 divers at the scene to continue the search for bodies even during the lifting operation," Levitin said.Specialist military divers were brought in mid-week to aid in the search efforts.Four people face criminal charges over the sinking of the ship, which Russian media have called the most devastating river accident in the country's history.
summary_1: A total of 114 fatalities have been confirmed after the Russian cruise ship, Bulgaria, tragically sank last week, according to Russia's Emergency Situations Ministry. The victims include 66 women, 28 children, and 20 men. Fifteen individuals remain unaccounted for. Initially carrying 208 passengers, 79 survived the disaster. Divers have thoroughly examined the vessel, searching both its interior compartments and surrounding waters nearby and further along the Volga River, anticipating possible locations where remains might have drifted due to the current. Search parameters have expanded to cover a stretch of 200 kilometers from the incident site. Plans are moving forward to salvage the submerged ship within the next few days using two large boat cranes, one each from Moscow and Volgograd. To ensure continuous search operations throughout the recovery process, an additional 23 divers will stay onsite. Military specialists joined the rescue mission earlier this week. Legal action has commenced against four individuals implicated in the catastrophe, recognized as one of Russia's deadliest maritime incidents on record.
summary_2: Russia's Emergency Situations Ministry confirms 114 deaths from the sinking of the Bulgaria, with 15 still missing. The ship carried 208 passengers; 79 survived. Divers have searched the ship and a 200 km stretch of the Volga River. Two boat cranes will salvage the ship. Four individuals face legal action. This tragedy marks one of Russia's deadliest maritime incidents.
summary_3: The Russian Emergency Situations Ministry has confirmed that over 100 people died when the Bulgaria sank, making it one of Russia's deadliest maritime incidents, with four individuals facing legal action.

text: Halting just outside the village, Harry formed his men with a front across the whole road, and directed the lines to advance, twenty yards apart.Then, placing himself at their head, he gave the word, and charged down the street upon the Roundheads.The latter, occupied by their attack upon the houses, were unconscious of the presence of their foe until he was close upon them, and were taken utterly by surprise.The force of the charge was irresistible, and the Roundheads, dispersed and on foot, were cut down in all directions.Groups of twos and threes stood together and attempted resistance, but the main body thought only of regaining their horses.In three minutes after the Royalists entered the village the surviving Roundheads were in full flight, hotly pursued by the victorious Cavaliers.These, being for the most part better mounted, overtook and slew many of the Roundheads, and not more than half the force which had set out returned to their quarters at Didcot.The pursuit continued to within half a mile of that place, and then Harry, knowing that there was a force of Roundhead infantry there, drew off from the pursuit, and returned to Chalcombe.He found that more than half of Sir Ralph Willoughy's men had been killed, many having been cut down before they could betake themselves to their arms, those quartered in the inn, and at two or three of the larger houses, having alone maintained a successful resistance until the arrival of succor.
summary_1: Harry led his troops to a village where Roundheads were attacking buildings. The Royalists surprised the enemy, who were unprepared for battle. The impact of the assault caused chaos among the Roundheads, resulting in many casualties. Small groups resisted briefly, while others fled. Most tried to reach their horses. Within three minutes, the remaining Roundheads retreated, pursued by the triumphant Cavaliers. Many escaped, leaving behind less than half of their initial forces. The chase ended near Didcot, when Harry halted due to nearby Roundhead infantry. Upon returning to Chalcombe, Harry discovered that more than half of Sir Ralph Willoughby's soldiers had perished, mainly because they couldn't access their weapons during the confusion.
summary_2: Royalist forces under Harry attacked an unsuspecting Roundhead contingent in a village, causing chaos and heavy losses. Outmaneuvered, most Roundheads either surrendered or fled, abandoning over half their numbers. Pursuit ended near Didcot due to approaching Roundhead infantry. Back at Chalcombe, it was found that over half of Sir Ralph Willoughby's men had died, primarily from weapon access issues amidst the tumult.
summary_3: Harry's royalists defeated a Roundhead force, causing heavy casualties and seizing their weapons, but were halted by incoming reinforcements before reaching Didcot; meanwhile, Sir Ralph Willoughby suffered significant losses due to weapon access problems.

text: My father was named James Page Jackson because he was born on the old Jackson plantation in Lancaster county, Virginia.He named one of his daughters Lancaster for a middle name in memory of his old home.Clarice Lancaster Jackson was her full name.A man named Galloway bought my father and brought him to Arkansas.Some called him by the name of Galloway, but my father always had all his children keep the name Jackson.There were fourteen of us, but only ten lived to grow up.He belonged to Mr. Galloway at the time of my birth, but even at that, I did not take the name Galloway as it would seem like I should.My father was a good carpenter; he was a fine cook, too; learned that back in Virginia.I'll tell you something interesting.The first cook stove ever brought to this town was one my father had his master to bring.He was cook at the Anthony House.You know about that, don't you?It was the first real fine hotel in Little Rock.When father went there to be head cook, all they had to cook on was big fireplaces and the big old Dutch ovens.Father just kept on telling about the stoves they had in Virginia, and at last they sent and got him one; it had to come by boat and took a long time.My father was proud that he was the one who set the first table ever spread in the Anthony House.
summary_1: James Page Jackson, born on the Jackson plantation in Virginia, passed on his name to his daughter Clarice Lancaster Jackson. Bought by Galloway and moved to Arkansas, Jackson maintained his family name despite servitude. A skilled carpenter and accomplished cook, he introduced the first cooking stove to their new hometown, which revolutionized food preparation at the Anthony House - the first high-class hotel in Little Rock. Despite limited resources, including large fireplaces and heavy Dutch ovens, Jackson persistently advocated for modern equipment until the desired stove arrived from Virginia. His determination led to his appointment as head cook at the Anthony House, where he pioneered the setting of its inaugural dining table.
summary_2: Born into slavery, James Page Jackson kept his family name and became a skilled carpenter and cook. Moved to Arkansas, he championed using a cooking stove, eventually becoming head cook at the Anthony House after securing a stove from Virginia. This transformed food prep there, marking him as a culinary innovator.
summary_3: James Page Jackson, born into slavery, became a notable culinary innovator, transforming food preparation at the Anthony House by introducing a cooking stove.

text: We drove about a great deal--the country at the back of Deauville, going away from the sea, is lovely--very like England--charming narrow roads with high banks and hedges on each side--big trees with spreading branches meeting overhead--stretches of green fields with cows grazing placidly and horses and colts gambolling about. It is a great grazing and breeding country. There are many haras (breeding stables) in the neighbourhood, and the big Norman posters are much in demand. I have friends who never take their horses to the country. They hire for the season a pair of strong Norman horses that go all day up and down hill at the same regular pace and who get over a vast amount of country. We stopped once or twice when we were a large party, two or three carriages, and had tea at one of the numerous farmhouses that were scattered about. Boiling water was a difficulty--milk, cider, good bread and butter, cheese we could always find--sometimes a galette, but a kettle and boiling water were entirely out of their habits. They used to boil the water in a large black pot, and take it out with a big spoon. However, it amused us, and the water really did boil.
summary_1: The narrator describes a scenic drive through the countryside behind Deauville, which resembles England with its charming narrow lanes bordered by high banks and hedges, expansive green fields, and large trees. The area is known for horse breeding, housing many haras and sought-after Norman horses. Traveling in this region often involves hiring local Norman horses renowned for their endurance and steady pacing. During the journey, they stop at several farmhouses offering hospitality despite occasional inconveniences such as procuring boiling water. Despite these minor hiccups, the experience remains enjoyable due to the availability of essential amenities like milk, cider, bread, butter, cheese, and occasionally galettes.
summary_2: A picturesque drive near Deauville mirrors English landscapes, dotted with quaint lanes, verdant pastures, and esteemed horse farms. Known for hardy Norman steeds, travelers frequently rent local horses, prized for stamina and consistent gait. Pitstops at hospitable farmsteads offer sustenance - milk, cider, bread, butter, cheese, sometimes crepes - overcoming any logistical hurdles.
summary_3: During a scenic trip around Deauville, visitors enjoy riding sturdy local horses across green pastures and stopping by farms for refreshments like milk, cider, and crepes.

text: We were cornered in a sort of way already. But these butchers up the cavern had been surprised, they were probably scared, and they had no special weapons, only those little hatchets of theirs. And that way lay escape. Their sturdy little forms--ever so much shorter and thicker than the mooncalf herds--were scattered up the slope in a way that was eloquent of indecision. I had the moral advantage of a mad bull in a street. But for all that, there seemed a tremendous crowd of them. Very probably there was. Those Selenites down the cleft had certainly some infernally long spears. It might be they had other surprises for us.... But, confound it! if we charged up the cave we should let them up behind us, and if we didn't those little brutes up the cave would probably get reinforced. Heaven alone knew what tremendous engines of warfare--guns, bombs, terrestrial torpedoes--this unknown world below our feet, this vaster world of which we had only pricked the outer cuticle, might not presently send up to our destruction. It became clear the only thing to do was to charge! It became clearer as the legs of a number of fresh Selenites appeared running down the cavern towards us.
summary_1: The situation looked dire, yet offered an opportunity for escape. The group of adversaries ahead, despite being armed with small axes, showed signs of uncertainty. This hesitation provided a potential edge, similar to a furious bull amidst panicking humans. However, the sheer quantity of foes posed a challenge. Although seemingly outnumbered, standing ground could result in reinforcements arriving from behind. Conversely, charging forward risked getting trapped by enemies emerging from the chasm below. With limited understanding of the alien civilization's weaponry, anticipating unforeseen threats such as guns, explosives, or underworld projectiles added another layer of complexity. In conclusion, immediate action was necessary due to incoming forces.
summary_2: Ahead, enemy numbers pose challenges, but their hesitancy offers hope. Outnumbered, holding ground may bring backup, while advancing risks entrapment over a chasm. Unfamiliar weapons complicate matters. Swift action needed against unknown incoming forces.
summary_3: Despite being outnumbered with unfamiliar weapons, taking swift action now could secure an advantage against uncertain incoming enemies, though caution is required due to potential traps and backups.
