text: Enter the Shoguns: Japan's austere, ruthless, but statesmanlike new ruler, Yoritomo Minamoto, set up his government in Kamakura (just south of modern Tokyo), well away from the "softening" influence of court life that had been the undoing of his predecessor, Kiyomori.First of the national rulers to take the title of sei-i tai-shogun ("barbarian-subduing great general"), Minamoto expanded and consolidated his power by confiscating lands from some of the defeated Taira and redistributing them to his samurai vassals.Minamoto died in 1199, and the feudal structure passed intact to the tutelage of his widow's family, the Hojo, who were content to play regent to a figurehead shogun, in much the same way as the Fujiwara had done with the emperor.The fiction of Japanese imperial power had become infinitely extendable.The emperor at Kyoto — still seconded by a Fujiwara regent at court — legitimized a Minamoto who was himself a military dictator controlled by a Hojo regent.In a country where form and substance were inextricably interrelated, two things counted in politics: symbolic authority and real power.Neither could exist without the other.A thwarted Mongol invasion in 1274 weakened the Kamakura regime.The fighting brought none of the usual spoils of war that provincial warlords and samurai had come to expect as payment.And the treasury was empty after earthquake, famine, and plague had crippled the economy.Buddhist monasteries were using their private armies to support imperial ambitions to bring power back to Kyoto.Worst of all, the Kamakura warriors, resenting the way the Kyoto court referred to them as "Eastern barbarians," sought refinement in a ruinous taste for luxury: extravagant feasts, rich costumes, and opulent homes.Kamakura was falling apart.
summary_1: Yoritomo Minamoto became Japan's new ruler after defeating the Taira clan, establishing his government in Kamakura, distancing himself from the softening influence of the imperial court. As the first national ruler to hold the title of sei-i tai-shogun, he strengthened his power by seizing land from defeated Taira members and distributing it among his samurai vassals. After Minamoto's death in 1199, the feudal system remained under the control of the Hojo family, functioning as regents for subsequent figurehead shoguns, similar to how the Fujiwara had managed emperors before. The illusion of Japanese imperial power persisted, with the emperor in Kyoto legitimizing a military dictatorship led by a Hojo regent. In this society, both symbolic authority and actual power were essential; one couldn't survive without the other. A failed Mongol invasion in 1274 weakened the Kamakura regime since there were no typical wartime benefits for regional lords or samurais due to an exhausted treasury caused by natural disasters and disease. Buddhist temples increased their political involvement, supporting imperial aspirations to restore power in Kyoto. Meanwhile, the Kamakura warriors indulged in lavish lifestyles, seeking sophistication through expensive feasts, clothing, and luxurious homes. These excesses further destabilized Kamakura's stability.
summary_2: After Yoritomo Minamoto's victory over the Taira clan, he established a government in Kamakura, becoming Japan's ruler. He seized Taira lands, distributing them to samurai vassals, solidifying his power. Post-Minamoto, the Hojo family controlled the feudal system as regents, maintaining a military dictatorship. Despite this, the emperor in Kyoto retained symbolic authority. The Kamakura regime weakened due to a failed Mongol invasion, natural disasters, and disease. The Hojo's grip loosened as Buddhist temples backed imperial restoration. Extravagant lifestyles among Kamakura warriors also contributed to societal instability.
summary_3: Following Yoritomo Minamoto's triumph, he founded a government in Kamakura, assuming Japan's leadership, but after his death, the Hojo family ruled as regents, upholding a military dictatorship until the Kamakura regime faltered due to external invasions, natural calamities, and lavish lifestyles, while the emperor in Kyoto held onto nominal authority.

text: Once upon a time there was a princess who lived in a high tower and she was not allowed to leave because of her mean mother.One day she chose to leave but her mother would not let her.The princess climbed out the window of the high tower and climbed down the south wall when her mother was sleeping.She wandered out a good ways.Finally she went into the forest where there are no electric poles but where there are some caves.There she met a young man who was running.His name was John.John asked the princess why such a beautiful woman like her was out in the middle of a forest.She said that she had been trapped for her whole life by an evil woman who said she was her mother.The man said that he would take the princess to a castle that was near.He also said that he thought that she may be the missing princess.As they go through the forest they run into many problems.They see that they are lost and have no way of finding where to go.After several days pass, the princess climbs up to the top of a tree in order to find out where they are.She sees that the castle where they want to go is not that far away and near a mountain.After thinking of the best way to get there, John and the princess go to the castle where they live for the rest of their lives.
summary_1: A princess, long confined to a tower by her cruel mother, decides to escape one night while her mother sleeps. She descends from the tower via its southern wall and ventures deep into a nearby forest, eventually stumbling upon a stranger named John during his own trek. The two converse, with the princess sharing her backstory, prompting John to speculate that she could be a missing royalty. Together, they face various obstacles throughout the woods until the princess ascends a tall tree, spotting their destination - a distant castle situated near a mountain. After assessing their route, the pair successfully reaches the castle, signaling the beginning of their new life together.
summary_2: Escaping her tower prison, a princess meets John in the forest, revealing her identity. They bond, overcome challenges, and reach a faraway castle, marking a fresh start for both.
summary_3: A princess escapes imprisonment, befriends John, overcomes obstacles, and starts anew at a distant castle with him.

text: The next evening, she arrived with a stack of glistening stopboxes containing sushi, sashimi, oysters in their shells, and Terran vegetables fresh plucked from their hydroponic beds.Wondering about the reason for her extravagance, I asked how work had gone that day."Emil came in.He's taking Dream's End.""Emil?""You've no memory left, old one.Emil Malaquez."You did that to test my affections.""What?""Calling him by his first name.I did that in a comedy once.'Nights with Karl and Groucho.'It was before your time.""The critics liked it.""I'm glad."A moment later: "That's not why I called him 'Emil'.""No. We lunched together.He's nice."
summary_1: She brought an array of gleaming stopboxes filled with sushi, sashimi, unopened oysters, and recently picked Terra vegetables. When questioned about this generosity, she revealed that Emil Malaquez would be handling Dream's End. She initially claimed to have used his first name to gauge affection, reminiscing about a past comedy performance titled 'Nights with Karl and Groucho'. However, she later admitted that the true reason for using his first name was due to having lunch together, mentioning that he seemed like a pleasant individual.
summary_2: A woman arrives bearing gifts of seafood and produce, revealing her acquaintance Emil will manage Dream's End. Initially citing a comedy show, she admits their recent shared meal led to addressing him informally.
summary_3: The woman reveals that Emil will run Dream's End and acknowledges they recently had an intimate meal together.

text: The one person who, by his interference, could have settled all doubts was debarred by circumstances from interfering in the matter. Wykham Delandre had quarrelled with his sister--or perhaps it was that she had quarrelled with him--and they were on terms not merely of armed neutrality but of bitter hatred. The quarrel had been antecedent to Margaret going to Brent's Rock. She and Wykham had almost come to blows. There had certainly been threats on one side and on the other; and in the end Wykham, overcome with passion, had ordered his sister to leave his house. She had risen straightway, and, without waiting to pack up even her own personal belongings, had walked out of the house. On the threshold she had paused for a moment to hurl a bitter threat at Wykham that he would rue in shame and despair to the last hour of his life his act of that day. Some weeks had since passed; and it was understood in the neighbourhood that Margaret had gone to London, when she suddenly appeared driving out with Geoffrey Brent, and the entire neighbourhood knew before nightfall that she had taken up her abode at the Rock. It was no subject of surprise that Brent had come back unexpectedly, for such was his usual custom. Even his own servants never knew when to expect him, for there was a private door, of which he alone had the key, by which he sometimes entered without anyone in the house being aware of his coming. This was his usual method of appearing after a long absence.
summary_1: Margaret Delandre had a falling out with her brother, Wykham, prior to her stay at Brent's Rock. Their argument led to Margaret leaving Wykham's house without packing any of her belongings. Following this incident, Margaret moved into Brent's Rock, accompanied by Geoffrey Brent. This news spread quickly throughout their community. Meanwhile, Wykham was barred from intervening due to their strained relationship. Margaret was initially believed to be in London post her departure from Wykham's residence. However, she resurfaced living at Brent's Rock, causing quite a stir within their social circle. Geoffrey Brent was known for making sudden returns, utilizing a secret entrance unknown to his staff, adding to the intrigue around his comings and goings.
summary_2: After an argument, Margaret Delandre left her brother Wykham's home for Brent's Rock, accompanied by Geoffrey Brent. The unexpected move sparked rumors, especially since Wykham was prevented from interfering. Initially thought to be in London, Margaret's actual location at Brent's Rock caused a sensation in their social circle. Known for surprise visits via a hidden entrance, Geoffrey further fueled the intrigue surrounding their situation.
summary_3: Margaret Delandre moved to Brent's Rock with Geoffrey Brent after an argument with her brother Wykham, igniting rumors due to Wykham's inability to intervene and the secrecy around their location.

text: (CNN) -- We'll let you finish, but The Muppets have the best Instagram account of all time.The feed was launched just over a month ago as part of a promotional push for their upcoming movie, "Muppets Most Wanted."But in between quippy posters and ads for the film, which is a sequel to 2011's blockbuster "The Muppets" with Jason Segel, there are ingenious "selfies" from the Muppets crew.In fact, the first post was a coy snapshot from Kermit, Miss Piggy and Gonzo, with a filter in full effect: And the selfies grew more adorable -- and more hilarious -- from there: We now have evidence of the time Animal burst in on Beaker in the bathroom.And we know what Gonzo does after a hard day of stunts."Gonzo treated himself to a massage today to try to work out all of his stuntman kinks.Even weirdos need pampering.#bougielife #yolo," reads the caption to this pic: The Muppets' curmudgeonly yet lovable critics, Statler and Waldorf, are still trying to get the hang of taking the perfect selfie -- "This is the fanciest calculator we've ever seen!"they were heard saying when the photo was taken -- while Rowlf is clearly a selfie king.From the Swedish Chef to Miss Piggy's evil alter ego, everyone has gotten in on the first-person photo sessions.The only people noticeably missing from the account are the Muppets' human co-stars in "Muppets Most Wanted," like Tina Fey, Ty Burrell and Ricky Gervais.As with the first "Muppets" film, which also starred Amy Adams, Chris Cooper and Rashida Jones, the "Muppets" sequel has plenty of human star power.In addition to Fey and Gervais, "Muppets Most Wanted" also has appearances from Tom Hiddleston, Salma Hayek, Stanley Tucci and Lady Gaga.
summary_1: A new Instagram account belonging to The Muppets was started about five weeks ago to promote their forthcoming movie, "Muppets Most Wanted". The account features humorous posters and advertisements for the film, interspersed with delightful "selfies" from various Muppet characters. The initial post featured Kermit, Miss Piggy, and Gonzo with a filter, setting the tone for subsequent posts. The selfies range from funny (Animal interrupting Beaker in the bathroom) to relaxing (Gonzo enjoying a massage), showcasing each character's personality. Noteworthy absentees from the account are the human cast members of "Muppets Most Wanted", such as Tina Fey, Ty Burrell, and Ricky Gervais. Despite their absence, the account includes a wide array of human stars from the movie, including Tom Hiddleston, Salma Hayek, Stanley Tucci, and Lady Gaga.
summary_2: The Muppets launched an Instagram promoting "Muppets Most Wanted," featuring humorous posters, ads, and playful "selfies." Posts include Kermit, Miss Piggy, Gonzo, Animal, and others, highlighting each one's personality. Human cast like Tina Fey absent, but other stars like Tom Hiddleston present.
summary_3: The Muppets started an Instagram campaign for "Muppets Most Wanted," sharing amusing character-specific posts, including celebrities like Tom Hiddleston.

text: The Golden Heian Era: The geomancers in 794 decided that Heian-kyo (modern Kyoto) would be an auspicious site for the imperial family.It was indeed — until 1869.Grants of tax-free land over the years had been made to Buddhist temples and members of the court aristocracy.The most powerful families thus carved out for themselves whole regions that were to become the fiefdoms of Japanese feudalism.By the end of the eighth century the clans had created a hierarchy of shiki, or rights, from the highest to the lowest ranks of society.The aristocrat or court patron lent his prestige to a powerful provincial proprietor, who employed a competent estate-manager to oversee smallholders, who in turn worked their farms with dependent laborers.This elaborate structure of interdependent rights and obligations was to serve Japanese society right into the 20th century.Meanwhile, Heian court life blossomed in an effusion of aesthetic expression.Princes and princesses judged the merits of birds, insects, flowers, roots, or seashells.Literary party games held in ornate palace gardens required each guest to compose a small poem as his wine cup floated toward him along a miniature winding channel of water.Expeditions were organized to the best viewing points for the first spring cherry blossoms, and special pavilions were built to watch the rising of the full moon.Every gesture, from the most banal opening of an umbrella to the sublimest act of lovemaking, had its appropriate ceremonial.Conversation often took the form of elegant exchanges of improvised verse.The changing role of Chinese culture in Japanese life was epitomized in the language itself.In the absence of an indigenous alphabet, Japanese scholars had with the greatest difficulty tried to adapt the complex ideograms of monosyllabic Chinese to the essentially polysyllabic Japanese.Thus developed the katakana system used as a vehicle for writing Buddhist names and concepts.After rival Fujiwara factions had been struggling for years to gain control of the imperial throne, they turned to the Taira and Minamoto armies in 1156 to wage the four-year war that heralded the end of the golden age of the Heian court.The Taira, controlling the region along the Inland Sea, defeated the Minamoto armies based in the Kanto province east of the capital.
summary_1: The Heian era, established in 794, thrived until 1869. Initially, grants of tax-exempt land led to powerful families dominating regions, forming the basis of future feudal fiefs. By the end of the 8th century, these families established a hierarchical system of rights, influencing every level of society. Aristocrats lent prestige to regional leaders, who managed smaller holdings through capable administrators. This intricate network of dependencies persisted into the 20th century. Culturally, the Heian court flourished with artistic refinement. Courtiers evaluated natural elements like birds, flowers, and even seashells. Literary gatherings featured poetry contests, while cherry blossom viewings and lunar observations became popular pastimes. Every action, no matter how mundane, carried specific rituals. Conversations frequently involved poetic verses. As early Japanese lacked an alphabet, scholars adapted Chinese characters for religious purposes, leading to the creation of the Katakana system. Regrettably, internal strife among Fujiwara factions resulted in wars between Taira and Minamoto forces in 1156. Ultimately, the Taira triumphed, marking the decline of the glorious Heian court era.
summary_2: The Heian period (794-1869) saw powerful families controlling regions, creating a hierarchy shaping future feudal fiefs. The aristocracy added prestige to local leaders, who administered smaller holdings. This complex dependency system lasted into the 20th century. Culturally, the Heian court was marked by artistic sophistication, with nature appreciated through poetry and rituals. Scholars later developed Katakana from Chinese characters due to Japan's lack of its own alphabet. However, internal conflicts weakened the Heian court, culminating in wars between Taira and Minamoto forces, signaling the beginning of the Heian era's downfall.
summary_3: During the Heian period (794-1869), powerful families controlled regions, forming a hierarchical structure that influenced future feudal fiefs, while culturally, the Heian court showcased artistic sophistication, leading to the development of Katakana due to Japan's absence of an indigenous alphabet; however, internal strife led to the decline of the Heian era, exemplified by wars between Taira and Minamoto forces.

text: In India to purchase some horses , British aristocrat , Lord Esketh and his wife , Edwina , come to the town of Ranchipur at the invitation of the elderly Maharani .Their marriage is an unhappy one and Lord Esketh announces his intention to return to England and begin divorce proceedings .The spoiled , insensitive Edwina scoffs at this .She renews in Ranchipur an acquaintance with a former lover , Tom Ransome , now a dissolute alcoholic .She also meets and attempts to seduce a distinguished Hindu physician , Dr. Rama Safti , a decent man who is the elderly Maharani's personal choice to succeed her someday .Safti at first resists , but ultimately succumbs to Edwina's charms and falls hopelessly in love with her .Lord Esketh becomes aware of this , but Safti saves him from a man-eating tiger during a safari .Safti admits his love for Edwina to Lord Esketh , who is now sympathetic toward this good man's plight .Ransome feels the same way , warning Edwina to stay away from Safti , a friend he admires .Edwina similarly falls into disfavor with the Maharani , who explains that Safti has been raised to lead a pure life and that Edwina is unworthy of him .Ranchipur suddenly is ravaged by a natural disaster , an earthquake and flood .Dr. Safti is so busy saving lives that he can not personally care for Edwina , who has fallen ill .Ransome looks after her as well as for young Fern Simon , who has declared her love for him .When a dam is exploded by dynamite and as a result the flood waters recede , it is Dr. Safti who reveals that Ransome is the one who risked his personal safety to save the people of Ranchipur .
summary_1: British noble Lord Esketh and his spouse Edwina visit Ranchipur, India, upon the Maharani's invite, intending to buy horses. Their union is strained; Lord Esketh plans to leave for England and initiate divorce proceedings, which Edwina dismisses. She rekindles ties with past lover Tom Ransome while pursuing a relationship with honorable Hindu doctor Rama Safti, whom she successfully romances despite initial resistance. Aware of their affair, Lord Esketh spares Safti when attacked by a man-eating tiger. Upon realizing Safti reciprocates Edwina's feelings, Lord Esketh empathizes. Meanwhile, Ransome - once friends with Safti - cautions Edwina against further involvement due to Safti's purity. The Maharani shares similar sentiments about Edwina being unfit for Safti. Soon, Ranchipur faces catastrophe via earthquakes and flooding, leaving Edwina sick and without immediate medical attention. During these crises, Ransome cares for both Edwina and local girl Fern Simon, who confesses romantic interest in him. After the controlled explosion of a dam reduces flood levels, Safti acknowledges Ransome's bravery in saving many citizens.
summary_2: Lord Esketh and wife Edwina visit Ranchipur at the Maharani's invitation. Tensions rise as Lord Esketh plans to divorce Edwina, who reconnects with ex-lover Tom Ransome and starts a relationship with Dr. Rama Safti. Amidst this, an injured Lord Esketh spares Safti from a tiger attack out of respect. Despite warnings from Ransome and the Maharani about her unsuitability for Safti, Edwina continues the affair. Natural disasters strike Ranchipur, leaving Edwina ill. Ransome cares for her and Fern Simon, while Safti recognizes Ransome's heroism during the disaster.
summary_3: In Ranchipur, Lord Esketh and his wife, Edwina, visiting the Maharani, face tension as Edwina resumes a past love with Tom Ransome and starts a new romance with Dr. Rama Safti, even after her husband plans a divorce; natural disasters hit, making Edwina sick, but she's cared for by Ransome, acknowledged by Safti for his bravery.

text: From a human point of view, a habitat is where you live.It might be your city, town, or neighborhood.Your habitat can be altered.Most people move a few times in their lives.But a plant cannot move.An animal may not be suited to live in another area.A habitat is the natural home or environment of an organism.Humans often destroy the habitats of other organisms.The loss of habitat can cause the extinction of species.Extinction is when a species disappears forever.Once a species is extinct, it can never be brought back.Humans cause habitat destruction in many ways.There are two common ways this happens.Land may be cleared.Another way is when an animal or plant is brought to an area where it does not belong.
summary_1: A habitat refers to the natural living space for any organism. For humans, it could be a city, town, or community they inhabit, which can change over time due to relocation. However, unlike humans, plants cannot move while animals may struggle adapting to new environments. A habitat encompasses the essential resources required by an organism for survival. Human activities frequently result in habitat destruction, leading to severe consequences such as species extinction. Extinction implies the permanent disappearance of a species, rendering its restoration impossible. Habitat devastation occurs primarily through land clearing and invasive species introduction. These actions disrupt ecosystems and endanger native organisms, potentially resulting in irreversible biodiversity loss.
summary_2: A habitat denotes the environment where an organism naturally lives, including cities for humans, who can relocate. Unlike mobile animals, plants remain stationary. An organism's habitat provides necessary resources for survival. Humans often destroy habitats, causing species extinction - a permanent condition due to resource depletion from factors like deforestation and invasive species, threatening native life forms and risking irrevocable biodiversity reduction.
summary_3: Humans and other organisms rely on their specific habitats for vital resources, but human activities can lead to irreversible habitat destruction, species loss, and reduced biodiversity.

text: The Bush administration in its first months faced many problems other than terrorism.They included the collapse of the Middle East peace process and, in April, a crisis over a U.S." spy plane" brought down in Chinese territory.The new administration also focused heavily on Russia, a new nuclear strategy that allowed missile defenses, Europe, Mexico, and the Persian Gulf.In the spring, reporting on terrorism surged dramatically.In chapter 8, we will explore this reporting and the ways agencies responded.These increasingly alarming reports, briefed to the President and top officials, became part of the context in which the new administration weighed its options for policy on al Qaeda.Except for a few reports that the CSG considered and apparently judged to be unreliable, none of these pointed specifically to possible al Qaeda action inside the United States-although the CSG continued to be concerned about the domestic threat.The mosaic of threat intelligence came from the Counterterrorist Center, which collected only abroad.Its reports were not supplemented by reports from the FBI.Clarke had expressed concern about an al Qaeda presence in the United States, and he worried about an attack on the White House by "Hizbollah, Hamas, al Qida and other terrorist organizations."In May, President Bush announced that Vice President Cheney would himself lead an effort looking at preparations for managing a possible attack by weapons of mass destruction and at more general problems of national preparedness.The next few months were mainly spent organizing the effort and bringing an admiral from the Sixth Fleet back to Washington to manage it.The Vice President's task force was just getting under way when the 9/11 attack occurred.
summary_1: The early months of the Bush administration saw several issues beyond terrorism, such as the crumbling Middle East peace process, a U.S. spy plane incident in China, focus on Russia, Europe, Mexico, and the Persian Gulf. However, by spring, there was a surge in reporting on terrorism. Chapter 8 delves into this reporting and how agencies reacted. These reports, shared with the President and senior officials, set the stage for the administration's considerations on al Qaeda policy. A handful of these reports, deemed unreliable, hinted at potential al Qaeda actions within the U.S., but the primary worry remained the international threat. The Counterterrorist Center provided most of the intel, focusing solely on foreign sources, without input from the FBI. Despite concerns about a U.S.-based al Qaeda presence, Clarke fretted about attacks on the White House by groups like Hizbollah, Hamas, al Qida, among others. In May, Vice President Cheney took charge of preparing for a potential WMD assault and broader emergency management tasks. Regrettably, the Vice President's group was still gearing up when the 9/11 tragedy struck.
summary_2: In the initial phase of Bush's tenure, various global matters emerged, including a faltering Middle East peace effort, a U.S. spy plane crisis in China, attention on Russia, Europe, Mexico, and the Persian Gulf. By spring, terrorism coverage surged. Reports, seen by the President and top officials, shaped the administration's stance on al Qaeda policy. Some reports, labeled dubious, suggested possible al Qaeda activities in the U.S., yet the main concern was the international threat. Most intelligence came from the Counterterrorist Center, concentrating on external sources, excluding FBI insights. Despite worries about domestic al Qaeda activity, fears of attacks on the White House by groups like Hizbollah, Hamas, al Qida persisted. By May, Vice President Cheney led preparations for potential WMD strikes and wider emergency duties. Unfortunately, his team was still readying when 9/11 occurred.
summary_3: During Bush's early presidency, global issues arose such as a stalling Middle East peace process, a U.S. spy plane incident in China, focus on Russia, Europe, Mexico, and the Persian Gulf, followed by increased terrorism scrutiny after spring; intelligence primarily sourced externally from the Counterterrorist Center informed the administration's stance on al Qaeda, with Vice President Cheney preparing for potential WMD attacks and broader emergency tasks, but his team was unprepared during 9/11.

text: (CNN) -- As Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad visited the U.N. General Assembly in New York last month, the spotlight was once again on Iran.And true to form, the Iranian president made his fair share of provocative statements for the Western media.But while Ahmadinejad's mercurial rants captured our media's attention, back in Iran a coordinated strategy against the women's movement continued.On the eve of Ahmadinejad's arrival to New York, Shiva Nazar Ahari, a prominent young female defender of human rights, received a heavy sentence of six years in prison on charges including the vague crime of "waging war against God" -- a convenient catch-all offense for anyone who criticizes the regime and its human rights record.There's no denying it -- Iran's women have had a bad year.Nazar Ahari joins a steadily increasing number of other women's rights activists who are in prison for no greater crime than their attempt to fight for the rights of the women.Hengameh Shahidi, Alieh Eghdam Doust, Bahareh Hedayat and Mahdiyeh Golrou have all been sent to Tehran's notorious Evin Prison on trumped-up charges related to their activism.And while Nobel Peace Prize laureate Shirin Ebadi, arguably the most internationally recognized Iranian women's rights activist, remains unable to safely return to her country, the government is targeting those affiliated with her for arrest and imprisonment, including her lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh and her former aide Jinous Sobhani.Since the 2009 disputed elections and associated government crackdown on the overall reform movement, the government has increasingly targeted women activists.The reasons behind this go well beyond the misogynist nature of Iran's religious leadership.Rather, it is more part of a deliberate and calculated strategy of the Iranian authorities to strike at the heart of the regime's greatest vulnerability -- internal legitimacy with its own people.See more CNN.com opinion articles Iran's government recognizes and fears the broader power of the women activists who have been on the front line of reform in Iran for more than a decade.One can roughly draw an analogy between the women's movement in Iran to movements of religious groups in Burma or Tibet, or the labor "solidarity" movements in the former Eastern bloc and associated labor-Roman Catholic solidarity in Poland -- all advocating initially for the freedoms of a specific group but which provoked government fears for their transformative power to promote broader human rights progress.While the outside world occasionally reacts to the most egregious manifestations of Iran's repression of women -- such as the international condemnation associated with Sakineh Mohammadi Ashtiani, an Iranian widow sentenced to stoning on charges of alleged adultery -- these events are often portrayed simply as a consequence of the regime's archaic viewpoint about gender.
summary_1: Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's visit to the U.N. General Assembly in New York drew global attention, but back in Iran, a strategic campaign against the women's movement persisted. Notably, Shiva Nazar Ahari, a young human rights advocate, was sentenced to six years in prison on charges including "waging war against God." She is among many women's rights activists incarcerated for fighting for women's rights. Hengameh Shahidi, Alieh Eghdam Doust, Bahareh Hedayat, and Mahdiyeh Golrou were also jailed for their activism. The government has been specifically targeting women activists since the 2009 contentious elections, reflecting a larger plan to undermine domestic support for the regime. This trend extends beyond mere misogyny; it represents a calculated move by the Iranian authorities to suppress potential threats to their rule. Renowned women's rights advocate Shirin Ebadi cannot safely return home due to ongoing persecution, and her associates face similar risks. Despite sporadic international outrage over incidents like Sakineh Mohammadi Ashtiani's stoning sentence, the underlying issue lies in the government's deep-seated fear of the transformative impact that empowered women could bring to the broader human rights landscape.
summary_2: During Ahmadinejad's U.N. visit, women's rights advocate Shiva Nazar Ahari was sentenced to six years in prison in Iran. She's one of several activists targeted since the 2009 elections, indicating a strategy to quell dissent. Other jailed advocates include Hengameh Shahidi, Alieh Eghdam Doust, Bahareh Hedayat, and Mahdiyeh Golrou. Renowned activist Shirin Ebadi remains in exile due to persecution. This isn't just about misogyny—it's a strategic silencing of those who could transform the human rights landscape.
summary_3: Iranian President Ahmadinejad visited the U.N. while women's rights advocate Shiva Nazar Ahari was sentenced to six years in prison, part of a strategy to suppress dissent since the 2009 elections, with other jailed advocates like Hengameh Shahidi, Alieh Eghdam Doust, Bahareh Hedayat, and Mahdiyeh Golrou.

text: Alexander II's death caused a great setback for the reform movement.One of his last ideas was to draft plans for an elected parliament, or Duma, which were completed the day before he died but not yet released to the Russian people.In a matter of 48 hours, Alexander II planned to release his plan for the duma to the Russian people.Had he lived, Russia might have followed a path to constitutional monarchy instead of the long road of oppression that defined his successor's reign.The first action Alexander III took after his father's death was to tear up those plans.A Duma would not come into fruition until 1905, when Alexander II's grandson, Nicholas II, commissioned the Duma following extreme pressure on the monarchy as a result of the Russian Revolution of 1905.The assassination triggered major suppression of civil liberties in Russia, and police brutality burst back in full force after experiencing some restraint under the reign of Alexander II, whose death was witnessed first-hand by his son, Alexander III, and his grandson, Nicholas II, both future emperors who vowed not to have the same fate befall them.Both of them used the Okhrana to arrest protestors and uproot suspected rebel groups, creating further suppression of personal freedom for the Russian people.A series of anti-Jewish pogroms and antisemitic legislation, the May Laws, were yet another result.Finally, the tsar's assassination also inspired anarchists to advocate "'propaganda by deed'--the use of a spectacular act of violence to incite revolution."With construction starting in 1883, the Church of the Savior on Blood was built on the site of Alexander's assassination and dedicated in his memory.
summary_1: Assassination of Tsar Alexander II led to significant setbacks in the reform movement. He had been planning to introduce an elected parliament, known as the Duma, having finalized the plans just a day prior to his demise. However, these plans never saw the light of day due to his untimely death. Instead, his successor, Alexander III, scrapped the idea immediately upon taking over. The concept of a Duma did not materialize until 1905, during the reign of Alexander II's grandson, Nicholas II, prompted by intense pressure from the Russian Revolution of 1905. Post Alexander II's assassination, there was a surge in repression of civil liberties, marked by increased police brutality, despite it being somewhat curbed earlier during Alexander II's rule. Both Alexander III and later Nicholas II employed the secret police, the Okhrana, to quell protests and suppress rebellious groups, thereby further restricting individual freedoms. This period also saw a rise in anti-Jewish pogroms and discriminatory laws, infamously known as the May Laws. Furthermore, the killing incited advocacy for 'propaganda by deed,' a philosophy endorsing violent acts to instigate revolution. As a memorial, the Church of the Savior on Blood was constructed at the location of Alexander's assassination, opening years later in 1883 as a tribute to him.
summary_2: Alexander II's assassination halted his plan for a Duma, leading to increased repression under Alexander III and Nicholas II. Civil liberties were suppressed, the Okhrana was used to quash dissent, and Jewish people faced persecution. The concept of a Duma was revived in 1905, influenced by the 1905 Revolution. A memorial, the Church of the Savior on Blood, was built at the assassination site.
summary_3: After Alexander II's assassination, repressive rule under Alexander III and Nicholas II ensued, with civil liberties suppressed, the Okhrana suppressing dissent, and Jewish people facing persecution; this continued until the concept of a Duma was revived in 1905 due to the 1905 Revolution, resulting in the Church of the Savior on Blood being built at the assassination site.

text: It is not enough to describe some objects by their location.We may also need to know its direction.For example, a wind blows a storm over your school.Where is that storm coming from?Where is it going?How can we describe a direction?The most common way is by using a compass.A compass is a device with a floating needle (Figure 2.1).The needle is a small magnet.The needle aligns itself with the Earth's magnetic field.The compass needle always points to magnetic north.If you have a compass and you find north.You can then know any other direction.See the directions, such as east, south, west, etc., on a compass rose.The Earth has two poles.It has a magnetic north pole.It also has a geographic north pole.These two poles are close to each other but not the exact same place.
summary_1: Objects aren't just described by location; direction is also crucial. For instance, a storm blown by the wind towards your school - where did it originate, and where is it heading? Describing direction often involves a compass, which contains a floating needle acting as a tiny magnet. This needle aligns with the Earth's magnetic field, consistently pointing towards magnetic north. With a compass, finding north allows for determining other directions through the compass rose markings for east, south, west, and so forth. The Earth features both a magnetic north pole and a geographic north pole, located near one another yet distinct.
summary_2: Compasses indicate direction using Earth's magnetic field, pointing to magnetic north. Knowing this helps determine other cardinal points. Storms move in specific directions from an origin point. While magnetic and geographic poles are close, they differ. A compass needle acts like a small magnet, lining up with Earth's magnetic field, showing magnetic north. This is vital for navigation and understanding object movement.
summary_3: A compass indicates direction by aligning with Earth's magnetic field, pointing to magnetic north, which is crucial for navigation and understanding object movement, even though magnetic and geographic poles slightly differ.

text: "What goes up must come down."You have probably heard that statement before.At one time this statement was true, but no longer.Since the 1960s, we have sent many spacecraft into space.Some are still traveling away from Earth.So it is possible to overcome gravity.Do you need a giant rocket to overcome gravity?No, you actually overcome gravity every day.Think about when you climb a set of stairs.When you do, you are overcoming gravity.What if you jump on a trampoline?You are overcoming gravity for a few seconds.Everyone can overcome gravity.You just need to apply a force larger than gravity.Think about that the next time you jump into the air.You are overcoming gravity for a brief second.Enjoy it while it lasts.Eventually, gravity will win the battle.
summary_1: The adage "what goes up must come down" isn't entirely accurate anymore. With advancements in technology since the 1960s, numerous spacecraft now journey away from Earth, defying gravity. Everyday occurrences like climbing stairs or jumping on a trampoline illustrate overcoming gravity - it's simply applying a force greater than gravity. So, while gravity may usually prevail, there are moments when we conquer it, even if only briefly.
summary_2: Since the 1960s, spacecraft have been able to travel away from Earth, disproving the saying "what goes up must come down." We often overcome gravity in daily activities like ascending stairs or bouncing on a trampoline. Gravity typically wins, but there are instances where we temporarily defeat it.
summary_3: Spacecraft since the 1960s have defied the adage "what goes up must come down" by traveling away from Earth, demonstrating occasional victories over gravity in everyday actions like climbing stairs or jumping on a trampoline.

text: { { lang } } centers on a man who roams the street night after night .Hidden under his hat and rain jacket he strives for one goal : to find the culprit - the one whom he can make responsible for his suffering .If he wanted to , he could confront him , but he lacks the audacity to do so .He considers suicide , but his courage fails him once again .The options do not appear to present him with a way out and would not personally satisfy him .Finley blames not himself , but only others .In this case he looks to his girlfriend , Violet .He drowns Violet in the bath whilst giving her a massage , Which had become a common ritual for them .On one hand he does this out of malice , on the other to be close to her just one more time .Through this action he wishes to break the growing distance he has come to feel between them , though the actual outcome is the infliction of the greatest possible loneliness , as he turns into a monster .Finley only realizes with hindsight that his misdeeds far surpass those of Violet .
summary_1: "Lang" follows a man named Finley who wanders the streets at night, seeking vengeance for his perceived wrongdoings against him. He hides beneath a hat and raincoat, aimlessly searching for someone to blame for his distress. Despite contemplating suicide, he cannot gather the courage to follow through. Instead, he shifts the responsibility onto others, specifically his girlfriend, Violet. In a cruel twist, Finley murders Violet by drowning her during their regular massages. His intention is to bridge the emotional gap between them, but instead, it results in immense isolation as he transforms into a "monster." It's only later that Finley acknowledges his transgressions exceeded Violet's supposed wrongdoings.
summary_2: Finley, from "Lang," roams city nights seeking revenge for perceived slights. Wearing a hat and coat, he searches randomly until targeting girlfriend Violet. Though suicidal, he lacks the nerve to act on these feelings. Blaming others, especially Violet, Finley eventually kills her via drowning during massages. Hoping this will heal their rift, Finley finds himself even more isolated. Realizing his actions were far worse than any alleged misdeeds committed by Violet, Finley finally accepts guilt for his monstrous behavior.
summary_3: Grieving over perceived wrongs, Finley seeks vengeance against girlfriend Violet, ultimately killing her before acknowledging responsibility for his own monstrous acts.

text: Should places at the same distance from the equator have the same climate?You might think they should.Unfor- tunately, you would not be correct to think this.Climate types vary due to other factors besides distance from the equator.So what are these factors?How can they have such a large impact on local climates?For one thing, these factors are big.You may wonder, are they as big as a car.Think bigger.Are they bigger than a house?Think bigger.Are they bigger than a football stadium?You are still not close.We are talking about mountains and oceans.They are big features and big factors.Oceans and mountains play a huge role in climates around the world.You can see this in Figure above .Only one of those factors is latitude, or distance from the equator.
summary_1: Places similar distances from the equator don't necessarily share the same climate due to influencing factors beyond mere proximity to the equator. The primary determinants are geographical features like mountains and oceans, which dwarf other elements in their impact on regional climates. While latitude plays a part, it's just one piece of the puzzle. These larger geographical aspects create diverse microclimates worldwide.
summary_2: Different places similar distances from the equator have varying climates due to influential geographical features like mountains and seas. Although latitude matters, large geographical aspects mainly shape various localized climates globally.
summary_3: Geography primarily influences climate more than mere latitude, with regional features shaping distinct local climates worldwide.

text: "Femme" is an apt description of the depiction of Madame White Snake and all her incarnations.It refers to a woman who is dangerously attractive, and lures men to their downfall with her sexual attractiveness.In both incarnations of Madame White snake, the authors depict her as bewitchingly beautiful.Toyoo, her human lover in "Lust of the White Serpant" cannot shake the image of her beauty from his mind and dreams of her, and finds himself "disturbed and agitated" by her "ethereal beauty".In "Eternal Prisoner," Madame White Snake's bewitching beauty follows her lover Hsü into his dreams, and the next morning "he was so distracted that he could not concentrate on doing business." Both of these stories align negative connotations with her beauty, suggesting that her sexuality is the cause of their distraction.In addition to distracting sexuality, the irregular characterization of Madame White Snake might be another trait her character has in common with the archetypical noir femme fatale.In her essay analyzing the noir film from a feminist perspective, Christine Gledhill writes "Not only is the hero frequently not sure whether the woman is honest or a deceiver, but the heroine's characterisation is itself fractured so that it is not evident to the audience whether she fills the [femme fatale] stereotype or not".
summary_1: The term "Femme Fatale" accurately represents the portrayal of Madame White Snake in both "Lust of the White Serpent" and "Eternal Prisoner". The character is depicted as dangerously attractive, leading men astray with her seductive beauty. Toyoo, smitten by her ethereal charm in "Lust of the White Serpent", remains haunted by her beauty, which disrupts his peace and tranquility. Similarly, in "Eternal Prisoner", Madame White Snake's enchanting looks follow Hsü even into his dreams, causing him to lose focus on his work the next day. In both narratives, the protagonists associate her captivating appearance with negativity, implying that her sexuality leads them astray. Furthermore, similar to the typical noir Femme Fatale, Madame White Snake exhibits inconsistent character traits. As noted by Christine Gledhill, the unpredictability surrounding the noir heroine makes it difficult for the audience to determine if they fit the femme fatale mold.
summary_2: Madame White Snake, known as a 'Femme Fatale', charms men with her allure in "Lust of the White Serpent" and "Eternal Prisoner." Her attractiveness brings trouble; Toyoo and Hsü are tormented by her beauty, affecting their daily lives. Both characters link her enticing appearance with negative consequences. Like classic noir femmes fatales, she has conflicting personality traits, making it hard for audiences to categorize her.
summary_3: In "Lust of the White Serpent" and "Eternal Prisoner," Madame White Snake's captivating beauty entrances men like Toyoo and Hsü, leading to turmoil, reflecting typical femme fatale characteristics that challenge easy categorization.

text: Independence with Partition: The British began to see India's independence as inevitable; however, only a few seemed to understand the vital role of the religious groups.Britain prepared a parliamentary democracy with majority rule, but the majority were Hindus — and Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs had been killing each other in war for many centuries.Nehru's Congress Party, largely Hindu with a socialist leadership, wanted a parliamentary democracy.As counterweight, British legislation reserved parliamentary seats for religious minorities, but the Punjab and Bengal had such a complicated mixture of Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs that it was not possible to avoid fights over how separate constituencies were to be formed.The seeds of future trouble were sown.The legislation on reserving seats gave the Muslims the basis for an alternative to an India in which they were only a quarter of the population: Partition.In 1930, the poet Muhammad Iqbal proposed a separate Muslim homeland in the northwest of India.A small group of Indian Muslims at Cambridge came up with the name Pakistan, using the initials of the Punjab, Afghania (N.W. Frontier Province), Kashmir, and Sind (at the same time producing the word pak, meaning "pure"), and adding "stan," the Persian suffix for the word "country." The Muslim campaign for Partition was led by London-trained Bombay lawyer, Muhammad Ali Jinnah.Meanwhile, Gandhi vehemently opposed any dismemberment of the country, and tried to keep people united by fasting to uphold the spirit of love, and by focussing on the common adversary: the British.Advocating civil disobedience, he led his famous Salt March to the sea, to scoop up salt and circumvent the hated British salt tax.This put more than 60,000 in jail.Against this militancy, World War II did not elicit the solidarity of the first.Indians courageously fought alongside the British troops, in Burma, the Middle East, and Europe, but Gandhi saw the British as a provocation for Japanese invasion and was jailed yet again, for launching a "Quit India" campaign in the year 1942.Some anti-British extremists saw the Japanese as an Asian liberator.Winston Churchill didn't want any Indian independence and so it was probably as well for India that he was defeated by Attlee's Labor Party in 1945.With riots growing ever more bloody in Bengal, Bihar, and the Punjab, India's last viceroy, Lord Mountbatten, kept a mandate to make the British departure as quick and as smooth as possible.Quick it was — six months after his arrival — but not smooth.
summary_1: The inevitability of India's independence was recognized by Britain, but the critical role of religious groups was overlooked. A parliamentary democracy was envisioned, but with Hindus being the majority, conflicts between Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs were unavoidable due to historical tensions. Nehru's Congress Party, predominantly Hindu and socially inclined, advocated for a democratic system. To balance this, the British reserved parliamentary seats for religious minorities. However, forming distinct constituencies in regions like Punjab and Bengal proved contentious due to their complex demographic makeup. This laid the groundwork for future strife. The reservation policy provided Muslims a foundation for an alternate to living in a nation where they constituted merely a quarter of the populace -Partition. In 1930, Muhammad Iqbal suggested a separate Muslim state in Northwest India. At Cambridge, a small collective of Indian Muslims conceived the term 'Pakistan', combining the initials of Punjab, Afghania, Kashmir, and Sind, and appending 'stan', the Persian word for 'land'. The movement for Partition was spearheaded by Muhammad Ali Jinnah, a London-educated barrister from Bombay. Conversely, Gandhi strongly objected to any division of the country, employing fasting and promoting unity among people while focusing on the shared enemy - the British. He championed civil disobedience, leading his renowned Salt March to the ocean to gather salt, thereby evading the detested British salt tax, resulting in over 60,000 arrests. Despite Indians bravely fighting alongside British forces during WWII, Gandhi perceived the British presence as inciting Japanese invasion, landing him in prison once more for instigating the 'Quit India' campaign in 1942. Some anti-British radicals deemed Japan a potential liberator. Despite Churchill's reluctance towards any Indian autonomy, his defeat by Attlee's Labor Party in 1945 likely benefited India. With escalating violence in Bengal, Bihar, and Punjab, India's final viceroy, Lord Mountbatten, aimed to ensure a hasty and orderly British withdrawal, concluding in six months following his arrival, albeit not without complications.
summary_2: In 1947, Britain granted India independence, yet neglected the influence of religious divisions. Though a parliamentary democracy was established, communal tensions persisted due to historical friction. Nehru's Congress Party, primarily Hindu and socially oriented, promoted democracy, balanced by British reservation of seats for religious minorities. However, creating distinct constituencies in mixed regions sparked controversy. This led to the concept of Pakistan, derived from Punjab, Afghania, Kashmir, and Sind, combined with 'stan', meaning 'land'. Muhammad Ali Jinnah led the partition movement, while Mahatma Gandhi vehemently opposed division, favoring unity and resistance against British rule. Despite shared struggle in WWII, Indians faced British oppression, culminating in the Quit India campaign. Amidst rising violence, Lord Mountbatten expedited a peaceful British exit in 1947, marking the end of colonial rule.
summary_3: Britain granted India independence in 1947 but overlooked religious tensions, leading to communal strife despite democratic governance; Nehru's Congress Party, predominantly Hindu, advocated for democracy, while Jinnah's Muslim League pushed for Pakistan, ultimately dividing India into two nations, amidst opposition from Gandhi and increasing violence.

text: Dam Good Luck: From the beginning, Las Vegas was built to serve travelers.The railroad needed a way station, and Las Vegas was the place.Growth continued for ten years, and by 1915 the town had telephones, round-the-clock electricity, and a growing population — many of whom worked in the railroad repair shop.But such heady progress would soon come to a halt.The growing competition in rail transport resulted in Union Pacific buying the Los Angeles–Salt Lake line.Union Pacific then consolidated its operations, eliminating the Las Vegas repair facility.Additionally, Las Vegas had been made a part of Nevada's new Clark County in 1909, a year when the legislature also outlawed gambling.These unfortunate circumstances threatened to relegate Las Vegas to the status of a small desert community that could no longer support its 3000 residents.But the southwest's growing need for water, combined with Las Vegas's fortuitous proximity to the Colorado River, would give Las Vegas a second chance to achieve prosperity.Construction on Hoover Dam (originally Boulder Dam, subsequently renamed for the president who authorized the project) began in 1931 in a canyon 45 miles (72 km) southeast of Las Vegas.Providing an influx of $165 million to the southwestern economy, Hoover Dam played a major role in preventing Las Vegas from drying up, both financially and literally.Not only did it create jobs, but it also created Lake Mead, the massive reservoir that today provides water to all of southern Nevada.More Government Help: The construction of Hoover Dam did not single-handedly save Las Vegas, however.The state legislature helped as well, by legalizing gambling in 1931 and thus solidifying the future of the town, though legislators and residents could never have known this at the time.The hordes of people who attended Hoover Dam's 1935 dedication set the city's now-formidable public relations machine into action.They went to work on what has become one of the lengthiest citywide tourism campaigns ever attempted.It didn't take long for the city to establish itself as a wild-West town with an "anything goes" attitude.Vices outlawed or heavily controlled elsewhere were legal here, available any hour of any day (or night).
summary_1: In the early 1900s, Las Vegas thrived as a railway hub until the rail industry's decline led to the closure of its repair shop. The town's fortune seemed tied to the Fate's cruel whims when Clark County outlawed gambling in 1909, the same year it absorbed Las Vegas. However, salvation came in the form of the Colorado River, which flowed conveniently close to Las Vegas. Construction of the Hoover Dam started in 1931, infusing $165 million into the region and creating much-needed jobs. Moreover, the dam transformed the area into a significant source of water for Nevada, ensuring the city's survival. Simultaneously, the state government legalized gambling in 1931, further boosting Las Vegas' growth. By embracing vices banned elsewhere, Las Vegas positioned itself as a lawless haven, kickstarting its legendary reputation and tourism industry.
summary_2: Las Vegas shifted from a prosperous railway center to an economically depressed town after the local railroad workshop closed. In 1909, gambling was prohibited in Clark County, where Las Vegas is located. Nevertheless, hope emerged with the construction of the Hoover Dam in 1931, injecting $165 million into the region and providing essential employment opportunities. Additionally, the dam provided vital water resources for Nevada, securing the city's future. Coinciding with this development, gambling became legal in 1931, fueling Las Vegas' expansion. Embracing activities shunned by other regions, Las Vegas established itself as a sinful sanctuary, igniting its iconic status and tourist trade.
summary_3: After the closure of a major railroad workshop, Las Vegas transitioned from a thriving railway hub to an economically struggling town until the construction of the Hoover Dam in 1931, which brought significant investment, job opportunities, and crucial water supplies, while legalized gambling transformed it into a famous "sin city" that flourished as a tourist destination.

text: Backers of Legal Aid services for the poor are pushing a measure that would increase court filing fees in Kentucky to raise money for the program, which faces steep funding cuts.The proposed bill, sponsored by Rep. Charles Geveden, D-Wickliffe, would double the portion of the fee that goes to Legal Aid -- in district court to $10 from $5 and in circuit court to $20 from $10.Kentucky's current fee for filing a case in district court is $50.50, and in circuit court $108.The increase still would leave Kentucky's filing fee costs below those of surrounding states and would raise about $1.3 million a year -- almost enough to replace what Legal Aid is losing from federal and other sources, said Jamie Hamon, executive director of the Access to Justice Foundation, a state poverty law resource center in Lexington.Geveden said his measure appears to be the only potential source of money for the program, which is being forced to lay off workers and close offices around the state.Geveden said he's concerned because federal funding hasn't increased in recent years, and states with increased poverty are taking a greater share of the money.''If you don't come up with the money somewhere, legal services to people in need will diminish or go away,'' he said.Hamon said the proposed bill has attracted a number of co-sponsors, and Legal Aid backers are hoping to get it passed in the upcoming legislative session.Hamon said she knows fee increases aren't popular with lawmakers but hopes they realize the crisis Legal Aid is facing.''A lot of poor people are not going to get served,'' she said.The measure has the endorsement of the Kentucky Bar Association.The association's board of governors voted unanimously last month to back the bill, said KBA President Stephen Catron, a Bowling Green lawyer.Legal Aid ''has been a godsend to a great number of people in this state,'' Catron said.''We simply must find a way to provide those services to the public.''Larry York, executive director of Appalachian Regional Defense Fund, which provides Legal Aid services in 37 Eastern Kentucky counties and is a KBA board member, said he hopes the measure is approved.''It would really offset the current cuts,'' he said.
summary_1: A proposal seeks to boost court filing fees in Kentucky to fund Legal Aid services for the underprivileged, addressing significant budget reductions. The suggested legislation, championed by Representative Charles Geveden, aims to hike the Legal Aid contribution from $5 to $10 in district courts and from $10 to $20 in circuit courts. Currently, district court filings cost $50.50, while circuit court ones amount to $108. Despite the rise, these rates would remain lower than neighboring states', potentially generating approximately $1.3 million annually - nearly equating to the funds lost from federal and other sources. This increase could prevent job losses and office closures at Legal Aid. Federal funding stagnation and rising poverty levels have strained Legal Aid resources, compelling them to dismiss employees and shut down facilities. Although fee rises may not be favored among politicians, supporters like Jamie Hamon, executive director of the Access to Justice Foundation, urge their consideration due to the impending Legal Aid crisis. The Kentucky Bar Association also endorses the bill, emphasizing Legal Aid's crucial role in assisting numerous individuals across the state.
summary_2: Representative Charles Geveden proposes raising court filing fees in Kentucky to support Legal Aid services for disadvantaged people, counteracting substantial budget cuts. If passed, district court fees will increase from $5 to $10, and circuit court fees from $10 to $20. This move could generate around $1.3 million yearly, preventing job losses and office closures at Legal Aid. Supporters, including the Kentucky Bar Association, highlight Legal Aid's importance in helping many Kentuckians. Rising poverty and stalled federal funding have stretched Legal Aid resources thin, leading to employee layoffs and office closures. While fee increases might not be popular among politicians, advocates argue they are necessary given the imminent Legal Aid crisis.
summary_3: Charles Geveden proposed increasing Kentucky court filing fees to fund Legal Aid services, potentially generating $1.3 million annually and preventing job losses and office closures at Legal Aid, which faces budget cuts and increased demand due to rising poverty and stalled federal funding.

text: Jenny was a 13 year old girl with blond hair and blue eyes.She had gotten out of her last day of school and was free for the summer.Two of her friends were going to the nearby beach to do some swimming and enjoy the sun.Jenny went with them and when they got there the beach was very full and there were people everywhere.They changed into their bathing suits and went to the water.The water was very cold.They chose not swim and walked to the sand.Then they laid down on some towels and enjoyed the sun.After several hours Jenny and her friends fell asleep.They woke up and the sun was beginning to set.When Jenny sat up she found that it was painful to touch her skin.When she looked down she saw that she had a very bad sunburn.Her friends were also very badly sunburned so they went home.Jenny's mother gave her a cream to put on the sunburn.Afterwards she felt a lot better and went to sleep.
summary_1: Jenny, a 13-year-old girl with blonde hair and blue eyes, concludes her school year and looks forward to summer. Two friends join her for a beach trip, where the crowd is dense. They change into swimwear but opt against swimming due to chilly water. Instead, they bask in the sun until falling asleep. Upon waking, they find the sun setting and realize they've acquired severe sunburns. Their discomfort prompts an immediate departure. Once home, Jenny's mother applies soothing cream to ease the burns, enabling Jenny to rest peacefully.
summary_2: Jenny, a 13-year-old girl, finishes school and heads to the beach with two friends. Despite wearing swimsuits, they avoid the cold water, choosing to sunbathe instead. After dozing off, they awaken to find themselves badly sunburnt, prompting a hasty exit. Back home, Jenny's mother treats their burns, allowing them to finally relax.
summary_3: Jenny and her friends get sunburned at the beach and are treated by Jenny's mother when they return home.

text: { { Plot } } Tom plays pool in a deserted pool hall , pocketing two balls by lowdown means and then wakes Jerry up by shooting the 10-ball into the pocket where he is sleeping . Jerry awakes just in time to avoid the 10-ball and is carried out to the ball return , where the 10 and the 13 smash the mouse between each other . Jerry is mad and walks up through the pocket , first sees nothing , but after a few steps back to the pocket , he spots Tom perched behind it . Jerry tries to jump into another corner pocket , but Tom aims a cue ball with so much force that it roll's into the pocket , and spins back out of it and it rolls Jerry backwards to Tom , who has made a ramp with his cue stick for the mouse to slide up . Jerry stops at the top of the stick and is then blown down by Tom , who then shoots a stream of balls to make the mouse flat . The whole train rebounds back towards the cat and the balls stack up at Tom's end of the table . Tom shoots all the balls in succession with his cue , and then tries to shoot Jerry , but the mouse hangs onto the cue tip . The cat , as if he were saying `` Have it your way '' , chalks up and shoots the 8-ball using Jerry . The mouse drops off the cue tip and then is upended by the 8-ball rolling in circles , and Tom forces Jerry to jump through the ball rack as if he were a circus performer . Tom then sets it on fire to add an additional level of torment , and when Jerry accomplishes this with poise , Tom discards the flaming rack and shoots the 8-ball across the table and back .
summary_1: Tom takes advantage in a desolate pool hall, illegally potting two balls before rousing Jerry from sleep with a direct hit to the pocket where he lies. Startled, Jerry narrowly escapes the incoming ball, only to be propelled to the ball return where the 10 and 13 crush him mercilessly. Frustration ensues as Jerry confronts Tom, lurking menacingly behind the pocket. In retaliation, Jerry attempts to leap into another corner pocket, but Tom counters with such force that the cue ball careens back, knocking Jerry off balance and directly into Tom's awaiting trap - a makeshift ramp crafted from the cue stick. As Jerry ascends, Tom blasts him with a barrage of balls, launching him backward onto the cat's side of the table. An array of balls ricochets toward Tom, piling high at his end. Ignoring any threat, Tom systematically knocks each ball off, aiming for Jerry who clings desperately to the cue tip. Defiant, Jerry remains latched until Tom concedes, striking the 8-ball while Jerry balances precariously on the cue tip. With one final shove, the 8-ball barrels forward, sending Jerry somersaulting through the air and into a fiery ball rack. Triumphant, Tom casts aside the burning apparatus, hurling the 8-ball against the opposite wall, signaling the conclusion of their tumultuous game.
summary_2: In a deserted billiards parlor, Tom exploits an unsuspecting Jerry, leading to escalating conflict. Starting with a sneak attack, Tom dislodges Jerry from slumber, causing him to stumble towards the ball return, crushed by the 10 and 13 balls. Angered, Jerry challenges Tom, resulting in a series of aggressive exchanges. Eventually, Tom constructs a ramp using the cue stick, which sends Jerry soaring into a risky position. Despite Jerry's tenacious grip on the cue tip, Tom persists, toppling Jerry with a relentless volley of balls. Victorious, Tom strikes the 8-ball, ejecting Jerry into a flaming ball rack, ultimately demolishing it. The intense match concludes with Tom discarding both the heated equipment and the defeated foe.
summary_3: Tom tricks Jerry into a dangerous game at a pool hall, eventually trapping him in a burning ball rack.

text: The factory is highly automated and designed to shift flexibly to produce many different kinds of chips to suit demand."The diversity is the big difference with this plant," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a research firm."It gives IBM the capability to make so many different kinds of custom chips, and the world is going to custom chips."The 140,000-square-foot plant is a testament to advanced manufacturing technology.The 300-millimeter silicon wafers -- about the size of a standard pizza -- are shuttled around the facility in enclosed plastic pods, which ride on overhead tracks.They drop down from wires automatically into machines, sheathed in stainless steel and glass, for each stage of processing and fabrication.Throughout the 500 processing steps, which typically last 20 days, the wafers are not touched by human hands.The circuits etched into the chips are less than one thousandth the width of a human hair.Human operators are there to monitor the systems, catch errors and fine-tune the production process for maximum efficiency.Because each of the hundreds of processing machines is self-enclosed, and essentially airtight, the uniforms operators wear are less constricting than in the previous generation of chip plants, which looked like space suits.The operators at the East Fishkill factory wear light nylon uniforms, light blue shoe coverings and translucent hair nets made of paper.They look more like workers in a bakery.Yes, said Richard Brilla, director of the new facility, "but the donuts are a lot more costly here."Each wafer, holding hundreds of chips, is worth $6,000 to $10,000 apiece, depending on what insulation, circuitry and materials are used.
summary_1:
IBM's East Fishkill factory stands out due to its high automation and flexibility in producing various types of chips. The plant, spanning 140,000 square feet, is a showcase of advanced manufacturing technology. It utilizes 300-millimeter silicon wafers, roughly the size of a typical pizza, which move around in sealed plastic pods on overhead tracks. These wafers transition between over 500 processing stages, lasting approximately 20 days, without any human contact. The circuits etched onto the chips are incredibly small, measuring less than one-thousandth the width of a human hair. 

Despite the high level of automation, human oversight is still crucial. Operators monitor the systems, rectify errors, and optimize the production process. Unlike older facilities that required space suit-like attire, operators at this plant wear lighter uniforms, resembling those of bakery workers. This change is due to the self-contained nature of the processing machines, which are essentially airtight. Each wafer, containing numerous chips, is valued between $6,000 and $10,000, depending on the insulation, circuitry, and materials used.
summary_2: IBM's East Fishkill factory uses advanced tech to produce diverse chips on automated lines. Spread across 140,000 sq ft, it houses 300mm silicon wafers moved in sealed pods via overhead tracks. Wavers undergo 500+ processes over 20 days without human touch. Circuits, smaller than a human hair's thousandth, form on each chip. Despite automation, humans supervise operations, correct issues, and enhance productivity. Workers now don light uniforms instead of bulky suits due to enclosed machinery. A single wafer, with multiple chips, costs $6,000-$10,000 based on insulation, circuitry, and materials.
summary_3: IBM's East Fishkill factory utilizes automated systems to manufacture various chips on 300mm silicon wafers, which undergo 500+ processes over 20 days without human contact, resulting in tiny circuits that cost up to $10,000 per wafer.

text: Crusaders, Mamelukes, and Turks: The Crusaders established a feudal Christian state with Godfrey at its head.They built many impressive churches during the term of the first Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem, but in 1187 they were driven out by Muslim forces under the great warrior Saladin.During the Sixth Crusade (1228– 1229), the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II managed to secure Jerusalem for the Christians by negotiation.The Christians, however, could not hold the city.After they lost Jerusalem, a Mongol invasion swept through, and in 1244 the Mameluke dynasty of Egypt took control, ruling Jerusalem for the next 250 years.The city struggled to rebuild from Crusader wars and invasions.Much of the best Islamic architecture in the city was constructed in the Mameluke era, but the past thousand years had taken their toll: Jerusalem was unable to regain the prosperity it had enjoyed in earlier times.In the early 16th century, the Ottoman Turkish Empire was advancing through the Middle East.Jerusalem fell to the Ottomans in 1517, remaining under their control for 400 years.Suleiman the Magnificent rebuilt the walls and gates in the form they retain to this day.Fountains, inns, religious schools, and barracks were constructed.But when Suleiman died, his empire, including Jerusalem, began a long period of decline.The Holy City remained a backwater until the 19th century, when renewed interest among Christian pilgrims made it the destination of thousands of travelers each year.
summary_1: The First Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem, led by Godfrey, was established after Crusaders conquered the region. They built notable churches, but Muslim forces under Saladin expelled them in 1187. During the Sixth Crusade (1228-1229), Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II secured Jerusalem for Christians through diplomacy, although they later lost it again. A Mongol invasion followed, and the Mameluke dynasty controlled Jerusalem from 1244 until 1517, constructing significant Islamic architecture despite challenges. In 1517, the Ottoman Turkish Empire, under Suleiman the Magnificent, took over Jerusalem, renovating its walls and infrastructure. However, the city's prosperity didn't return due to the declining Ottoman rule. By the 19th century, increased Christian pilgrimages sparked renewed global interest in Jerusalem, making it a popular destination once more.
summary_2: Established by Crusaders, the First Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem flourished under Godfrey, constructing renowned churches. Subsequently, Saladin's Muslim forces expelled the Crusaders in 1187. The Sixth Crusade (1228-1229) saw Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II regain Jerusalem via diplomacy, though it was lost again. A Mongol invasion ensued, with the Mameluke dynasty governing Jerusalem from 1244, building significant Islamic structures amidst hardships. In 1517, the Ottoman Turkish Empire, under Suleiman the Magnificent, assumed control, refurbishing the city's walls and infrastructure. Despite this, Jerusalem's prosperity waned under faltering Ottoman rule. Renewed global interest emerged in the 19th century due to increasing Christian pilgrimages, restoring Jerusalem's popularity.
summary_3: From Crusader establishment through Ottoman reign, Jerusalem experienced religious shifts, foreign occupations, and monumental construction projects, peaking in prominence during the 19th century resurgence spurred by heightened Christian pilgrimage.

text: `` The Octopus , '' a masked crime lord , is bent on crippling the nation with a wave of terror .He starts with the transportation system and then moves onto industry .He demands tribute from railroad magnates and other captains of industry .Richard Wentworth , an amateur criminologist who is friendly with the police , is secretly `` The Spider , '' a masked vigilante equally determined to wipe the Octopus and his gang off the face of the earth .Pleasant and smiling in civilian life , Wentworth is often ruthless as the Spider , slinging two guns against the public enemies who attack him .Wentworth also masquerades as affable underworld lowlife Blinky McQuade .Disguised as McQuade , Wentworth can infiltrate gangland at the hired-gun level and keep current on the gang's plans .The only people who know Wentworth's other identities are his assistants Jackson and Ram Singh , his butler Jenkins , and his fianc e Nita .The Octopus was a villain in a single issue pulp believed to have been written by Norvell Page who wrote most of The Spider pulp stories .He is garbed completely in white and is only ever seen sitting in a chair .Unlike the pulps , The Spider is garbed in a lightweight full length costume with web-like markings on it Which resemble Spiderman's costume .The serial follows the standard formula of fights , shoot-outs , Wentworth's friends being kidnapped at various times and having to be rescued .Each chapter ends with The Spider or his friends in deep trouble , often about to be killed , but the effect is spoiled by a trailer for the next episode Which shows them in full health and fighting the villains .
summary_1:
"The Octopus," a menacing criminal overlord, aims to paralyze the country with fear, targeting transportation and industrial systems before demanding tributes from railway tycoons and business leaders. Richard Wentworth, a mild-mannered criminology enthusiast with close ties to law enforcement, leads a double life as "The Spider." A ruthless vigilante, The Spider wages war against the Octopus and his minions. In disguise as Blinky McQuade, a seemingly carefree underworld figure, Wentworth gathers valuable inside information within the criminal underworld while maintaining cover among thugs. Only Wentworth's associates—Jackson, Ram Singh, Jenkins, and fiancé Nita—are aware of his dual identity.

Originally appearing in a standalone pulp magazine issue, likely penned by Norvell Page, The Octopus dons an all-white ensemble and remains seated during appearances. Conversely, The Spider wears a sleek outfit adorned with spiderweb patterns reminiscent of Spider-Man's suit. The storyline revolves around recurring themes such as battles, gunfights, and daring rescue missions where allies are frequently captured and subsequently saved. Each episode concludes with cliffhangers showing The Spider or companions facing imminent peril, usually near death, only to be contradicted by previews displaying their wellbeing and continued battle against adversaries.
summary_2: In "The Octopus" tale, a sinister crime boss threatens national infrastructure, prompting Richard Wentworth, who lives two lives as both a criminology expert linked to law enforcement and a relentless vigilante known as 'The Spider', to combat this menace. As 'Blinky McQuade,' he mingles with crooks for intel, supported by friends Jackson, Ram Singh, Jenkins, and lover Nita, unbeknownst to others. This thrilling series highlights fierce conflicts, hostage situations, and dramatic escapes, often leaving characters on edge but ultimately safe at the end of each installment.
summary_3: In "The Octopus," The Spider, also a criminologist, battles a crime boss threatening national security, risking danger and saving his team in every episode.
