text: Captured Moments by Will Shetterly I remember Papa's stopbox, a teal blue Tiempo Capturado that Mama brought home for his birthday.It was huge and inefficient, and she should never have spent so many pesos on a toy, but Papa would not let her return it.He used it to preserve baby tomatoes, cucumbers, and strawberries in translucent cubes that he stored in the pantry for spring-time meals in the middle of winter.Mama kept her mink jacket, a family hand-me-down, safe from time in a stopbox, and lent the capturador to my uncle for his stamp collection.Sometimes they would let us little ones to seal a treasured toy or a last piece of birthday cake until we begged them for its release, usually a few hours after enclosing it.When my father died, a year after my mother, my sisters and I cleaned out their apartment.We found our baby shoes protected in stopboxes.I took mine home, where they sat above my computer while I worked on my first play.One night when I did not believe love had ever existed for anyone, I used my own capturador, a sleek titanium Sanyo Tardar Ahora, to undo the stopbox.Bringing my face close to the shoes, I breathed deeply of air that my parents had trapped while closing up that symbol of their love for me.The instant would have been improved had my baby shoes been cleaned before they were encased.But as soon as I coughed, I laughed, and I did not try to kill myself that night.
summary_1: Author Will Shetterly reflects on the significance of 'stopboxes', time-preserving devices, in his life. His father owned a bulky Tiempo Capturado, which he filled with seasonal produce for off-season consumption. The author's mother preserved her mink jacket and the uncle's stamps in similar boxes. These contraptions allowed users to store items temporarily, preserving them in a paused state. After his father's demise, the narrator discovered his baby shoes, safely tucked away in a stopbox, during an apartment cleanup. This discovery led him to use his personal Sanyo Tardar Ahora to revisit the moment his parents sealed the box. Inhaling the trapped air, he felt connected to his parents' affectionate act, finding comfort amidst despair.
summary_2: Will Shetterly recounts his experiences with "stopboxes," time-halting devices. He had a large Tiempo Capturado where his dad stored seasonal goods. His mom kept her mink coat and uncle's stamps similarly. These gadgets enabled temporary storage, keeping things in suspended animation. Post his father's death, the narrator found his infant shoes in a stopbox while cleaning up. Using his own Sanyo Tardar Ahora, he relived the instant his parents preserved it, drawing solace from their loving gesture despite his grief.
summary_3: Shetterly reflects on using "stopboxes" to store items temporarily, including finding cherished memories in a device after his father's passing.

text: Albanian was proved to be an Indo-European language in 1854 by the German philologist Franz Bopp.The Albanian language comprises its own branch of the Indo-European language family.Some scholars believe that Albanian derives from Illyrian while others claim that it derives from Daco-Thracian.(Illyrian and Daco-Thracian, however, might have been closely related languages; see Thraco-Illyrian.) Establishing longer relations, Albanian is often compared to Balto-Slavic on the one hand and Germanic on the other, both of which share a number of isoglosses with Albanian.Moreover, Albanian has undergone a vowel shift in which stressed, long o has fallen to a, much like in the former and opposite the latter.Likewise, Albanian has taken the old relative jos and innovatively used it exclusively to qualify adjectives, much in the way Balto-Slavic has used this word to provide the definite ending of adjectives.The cultural renaissance was first of all expressed through the development of the Albanian language in the area of church texts and publications, mainly of the Catholic region in the North, but also of the Orthodox in the South.The Protestant reforms invigorated hopes for the development of the local language and literary tradition when cleric Gjon Buzuku brought into the Albanian language the Catholic liturgy, trying to do for the Albanian language what Luther did for German.
summary_1: In 1854, Albanian was confirmed as an Indo-European language by German philologist Franz Bopp. It forms its own branch within this language family. Scholarly debates exist over Albanian's origins, with some arguing it stems from Illyrian and others suggesting Daco-Thracian roots. Regardless, Albanian shares similarities with both Balto-Slavic and Germanic languages due to shared isoglosses and phonetic shifts. For instance, Albanian has experienced a vowel shift where stressed, lengthy 'o' becomes 'a', mirroring changes in Balto-Slavic and contrasting Germanic. Additionally, Albanian utilizes the term 'jos' uniquely to modify adjectives, paralleling how Balto-Slavic uses it for definitive article purposes. The Albanian language blossomed during the cultural renaissance, particularly in religious literature. This was especially true in the Northern Catholic region and, to a lesser extent, in the Southern Orthodox sector. The Protestant Reformation further stimulated aspirations for the Albanian language and literary culture, inspiring cleric Gjon Buzuku to translate Catholic liturgy into Albanian, echoing Luther's impact on German.
summary_2: Albanian, classified as an independent branch of the Indo-European language family since 1854, shows affinities with Balto-Slavic and Germanic languages. Its origin is disputed, with theories linking it to either Illyrian or Daco-Thracian. Shared isoglosses and phonetic shifts result in parallel developments, such as the unique use of 'jos' and a specific vowel shift. The language flourished during the cultural renaissance, notably in religious literature, boosted by the Protestant Reformation and figures like Gjon Buzuku who translated Catholic liturgy into Albanian.
summary_3: Albanian, its origins debated between Illyrian and Daco-Thracian ties, shares similarities with Balto-Slavic and Germanic languages, and experienced growth during the cultural renaissance due to the Protestant Reformation, as seen in religious literature and Gjon Buzuku's translation of Catholic liturgy into Albanian.

text: (CNN) -- Japan's prime minister conceded defeat in parliamentary elections Sunday, signaling the return to power of the Liberal Democratic Party and ending the brief rule of the disappointing upstart Democratic Party of Japan.Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda pledged to step down as party president after exit polls showed a smashing loss in lower house voting.The party, once seen as a breath of fresh air in Japanese politics, came to be regarded as increasingly ineffective."We got a regrettable result," Noda said."The result is everything in the politics.The biggest responsibility lies on me.I will quit as the partly leader of DPJ."The move clears the way for the return to power of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, the current leader of the conservative-leaning Liberal Democratic Party, or LDP."The Japanese people will be keenly looking whether the LDP can meet with their expectations," Abe said in interviews after the polling.The LDP ruled the country almost continuously since its establishment in 1955 until it was forced from power three years ago by the DPJ.Public broadcaster NHK said the LDP and its coalition partner, the new Komei party, gained at least 302 seats in the 480-seat lower house.CNN's main affiliate, TV Asahi, reports the LDP/Komei coalition gained at least 312 seats.The official count is expected to be released Monday.The LDP is inheriting a struggling economy, regional tensions and questions over Japan's role in Asia."The economy is at the bottom.It's our first mission to turn it around," Abe said.
summary_1: In an election held in Japan, the ruling Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ) suffered a significant setback, leading to Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda's concession of defeat. The DPJ, initially hailed as a refreshing change in Japanese politics, was criticized for becoming ineffectual. After exit polls indicated a resounding loss in the lower house voting, Noda vowed to resign as party head. This paves the way for the probable comeback of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who currently leads the conservative Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). Abe expressed that the public would closely observe if the LDP could fulfill their expectations. The LDP had been in power almost uninterruptedly since its formation in 1955 but was dethroned three years ago by the DPJ. Public broadcaster NHK reported that the LDP and its ally, the New Komei Party, secured a minimum of 302 seats in the 480-seat lower house. CNN's affiliate, TV Asahi, projected the LDP/Komei coalition to have won at least 312 seats. The official results are due on Monday. Inheriting a stagnant economy, regional disputes, and uncertainty about Japan's position in Asia, Abe acknowledged the need to revive the economy as his primary task.
summary_2: After losing an election, PM Noda conceded defeat, promising to step down as DPJ leader. Exit polls showed a massive win for ex-PM Abe's Liberal Democrats, likely making him prime minister again. The DPJ, once seen as a breath of fresh air in Japanese politics, faced criticism for being ineffective. The Liberal Democrats and their allies are predicted to secure over 300 out of 480 lower house seats. If confirmed, this will mark the end of the DPJ's three-year rule and the return of the Liberals, who ruled nearly uninterrupted since 1955. Abe pledged to focus on economic recovery upon taking office.
summary_3: Ex-PM Abe's Liberal Democrats won a landslide victory in the recent election, set to regain power after three years, ending the DPJ's reign and prompting PM Noda's resignation due to ineffectiveness criticisms.

text: General relativity includes a dynamical spacetime, so it is difficult to see how to identify the conserved energy and momentum.Noether's theorem allows these quantities to be determined from a Lagrangian with translation invariance, but general covariance makes translation invariance into something of a gauge symmetry.The energy and momentum derived within general relativity by Noether's presecriptions do not make a real tensor for this reason.Einstein argued that this is true for fundamental reasons, because the gravitational field could be made to vanish by a choice of coordinates.He maintained that the non-covariant energy momentum pseudotensor was in fact the best description of the energy momentum distribution in a gravitational field.This approach has been echoed by Lev Landau and Evgeny Lifshitz, and others, and has become standard.The use of non-covariant objects like pseudotensors was heavily criticized in 1917 by Erwin Schrodinger and others.
summary_1: In General Relativity, identifying conserved energy and momentum becomes challenging due to its dynamic spacetime. Noether's theorem typically aids in determining these quantities via a Lagrangian with translation invariance. However, general covariance transforms translation invariance into a kind of gauge symmetry, resulting in energy and momentum that don't form a genuine tensor due to this effect. Einstein contended that this is fundamentally correct since the gravitational field can be eliminated through a coordinate choice. He asserted that the non-covariant energy-momentum pseudotensor offers the most accurate depiction of energy-momentum distribution within a gravitational field. This viewpoint aligns with those of Lev Landau and Evgeny Lifshitz, forming an established convention. Despite criticism in 1917 from Erwin Schrödinger and others regarding the utilization of non-covariant entities such as pseudotensors, this remains a common practice.
summary_2: General Relativity struggles to identify conserved energy and momentum because it has changing spacetime. A theorem by Emmy Noether usually helps find them using a Lagrangian with translation invariance. But general covariance turns translation invariance into a sort of gauge symmetry, making energy and momentum unfit for being real tensors. Albert Einstein agreed, arguing that the non-covariant energy-momentum pseudotensor best shows energy-momentum distribution in gravity fields. Though some criticized using non-covariant things like pseudotensors back in 1917, many scientists still follow this approach today.
summary_3: Despite General Relativity's challenges in identifying conserved energy and momentum due to changing spacetime, scientists often use Einstein's approach, employing a non-covariant energy-momentum pseudotensor to illustrate energy-momentum distribution in gravity fields, even though this method involves non-covariant elements, which some critics dislike.

text: Adrienne Saunders is happily married to her art dealer husband , Jack .They have a daughter named Mary .Adrienne hears from a friend that she thought she saw Jack in town when he claimed to be on an out of town business trip .Adrienne confronts him , but he denies being in town , and their lives continue .Soon after a museum curator is mysteriously murdered , and a relic that Jack bought for the museum is revealed to be a fake .Jack is placed under suspicion , and then Adrienne receives word from the police that Jack perished in a car accident .In trying to wrap up Jack 's affairs , Adrienne begins to suspect that her husband had switched identities with a high school classmate , Frank Sullivan .When she sees a high school yearbook picture of her husband attributed to Sullivan , she is convinced .She tracks down a relative of Saunders , who confirms that Frank and Jack were inseparable in high school .After Jack died , the relative never saw Frank again .She explained that Frank 's father was an alcoholic and that his mother worked as a toll booth operator .She directs Adrienne to Frank 's mother , who lives in a rundown apartment in Brooklyn .Frank 's mother bitterly receives the news that she has a granddaughter , telling Adrienne that Frank was always selfish and that he never looked in on her .A stalker lurks at Adrienne 's loft .He comes in to Adrienne 's bed while she is asleep and caresses her .He watches Mary , who is spooked by the man in her room at night .
summary_1: Adrienne Saunders, contentedly wedded to her art dealing spouse, Jack, shares their life with their child, Mary. A friend spots what appears to be Jack in town, despite his claim of being away on business. Confronting him, Adrienne gets denied. Soon after, a museum curator's unexpected demise occurs, linking it to a counterfeit relic purchased by Jack for the museum. The finger points at Jack, followed by suspicions around his alleged car crash death. As Adrienne settles Jack's matters, evidence indicates that her husband may have assumed the identity of a former classmate, Frank Sullivan. Confirmation arrives via a high school yearbook photo bearing Jack's face yet labeled as Sullivan. Adrienne contacts one of Jack's relatives, learning about Frank and Jack's close bond during high school. Post-Jack's passing, contact with Frank ceases. She learns that Frank's dad struggled with alcoholism and his mom held a job at a toll booth. Directed to Frank's mother living in a shabby Brooklyn apartment, she reveals Frank's self-centered nature and discloses that he never visited. Meanwhile, an ominous stranger keeps watch over Adrienne's home, entering her bedroom while she sleeps, touching her, and later appearing near Mary's room, causing distress.
summary_2: Adrienne Saunders investigates her husband Jack's past when a friend identifies him in town, contradicting his claimed absence. After a museum curator dies from a supposedly fake artifact bought by Jack, Jack himself is suspected dead in a car accident. However, evidence suggests Jack had adopted Frank Sullivan's identity, leading Adrienne to meet Frank's estranged mother who confirms Frank's selfishness and lack of family connection. An unknown man stalks Adrienne and her daughter, heightening tension.
summary_3: After discovering that her husband may have assumed another man's identity, Adrienne uncovers his history of deceit, causing an unknown man to stalk her and her daughter.

text: Even after  Bin Laden's departure from the area, CIA officers hoped he might return, seeing the camp as a magnet that could draw him for as long as it was still set up.The military maintained readiness for another strike opportunity.On March 7, 1999, Clarke called a UAE official to express his concerns about possible associations between Emirati officials and  Bin Laden.Clarke later wrote in a memorandum of this conversation that the call had been approved at an interagency meeting and cleared with the CIA.When the former  Bin Laden unit chief found out about Clarke's call, he questioned CIA officials, who denied having given such a clearance.Imagery confirmed that less than a week after Clarke's phone call the camp was hurriedly dismantled, and the site was deserted.CIA officers, including Deputy Director for Operations Pavitt, were irate."Mike" thought the dismantling of the camp erased a possible site for targeting  Bin Laden.The United Arab Emirates was becoming both a valued counterterrorism ally of the United States and a persistent counterterrorism problem.From 1999 through early 2001, the United States, and President Clinton personally, pressed the UAE, one of the Taliban's only travel and financial outlets to the outside world, to break off its ties and enforce sanctions, especially those relating to flights to and from Afghanistan.These efforts achieved little before 9/11.In July 1999, UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Hamdan bin Zayid threatened to break relations with the Taliban over  Bin Laden.The Taliban did not take him seriously, however.Bin Zayid later told an American diplomat that the UAE valued its relations with the Taliban because the Afghan radicals offered a counterbalance to "Iranian dangers" in the region, but he also noted that the UAE did not want to upset the United States.
summary_1: CIA officers remained vigilant regarding a potential reappearance of Bin Laden at a training camp even after his departure. The US military stayed prepared for any further attack opportunities. In March 1999, Counterterrorism Coordinator Richard Clarke contacted a UAE official to discuss concerns about alleged connections between certain Emirati officials and Bin Laden. This communication was reportedly authorized at an interagency meeting and vetted by the CIA. However, when the ex-head of the Bin Laden unit learned about Clarke's contact, there was disagreement, as CIA officials claimed no approval had been granted. Shortly after Clarke's call, images showed the hasty disassembly of the camp, suggesting a possible target location for Bin Laden had vanished. Some CIA members, like Deputy Director for Operations Pavitt, felt the camp's disbandment eliminated a potential aim point for Bin Laden. From 1999 until early 2001, the US, along with President Clinton, urged the UAE - a crucial counterterrorism partner and one of the few links to the outside world for the Taliban - to sever ties and implement sanctions, specifically those concerning flights to and from Afghanistan. These attempts yielded minimal results prior to 9/11. For instance, despite threats from UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Hamdan bin Zayid to cut ties with the Taliban due to Bin Laden in mid-1999, they dismissed these warnings. Bin Zayid expressed concern about Iranian influence; nonetheless, he emphasized the importance of maintaining good relations with the Taliban to balance against regional risks while avoiding strife with the US.
summary_2: In 1999, Richard Clarke, a Counterterrorism Coordinator, discussed concerns about Bin Laden's supposed Emirati connections with a UAE official. This followed CIA's vigilance over potential Bin Laden reemergence at camps. After learning about Clarke's contact, a dispute arose within the CIA, as some members denied granting approval. Post-March 1999, the camp linked to Bin Laden swiftly disassembled, eliminating a probable target site. Despite urging the UAE to end ties with the Taliban and impose sanctions, little progress occurred before 9/11. Efforts included warning the Taliban about Iranian influence but preserving regional stability and US relations.
summary_3: In 1999, Richard Clarke discussed Bin Laden's alleged UAE links with an official, but a dispute arose in the CIA about approving this contact. The camp tied to Bin Laden was quickly dismantled, and efforts to end UAE ties with the Taliban and impose sanctions made little progress before 9/11.

text: Hundreds of thousands of years before China was to become the world's longest-running civilization, the prologue was enacted by means of the flicker of a carefully tended fire.Peking Man, a forebear of Homo sapiens, achieved a mastery of fire.We might call it the first Chinese invention.Not that he devised flint and steel, matches, or any other way of creating fire.Peking Man simply learned how to capture flame, perhaps from a forest fire, and keep it alight.He thus enjoyed two revolutionary luxuries: light and heat.Technologically and sociologically, it was a phenomenal breakthrough: with fire, communities could live year 'round in one cave, in which cooking and even smelting could be pursued.And so, by 600,000 b.c., about 50 km (31 miles) southwest of present-day Beijing, the ancestors of mankind were ready to settle down.Several hundred thousand years later, when Marco Polo reached the capital of China, he was astonished by a further development in fire technology.The Chinese, he announced, used black stones dug out of mountains as fuel.Europeans did not yet have a word for "coal," nor had they discovered a use for it.The First Dynasty The confluence of mythology and history in China took place around 4,000 years ago during what is referred to as the Xia (Hsia) Dynasty.This was still the Stone Age, but the people are thought to have made silk from thread produced by the worms they cultivated on the leaves of their mulberry trees.And written language (which evolved as early as 4,500 to 5,000 years ago) was already in use, originally by oracles and then by official scribes — China's first scholars.During the second of the quasi-legendary dynasties, the Shang (from about the 16th to 11th centuries b.c.), the Chinese developed an interest in art.Careful geometric designs as well as dragon and bird motifs adorned bowls and implements.And with the arrival of the Bronze Age, the Chinese created bronze vessels of such beauty and originality that, until modern times, archaeologists refused to believe they were cast 3,000 years ago.The Shang Dynasty gave rise to the concept of one Chinese nation under one government.
summary_1: Fire played a crucial role in human advancement long before China became Earth's enduring civilization. Around 600,000 BC, Peking Man, an ancestor of humans, mastered fire, marking the first Chinese invention - the ability to harness and maintain flames, possibly sourced from natural fires and preserved thereafter. This innovation provided light and heat, enabling communities to inhabit caves all year round, facilitating activities like cooking and metalworking. By 4,000 years ago, during the Xia Dynasty, the ancient Chinese began using coal, a resource Europeans hadn't yet discovered. During this era, silk production started, utilizing silkworm threads from mulberry tree leaves. Written language also emerged, initially employed by oracles and subsequently by official scribes, heralding the advent of scholarship. In the subsequent Shang Dynasty, lasting approximately from the 16th to 11th centuries BC, artistic expression flourished with intricate geometric patterns and animal motifs gracing pottery and tools. With the dawn of the Bronze Age, stunning and unique bronze vessels came into existence, astounding archaeologists due to their age and craftsmanship. The Shang Dynasty marked the genesis of the unified Chinese state, setting the stage for China's rich cultural legacy.
summary_2: Human progress was revolutionized by fire, starting with Peking Man controlling it around 600,000 BC. Fire brought light, warmth, enabled cave dwelling, and sparked innovations such as cooking and metallurgy. Coal use began in the Xia Dynasty (circa 4,000 years ago), coinciding with silk production and written language emergence. Under the Shang Dynasty, artistry bloomed on pottery and tools, leading to the creation of distinctive bronze vessels, signaling the start of the unified Chinese state and its cultural heritage.
summary_3: The discovery and control of fire by early humans, beginning with Peking Man, led to significant advancements including lighting, heating, facilitating cave life, and fostering inventions like cooking and metalworking; coal usage started during the Xia Dynasty, coinciding with developments in silk production and writing, while the Shang Dynasty saw artistic evolution in pottery and tool crafting, culminating in the creation of unique bronze pieces that marked the dawn of China's unified culture.

text: In February 1998, the 40-year-old Saudi exile Usama  Bin Laden and a fugitive Egyptian physician, Ayman al Zawahiri, arranged from their Afghan headquarters for an Arabic newspaper in London to publish what they termed a fatwa issued in the name of a "World Islamic Front."A fatwa is normally an interpretation of Islamic law by a respected Islamic authority, but neither  Bin Laden, Zawahiri, nor the three others who signed this statement were scholars of Islamic law.Claiming that America had declared war against God and his messenger, they called for the murder of any American, anywhere on earth, as the "individual duty for every Muslim who can do it in any country in which it is possible to do it."Three months later, when interviewed in Afghanistan by ABC-TV,  Bin Laden enlarged on these themes.He claimed it was more important for Muslims to kill Americans than to kill other infidels."It is far better for anyone to kill a single American soldier than to squander his efforts on other activities," he said.Asked whether he approved of terrorism and of attacks on civilians, he replied:"We believe that the worst thieves in the world today and the worst terrorists are the Americans.Nothing could stop you except perhaps retaliation in kind.We do not have to differentiate between military or civilian.As far as we are concerned, they are all targets."Note: Islamic names often do not follow the Western practice of the consistent use of surnames.Given the variety of names we mention, we chose to refer to individuals by the last word in the names by which they are known: Nawaf al Hazmi as Hazmi, for instance, omitting the article "al" that would be part of their name in their own societies.We generally make an exception for the more familiar English usage of "Bin" as part of a last name, as in  Bin Laden.Further, there is no universally accepted way to transliterate Arabic words and names into English.We have relied on a mix of common sense, the sound of the name in Arabic, and common usage in source materials, the press, or government documents.When we quote from a source document, we use its transliteration, e.g.,"al Qida" instead of al Qaeda.Though novel for its open endorsement of indiscriminate killing,  Bin Laden's 1998 declaration was only the latest in the long series of his public and private calls since 1992 that singled out the United States for attack.In August 1996,  Bin Laden had issued his own self-styled fatwa calling on Muslims to drive American soldiers out of Saudi Arabia.
summary_1: In February 1998, Usama Bin Laden and Ayman al Zawahiri, then based in Afghanistan, issued a fatwa via a London-based Arabic newspaper, declaring a jihad against Americans. The six-page edict, attributed to a "World Islamic Front", called for the killing of any American as a religious duty for every Muslim. This was followed by an interview in Afghanistan with ABC News where Bin Laden reiterated his call for violence against Americans, labeling them as "the worst thieves in the world". He argued that attacking civilians was justified due to U.S. actions, stating that all Americans were legitimate targets, both military and civilian. This marked a shift towards endorsing indiscriminate killing. Prior to this, Bin Laden had consistently targeted the U.S. in his statements since 1992, notably issuing a fatwa in August 1996 urging Muslims to expel American soldiers from Saudi Arabia.
summary_2: In 1998, Usama Bin Laden and Ayman al Zawahiri declared a fatwa for a jihad against Americans, published in a UK paper. They urged Muslims to kill any American, marking a shift towards accepting indiscriminate killing. In an ABC News interview, Bin Laden repeated his call for violence against Americans, justifying attacks on civilians due to U.S. actions. Since 1992, Bin Laden had consistently targeted the U.S., including a 1996 fatwa urging Muslims to expel American soldiers from Saudi Arabia.
summary_3: In 1998, Usama Bin Laden and Ayman al Zawahiri issued a fatwa for a global jihad against Americans, sanctioning indiscriminate killing, marking a shift from Bin Laden's initial focus on expelling American soldiers from Saudi Arabia starting in 1992.

text: Alexander the Great's accomplishments and legacy have been depicted in many cultures.Alexander has figured in both high and popular culture beginning in his own era to the present day.The Alexander Romance, in particular, has had a significant impact on portrayals of Alexander in later cultures, from Persian to medieval European to modern Greek.Alexander may already have considered himself as the "King of Asia" after his victory at Issos, a conception strengthened by his subsequent successes.The conception might have inspired the title given to Alexander in Babylonian documents, "king of the world (since "king of Asia" had no meaning in Babylonian geography).It might also be alluded in the sarcastic comments by Anaxarchus, trying to rouse Alexander after the murder of Cleitus.or in the orator Demades' comments that if Alexander were dead, "The whole world would stink of his corpse".Alexander is called "kosmokrator", ruler of the world, in the later Alexander Romance.Alexander features prominently in modern Greek folklore, more so than any other ancient figure.The colloquial form of his name in modern Greek ("O Megalexandros") is a household name, and he is the only ancient hero to appear in the Karagiozis shadow play.One well-known fable among Greek seamen involves a solitary mermaid who would grasp a ship's prow during a storm and ask the captain "Is King Alexander alive?".The correct answer is "He is alive and well and rules the world!", causing the mermaid to vanish and the sea to calm.Any other answer would cause the mermaid to turn into a raging Gorgon who would drag the ship to the bottom of the sea, all hands aboard.
summary_1: Alexander the Great holds significance in various cultures, with depictions spanning from his time to the present day. A crucial influence on these portrayals is the Alexander Romance, which has shaped perceptions from Persia to medieval Europe and modern Greece. The idea of Alexander as "King of Asia" likely emerged post his triumph at Issos, bolstered by his continued conquests. This notion could underpin the Babylonian reference to him as "king of the world," considering "king of Asia" held little relevance in Babylonian geography. This concept might also surface in Anaxarchus' sardonic remarks about awakening Alexander after Cleitus' death, or Demades' commentary implying global chaos should Alexander pass away. In the Alexander Romance, Alexander earns the title "kosmokrator," signifying his rule over the world. Modern Greek lore highlights Alexander more than any other historical character. His colloquial name, "O Megalexandros," enjoys widespread familiarity, and he is the sole ancient hero featured in the Karagiozis shadow play. A notable maritime myth encompasses a singular mermaid clutching a ship's prow amidst tempestuous weather. She queries the captain, "Is King Alexander alive?", to which an affirmative response, "He is alive and thriving, ruling the world!", makes her disappear, calming the sea. Conversely, any alternative reply summons a wrathful Gorgon who plunges the vessel and its crew into the ocean depths.
summary_2: The legacy of Alexander the Great appears in diverse cultures, influenced by the Alexander Romance. Named 'Kosmokrator,' he's a significant figure in modern Greek lore, surpassing other historical characters. A mermaid myth reflects this, where an affirmed "King Alexander lives!" calms stormy seas, while a negative response invokes a deadly Gorgon.
summary_3: In modern Greece, Alexander the Great, known as 'Kosmokrator', remains a more revered cultural icon than other historical figures, with his legacy reflected in various tales, including a mermaid myth where affirming "King Alexander lives!" pacifies turbulent waters, but denying it summons a lethal Gorgon.

text: Tropical climates are found around the equator.These climates have warm temperatures year round.Tropical climates may be very wet or wet and dry.Tropical wet climates occur at or very near the equator.They have high rainfall year round.Tropical rainforests grow in this type of climate.Tropical wet and dry climates also occur near the equator.They receive less rainfall.Most of the rain falls in a single season.The rest of the year is dry.Few trees can withstand the long dry season.The main plants are grasses.Dry climates receive very little rainfall.They also have high rates of evaporation.This makes them even drier.Deserts can get less than 25 centimeters of rain per year.Thats less than 10 inches per year.How much rain do you get at your house?
summary_1: Tropical climates prevail around the equator, characterized by consistently warm temperatures throughout the year. These climates are categorized into two types: tropical wet and tropical wet and dry. Tropical wet climates, situated right on the equator, experience substantial rainfall annually due to their geographical location. This constant precipitation fosters the growth of lush tropical rainforests. On the other hand, tropical wet and dry climates, although also located near the equator, receive less annual rainfall compared to their counterparts. The majority of the rainfall occurs within a specific season, followed by an extended dry period. Surviving in these conditions is challenging for many tree species, making grasses the predominant flora. Dry climates see minimal rainfall and exhibit high evaporation rates, further exacerbating the aridity. Desert regions might receive less than 25 centimeters of rainfall per annum, equivalent to under 10 inches each year. A question for reflection: how much rain does your residence typically receive?
summary_2: Equatorial areas have either tropical wet or tropical wet and dry climates. Tropical wet zones, straddling the equator, get abundant rain all year, nurturing dense rainforests. Nearby, tropical wet and dry climates receive less rain overall but feature distinct wet and dry seasons, promoting grass dominance over trees. Arid desert regions, faring poorly rain-wise, may get scantier than 25 cm of rainfall annually. Consider this: what's your area's average annual rainfall?
summary_3: Equatorial regions experience either consistently rainy tropical climates favoring rainforests or tropical wet and dry climates with distinct wet/dry periods that foster grass growth, while arid deserts see minimal rainfall below 25 cm per year.

text: So what is gravity?A typical definition of gravity is that it is a force.It causes an attraction between two masses.According to this definition, anything that has mass exerts a force.Any object exerts gravity on other objects.It does not matter how small it is, it has gravity.The more matter an object has, the more gravity it has.Your pencil has a tiny bit of gravity, but far too little to notice.What about a planet?It would have a lot of gravity.An objects gravity exerts a pull on other objects.Friction only occurs between objects that are touching.Gravity can act between objects that are not touching.In fact, gravity can act over very long distances.Where else can you feel gravity?
summary_1: Gravity is defined as a force causing an attractive relationship between two masses. Every physical entity, regardless of size, possesses some degree of gravity; even a pencil has a minuscule amount. The greater an object's mass, the stronger its gravitational pull. Unlike friction, which necessitates direct contact, gravity operates across vast distances. This phenomenon isn't confined to planets alone; everything, from the smallest particle to the largest celestial body, is subject to its influence.
summary_2: Gravity describes the attractive force between any two masses, however small. Greater mass intensifies this pull, but it extends beyond immediate contact, impacting all matter, big or small, throughout the universe.
summary_3: Any two masses exert an attractive force called gravity, which affects everything in the universe with varying intensity depending on their size.

text: Honours and legacy In 1929, Soviet writer Leonid Grossman published a novel The d'Archiac Papers, telling the story of Pushkin's death from the perspective of a French diplomat, being a participant and a witness of the fatal duel.The book describes him as a liberal and a victim of the Tsarist regime.In Poland the book was published under the title Death of the Poet.In 1937, the town of Tsarskoye Selo was renamed Pushkin in his honour.There are several museums in Russia dedicated to Pushkin, including two in Moscow, one in Saint Petersburg, and a large complex in Mikhaylovskoye.Pushkin's death was portrayed in the 2006 biographical film Pushkin: The Last Duel.The film was directed by Natalya Bondarchuk.Pushkin was portrayed onscreen by Sergei Bezrukov.The Pushkin Trust was established in 1987 by the Duchess of Abercorn to commemorate the creative legacy and spirit of her ancestor and to release the creativity and imagination of the children of Ireland by providing them with opportunities to communicate their thoughts, feelings and experiences.A minor planet, 2208 Pushkin, discovered in 1977 by Soviet astronomer Nikolai Stepanovich Chernykh, is named after him.A crater on Mercury is also named in his honour.MS Alexandr Pushkin, second ship of the Russian Ivan Franko class (also referred to as "poet" or "writer" class).Station of Tashkent metro was named in his honour.The Pushkin Hills and Pushkin Lake were named in his honour in Ben Nevis Township, Cochrane District, in Ontario, Canada.UN Russian Language Day, established by the United Nations in 2010 and celebrated each year on 6 June, was scheduled to coincide with Pushkin's birthday.
summary_1: Leonid Grossman's 1929 novel, The d'Archiac Papers, presents Pushkin's life and death from a French diplomat's viewpoint. The book depicts Pushkin as a liberal and a casualty of the Tsarist regime. It was published in Poland as Death of the Poet. In 1937, Tsarskoye Selo was renamed Pushkin in his honor. Several Russian museums are dedicated to Pushkin, including two in Moscow, one in Saint Petersburg, and a significant complex in Mikhaylovskoye. The 2006 biographical film Pushkin: The Last Duel, directed by Natalya Bondarchuk, features Sergei Bezrukov as Pushkin. The Pushkin Trust, founded in 1987, celebrates Pushkin's artistic heritage and fosters Irish children's creativity. Asteroid 2208 Pushkin and a Mercury crater bear his name. The MS Alexandr Pushkin cruiser, a Tashkent metro station, Pushkin Hills, and Pushkin Lake in Canada are also named for him. UN Russian Language Day, celebrated annually on 6th June since 2010, marks Pushkin's birthdate.
summary_2: The 1929 novel, The d'Archiac Papers, explores Pushkin's life through a French diplomat's perspective, portraying him as a liberal and a victim of the Tsarist regime. Numerous museums and landmarks worldwide commemorate Pushkin, including those in Russia and Ireland's Pushkin Trust. His legacy extends to space with an asteroid and a Mercury crater named after him. The annual UN Russian Language Day also honors his birthdate.
summary_3: "The d'Archiac Papers" details Pushkin's life from a French diplomat's viewpoint, while numerous global institutions celebrate him, culminating in a UN holiday and celestial recognition.

text: Literary career During the war Camus joined the French Resistance cell Combat, which published an underground newspaper of the same name.This group worked against the Nazis, and in it Camus assumed the nom de guerre Beauchard.Camus became the paper's editor in 1943.He first met Sartre at the dress rehearsal of Sartre's play, The Flies, in June 1943.When the Ailies liberated Paris in August 1944, Camus witnessed and reported the last of the fighting.Soon after the event on 6 August 1945, he was one of the few French editors to publicly express opposition and disgust to the United States' dropping the atomic bomb in Hiroshima.He resigned from Combat in 1947 when it became a commercial paper.After the war, Camus began frequenting the Cafe de Flore on the Boulevard Saint-Germain in Paris with Sartre and others.He also toured the United States to lecture about French thought.Although he leaned left, politically, his strong criticisms of Communist doctrine did not win him any friends in the Communist parties and eventually alienated Sartre.In 1949, his tuberculosis returned, whereupon he lived in seclusion for two years.In 1951, he published The Rebel, a philosophical analysis of rebellion and revolution which expressed his rejection of communism.Upsetting many of his colleagues and contemporaries in France, the book brought about the final split with Sartre.The dour reception depressed Camus; he began to translate plays.Camus's first significant contribution to philosophy was his idea of the absurd.He saw it as the result of our desire for clarity and meaning within a world and condition that offers neither, which he expressed in The Myth of Sisyphus and incorporated into many of his other works, such as The Stranger and The Plague.Despite his split from his "study partner", Sartre, Camus was still categorized as an Existentialist.He specifically rejected that label in his essay "Enigma" and elsewhere.
summary_1: Post-war, Camus played a part in the French Resistance through Combat, taking on the alias Beauchard and becoming its editor. He crossed paths with Sartre at the premiere of The Flies and covered the Liberation of Paris in 1944. In 1945, Camus stood apart by condemning the atomic bombing in Hiroshima. Following his departure from Combat in '47, he engaged in discussions at Café de Flore and embarked on US tours to discuss French ideologies. Politically, despite his leanings towards the left, his critiques of Communism led to strained relationships, culminating in estrangement from Sartre. His health suffered due to recurring tuberculosis, prompting isolation until publishing The Rebel in 1951. This work, critical of communism, widened rifts among peers and marked the end of his friendship with Sartre. Although labeled an Existentialist, Camus distanced himself from this classification throughout his writings. Notably, he introduced the concept of the absurd - humanity's pursuit of order amidst chaos - foundational to works like The Myth of Sisyphus, The Stranger, and The Plague.
summary_2: After WWII, Albert Camus was active in the French Resistance via Combat, using the pseudonym Beauchard. He met Jean-Paul Sartre at The Flies premiere and reported on Paris' liberation. Condemning the Hiroshima bombing in 1945, he later toured America discussing French ideas. Despite political alignment with the left, Camus criticized Communism, causing friction that ended his friendship with Sartre. Health issues isolated him but didn't stop him from writing influential works embracing "the absurd" – humanity seeking order amid chaos.
summary_3: Post-WWII, Albert Camus, through Combat under the name Beauchard, resisted in France; met Sartre at The Flies premiere, covered Paris' liberation, condemned the '45 Hiroshima bombing, then lectured across America about French thought. Although aligned with the left, Camus critiqued Communism, which strained relations with Sartre, while health problems emerged but failed to hinder his prolific writings embodying human pursuit of meaning despite life's inherent disorder.

text: Reuters Holdings PLC said Michael Reupke resigned as general manager to pursue unspecified interests, a move the news organization termed an "amicable separation."Mr. Reupke, 52 years old and a 27-year Reuters veteran, had been the information-services company's general manager for only six months.His appointment to that post, which has senior administrative, staff and policy responsibilities, followed a several-year tenure as Reuters's editor in chief.No successor was named, and Mr. Reupke's duties will be split among three other senior Reuters executives, the company said.In a telephone interview, Mr. Reupke said his departure was for "personal reasons," which he declined to specify."There is no business reason for my departure," nor any disagreement over policy, he added.He also rejected reports that his departure stemmed from disappointment the general manager's post hadn't also led to a board directorship at the London-based news organization.Mr. Reupke was one of three executives on Reuters's eight-person executive committee who didn't also serve on the company's board of directors."If I were choosing the people of tomorrow, I would have chosen the people who are now on the board," he said.A Reuters spokesman said the departure reflects "no change in strategy or profits."Mark Shepperd, an analyst at UBS Philips & Drew in London, said, "I suspect (the departure) will be fairly irrelevant for the company.I would be very surprised if his departure signals any change in strategy or change in profit expectations."On London's Stock Exchange, Reuters shares rose five pence to 913 pence ($14.43).In the U.S. over-the-counter market, American depositary shares for Reuters, each representing three shares in the London market, closed unchanged at $43.875.The senior of the three executives who will assume Mr. Reupke's duties is Nigel Judah, 58, finance director and a Reuters board director.Peter Holland, 45, deputy general manager, becomes director of corporate affairs.And Patrick Mannix, 46, international technical manager, becomes director of group quality programs.
summary_1:
Michael Reupke, General Manager of Reuters Holdings PLC, stepped down after six months due to personal reasons. The decision was described as an amicable separation, with no specific reasons given. No successor was immediately appointed, and Reupke's duties were divided among three other senior executives: Nigel Judah, Peter Holland, and Patrick Mannix. Reupke, a 27-year Reuters veteran, served as Editor-in-Chief before becoming General Manager. His departure is not expected to impact the company's strategy or profits, according to a Reuters spokesman and financial analyst Mark Shepperd. Reuters shares remained stable following the announcement.
<|im_end|>
summary_2: Reuters Holdings PLC's General Manager, Michael Reupke, resigned after six months for personal reasons. His exit was friendly, with no detailed explanation. Three executives took over his responsibilities. Reupke, a 27-year Reuters veteran, had been Editor-in-Chief prior. His departure isn't seen affecting Reuters' plans or earnings, say a spokesperson and analyst. Reuters shares stayed steady post-announcement.
summary_3: After six months, Reuters Holdings PLC's General Manager, Michael Reupke, resigned due to personal reasons, his departure is not expected to impact Reuters' plans or earnings.

text: Critics say that is not nearly enough compared with other prescribers, such as M.D. psychiatrists or nurse practitioners who have at least six years' medical education and clinical experience.Neither Davison nor most other RxP opponents doubt the efficacy of medications.Their greatest objection is to the notion of turning psychology into a prescribing profession.In a field that has struggled long and hard to prove that mind, mood and behavior can be studied empirically, the past decade, Davison says, has seen "exciting developments" that demonstrate the validity of various psychotherapeutic interventions and the psychosocial-behavioral models on which they are based."The timing is peculiar to abandon psychological science or to convert it to a medical science," explains Elaine M. Heiby of the University of Hawaii, who chairs a committee of the 1,000-member American Association of Applied and Preventive Psychology that is concerned about the medicalization of psychology."Making sure that practicing psychologists are giving patients interventions based on the best available psychological science should be the APA's priority," argues Emory University's Scott Lilienfeld, president of the Society for a Science of Clinical Psychology (SSCP).More than any philosophical betrayal of psychology, RxP opponents fear that the movement will undermine the science they love.They believe that if prescriptive authority becomes the norm, biomedical requirements will inevitably seep into the psychology curriculum, at the expense of traditional psychological science and methodology.Lilienfeld feels that many clinical psychologists already receive inadequate training in fundamentals such as research design and evaluation.RxP opponents charge the APA with pushing its prescription-privileges agenda without adequately assessing support for it in the field.The 300-member SSCP is the only group within the APA to have taken a formal stance against prescription privileges.The APA has scheduled 30 minutes at its meeting in August for an RxP debate, but its leadership believes it already has an accurate sense of support for its RxP policy."Except for this small vocal minority, we have just not gotten a lot of groundswell against this from members," says APA president Philip G. Zimbardo of Stanford University.With prescription privileges now a reality in one state, some RxP opponents concede that it may be too late.This year four states besides New Mexico -- Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois and Tennessee -- have pending legislation for psychologist prescription privileges.Over the past decade, 14 state legislatures have considered such laws.Between 1991 and 1997, a U.S. Department of Defense psychopharmacology demonstration project involving two to four years' training produced 10 military psychologists who can write prescriptions.
summary_1: A controversy exists regarding whether psychologists should obtain prescribing rights, a concept known as RxP. Critics argue that psychologists lack sufficient medical education and clinical experience compared to M.D. psychiatrists or nurse practitioners. However, RxP opponents do not dispute medication effectiveness; their primary concern lies in transforming psychology into a prescribing profession. The last decade has brought significant advancements supporting psychotherapy interventions and psychosocial-behavioral models. Opponents worry that granting prescriptive authority could shift focus away from these developments towards biomedical aspects, potentially diminishing traditional psychological science and methodology. They also claim insufficient training in areas like research design and evaluation. Despite opposition from groups like the Society for a Science of Clinical Psychology, the American Psychological Association (APA) plans to proceed with its RxP policy, believing there is minimal resistance among its members. Four states currently have active legislation for psychologist prescription privileges, and 14 state legislatures have previously considered similar laws.
summary_2: The debate over psychologists obtaining prescribing rights, or RxP, is contentious. Critics argue psychologists lack adequate medical education and experience compared to MD psychiatrists or nurse practitioners. Opponents fear transforming psychology into a prescribing field may shift focus from psychotherapy advances to biomedical aspects, undermining traditional psychological science. Insufficient training in areas like research design is another concern. Despite opposition from groups like the Society for a Science of Clinical Psychology, the APA intends to continue its RxP policy, perceiving little resistance. Four states allow psychologist prescription privileges, with 14 others having previously considered such laws.
summary_3: Critics oppose psychologists gaining prescribing rights due to concerns about insufficient medical training and potential shifts away from traditional psychological science towards biomedicine, but four states have already granted these privileges.

text: Taliban and American aid.After the September 11 attacks, it was necessary for conservatives to somehow explain away the fact that the US government gave 245 million dollars to the new evildoers du jour.Never mind the fact that authors such as Robert Scheer warned of aiding the Taliban as early as in May 2001.Never mind that they did so not out of some humanitarian motivation, but because of the Taliban's violent enforcement of the ban on opium poppies.Never mind that in a regime that is controlled by warlords, it does not matter who is authorized to distribute the aid -- the ruling regional warlords will seize control of it and use it to their own advantage.Never mind that this very argument has been used by hawks in opposition to sending humanitarian aid to Iraq's Saddam Hussein.Never mind that the Taliban continued selling opium in spite of the deal.Never mind that this is all documented on Michael Moore's website about the film.Gun homicides.Statistics are Moore's weakest point, and it is surprising that his critics don't dwell on them longer.That's because they know all too well that Moore is correct: The United States have a far greater homicide rate (both gun- and non-gun) than most other first world countries.His main mistake is that he does not use population corrected data, his second mistake is that he does not cite his sources (and, as you correctly point out, he probably uses different reporting methods for the different countries).A good comparison of international homicide rates can be found on the relatively neutral guncite.com website.
summary_1: Following the September 11 attacks, conservatives had to account for the U.S. giving $245 million to the then-designated evil doers, the Taliban. This was despite warnings from authors like Robert Scheer in May 2001 about aiding the Taliban. The aid was not motivated by humanitarian reasons, but due to the Taliban's harsh enforcement of the opium poppy ban. However, in a warlord-controlled regime, authorized distributors cannot control the aid, which falls into the hands of local warlords. This is a contradiction to arguments made by hawks against providing humanitarian aid to Saddam Hussein's Iraq. Despite a deal aimed at stopping opium sales, the Taliban continued dealing in opium. Michael Moore's documentary provides evidence of these facts. Moving onto gun violence, while statistics are not Moore's strongest suit, he accurately points out the higher homicide rate (including both gun and non-gun crimes) in the U.S., compared to many developed nations. Although Moore fails to provide population-corrected data and source citations, it remains true that the U.S. experiences more homicides relative to its peer countries. A reliable resource for comparing global homicide rates is guncite.com.
summary_2: After 9/11, conservatives faced questions over $245m given to the Taliban, warned about earlier by Robert Scheer. The aid, driven by the opium poppy ban enforcement, reached local warlords, contradicting arguments against aid to Saddam's Iraq. Despite a deal, the Taliban persisted with opium trade. Michael Moore's film highlights the U.S.'s higher homicide rate, including gun and non-gun crimes, compared to several developed nations. Though lacking specific sources, his claim holds when considering unadjusted data on homicides in relation to peer countries. For accurate comparisons, visit guncite.com.
summary_3: Post-9/11, it was revealed that the U.S. had given $245m to the Taliban, which was used by local warlords for opium trading despite a ban, similar to concerns about aiding Saddam's Iraq. Meanwhile, Michael Moore highlighted the U.S.'s higher homicide rate than several developed nations, a fact supported by unadjusted data from gun and non-gun crimes.

text: Befitting a lush, tropical island stranded in the middle of the ocean, Madeira’s origins are shrouded in mystery and fanciful legend.Some claim that the archipelago is what remains of Plato’s lost Atlantis, or part of a landmass that once fused the continents of Europe and America.The Portuguese Step Ashore: Recorded history of the volcanic archipelago begins in relatively recent times: 1418, just as the golden age of Portuguese discovery was erupting.Under the leadership of Henry the Navigator, caravels set out from the westernmost point of the Algarve, in southern Portugal, in search of foreign lands, fame, and wealth.João Gonçalves Zarco, sailing in the service of Prince Henry, made the first of many famous Portuguese discoveries, which would culminate a century later in Magellan’s historic circumnavigation of the globe.Zarco happened upon a small volcanic archipelago 1,000 km from Lisbon.Perhaps Zarco knew precisely where he was heading, having learned of the existence of Madeira from a Castilian source.After all, the waters of the Canary Islands, only 445 km (275 miles) to the south, had occupied busy shipping lanes for very nearly a century, and Genovese maps from the mid-14th century depict both Madeira and Porto Santo.More likely, Zarco was heading for Guinea and storms forced him onto the beach of Porto Santo.If so, then he was extremely fortunate, for he managed to land on the only large, sandy beach for hundreds of miles around.Little wonder he subsequently named it Porto Santo (Holy Port).The following year Zarco returned to claim the larger island he had seen from Porto Santo, and with him went Tristão Vaz Teixeira and Bartolomeu Perestrelo.They officially became the first men to set foot on the heavily forested island, naming it Ilha da Madeira, “Island of Timber.” The Portuguese Crown, delighted with its first important discovery, immediately embarked on a program of colonization.Zarco and Teixeira were appointed co-go­vern­ors of Madeira, while Perestrelo was awarded Porto Santo.
summary_1: In 1418, during the height of the Age of Discovery, João Gonçalves Zarco, under Henry the Navigator's command, discovered the volcanic archipelago of Madeira. Zarco might have been guided by a Castilian source or could have stumbled upon it due to a storm while en route to Guinea. Regardless, he named the main island "Ilha da Madeira" or "Island of Timber," and the smaller one, Porto Santo or "Holy Port." The latter name originated from the single large, sandy beach found there, a rarity in the area. The following year, Zarco claimed the larger island and was joined by Tristão Vaz Teixeira and Bartolomeu Perestrelo. The Portuguese Crown, pleased with this significant discovery, initiated a colonization plan. Zarco and Teixeira were appointed co-governors of Madeira, and Perestrelo received Porto Santo.
summary_2: In 1418, under Henry the Navigator's orders, João Gonçalves Zarco discovered the Madeira archipelago. He named the main island "Ilha da Madeira" and the smaller one, Porto Santo. Zarco, Tristão Vaz Teixeira, and Bartolomeu Perestrelo later settled there. The Portuguese Crown, delighted by this discovery, began colonization. Zarco and Teixeira became co-governors of Madeira, and Perestrelo governed Porto Santo.
summary_3: In 1418, under Henry the Navigator's orders, João Gonçalves Zarco discovered the Madeira archipelago, naming the main island "Ilha da Madeira" and the smaller one, Porto Santo; he and his companions later settled there, marking the beginning of Portugal's colonization.

text: Madame White Snake: East Asian Femme Fatale of Old The Chinese legend of Madame White Snake, the snake demon that takes human form and becomes the wife of a man, has exerted a lasting influence over East Asian folktales and fiction for centuries.Two quintessential novellas, "The Lust of the White Serpant" from Ugetsu Monogatari by the Japanese author Ueda Akinari and "Eternal Prisoner under Thunder Peak Pagoda" a traditional Chinese story, are both relatively complex and demonstrate not only the evolution of the White Snake figure to become a more believable human, but also what aspects may have given her enduring appeal.While both these stories are ostensibly morality tales about the dangerous beauty of this femme fatale, the true source of pleasure from these narratives is the femme fatale's transgressive behavior, not her eventual punishment for it.Early tales of Madame White Snake appeared in China as early as the Song Dynasty, and initially her portrayal was fairly direct, as a villainous demon who drains the life force out of her human husband.But over time, characterizations of her became more complex, and the persona of Madame White Snake became more sympathetic, and perhaps even a model of the ideal Confucian wife, particularly in "Pagoda".Whalen Lai notes, "She was a loving wife, a caring mother, rescuer of her family from the first flood, and, at that point, a general benefactor of man.She took on the virtues of a traditional Chinese female, particularly forbearance".But if she were really an ideal wife, why could she not live happily with her human mate?Her dangerous sexuality is the key.Femme fatale might seem an unusual term to apply to a character from pre-modern Chinese and Japanese literature who may exemplify the virtues of an ideal Confucian wife, since it is primarily associated with film characters, particularly those of the film noir genre.But this term, which is relatively speaking, a neologism (The earliest uses were around the beginning of the 20th century
summary_1: The tale of Madame White Snake, a shape-shifting serpent who assumes human form and marries a man, has significantly influenced East Asian lore and literature. Two prominent works featuring this enchantress are "The Lust of the White Serpent," part of Ugetsu Monogatari by Ueda Akinari, and the classic Chinese narrative "Eternal Prisoner under Thunder Peak Pagoda." Both stories, often presented as cautionary tales about the perils of seductive women, find greater appeal in the transgressive actions of the femme fatale rather than her subsequent chastisement. Initially depicted as a malevolent spirit draining her human spouse's vitality, Madame White Snake evolved into a more empathetic character over time. She embodies the virtuous traits of a traditional Chinese wife, such as patience and nurturance, yet cannot coexist peacefully with her human partner due to her volatile sexuality. Although the term 'femme fatale' is predominantly linked with modern film characters, notably those from film noir, its application here emphasizes the captivating yet destructive nature of this seemingly perfect wife archetype.
summary_2: Madame White Snake, a snake-turned-wife, stars in two major East Asian works, "Lust of the White Serpent" and "Eternal Prisoner under Thunder Peak Pagoda". Originally portrayed negatively, she later becomes sympathetic despite being seen as a dangerous woman. Her allure stems from her dual identity - a loving wife with explosive sexuality, causing conflict between her husband and herself. The concept of 'femme fatale', typically tied to modern films, aptly fits this ancient figure.
summary_3: In "Lust of the White Serpent" and "Eternal Prisoner under Thunder Peak Pagoda," Madame White Snake transforms from a villainous seductress into a sympathetic character, embodying both a devoted spouse and an enticing yet perilous woman, reflecting the timeless archetype of the femme fatale.

text: (CNN) -- Deposed Honduran President Jose Manuel Zelaya will not be reinstated as head of state, an overwhelming majority of the Honduran congress voted Wednesday.In an hours-long process, 111 lawmakers voted in favor of a motion not to return Zelaya to office.A majority of 65 votes in the 128-member body was required to reject his reinstatement.Zelaya was removed from office in a military-led coup on June 28 and replaced by congressional leader Roberto Micheletti.On Wednesday, lawmakers voted one by one and addressed the chamber as they cast their vote, making for a slow process.The vote was a key part of a U.S.-brokered pact that representatives for Zelaya and Micheletti signed October 29, giving Congress the power to decide Zelaya's fate.The United States expressed disappointment Thursday over the latest rebuff to its diplomatic efforts to end the political crisis in Honduras.U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs Arturo Valenzuela continued to call on the Honduran government to allow Zelaya's return and to create a unity government in the interim period before the new president takes office next month."We are disappointed by this decision since the United States had hoped the [Honduran] Congress would have approved his return," Valenzuela said in a conference call with journalists in Washington."Our policy since June 28 has been consistently principled.It has condemned the coup d'etat and continued to accept President Zelaya as the democratically elected and legitimate leader of Honduras throughout this political crisis."The United States continues to call for Honduras to engage in national reconciliation and creation of a truth commission to investigate the crisis, in addition to the unity government."The absence of democratic, constitutional order is the unacceptable status quo," a senior U.S. administration official said on the conference call, remaining anonymous under the ground rules of the call and because of the sensitivity of the situation."The election is a step toward a day where Honduras will have an electorally legitimate government in place."
summary_1: Jose Manuel Zelaya won't be reinstated as Honduran president, according to a significant majority of the Honduran congress. The legislative body, comprising 128 members, saw 111 voting against Zelaya's restoration. This move aligns with a US-mediated agreement between Zelaya and interim president Roberto Micheletti. Despite international pressure, including from the US, the congress decided Zelaya's fate. The US, which had previously denounced the coup, expressed disappointment but acknowledged the election results, hoping it would lead to a legitimate government. The US also urged for a unity government, national reconciliation, and a truth commission investigation into the crisis. A senior US administration official emphasized the need for an electorally legitimate government, stating that the current lack of democratic, constitutional order is unacceptable.
summary_2: Honduras' Congress votes down Zelaya's return as President, despite international pressure. Out of 128 members, 111 vote 'no'. The decision aligns with a US-backed deal between Zelaya and interim leader Roberto Micheletti. The US, initially opposing the coup, accepts the election outcome, aiming for a legitimate government via a unity gov't, national reconciliation, and a probe into the crisis. The US admin stresses the importance of restoring democratic, constitutional order.
summary_3: Congress rejects Zelaya's presidency in Honduras, agreeing with a US-backed deal; the US supports the election outcome, emphasizing democratic restoration.

text: In 1990, the U.S. Custom House in New York City was renamed after Hamilton.In 1880, his son John Church Hamilton commissioned Carl Conrads to sculpt a granite statue, now located in Central Park, New York City.One statue honoring Alexander Hamilton in Chicago was mired in controversy, at least concerning the surrounding architecture.Kate Sturges Buckingham (1858-1937), of the Buckingham Fountain family, commissioned the monument.Its impetus was that Treasury Secretary Hamilton "secured the nation's financial future and made it possible for her own family to make its fortune in grain elevators and banking.Consequently, John Angel was hired to model a figurative sculpture and the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen was to create a "colossal architectural setting" for it.The proposed 80-foot tall columned shelter was poorly received.By Ms. Buckingham's death in 1937, the sculpture's setting.location and design were uncertain.Conspiracy allegations surfaced, and the matter became mired in litigation.After the courts ordered the construction to be completed by 1953, the trustees hired architect Samuel A. Marx.The structure was completed, had structural problems, and was eventually demolished in 1993.The statue was gilded, and is still on display.A statue, by James Earle Fraser, was dedicated on May 17, 1923, on the south terrace of the Treasury Building, in Washington.
summary_1: Alexander Hamilton has been commemorated with several statues due to his significant contributions to the United States' financial system. In 1990, the U.S. Custom House in New York City was renamed in his honor. In 1880, Hamilton's son, John Church Hamilton, commissioned Carl Conrads to create a granite statue of him, which currently resides in Central Park, New York City. Another statue in Chicago, funded by Kate Sturges Buckingham, faced controversy primarily due to the proposed architectural setting designed by Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen. The planned 80-foot tall columned shelter did not receive wide acceptance, leading to uncertainty about the location and design even after Buckingham's passing in 1937. Legal disputes further complicated matters until court orders mandated completion by 1953. Architect Samuel A. Marx oversaw the project, but the finished structure suffered from structural issues and was ultimately demolished in 1993. Despite this setback, Hamilton's statue remains on display, having undergone gilding. Additionally, a statue crafted by James Earle Fraser was unveiled on May 17, 1923, on the south terrace of the Treasury Building in Washington D.C., serving as another tribute to Hamilton's enduring legacy.
summary_2: Hamilton honored with multiple statues for US financial impact; one each in NYC's Central Park and the Treasury Building in DC, plus a controversial one in Chicago that faced opposition and was eventually demolished in 1993 despite being funded by Kate Sturges Buckingham.
summary_3: Statues commemorating Hamilton's financial influence stand in both New York City's Central Park and the Treasury Building in Washington D.C., but a contentious one in Chicago, funded by Kate Sturges Buckingham, was destroyed in 1993 due to public opposition.

text: Magnetism is the ability of a material to be attracted by a magnet.It also include the ability for some material to act like a magnet.No doubt youve handled refrigerator magnets.You can see some in Figure 1.28.You probably know they stick to a metal refrigerator.This is what holds your homework up.Maybe your little sisters drawings are hung on the fridge in this manner.Do magnets stick to all materials?Of course not.You have probably checked and they do not stick to other surfaces.They do not stick to wooden doors or glass windows.Wood and glass are not attracted to a magnet.Obviously, only certain materials are attracted to magnets.
summary_1: Magnets possess the quality of attraction to specific materials. This trait is known as magnetism. A common example is the refrigerator magnet, which adheres to metallic substances due to its magnetic properties, effectively displaying notes, photos, or children's artwork (Figure 1.28). However, not all materials react similarly to magnets; wood and glass, for instance, remain unaffected. Thus, it can be concluded that magnetism selectively interacts with particular substances, excluding others from their attractive force.
summary_2: Magnets have an attractive force towards certain materials through magnetism, like fridge magnets sticking to metal surfaces but not affecting wood or glass.
summary_3: Magnets attract specific materials due to their magnetic properties, demonstrated when they stick to metal surfaces yet don't affect wood or glass.

text: In actual practice, however, we act too often as if we only cared for economic values. If we are to live up to our educational profession, we must look our aim in the face and honestly practise what we believe. While training of character and conduct is the accepted aim for education in general, to make this useful and practical each teacher must fix her attention on how this ultimate aim affects her own special part of the whole work. By watching the free child she will discover how best she can help him: he knows his own business, and when unfettered by advice or command shows plainly that he is chiefly concerned with _gaining experience_. He finds himself in what is to him a new and complex world of people and things; actual experience is the foundation for a complete living, and the stronger the foundation the better the result of later building. _The first vital principle then is that the teacher of young children must provide life in miniature; that is, she must provide abundant raw material and opportunities for experience_.
summary_1: Educators should prioritize teaching practices that foster character development over solely focusing on economic value acquisition. The primary goal of education is to shape students' characters and behaviors positively. To achieve this objective effectively, educators need to focus on their specific roles within the broader educational context. Observing children freely interacting allows teachers to identify optimal ways they can assist them. Children inherently seek experiences to learn about themselves and their surroundings. These real-life interactions form the basis for comprehensive personal growth. Therefore, it is essential that educators create microcosms offering ample learning opportunities and resources necessary for meaningful experiences. This approach enables students to build strong foundations for future development.
summary_2: Teachers must emphasize shaping student behavior and character over just boosting employability skills. Education's main aim is cultivating positive traits and habits through tailored methods based on kids' natural curiosity. By fostering an engaging environment filled with diverse experiences, educators help lay solid groundwork for pupils' ongoing progress.
summary_3: Education should prioritize shaping students' character and behaviors over solely enhancing employable skills, using personalized approaches that leverage their innate curiosity to create an enriching learning environment.

text: New York (CNN) -- Three defendants pleaded guilty in federal court Wednesday to conspiring to defraud a Holocaust reparations organization out of $57.3 million, according to court documents.Genrikh Kolontyrskiy, Moysey Kucher and Dora Kucher, all of Brooklyn, helped produce and process some of the thousands of fraudulent applications for the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany that are under investigation.The organization, also known as the Claims Conference, distributes more than $400 million a year from funds provided by the German government to victims of the Holocaust."Our efforts to hold to account all of the individuals who participated in defrauding an organization that exists solely for the purpose of aiding victims of Nazi atrocities continues," said Preet Bharara, U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, in a statement.The defendants aided in defrauding two funds managed by the Claims Conference, the Article 2 Fund and the Hardship Fund, of $45 million and $12.3 million, respectively, according to court documents.The Article 2 Fund makes monthly payments of around $400 to survivors of Nazi persecution who make less than $16,000 per year "and either lived in hiding or under a false identity for at least 18 months," according to a news release from the U.S. Attorney's office.The Hardship Fund pays a one-time payment of $3,500 to "victims of Nazi persecution who evacuated the cities in which they lived and were forced to become refugees."Kolontyrskiy, 80, knowingly processed fraudulent applications for payment while employed with the Article 2 Fund, according to court documents.Moysey Kucher, 66, and Dora Kucher, 58, recruited individuals to provide identification documents that were used to prepare fraudulent applications for both funds, in exchange for money paid out to the false applicants, according to court documents.Jesse Siegel, Kolontyrskiy's attorney, said his client was by no means a major instigator, but he takes responsibility for his actions.
summary_1: Three people pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud a Holocaust reparations group, the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, of $57.3 million. Genrikh Kolontyrskiy, Moysey Kucher, and Dora Kucher, all from Brooklyn, were involved in processing fraudulent applications for the organization. The trio assisted in defrauding the Article 2 Fund and the Hardship Fund of $45 million and $12.3 million, respectively. Kolontyrskiy, aged 80, knowingly processed fake claims while working with the Article 2 Fund. Moysey Kucher, 66, and Dora Kucher, 58, recruited individuals to supply identification documents for creating fraudulent applications, receiving payouts in return. Jesse Siegel, Kolontyrskiy's lawyer, stated that his client wasn't a significant instigator but admits guilt for his involvement. The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany dispenses over $400 million annually from German government funds to aid Holocaust victims.
summary_2: Three Brooklyn residents pled guilty to swindling $57.3 million from the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany. Genrikh Kolontyrskiy, Moysey Kucher, and Dora Kucher were part of a scheme defrauding the Article 2 Fund and Hardship Fund of $45 million and $12.3 million, respectively. The trio submitted false claims, provided fake IDs, and received payments. While Kolontyrskiy, 80, handled phony applications at the Article 2 Fund, Moysey Kucher, 66, and Dora Kucher, 58, procured identifications and got kickbacks. Although Kolontyrskiy's attorney claimed he was not a major player, he confessed to participation. The Conference gives out over $400 million yearly from German government money to support Holocaust survivors.
summary_3: Three Brooklyn residents pleaded guilty to scamming $57.3 million from the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany by submitting false claims, providing fake IDs, and receiving payments.

text: Dr. Benjamin Stone is a hotshot young surgeon who longs to leave the drudgery of a Washington , D.C. emergency room and finally leaps at his chance at more money and less death as a plastic surgeon in Beverly Hills . On his last day , Ben's relationship with his co-workers is presumed to be anything but a warm one .
