None of his colleagues will join him for a drink and a cake in his honor has an iced portion of the phrase `` Good riddance , asshole '' sliced out . Ben's cross-country drive in a 1956 Porsche 356 Speedster is interrupted when he crashes in the rural hamlet of Grady , South Carolina . The crash damages the fence of local Judge Evans , who sentences him to community service at a nearby hospital . Ben offers to pay for the fence , but the stern judge increases his community service each time he talks back . Defeated , he reports to the hospital , where Nurse Packer humbles him by ordering him to clock in and out , as would a factory worker . Though upset , Ben quickly makes friends with Mayor Nick Nicholson , the town cafe's proprietor/head waitress , and Melvin , the local mechanic tasked with repairing Ben's car . Ben soon finds his clinic work to be much more laid-back than the emergency room . He has simple cases such as spots before the eyes , fishing hook impalings , and even reading mail for a young illiterate couple , whose baby he later delivers . The experience also humbles Ben when he mistreats a case of mitral valve regurgitation leading to late cyanosis in the child .
summary_1:
Dr. Benjamin Stone, a talented yet detached surgeon, departs from his ER position in Washington D.C., leaving behind a cold farewell from his coworkers. His new opportunity lies in plastic surgery within Beverly Hills. However, on his final day, a mishap occurs - a drunk driver collides into Dr. Stone’s vintage vehicle, a '56 Porsche 356 Speedster, stranding him in Grady, South Carolina.

Judge Evans sentences Dr. Stone to community service at the local hospital after damaging the judge's fence during the accident. Despite offering financial compensation, Ben's sarcasm triggers harsher punitive measures from Judge Evans. Begrudgingly, Dr. Stone starts working at the hospital under the watchful eye of Nurse Packer, who treats him like any other employee.

During this unexpected stay, Dr. Stone meets several residents including Mayor Nick Nicholson, café owner and headwaitress; Melvin, the auto mechanic responsible for fixing the Porsche; and various patients requiring medical assistance. As days pass, Ben forms friendships with these individuals while tending to minor injuries and participating in lighter tasks compared to his previous role.

A notable incident involves a misdiagnosed heart condition that nearly costs a child their life due to Dr. Stone's negligence. This event serves as a sober reminder about the importance of treating every patient diligently, regardless of the severity of their affliction. Ultimately, Dr. Stone learns valuable lessons about compassion and responsibility throughout his journey in Grady, which forever alters both his personal and professional perspectives.
summary_2: After an accident lands Dr. Benjamin Stone in Grady, SC, he's sentenced to community service at the local hospital. Initially dismissive, Stone gradually bonds with locals, forming friendships and learning about responsibility and empathy, especially when a misdiagnosis underscores the value of careful treatment for all patients.
summary_3: Assigned to community service at a local hospital after an accident, Dr. Benjamin Stone learns about responsibility, empathy, and careful patient treatment while bonding with locals.

text: Hamilton argued that the natural faculties of blacks were as good as those of free whites, and he warned that the British would arm the slaves if the patriots did not.In his 21st-century biography, Chernow cites this incident as evidence that Hamilton and Laurens saw the Revolution and the struggle against slavery as inseparable.Hamilton attacked his political opponents as demanding freedom for themselves and refusing to allow it to blacks.In January 1785, Hamilton attended the second meeting of the New York Manumission Society (NYMS).John Jay was president and Hamilton was the first secretary and later became president.Chernow notes how the membership soon included many of Hamilton's friends and associates.Hamilton was a member of the committee of the society that petitioned the legislature to end the slave trade, and that succeeded in passing legislation banning the export of slaves from New York.In the same period, Hamilton felt bound by the rule of law of the time and his law practice facilitated the return of a fugitive slave to Henry Laurens of South Carolina.He opposed the compromise at the 1787 Constitutional Convention by which the federal government could not abolish the slave trade for 20 years, and was disappointed when he lost that argument.Hamilton never supported forced emigration for freed slaves.Horton has argued from this that he would be comfortable with a multiracial society, and that this distinguished him from his contemporaries.In international affairs, he supported Toussaint L'Ouverture's black government in Haiti after the revolt that overthrew French control, as he had supported aid to the slaveowners in 1791--both measures hurt France.Scant evidence has been interpreted by a few to indicate Hamilton may have owned household slaves, as did many wealthy New Yorkers (the evidence for this is indirect; McDonald interprets it as referring to paid employees).
summary_1: Alexander Hamilton advocated for racial equality, viewing the revolutionary fight for independence and the battle against slavery as one cause. He criticized opponents who sought personal liberty but denied it to others based on race. In 1785, Hamilton joined the New York Manumission Society (NYMS), serving as its first secretary and later becoming president. The NYMS aimed to end the slave trade, successfully lobbying for a ban on slave exports from New York. Despite these efforts, Hamilton adhered to contemporary laws, including assisting in returning a runaway slave to Henry Laurens. At the 1787 Constitutional Convention, Hamilton disagreed with the decision allowing the federal government to delay ending the slave trade for two decades. Unlike some peers, Hamilton didn't support forced emigration for freed slaves, suggesting comfort with a multi-racial society. His stance favored foreign policies benefiting both white and black communities, such as supporting Toussaint L'Ouverture's post-revolutionary Haitian administration despite earlier assistance to suppress the slave uprising there. Although speculation exists about Hamilton owning household slaves like other affluent New Yorkers, direct evidence remains elusive.
summary_2: Hamilton championed racial equality, opposing those denying freedom based on race. Joining the NYMS in 1785, he served as secretary then president, pushing for an end to the slave trade. However, he followed existing laws, even helping return a runaway slave. At the 1787 convention, he opposed prolonging the slave trade. Unlike some contemporaries, he accepted a multiracial society and backed pro-black foreign policies. While rumors suggest he owned slaves, definitive proof is lacking.
summary_3: In his time with the NYMS, Hamilton advocated against racism, fought to end the slave trade, but still upheld certain unjust laws; although there are rumors that he owned slaves, no solid evidence has been found.

text: Radio Televizioni Shqiptar (RTSH) is the public radio and TV broadcaster of Albania, founded by King Zog in 1938.RTSH runs three analogue television stations as TVSH Televizioni Shqiptar, four digital thematic stations as RTSH, and three radio stations using the name Radio Tirana.In addition, 4 regional radio stations serve in the four extremities of Albania.The international service broadcasts radio programmes in Albanian and seven other languages via medium wave (AM) and short wave (SW).The international service has used the theme from the song "Keputa nje gjethe dafine" as its signature tune.The international television service via satellite was launched since 1993 and aims at Albanian communities in Kosovo, Serbia, Macedonia, Montenegro and northern Greece, plus the Albanian diaspora in the rest of Europe.RTSH has a past of being heavily influenced by the ruling party in its reporting, whether that party be left or right wing.According to the Albanian Media Authority, AMA, Albania has an estimated 257 media outlets, including 66 radio stations and 67 television stations, with three national, 62 local and more than 50 cable TV stations.Last years Albania has organized several shows as a part of worldwide series like Dancing with the Stars, Big Brother Albania, Albanians Got Talent, The Voice of Albania, and X Factor Albania.
summary_1: Radio Televizioni Shqiptar (RTSH), established by King Zog in 1938, serves as Albania's public radio and TV broadcaster. It operates three analogue TV channels under TVSH Televizioni Shqiptar, four digital thematic stations simply named RTSH, and three radio stations known as Radio Tirana. Four regional radio stations also operate in Albania's corners. Its international service airs radio programs in Albanian and seven other languages on medium wave (AM) and short wave (SW). This service has utilized the theme from "Keputa nje gjethe dafine" as its signature tune. Launched in 1993, the international television service targets Albanian communities in neighboring countries and the global Albanian diaspora. Historically, RTSH has been swayed politically, reflecting the stance of whichever party holds power, regardless of ideological leaning. As per the Albanian Media Authority (AMA), Albania hosts approximately 257 media outlets, comprising 66 radio stations, 67 television stations, three national networks, 62 local stations, over 50 cable TV stations, and various worldwide franchises such as Dancing with the Stars, Big Brother Albania, Albanians Got Talent, The Voice of Albania, and X Factor Albania.
summary_2: Established in 1938, Radio Televizioni Shqiptar (RTSH) is Albania's public broadcaster, operating three TV channels, four digital stations, and three radio stations. Four regional radio stations also exist. Its international service broadcasts in eight languages via AM and SW, using "Keputa nje gjethe dafine" as its theme. The international TV service, launched in 1993, caters to Albanian communities and the global diaspora. Politically influenced, RTSH reflects the ruling party's stance. Albania has about 257 media outlets, including 66 radio stations, 67 TV stations, and numerous cable TV stations and franchises like Dancing with the Stars.
summary_3: Radio Televizioni Shqiptar (RTSH), established in 1938, operates multiple TV and radio stations, broadcasting in several languages with a focus on serving Albanian communities; it has been politically influenced.

text: When land is cleared, habitats are lost.It may be cleared for agriculture.It may also be used for building new homes or businesses.Within the past 100 years, the amount of land used for agriculture has almost doubled.Land used for grazing cattle has more than doubled.Many wetlands have also been lost to agriculture.The U.S. has lost almost all the natural tall-grass prairies.Thee areas of tall thick grass have virtually disappeared.These areas of land had thick fertile soil.Their grasses had very deep root systems.These deep and thick roots reduced the amount of soil erosion.They also were home to many plants and animals.Prairies were wonderful places.They were home to colorful flowers, prairie dogs, and herds of bison.
summary_1: Clearing land leads to habitat loss, often due to agricultural expansion and construction of buildings. Over the last century, farmland has nearly doubled, with grazing space for cattle more than doubling. Agriculture has caused significant wetland reduction too. The United States has largely lost its native tall-grass prairies, which featured rich soils and extensive root systems that minimized soil erosion while hosting diverse flora and fauna, including vibrant wildflowers, prairie dogs, and vast bison herds, making these landscapes ecologically valuable and vibrant ecosystems.
summary_2: Farmland has almost doubled over the past century, causing substantial wetland reduction and eliminating most American tall-grass prairies. Rich in plant life and wildlife like prairie dogs and bison, these grasslands had deep roots preventing soil erosion. Habitat loss from agriculture and building construction threaten their survival.
summary_3: Over the last century, farmland expansion has led to significant reductions in wetlands and near-extinction of American tall-grass prairies, which once teemed with diverse flora and fauna, including prairie dogs and bison, and boasted deep-rooted vegetation that prevented soil erosion; habitat loss due to agricultural activities and construction poses ongoing threats to their existence.

text: American Airlines Flight 11: FAA Awareness.Although the Boston Center air traffic controller realized at an early stage that there was something wrong with American 11, he did not immediately interpret the plane's failure to respond as a sign that it had been hijacked.At 8:14, when the flight failed to heed his instruction to climb to 35,000 feet, the controller repeatedly tried to raise the flight.He reached out to the pilot on the emergency frequency.Though there was no response, he kept trying to contact the aircraft.At 8:21, American 11 turned off its transponder, immediately degrading the information available about the aircraft.The controller told his supervisor that he thought something was seriously wrong with the plane, although neither suspected a hijacking.The supervisor instructed the controller to follow standard procedures for handling a "no radio" aircraft.The controller checked to see if American Airlines could establish communication with American 11.He became even more concerned as its route changed, moving into another sector's airspace.Controllers immediately began to move aircraft out of its path, and asked other aircraft in the vicinity to look for American 11.At 8:24:38, the following transmission came from American 11: American 11: We have some planes.Just stay quiet, and you'll be okay.We are returning to the airport.The controller only heard something unintelligible; he did not hear the specific words "we have some planes."The next transmission came seconds later: American 11: Nobody move.Everything will be okay.If you try to make any moves, you'll endanger yourself and the airplane.
summary_1: Early suspicions arise regarding American Airlines Flight 11. At 8:14, the Boston Center air traffic controller noticed irregularities when American 11 didn't adhere to instructions to ascend to 35,000 feet. Repeated attempts were made to reach the plane over the emergency frequency, but to no avail. The situation worsened at 8:21 when American 11 switched off its transponder, reducing crucial data availability. Despite these anomalies, neither the controller nor the supervisor initially considered hijacking as a possibility. Instead, they followed protocols for managing a "no radio" aircraft, including attempting to reconnect through American Airlines. Alarm heightened further due to unexpected changes in the flight path, leading controllers to reroute nearby aircraft and solicit assistance from others to locate American 11. Two critical transmissions were received at 8:24:38 - first, an indistinct message, then a chilling declaration, "Nobody move. Everything will be okay. If you try to make any moves, you'll endanger yourself and the airplane." However, the controller only caught fragments of these communications, remaining oblivious to their ominous meaning.
summary_2: At 8:14, American Airlines Flight 19 deviates from instructions, ignoring orders to climb to 35,000 feet. Repeated attempts to contact the plane fail as it switches off its transponder at 8:21, limiting data access. Initially, neither the controller nor the supervisor consider hijacking, treating it instead as a "no radio" incident. They attempt to reconnect via American Airlines, while also dealing with unusual flight path alterations. At 8:24:38, two significant messages emerge: an unclear one and a chilling threat, "Nobody move... if you try to make any moves, you'll endanger yourself and the airplane." Unfortunately, the controller only catches parts of these messages, remaining unaware of their gravity.
summary_3: In response to repeated ignored instructions to ascend to 35,000 feet and subsequent loss of communication after transponder shutoff, American Airlines Flight 19 is initially treated as a routine "no radio" event, but later reveals signs of potential hijacking through cryptic communications about possible danger around 8:24.

text: When Alexander destroyed Tyre, most of the towns on the route to Egypt quickly capitulated.A later tradition recorded his entry into Jerusalem: according to Josephus, Alexander was shown the Book of Daniel's prophecy, presumably chapter 8, which described a mighty Greek king who would conquer the Persian Empire.He spared Jerusalem and pushed south into Egypt.However, Alexander met with resistance at Gaza.The stronghold was heavily fortified and built on a hill, requiring a siege.When "his engineers pointed out to him that because of the height of the mound it would be impossible... this encouraged Alexander all the more to make the attempt".After three unsuccessful assaults, the stronghold fell, but not before Alexander had received a serious shoulder wound.As in Tyre, men of military age were put to the sword and the women and children were sold into slavery.Alexander advanced on Egypt in later 332 BC, where he was regarded as a liberator.He was pronounced son of the deity Amun at the Oracle of Siwa Oasis in the Libyan desert.Henceforth, Alexander often referred to Zeus-Ammon as his true father, and after his death, currency depicted him adorned with rams horn as a symbol of his divinity.During his stay in Egypt, he founded Alexandria-by-Egypt, which would become the prosperous capital of the Ptolemaic Kingdom after his death.
summary_1: In 332 BCE, when Alexander the Great destroyed Tyre, many cities en route to Egypt surrendered without much resistance. A later account by Josephus states that during Alexander's approach towards Jerusalem, he was shown a prophecy from the Book of Daniel (specifically, chapter 8) that foretold a powerful Greek ruler conquering the Persian Empire. Sparing Jerusalem, Alexander moved forward to Egypt, where he was seen as a liberator. Here, he was proclaimed the son of the god Amun at the Oracle of Siwa Oasis in the Libyan desert, further solidifying his divine status. He subsequently started referring to himself as the son of Zeus-Ammon. After his death, he was often portrayed with ram's horns, signifying his divine nature. While besieging Gaza, a strongly fortified city situated on a hill, Alexander faced resistance; despite expert advice suggesting otherwise due to its elevation, he decided to attack. Following three failed attempts, the stronghold finally succumbed, leading to the execution of men of fighting age and enslavement for women and children. In Egypt, Alexander established Alexandria-by-Egypt, which flourished as the capital of the Ptolemaic Kingdom posthumously.
summary_2: Alexander the Great spared Jerusalem after seeing a prophecy about him in Daniel. He then defeated Gazan resisters, executing men and enslaving women/children. Later, he founded Alexandria-by-Egypt, becoming known as the son of Zeus-Ammon.
summary_3: After sparing Jerusalem due to a prophecy in Daniel, Alexander the Great conquered Gazan resisters, resulting in executions and enslavement, before founding Alexandria-by-Egypt and being hailed as Zeus-Ammon's son.

text: The Dutch Take Over: Intent on capturing a piece of the Portuguese trade in pepper and other spices, the Java-based Dutch Ailied with the Malays in 1633 to blockade Melaka.The trade blockade was to last eight years, and ended in a seven-month siege.The Portuguese surrendered in 1641, wracked by malaria and dysentery and denied their usual reinforcements from Goa.By then, the city had become a stagnant backwater.Unlike the Portuguese, the Dutch decided to do business with the Malays of Johor, who controlled the southern half of the peninsula together with Singapore and the neighboring Riau islands.A trade treaty gave the Dutch command of the spice trade but reserved Johor's rights in tin exports from Perak, Selangor, and Klang.Without ever retrieving the supremacy of the old Melaka sultanate, Johor had become the strongest Asian power in the region.For the Dutch, Johor provided a buffer against other Europeans.Meanwhile, fresh blood came in with the migration into the southern interior of hardy Minangkabau farmers from Sumatra, while tough Bugis warriors from the east Indonesian Celebes (Sulawesi) roved the length and breadth of the peninsula.The Minangkabau custom of freely electing their leaders provided the model for rulership elections in modern federal Malaysia.Their confederation of States became today's Negeri Sembilan ("Nine States"), with Seremban as its capital.The name Minangkabau itself means roughly "buffalo horns" and is reflected in the distinctive upward curving roof in museums and government offices built in the traditional Minangkabau style.The Bugis were energetic merchants and great sailors.With the Dutch concentrating once more on Java and the Moluccas in the 18th century, the Bugis took advantage of the vacuum by raiding Perak and Kedah, imposing their chieftains in Selangor and becoming the power behind the throne in Johor.The Bugis in Johor's administration provided much of the spirit in that State's independent stand in the 19th and 20th centuries.Throughout this period, the east coast states enjoyed a relatively tranquil prosperity, Terengganu notably thriving from its textile industry and trading in pepper and gold with the Thais, Cambodians, and Chinese.The British, under the private auspices of the East India Company (EIC), were beginning to poke their noses into North Borneo.
summary_1: In 1633, the Dutch allied with the Malays to impose an eight-year trade blockade on Melaka, culminating in a seven-month siege. The Portuguese surrender in 1641 due to internal strife and diseases, marking the end of Melaka's glory days. The Dutch, taking over the spice trade, form a trade alliance with Johor, allowing them control over tin exports from Perak, Selangor, and Klang. This strategic move establishes Johor as the dominant regional force. Meanwhile, Minangkabau farmers and Bugis warriors migrate to the southern Malay Peninsula, introducing new customs and cultures. The democratic election system introduced by the Minangkabau influences modern federal Malaysia's political landscape. As the Dutch focus on Java and Moluccas in the 18th century, the Bugis seize the opportunity to expand their influence in Perak, Kedah, Selangor, and Johor. While the east coast states enjoy relative peace and prosperity, the British, through the EIC, start showing interest in North Borneo.
summary_2: The Dutch formed an alliance with Malays against Melaka in 1633, leading to its fall in 1641 after a long siege. The Dutch then controlled the spice trade, forming an alliance with Johor for tin export dominance. Simultaneously, Minangkabau and Bugis migration influenced local culture while shaping Malaysia's current democracy. In the 18th century, the Bugis expanded their power in Perak, Kedah, Selangor, and Johor, while the British showed interest in North Borneo.
summary_3: After seizing Melaka from the Portuguese in 1641, the Dutch dominated the spice trade, allied with Johor for tin exports, and saw cultural shifts due to Minangkabau and Bugis migrations; by the 18th century, Bugis influence grew in several states, coinciding with early British interest in North Borneo.

text: (CNN) -- The photographer who took images of former Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto moments before her assassination Thursday told CNN he was "surprised" to see her rise through the sunroof of her vehicle to wave to supporters after delivering her speech.Getty Images photographer John Moore captured Benazir Bhutto waving, moments before he heard gunshots."I ran up, got as close as I got, made a few pictures of her waving to the crowd," Getty Images senior staff photographer John Moore told CNN's online streaming news service, CNN.com Live, in a phone interview Thursday from Islamabad, Pakistan."And then suddenly, there were a few gunshots that rang out, and she went down, she went down through the sunroof," he said."And just at that moment I raised my camera up and the blast happened.... And then, of course, there was chaos."Watch Moore describe Bhutto's final moments » Moore said he was about 20 yards away from Bhutto's vehicle when he took his photographs.Bhutto was rushed to Rawalpindi General Hospital, where she was pronounced dead.Moore said he had been following Bhutto's story since her return to Pakistan in October.He was present October 19 when a terror attack targeting her motorcade in Karachi killed 136 people.In the aftermath of that attack, "The rallies had been very small," because of high security, Moore said.However, the Rawalpindi rally was announced beforehand, he observed."Whoever planned this attack -- they had time on their hands to plan everything properly, and you saw the results today," he said.Between 5,000 and 8,000 were at the Rawalpindi rally, which was held at a parkground, he said."We [the news media] all expected it to be filled ... but there were less people there than most of us expected to see," he said."When I talked with a number of people, they said that people were just afraid to come out, for the simple reason that they all remembered what happened in Karachi."Moore said he himself expected there could be another attack following the Karachi massacre.He said he stayed away from gates at the Rawalpindi parkground, where police were searching people, because he suspected that's where a bomb would go off.
summary_1: Photographer John Moore of Getty Images documented the last moments of former Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's life, capturing images of her standing through the sunroof of her car, waving to supporters just before her assassination. Moore was approximately 20 yards away when he heard gunfire and saw Bhutto fall through the sunroof. He managed to photograph the incident, but soon after, an explosion occurred. Bhutto was rushed to Rawalpindi General Hospital, where she was pronounced dead. Moore had been tracking Bhutto's story since her arrival in Pakistan in October, covering her October 19 homecoming parade in Karachi, where a terrorist attack targeted her motorcade and claimed 136 lives. Following the Karachi event, Bhutto's public appearances became more subdued due to heightened security measures. However, the Rawalpindi gathering attracted between 5,000 and 8,000 attendees despite initial expectations of larger crowds. Many citizens chose not to attend due to fear stemming from the earlier Karachi tragedy. Anticipating further attacks, Moore deliberately avoided areas with heavy security checks, suspecting potential threats might occur elsewhere.
summary_2: John Moore captured photos of Benazir Bhutto prior to her assassination, including one showing her standing in her car's sunroof, greeting supporters shortly before being shot. The explosion that followed took place near Moore, who had tracked Bhutto since her return to Pakistan in October. After surviving a deadly Karachi attack, Bhutto continued making public appearances amidst increased security until her death at a Rawalpindi rally attended by thousands. Fearing additional assaults, Moore stayed clear of heavily guarded zones, anticipating danger elsewhere.
summary_3: Photographer John Moore documented Benazir Bhutto's final days, capturing an image of her waving from her car's sunroof just before her assassination at a large Rawalpindi rally, having survived a previous attempt in Karachi.

text: On a busy Friday morning in Manhattan, nine pedestrians suffered bullet or fragment wounds after police unleashed a hail of gunfire at a man wielding a .45 caliber pistol who had just killed a former co-worker.The officers unloaded 16 rounds in the shadow of the Empire State Building at a disgruntled former apparel designer, killing him after he engaged in a gunbattle with police, authorities said.Three passersby sustained direct gunshot wounds, while the remaining six were hit by fragments, according to New York Police Commissioner Ray Kelly.All injuries were caused by police, he said Saturday.One officer shot nine rounds and another shot seven.Police identified the gunman as Jeffrey Johnson, 58, who was apparently laid off from his job as a designer of women's accessories at Hazan Import Co. last year.Johnson, who served in the U.S. Coast Guard in the mid-1970s, had two rounds left in his pistol.It holds eight, Kelly said.Police identified the slain co-worker as Steven Ercolino, 41, who had apparently filed a prior complaint against his assailant, claiming that he thought Johnson would eventually try to kill him.Both men had filed harassment complaints against each other in April 2011, Kelly added.Ercolino was listed as a vice president of sales at Hazan Import Corp., according to his LinkedIn profile."It's not something that should happen to a loving person like that," said his brother, Paul."He's going to be so missed by everybody.He was a light of so many lives."
summary_1: A shooting incident occurred in Manhattan on a Friday morning, resulting in nine individuals being struck by bullets or fragments. The police opened fire at an armed man who had fatally shot a previous coworker. This encounter took place near the Empire State Building. According to NYPD Commissioner Ray Kelly, three people received direct gunshots, while six others were hit by bullet fragments. Notably, all these injuries were inflicted by the police force. An officer fired nine shots, whereas another discharged seven bullets. The perpetrator was recognized as Jeffrey Johnson, a 58-year-old ex-apparel designer, previously employed at Hazan Import Co. He had been dismissed from his position as a designer of women's accessories. Following the altercation, it was discovered that Johnson still possessed two rounds for his .45 caliber pistol, which typically accommodates eight rounds. The deceased victim was recognized as Steven Ercolino, a 41-year-old male, formerly holding a role as a sales executive at Hazan Import Corporation. It appears that both men had earlier submitted harassment claims against one another in April 2011. Ercolino's brother expressed grief over the loss, describing him as "a light of so many lives" and emphasizing how deeply he will be missed.
summary_2: On August 24, in Manhattan, nine people were injured when police shot an armed ex-designer named Jeffrey Johnson, 58, after he fatally shot former colleague Steven Ercolino, 41. Three people were directly hit; six more were grazed by stray bullets. Both men had filed harassment complaints in 2011. Two officers fired 16 shots, killing Johnson. Ercolino's brother mourned him as "the light of so many lives."
summary_3: Police shot and killed an armed man who previously worked with his victim, resulting in injuries to nine individuals during a shooting incident in Manhattan on August 24.

text: A handful of Bronze Age relics has fostered an assumption that prehistoric settlers inhabited Ibiza thousands of years ago.Greater evidence of such a people is found on Mallorca and Menorca than on Ibiza, but one of the Balearics' most important sites is actually on the island of Formentera, where the megalithic monument/tomb of Ca Na Costa has been dated to 2000 b.c.Ibiza's key location between Africa and ancient Iberia made it a convenient stopover for Mediterranean seafarers, such as the Phoenician traders, who called the island Ibosim.The Greeks dubbed it Ebysos, the Romans called it Ebusus, and the Moors, Yebisah.The Carthaginians: A detailed history of the island doesn't begin until it became a colony of Carthage in the 7th century b.c..The Carthaginians originally came from the area comprising present-day Lebanon, and from their bases in North Africa and what's now Spain, they challenged the Roman Empire for domination of the Mediterranean region.Their interest in Ibiza lay partly in its vast salt flats, which to this day remain the source of a profitable industry.They capitalized on the natural resources by using the salt to cure fish, which they exported to their home country.The Carthaginians also carried out lead mining and continued to be of significance up until this century.It is believed that the lead pellets which were used by the Carthaginian general Hannibal were made on Ibiza.The Carthaginians also considered the island a holy place, and here in great splendour they buried thousands of their citizens in a huge necropolis on the Puig des Molins (Hill of the Windmills) below the Dalt Vila (Old Town) of Ibiza.Under the gnarled olive trees archaeologists have uncovered a treasure trove of statues, jewellery, pitchers, tools, and coins, which are now displayed in the town's two archaeological museums.The Romans never really infiltrated Ibiza, and even after the defeat of Hannibal in 202 b.c.during the Second Punic War their influence was restrained.Only with the fall of Carthage in 146 b.c.did they manage to make inroads, but, as local historians stress, Ibiza was neither conquered nor annexed by Rome, but confederated, retaining remarkable autonomy.For centuries to come the old Carthaginian traditions were allowed to continue on Ibiza alongside the new Roman way of life.
summary_1: Evidence suggests prehistoric inhabitants settled on Ibiza around 2000 B.C., though more substantial proof exists for similar settlements on nearby Mallorca and Menorca. The most significant site being the megalithic tomb at Ca Na Costa, located on the neighboring island of Formentera. Ibiza's strategic position between Africa and ancient Iberia attracted many civilizations throughout history due to its valuable resources. Among these early visitors were the Phoenicians, who named the island Ibosim, followed by the Greeks, who renamed it Ebysos, then the Romans, calling it Ebusus, and finally the Moors, naming it Yebisah. However, a comprehensive account of Ibiza's history begins during its colonization by the Carthaginians in the 7th century B.C. Originally hailing from modern-day Lebanon, the Carthaginians established themselves across North Africa and southern Spain, vying for control over the Mediterranean against the expanding Roman Empire. They focused on Ibiza primarily because of its expansive salt flats, utilizing them to preserve fish for exportation back to their homeland. Additionally, they engaged in lead mining, producing lead shot allegedly utilized by the famed Carthaginian commander Hannibal. Upon conquest, the Carthaginians regarded Ibiza as sacred ground, interring thousands of their deceased in an extensive cemetery situated on Puig des Molins, beneath the Old Town of Ibiza. This burial ground yielded numerous artifacts including sculptures, jewelry, pottery, instruments, and currency, all currently exhibited within Ibiza's dual archaeological museums. Despite the eventual decline of Carthage in 146 B.C., Roman influence remained minimal, limited to a loose federation rather than full occupation or assimilation. As a result, native customs persisted alongside newly introduced Roman practices for several centuries.
summary_2: Ibiza's history traces back to 2000 B.C., with significant Carthaginian colonization in the 7th century B.C. Strategically positioned between Africa and Iberia, it attracted various civilizations like the Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, and Moors. Notable are the Carthaginians, who exploited Ibiza's salt flats for fish preservation and lead mining. After conquering, they considered Ibiza sacred, burying thousands at Puig des Molins. Post-Carthage, Roman influence was minimal, allowing indigenous traditions to coexist with new Roman practices until full occupation.
summary_3: Dating back to 2000 B.C., Ibiza has seen various civilizations, including the Carthaginians who heavily utilized its salt flats and lead mines before considering it sacred and burying their dead there.

text: According to the radar reconstruction, American 77 reemerged as a primary target on Indianapolis Center radar scopes at 9:05, east of its last known position.The target remained in Indianapolis Center's airspace for another six minutes, then crossed into the western portion of Washington Center's airspace at 9:10.As Indianapolis Center continued searching for the aircraft, two managers and the controller responsible for American 77 looked to the west and southwest along the flight's projected path, not east-where the aircraft was now heading.Managers did not instruct other controllers at Indianapolis Center to turn on their primary radar coverage to join in the search for American 77.In sum, Indianapolis Center never saw Flight 77 turn around.By the time it reappeared in primary radar coverage, controllers had either stopped looking for the aircraft because they thought it had crashed or were looking toward the west.Although the Command Center learned Flight 77 was missing, neither it nor FAA headquarters issued an all points bulletin to surrounding centers to search for primary radar targets.American 77 traveled undetected for 36 minutes on a course heading due east for Washington, D.C. By 9:25, FAA's Herndon Command Center and FAA headquarters knew two aircraft had crashed into the World Trade Center.They knew American 77 was lost.At least some FAA officials in Boston Center and the New England Region knew that a hijacker on board American 11 had said "we have some planes."Concerns over the safety of other aircraft began to mount.A manager at the Herndon Command Center asked FAA headquarters if they wanted to order a "nationwide ground stop."While this was being discussed by executives at FAA headquarters, the Command Center ordered one at 9:25.The Command Center kept looking for American 77.At 9:21, it advised the Dulles terminal control facility, and Dulles urged its controllers to look for primary targets.At 9:32, they found one.Several of the Dulles controllers "observed a primary radar target tracking eastbound at a high rate of speed" and notified Reagan National Airport.FAA personnel at both Reagan National and Dulles airports notified the Secret Service.
summary_1: At 9:05, American 77 reappears on radar with Indianapolis Center, deviating from its expected route. It remains visible until 9:10 when it enters Washington Center's airspace. Despite searches focusing west and southwest, no one spots the plane heading east. Managers fail to activate primary radar coverage for assistance. The Command Center learns about the missing flight but doesn't issue a center-wide alert. From 9:03, when the first WTC crash occurs, concerns grow regarding additional endangered flights. At 9:21, the Herndon Command Center alerts Dulles Tower to watch for primary targets. At 9:32, Dulles controllers detect a fast-moving primary target and notify Reagan National Airport, prompting action from the Secret Service.
summary_2: On September 11, at 9:05 AM, Flight 77 diverges from its planned course and becomes invisible to radars while entering new airspace by 9:10 AM. Searches are conducted towards the west and southwest despite the aircraft moving eastwards. Radar surveillance isn't activated by managers, and awareness of the lost flight within the Command Center does not trigger an overall warning. Post-first World Trade Center crash at 9:03 AM, apprehension escalates over other vulnerable flights. By 9:21 AM, the Herndon Command Center cautions Dulles Tower to monitor unidentified primary targets. A speedy blip detected at 9:32 AM near Reagan National Airport triggers Secret Service response due to the earlier warnings.
summary_3: After Flight 77 deviated from its route on September 11, becoming undetectable by radar and heading eastward, concerns about other susceptible flights grew, leading to heightened vigilance for unknown targets, culminating in a swift response when a fast blip was spotted near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport at 9:32 AM.

text: For much of the world, the Algarve is synonymous with Portugal, yet the Portuguese will tell you the exact opposite: the region has little in common with the rest of the country.The southern stretch of coast is more reminiscent of a North African landscape than a European one.It has no cosmopolitan cities, like Lisbon and Porto, which are farther north.Most of Portugal is known for quaint towns, medieval castles, and grand palaces.The Algarve is more recognizable for impenetrable blocks of tourist apartments, hotels, and meticulously manicured golf courses.And beaches.Think Algarve and the mind pictures long, glorious stretches of golden sands, secluded coves framed by odd ochre-colored rock formations, and deep green waters.With about 160 km (100 miles) of coastline, Portugal's southern province is one of Europe's premier beach destinations.The occasionally chilly ocean is the Atlantic, but the Algarve has a sultry Mediterranean feel.Its consistent climate is the best in Portugal, and one of the kindest in the world: more than 250 days of sunshine a year — more than almost any other international resort area.The moderating effect of the Gulf Stream produces a fresh springtime breeze throughout winter, and in late January and February, white almond blossoms blanket the fields.In summer the heat is intense but rarely unbearable, and regardless, beautiful beaches and innumerable pools are always just a dive away.Magnificent year-round weather has made the Algarve a huge destination for sporting vacations.Superb golf facilities abound — several with tees dramatically clinging to cliffs and fairways just skirting the edge of the ocean — and horseback riding, tennis, big-game fishing, sailing, and windsurfing are immensely popular.Sports, beaches and hospitable weather — not to mention easily organized package vacations — are surely the reasons the Algarve receives as many visitors as the rest of Portugal in its entirety.But it's not just international tourists that descend on the Algarve; many Portuguese from Lisbon and elsewhere in the north have holiday homes and spend their summer vacations here.The coast is neatly divided into the rugged Barlavento to the west and the flat beauty of Sotavento to the east.West is where you'll find the famous orange cliffs and surreal eroded rock stacks.
summary_1: The Algarve, often equated with Portugal, feels distinctly different to locals due to its contrasting landscapes and offerings. Unlike northern regions, the Algarve boasts a unique blend of North African-like scenery along its extensive coastline, dotted with tourist apartments, hotels, and golf courses amidst stunning sandy shores. The 160 km expanse features gorgeous golden beaches nestled within peculiar ochre-hued rock formations and vibrant blue-green waters. Known for having over 300 sunny days per year, this prime European beach destination offers moderate temperatures, making it ideal for various sports such as golf, horseback riding, tennis, fishing, sailing, and windsurfing. With an influx of both foreigners and local Portuguese seeking respite during summer months, the Algarve stands out as a beloved vacation spot, offering myriad activities, pleasant weather, and idyllic vistas. Divided into two coastal areas - the rugged Barlavento and serene Sotavento - the Algarve promises memorable experiences marked by striking natural wonders and engaging pastimes.
summary_2: The Algarve region in Portugal has a distinctive identity from other parts of the country because of diverse landscapes and attractions. It combines elements like Northern Africa's scenic beauty, golden beaches, unusual cliff formations, and turquoise waterways. Famous for around 300 annual sunshine hours, it provides perfect conditions for outdoor pursuits like golf, sailing, and surfing. Tourists flock here every summer, drawn by appealing climate, leisure opportunities, and captivating sights. Dividing the area are the wilder western Barlavento and tranquil eastern Sotavento zones, each presenting unforgettable adventures and breathtaking nature displays.
summary_3: The Algarve region in Portugal boasts unique landscapes, abundant sunshine, attractive beaches, and two contrasting areas - the rugged Barlavento and serene Sotavento - offering various activities and stunning views, drawing numerous tourists annually.

text: The digestive system is the body system that digests food.It digest food in two ways, mechanically and chemically.Both help in the process of turning food into nutrients.The digestive system also eliminates solid food waste.The major organs of the digestive system include the mouth, esophagus, stomach, and small and large in- testines.These organs all work together to help you gain energy from the food you eat.Digestion starts in the mouth.When food is swallowed, it travels through the esophagus to the stomach.In the stomach, digestion continues and a small amount of absorption of nutrients takes place.Most chemical digestion and nearly all absorption of nutrients take place in the small intestine.This organ consists of three parts: duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.The large intestine is the last stop in the digestive system.This is where water is absorbed.The food not digested is released as waste.
summary_1: The digestive system breaks down food for energy and waste removal. It operates via mechanical and chemical processes across multiple organs. Digestion begins in the mouth, proceeding to the esophagus, then the stomach, followed by the small and large intestines. The mouth initiates digestion, moving food through the esophagus to the stomach, where further breakdown occurs along with some nutrient absorption. Most chemical digestion and nutrient absorption transpire in the small intestine, divided into the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. Lastly, the large intestine absorbs water and releases undigested food as waste.
summary_2: Food gets broken down for energy and waste disposal using both mechanical and chemical methods throughout various body parts. This process starts in the mouth, moves on to the esophagus, continues in the stomach, and finishes off in the small and large intestines. Initially, chewing triggers digestion, pushing food down the esophagus towards the stomach for additional breakdown while also enabling initial nutrient uptake. Further chemical digestion and significant nutrient assimilation occur within the small intestine (divided into three sections - duodenum, jejunum, and ileum). Finally, the large intestine soaks up water and eliminates remaining unprocessed food matter as waste.
summary_3: The human digestive system breaks down food through mechanical and chemical processes across multiple organs, beginning with mastication in the mouth, continuing in the stomach, and finishing with nutrient absorption and waste removal in the small and large intestines.

text: Cathy Wallace did not always know what she wanted to be when she grew up.She wanted to help people, but did not know exactly how.A suggestion from friends sparked her interest."When I was in college, I thought I wanted to be a doctor," she said."I found I didn't want to do that and realized an interest in psychology.I didn't know what I wanted to do, but all my friends thought I should go into law because I was always on a soapbox.I decided to try it."Recently, Wallace received the Outstanding Woman Lawyer in Public Interest Law Award.The award was voted on and presented by the women's caucus of West Virginia University College of Law.Wallace, 38, called Gastonia home from the age of 8 until she graduated from Hunter Huss High School in 1983.Her parents, Carter Bond, 66, and Carol Bond, 59, are still residents of Gastonia.From Hunter Huss, she moved on to pursue a degree at Pfeiffer University in Misenheimer.After graduation from Pfeiffer in 1987 with a bachelor's degree in both biology and psychology, she worked as legal secretary for attorney Louis A. Bledsoe Jr. for a year and a half."Working for Louis Bledsoe was a pivotal moment," she said."That was when I decided to go into the practice of law."She received her law degree at the University of Arkansas in 1992 and began her legal career in Public Defender Corp. in Princeton.She also taught criminal justice classes at Bluefield College in West Virginia.Wallace lives in Athens, W. Va., with her husband Rob, 37, and her daughters Rachel, 11, and Claire, 5.
summary_1: Cathy Wallace, originally from Gastonia, recently won the Outstanding Woman Lawyer in Public Interest Law Award from West Virginia University College of Law's women's caucus. Wallace, now living in Athens, West Virginia, with her husband and two daughters, had uncertain career goals growing up. She initially considered becoming a doctor due to her desire to assist people, but later discovered an interest in psychology. Friends suggested law, given her tendency to advocate for various causes. After receiving her law degree from the University of Arkansas in 1992, Wallace started working in Public Defender Corp. in Princeton and simultaneously taught criminal justice courses at Bluefield College in West Virginia. Her parents, Carter Bond, 66, and Carol Bond, 59, still reside in Gastonia.
summary_2: Cathy Wallace, hailing from Gastonia, received the Outstanding Woman Lawyer in Public Interest Law Award from WVU College of Law's women's caucus. Living in Athens, WV, with her family, she once pondered becoming a doctor to help others, then shifted towards psychology. Friends suggested law due to her advocacy. Graduating from UofA in 1992, she joined Princeton's Public Defender Corp., also teaching at Bluefield College. Her parents, Carter and Carol Bond, live in Gastonia.
summary_3: Cathy Wallace, originally from Gastonia, won an award for public interest law; after considering careers in medicine and psychology, she pursued law inspired by friends, working at Princeton's Public Defender Corp. and teaching at Bluefield College, while residing in West Virginia with her family.

text: On his return to Nuremberg in 1495, Durer opened his own workshop (being married was a requirement for this).Over the next five years his style increasingly integrated Italian influences into underlying Northern forms.Durer's father died in 1502, and his mother died in 1513.His best works in the first years of the workshop were his woodcut prints, mostly religious, but including secular scenes such as The Men's Bath House (ca.1496).These were larger and more finely cut than the great majority of German woodcuts hitherto, and far more complex and balanced in composition.It is now thought unlikely that Durer cut any of the woodblocks himself; this task would have been performed by a specialist craftsman.However, his training in Wolgemut's studio, which made many carved and painted altarpieces and both designed and cut woodblocks for woodcut, evidently gave him great understanding of what the technique could be made to produce, and how to work with block cutters.Durer either drew his design directly onto the woodblock itself, or glued a paper drawing to the block.Either way, his drawings were destroyed during the cutting of the block.
summary_1: In 1495, Albrecht Dürer established his own workshop in Nuremberg upon his return, a necessity for marriage at the time. Over the subsequent five years, Dürer's artistic style evolved, blending Italian influences with Northern forms. His father passed away in 1502, followed by his mother in 1513. During the early years of his workshop, Dürer produced notable woodcut prints, primarily religious, though some featured secular themes like The Men's Bath House (circa 1496). These prints were significantly larger, intricately cut, and compositionally balanced compared to previous German woodcuts. Although it's improbable that Dürer personally cut the woodblocks due to specialized craftsmen handling this process, his experience from Wolgemut's studio equipped him with extensive knowledge about woodblock production and collaboration with these artisans. Dürer either sketched designs directly on the woodblock or adhered a paper sketch to it. However, the act of cutting the block resulted in the destruction of these drawings.
summary_2: Albrecht Dürer founded his Nuremberg workshop in 1495, where he refined an innovative fusion of Italian and Northern styles over the next five years. Following his parents' deaths in 1502 and 1513, Dürer continued producing large, detailed woodcut prints, often featuring religious themes. Despite likely not carving the blocks himself, his Wolgemut training enabled effective collaboration with skilled craftsmen. Sketching designs onto woodblocks or using attached papers, Dürer ultimately destroyed these originals during the cutting process.
summary_3: In the six years after establishing his Nuremberg workshop in 1495, Albrecht Dürer masterfully blended Italian and Northern art styles, creating intricate, religious woodcut prints until 1513, even though he probably didn't carve the blocks himself.

text: (CNN) -- Women seeking an abortion in Texas will have to view a picture of the embryo or fetus and hear a description of its development before having the procedure, under a law that takes effect September 1.The bill stirred some controversy in Texas, but it easily passed through the state House and Senate, both of which are controlled by Republicans.It was signed into law Thursday by Republican Gov. Rick Perry.The law says that at least 24 hours before an abortion is performed, women must undergo a sonogram, a procedure that uses ultrasound to create an image.The doctor, then, is required to give, "in a manner understandable to a layperson, a verbal explanation of the results of the sonogram images, including a medical description of the dimensions of the embryo or fetus, the presence of cardiac activity, and the presence of external members and internal organs," the law states.There are some exceptions, including pregnancies that resulted from sexual assault, incest or other violations of law.Women seeking abortions also are exempt if the fetus has been found to have an irreversible medical condition that will cause a disability."Governor Perry was pleased to sign this important legislation, which bolsters our efforts to protect life by ensuring Texans are fully informed when considering such an important decision," said his deputy press secretary, Lucy Nashed.Critics say the new law is unnecessary."What no one is focusing on is that this is a mandate to humiliate women who want an abortion," said Yvonne Gutierrez, vice president for public affairs at the Planned Parenthood Trust of South Texas.Texas already requires a 24-hour consent period, and the new law will simply add emotional and financial costs to those seeking abortions, she said.
summary_1: A new Texas law necessitates that women seeking an abortion first view a sonogram image and listen to a detailed description of the embryo or fetus's development. The law, effective September 1, requires doctors to perform a sonogram at least 24 hours prior to the procedure. During this time, they must explain the sonogram results, detailing the embryo or fetus's size, cardiac activity, and visible body parts. Exemptions apply to pregnancies resulting from specific crimes like sexual assault, incest, or where the fetus has severe medical issues causing future disability. Governor Rick Perry, a Republican, approved the bill, stating it fortifies Texas's pro-life stance by ensuring women make informed decisions. Critics argue the law aims to shame women wanting abortions, adding emotional and financial burdens without benefiting their health outcomes. Despite existing 24-hour consent periods, critics claim the new law merely increases costs associated with obtaining an abortion.
summary_2: Texas passed a law requiring women seeking an abortion to undergo a sonogram at least 24 hours beforehand, during which doctors describe the embryo or fetus's features. Exemptions exist for certain criminal circumstances. Supporters say it strengthens Texas's pro-life position and informs decision-making; opponents believe it shames and imposes extra costs on these women.
summary_3: Texas enacted a law mandating that women seeking abortions first get a sonogram and hear about the fetus's characteristics, with exceptions for specific crimes, drawing support from those who view it as reinforcing Texas's pro-life stance and enhancing informed decision-making, but criticism from critics citing shame and additional expenses imposed on these women.

text: These experiments in political Islam faltered during the 1990s: the Iranian revolution lost momentum, prestige, and public support, and Pakistan's rulers found that most of its population had little enthusiasm for fundamentalist Islam.Islamist revival movements gained followers across the Muslim world, but failed to secure political power except in Iran and Sudan.In Algeria, where in 1991 Islamists seemed almost certain to win power through the ballot box, the military preempted their victory, triggering a brutal civil war that continues today.Opponents of today's rulers have few, if any, ways to participate in the existing political system.They are thus a ready audience for calls to Muslims to purify their society, reject unwelcome modernization, and adhere strictly to the Sharia.Social and Economic Malaise In the 1970s and early 1980s, an unprecedented flood of wealth led the then largely unmodernized oil states to attempt to shortcut decades of development.They funded huge infrastructure projects, vastly expanded education, and created subsidized social welfare programs.These programs established a widespread feeling of entitlement without a corresponding sense of social obligations.By the late 1980s, diminishing oil revenues, the economic drain from many unprofitable development projects, and population growth made these entitlement programs unsustainable.The resulting cutbacks created enormous resentment among recipients who had come to see government largesse as their right.This resentment was further stoked by public understanding of how much oil income had gone straight into the pockets of the rulers, their friends, and their helpers.Unlike the oil states (or Afghanistan, where real economic development has barely begun), the other Arab nations and Pakistan once had seemed headed toward balanced modernization.The established commercial, financial, and industrial sectors in these states, supported by an entrepreneurial spirit and widespread understanding of free enterprise, augured well.But unprofitable heavy industry, state monopolies, and opaque bureaucracies slowly stifled growth.More importantly, these state-centered regimes placed their highest priority on preserving the elite's grip on national wealth.Unwilling to foster dynamic economies that could create jobs attractive to educated young men, the countries became economically stagnant and reliant on the safety valve of worker emigration either to the Arab oil states or to the West.Furthermore, the repression and isolation of women in many Muslim countries have not only seriously limited individual opportunity but also crippled overall economic productivity.By the 1990s, high birthrates and declining rates of infant mortality had produced a common problem throughout the Muslim world: a large, steadily increasing population of young men without any reasonable expectation of suitable or steady employment-a sure prescription for social turbulence.
summary_1: Political Islam initiatives stumbled in the 1990s; Iran's revolutionary fervor waned, and Pakistani leaders discovered minimal interest in fundamentalist Islam among their populace. Islamist resurgence movements thrived but predominantly secured power in Iran and Sudan. In Algeria, the military intervened in 1991 when Islamists were poised to seize power democratically, igniting a protracted civil war. Present regime opponents lack avenues for political involvement, making them receptive to messages urging societal purification, rejection of unwanted modernization, and strict adherence to Sharia law. During the 1970s and early 1980s, an influx of wealth prompted oil-rich states to accelerate development, investing heavily in infrastructure, education, and social welfare programs. These efforts fostered expectations of entitlements without promoting social responsibility. By the late 1980s, dwindling oil revenues, costly development projects, and escalating populations rendered these benefits untenable, leading to substantial backlash. Public discontent grew due to perceived corruption and misappropriation of oil profits by ruling elites and their associates. Initially, non-oil producing Muslim nations and Pakistan showed promise with burgeoning commercial, financial, and industrial sectors. However, unproductive industries, state monopolies, and convoluted bureaucracies hindered progress. Governments prioritized safeguarding the elite's control over national resources, neglecting economic expansion and job creation. Consequently, these nations experienced economic stagnation, necessitating labor outflows to Arab oil states or Western nations. Additionally, gender discrimination impeded personal advancement and undermined overall economic vitality. High fertility rates and plummeting infant mortality resulted in surging youth populations confronted with dim prospects for stable, gainful employment, fueling potential social upheaval.
summary_2: Islamist politics faced setbacks in the '90s, with Iran's revolutionary zeal declining and Pakistani leaders finding little support for fundamentalist Islam. Movements like the Taliban rose, securing power mainly in Iran and Sudan. The '70s oil boom led to high expectations, but falling revenues in the '80s sparked public anger due to perceived corruption and misuse of funds. Non-oil rich Muslim nations also struggled due to inefficient industries, state monopolies, and gender bias, leading to economic stagnation and brain drain. A youth bulge, coupled with unemployment, raised concerns for future stability.
summary_3: In the '90s, Islamist politics suffered setbacks as Iran's revolutionary fervor waned and Pakistan's leaders found scant backing for fundamentalist Islam; economically, non-oil rich Muslim nations grappled with inefficiency, corruption allegations, gender bias, resulting in economic stagnation, brain drain, and a jobless youth bulge.

text: Our sun and other stars release light energy.At least this is what we see.Our Sun and stars also emit more than just light.Scientists call the type of energy that our Sun and stars release electromagnetic energy.This form of energy travels through space.Electromagnetic energy includes the light we see.It also includes much more.Many of these things we know about, but dont always think about.Electromagnetic energy includes radio waves, microwaves, and X rays.We now have devices in our homes and offices that release these same forms of energy.We use electromagnetic energy to make our lives better.
summary_1: The Sun and other stars radiate not just visible light, but also electromagnetic energy. This term denotes various kinds of energy traveling through space. While light is one such form, there are others like radio waves, microwaves, and X-rays. These are all part of our daily lives, often unnoticed. Devices around us utilize these energies for numerous purposes, enhancing our living standards.
summary_2: Stars, including the Sun, emit diverse forms of electromagnetic energy, including radio waves, microwaves, visible light, and X-rays. These unseen energies are commonplace and utilized by devices, improving our lives.
summary_3: The Sun and other stars emit various forms of electromagnetic radiation, like radio waves and X-rays, which power numerous devices enhancing our daily life.

text: Early in chapter 5 we introduced, along with Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, two other men who became operational coordinators for al Qaeda: Khallad and Nashiri.As we explained, both were involved during 1998 and 1999 in preparing to attack a ship off the coast of Yemen with a boatload of explosives.They had originally targeted a commercial vessel, specifically an oil tanker, but  Bin Laden urged them to look for a U.S.warship instead.In January 2000, their team had attempted to attack a warship in the port of Aden, but the attempt failed when the suicide boat sank.More than nine months later, on October 12,2000, al Qaeda operatives in a small boat laden with explosives attacked a U.S. Navy destroyer, the USS Cole.The blast ripped a hole in the side of the Cole, killing 17 members of the ship's crew and wounding at least 40.The plot, we now know, was a full-fledged al Qaeda operation, supervised directly by  Bin Laden.He chose the target and location of the attack, selected the suicide operatives, and provided the money needed to purchase explosives and equipment.Nashiri was the field commander and managed the operation in Yemen.Khallad helped in Yemen until he was arrested in a case of mistaken identity and freed with  Bin Laden's help, as we also mentioned earlier.Local al Qaeda coordinators included Jamal al Badawi and Fahd al Quso, who was supposed to film the attack from a nearby apartment.The two suicide operatives chosen were Hassan al Khamri and Ibrahim al Thawar, also known as Nibras.Nibras and Quso delivered money to Khallad in Bangkok during Khallad's January 2000 trip to Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok.In September 2000,  Bin Laden reportedly told Nashiri that he wanted to replace Khamri and Nibras.Nashiri was angry and disagreed, telling others he would go to Afghanistan and explain to  Bin Laden that the new operatives were already trained and ready to conduct the attack.Prior to departing, Nashiri gave Nibras and Khamri instructions to execute the attack on the next U.S.warship that entered the port of Aden.
summary_1: Chapter 5 introduced Khalid Sheikh Mohammed alongside two other men who became al Qaeda's operational coordinators: Khallad and Nashiri. In 1998-1999, they planned to attack a ship off Yemen's coast using a boat filled with explosives, initially targeting a commercial vessel, but Bin Laden suggested a U.S. warship. In January 2000, they tried attacking a warship in Aden, but their boat sank. On October 12, 2000, al Qaeda operatives in a boat loaded with explosives attacked the USS Cole, causing 17 deaths and over 40 injuries. This was an official al Qaeda operation led by Bin Laden, who picked the target, location, and supplied funds for explosives and equipment. Nashiri commanded the operation while Khallad assisted in Yemen, except when he was mistakenly arrested and released with Bin Laden's aid. Local al Qaeda coordinators included Jamal al Badawi and Fahd al Quso. The suicide operatives were Hassan al Khamri and Ibrahim al Thawar (also known as Nibras). Nibras and Quso handed money to Khallad in Bangkok in January 2000. In September 2000, Bin Laden considered replacing Khamri and Nibras, which angered Nashiri, leading him to defend his choices before leaving for Afghanistan to discuss this issue with Bin Laden. Before Nashiri left, he instructed Nibras and Khamri to proceed with the attack once a U.S. warship reappeared in Aden.
summary_2: In Chapter 5, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed joined Khallad and Nashiri as al Qaeda's operational coordinators. They plotted to assault a ship near Yemen using a bomb-laden boat, initially aiming at a commercial vessel, but Bin Laden proposed a U.S. warship. In January 2000, they attempted to strike a warship in Aden, but their boat sank. On October 12, 2000, al Qaeda members in a boat packed with explosives targeted the USS Cole, resulting in 17 fatalities and over 40 injuries. This was an authorized al Qaeda mission led by Bin Laden, who selected the target, site, and financed explosives and gear. Nashiri directed the operation, aided by Khallad in Yemen, barring a brief arrest. Jamal al Badawi and Fahd al Quso served as local al Qaeda coordinators. The suicide assailants were Hassan al Khamri and Ibrahim al Thawar. In January 2000, Nibras and Quso gave money to Khallad in Bangkok. By September 2000, Bin Laden contemplated substituting Khamri and Nibras, upsetting Nashiri, who defended his picks prior to departing for Afghanistan to confer with Bin Laden. Before Nashiri's departure, he ordered Nibras and Khamri to execute the attack upon a U.S. warship's return to Aden.
summary_3: Al Qaeda operatives, including Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, planned and executed the deadly 2000 USS Cole bombing, funded and approved by Osama bin Laden.

text: Defeated last month for re-election, Gov. Roy Barnes announced Tuesday that he will spend his first six months out of office as an unpaid attorney for the Atlanta Legal Aid Society, where he will represent poor people."One day I'll probably do some legal work that I will charge a handsome fee for - at least I hope there are those that are still willing to pay," he told reporters."But for now, I think it is important to fulfill my duty as a lawyer to help those who need it the most, to speak for those who cannot speak for themselves and to defend those whose life and livelihoods depend on it," he said.Previous governors have gone to prestigious law firms, joined corporate boards or returned to thriving businesses."I don't think I've ever heard of anybody doing this before," Emory University political science professor Merle Black said."If he's actually going to represent individuals for that organization, they're going to get great representation.You're going to get some powerful legal muscle there," Mr. Black said.Mr. Barnes said he already has his first case, but he wouldn't say what it is.Atlanta Legal Aid provides civil services to poor people in five metro Atlanta counties.Mr. Barnes said he was hoping to send a message to other lawyers."This privilege to practice law is just that - it's a privilege.And it comes with a cost and it comes with a bill .We as lawyers have a responsibility to make sure that everyone, regardless of whether they can afford it or not, has quality representation.And if we don't do that, then we're not much of a profession," he said.Steven Gottlieb, the society's executive director, said, "I can't imagine anything that could be better than to have the governor of the state, in his first act as a private citizen, donate six months of his time to represent poor people .
summary_1: Roy Barnes, former Georgia Governor, recently defeated in his re-election bid, declared that he would serve as an unpaid attorney for Atlanta Legal Aid Society for half a year, offering pro bono services to indigent clients. This move is unprecedented, according to Merle Black, a political scientist at Emory University. Barnes aims to assist those most in need, give voice to the voiceless, and protect those whose survival depends on legal defense. Post-governorship, previous officials typically join distinguished law firms, sit on corporate boards, or resume prosperous business ventures. However, Barnes intends to provide top-notch legal aid to underprivileged individuals. He has taken up his initial case but declined to disclose details. Established in five Metro Atlanta counties, Atlanta Legal Aid offers civil services to impoverished residents. Barnes expressed hope that his decision sends a strong message to fellow attorneys about their professional responsibilities towards providing quality representation to every individual, irrespective of financial means. Steven Gottlieb, the society's executive director, praised Barnes' choice to dedicate his first post-gubernatorial phase to advocating for marginalized communities.
summary_2: Ex-Governor Roy Barnes now works pro bono for Atlanta Legal Aid, helping indigent clients after losing his re-election. This is reportedly unique. Barnes seeks to aid the disadvantaged, giving voice to the voiceless. Typically, ex-officials pursue profitable paths. Instead, Barnes provides high-quality legal help to underserved people. The Atlanta Legal Aid Society, serving five metro Atlanta counties, applauded Barnes' commitment to advocate for marginalized groups.
summary_3: Former Governor Roy Barnes now offers free legal services through Atlanta Legal Aid, assisting underprivileged clients and advocating for marginalized groups, an unusual choice for a former official.

text: The movie is a powerful story that deals with feminism and patriarchy in the middle class of India .It is shot in the present and past tense showing lives of the characters Mahender and Sudha as they lived together as well as separately .The movie starts with Mahender getting down at the railway station and making his way to the waiting room just as it starts to rain heavily .A woman , Sudha , is already sitting in the waiting room .On seeing him , she tries to hide her face from him but later they confront each other .Mahender has an accomplished business dealing with photography .He respects his grandfather immensely .Incidentally , he had been engaged to Sudha for 5 years but always made some excuse to delay their wedding .However , this time his grandfather has fixed the wedding on the first week of the following month .He reveals to Sudha that he is having an affair with one of the most radical representations of feminism in a girl called Maya .He returns to tell Maya , but Maya has disappeared , leaving him some poetry .Mahender then marries Sudha and is quite happy , but the sudden return of Maya causes tensions in their married life .Mahender frequently tells Sudha about all the beautifully poignant , loving and authentic things Maya did over the years that they lived together .Later , Maya tries to commit suicide , and this leads to Mahender spending time with her over a few weeks .Sudha , not knowing about Maya 's suicide attempt and therefore believing that Mahender is being unfaithful to her , feels that her marriage was a mistake , and questions Mahender about his intentions .
summary_1: "Middle Class Melodrama" explores themes of feminism and societal norms within India, presented through alternating scenes of the past and present. The film commences with protagonist Mahender arriving at a train station, coinciding with Sudha's presence in the waiting area. Despite their history - five years of engagement - Mahender postponed their union due to an ongoing affair with Maya, a fervent feminist. However, after discovering Maya's disappearance, he proceeds to marry Sudha, experiencing happiness until Maya reemerges, straining Mahender and Sudha's relationship. As Mahender recounts fond memories of Maya, tension builds between husband and wife. A climactic suicide attempt by Maya intensifies the situation further, prompting suspicion and mistrust towards Mahender, who spends significant time attending to Maya's recovery. Misconstruing these actions, Sudha becomes increasingly distressed, contemplating the legitimacy of her marriage and Mahender's loyalty.
summary_2: "Middle Class Melodrama" examines feminism and social expectations in India via interwoven past and present sequences. Opening with Mahender meeting Sudha at a train station, they were once engaged but delayed their union because of his affair with ardent feminist Maya. After learning about Maya's absence, he marries Sudha, enjoying wedded bliss until Maya returns, causing friction. Recalling happy times with Maya creates tension between husband and wife. An attempted suicide from Maya escalates matters, leading Sudha to question her marriage and Mahender's faithfulness.
summary_3: In "Middle Class Melodrama," Mahender faces marital strife when an old flame rekindles tensions over gender roles and fidelity, prompting his current spouse to reassess their relationship after a suicide attempt by the ex-lover.

text: So it was that J.W. and Marty had come into the inner places of each other's lives. Of all the developments of Institute week, naturally the one which filled J.W.'s thoughts with a sort of awed gladness was Marty's decision to offer himself for the ministry. Joe Carbrook's right-about-face was much more dramatic, for J.W. saw, when the decision was made, that Marty could not have been meant for anything but a preacher. It was as fit as you please. As to Joe, previous opinion had been pretty equally divided; one side leaning to the idea that he might make a lawyer, and the other predicting that he was more likely to be a perpetual and profitable client for some other lawyer. In the light of the Institute happenings, it was to be expected that the question of college would promptly become a practical matter to four Delafield people. Marty was greatly troubled, for he knew if he was to be a preacher, he must go to college, and he couldn't see how. J.W. felt no great urge, though it had always been understood that he would go. Marcia Dayne had one year of normal school to her credit, and would take another next year, perhaps; but this year she must teach.
summary_1: J.W. and Marty have grown close, and Marty deciding to enter the ministry fills J.W. with joy. Joe Carbrook's change of heart is also significant. Earlier views on his future were split between law practice and being a lawyer's client. Now, post-Institute, the topic of college becomes relevant for four individuals from Delafield. Marty is concerned about college due to financial constraints, especially since becoming a preacher requires higher education. J.W. isn't particularly keen on college, yet everyone assumed he'd attend. Marcia Dayne has two years of normal school experience and plans to complete another the following year before teaching.
summary_2: Marty joining the ministry delights J.W., while Joe Carbrook reconsiders his path towards either practicing or needing legal services. College discussions arise among four friends from Delafield. Budget issues concern Marty regarding further studies; J.W.'s college attendance is expected despite his lack of enthusiasm. Marcia aims to finish her final year at normal school prior to teaching.
summary_3: Joe ponders pursuing law, while all four discuss and budget for college; Marty joins the ministry, and Marcia plans to teach after finishing normal school.

text: You just got done with a long run.You are gasping for air.Why does your body react this way?What is the purpose of breathing?All the cells of your body need oxygen to work properly.Your bodys circulatory system works with the respiratory system to deliver the oxygen.Your blood carries red blood cells.The main job of red blood cells is to carry oxygen throughout your body.The red blood cells get oxygen in the lungs.The lungs are the main organs of the respiratory system.The respiratory system is the body system that takes in oxygen.It then releases carbon dioxide back to the atmosphere.The carbon dioxide is the waste material from the cells.
summary_1: Running exhaustively depletes your body of oxygen, causing heavy panting to increase its intake. Breathing serves the crucial function of supplying essential oxygen to all bodily cells for optimal functioning. The circulatory and respiratory systems collaborate on this life-sustaining mission.
