Red blood cells, transported by the circulatory system, primarily facilitate oxygen distribution. These vital cells acquire oxygen within the lungs - the core components of the respiratory system. This intricate system facilitates oxygen uptake while expelling cellular waste product, carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere.
summary_2: Oxygen fuels our bodies through breathing. It enters via the lungs, hitching rides with red blood cells that distribute it throughout the body. Carbon dioxide, the waste product, gets exhaled. The circulatory and respiratory systems work together to make this happen. Exhaustive running speeds up this process due to increased oxygen demand.
summary_3: Breathing delivers oxygen to the body via lungs and red blood cells, expelling carbon dioxide; physical exertion intensifies this process.

text: Sara wanted to play on a baseball team.She had never tried to swing a bat and hit a baseball before.Her Dad gave her a bat and together they went to the park to practice.Sara wondered if she could hit a ball.She wasn't sure if she would be any good.She really wanted to play on a team and wear a real uniform.She couldn't wait to get to the park and test out her bat.When Sara and her Dad reached the park, Sara grabbed the bat and stood a few steps away from her Dad.Sara waited as her Dad pitched the ball to her.Her heart was beating fast.She missed the first few pitches.She felt like quitting but kept trying.Soon she was hitting the ball very far.She was very happy and she couldn't wait to sign up for a real team.Her Dad was very proud of her for not giving up.
summary_1: Eager to participate in baseball, Sara, who had no prior experience, decided to try her hand at it. Her father handed her a bat and accompanied her to the local park for practice. Despite initial doubts about her abilities, Sara looked forward to donning an actual uniform and joining a team. Upon arrival, Sara positioned herself a short distance from her dad, gripping the bat tightly while he prepared to pitch. Initially, Sara struggled, missing several balls; however, instead of succumbing to frustration, she persisted. Eventually, Sara began hitting the ball great distances, filling her heart with joy. Seeing his daughter's determination pay off, Sara's father expressed pride in her refusal to give up.
summary_2: Sara, new to baseball, practiced with her father at a park, growing determined despite early struggles. She improved, delighting in long hits, making him proud.
summary_3: Sara, a beginner, learned baseball from her dad, gradually improving and impressing him with solid hits.

text: Joe's parents are farmers and they have a huge farm with cows, chickens, and ducks.Joe loves the farm and all the things he gets to play around and play on.One day, Joe's father told him not to get near a tractor that was sitting in the field.His father was worried that Joe would climb on it and hurt himself.Joe went out to the field and was feeding the horses and cows.When he was done, he saw the tractor his father told him not to get near.He knew that climbing on the tractor wouldn't hurt anything, so he did.He climbed on to the seat and sat there.Then, he pretended he was his father and pretended that he was driving the tractor.Joe's father saw him playing on the tractor and called for him.Joe heard his father calling for him and got off the tractor really fast.When he did that, he fell off and hurt his arm.Joe was in pain and his father came running to check on him and picked him up and sat him on a bench and asked him why he did that.Joe looked at his father and said, "I wanted to be like you."Joe's father gave him a hug and asked him if he wanted to ride with him on the tractor.Joe did and after he got a bandage on his arm, he and his father rode in the field on the tractor.
summary_1: Joe, whose parents are farmers, lives on a large farm filled with animals such as cows, chickens, and ducks. One day, his father warns him to stay away from a stationary tractor in the field due to safety concerns. Curious and unafraid, Joe climbs onto the tractor while tending to the other animals, imagining himself operating the machinery like his father does. His father spots him and calls him over, causing Joe to quickly disembark and fall off, injuring his arm in the process. Upon seeing his son's distress, Joe's father rushes to help, applying first aid before asking about his actions. With tears in his eyes, Joe admits wanting to emulate his dad by driving the tractor himself. Touched, his father embraces him and offers to take him for a proper tractor ride once his injury has been treated.
summary_2: Joe, living on a farm, ignores his father's warning and climbs a tractor, getting injured. When confronted, he confesses his desire to operate it like his dad. Moved, his father consoles him and promises a supervised ride when he recovers.
summary_3: After climbing a tractor despite warnings and getting hurt, Joe admits his aspiration to his father, who then comforts him and plans a future supervised ride.

text: Have you ever looked closely at a globe?That continents look like a giant jig-saw puzzle.North America looks like it could fit next to Europe.The edge of South America matches Africa.Scientists noticed these same features.It caused them to start asking questions.They wanted to know if these continents were was connected?If so, how can something so large move so far?What could possibly have enough force to move such a giant slab of rock?Is there other evidence that can provide clues to the past positions of continents?How can answering these questions help us?A scientist named Alfred Wegener had these same questions.Wegener look at rocks on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.He noticed they were the same type and age.He thought that the rocks must have formed side by side.He proposed that the rocks then drifted apart.One part went with North America.The other part stayed with Europe.
summary_1: Alfred Wegener observed similarities between continental rocks and their relative locations, leading him to propose the theory of Continental Drift. Noticing matching rock types and ages on opposite sides of the Atlantic, he suggested that continents were once connected but subsequently moved apart. This idea emerged from his observation that the edges of North America align with Europe, while South America fits alongside Africa. The concept of continental movement led scientists to explore underlying forces capable of shifting massive landmasses. They sought further evidence in geological records, studying past positions of continents and potential causes for such movements. Understanding historical continent configurations provides valuable insights into Earth's tectonic behavior, fostering enhanced preparedness for natural disasters and improved environmental management strategies.
summary_2: Geologist Alfred Wegener proposed the Continental Drift theory after observing matching rock types and ages on opposites sides of the Atlantic. He noted how North America aligned with Europe and South America fit alongside Africa. His ideas spurred research into forces causing landmass shifts and study of past continent positions, enhancing disaster preparedness and environmental management.
summary_3: Geologist Alfred Wegener proposed the Continental Drift theory by identifying matching rock types and ages across the Atlantic, aligning North America with Europe and Africa, ultimately improving disaster preparation and environmental management through subsequent studies of shifting landmasses and past continents.

text: The White Rajahs of Borneo: In the 19th century, Borneo remained relatively undeveloped.Balanini pirates, fervent Muslims, disputed the coast of northeastern Borneo (modern Sabah) with the sultanate of Brunei.Sarawak's coast and jungle interior were controlled by the Iban — Sea Dayak pirates and Land Dayak slash-and-burn farmers.(The Dayaks practiced head-hunting, a ritual that was believed to bring spiritual energy to their communities.) The region was unproductive and without great resources, except for the Sarawak river valley, where the Chinese mined for gold and antimony.Brunei chiefs traded the metals through Americans in Singapore.In 1839, the governor of Singapore sent James Brooke (1803–1868) to promote trade links with the Sultan of Brunei.He had been an audacious cavalry officer in the Anglo-Burmese wars and now exploited the situation for his own benefit.In exchange for helping the regent end a revolt of uppity Malay chiefs, Brooke was made Rajah of Sarawak in 1841, with his capital in Kuching (founded by the Malays just 11 years earlier).He tried to halt the Dayaks' piracy and head-hunting while defending their more "morally acceptable" customs.His attempts to limit the opium trade met with resistance by the Chinese in Bau, who revolted.His counter-attack with Dayak warriors drove the Chinese out of Bau and across the Sarawak border.Thereafter, Chinese settlement was discouraged and did not achieve the commercial dominance it enjoyed on the peninsula.In 1863, Brooke retired to Britain, handing Sarawak over to his nephew Charles.More reserved and remote but a better administrator and financier than his uncle, Charles Brooke imposed on his men his own austere, efficient style of life.He brought Dayak leaders onto his ruling council but favored the time-honored colonial practice of divide-and-rule by pitting one tribe against another to keep the peace.Northeast Borneo (Sabah) was "rented" from the Sultan of Brunei by British businessman Alfred Dent.Dent was operating a royal charter for the British North Borneo Company — a charter similar to that of the EIC.
summary_1: James Brooke became the Rajah of Sarawak in 1841 after assisting the Sultan of Brunei in quelling a rebellion. Initially sent by the governor of Singapore to establish trading ties, Brooke took advantage of the opportunity to become Rajah. His rule aimed to curb piracy and head-hunting practices among the Iban, or Sea Dayaks, while preserving other traditional customs. Despite initial successes, he faced opposition when trying to suppress the opium trade, leading to a Chinese uprising in Bau. A military response led by Brooke and supported by Iban warriors forced the Chinese to retreat beyond Sarawak's borders. As a result, Chinese influence in commerce waned compared to their prominence on the peninsula. Upon retiring in 1863, Brooke passed the reigns to his nephew, Charles. More restrained yet effective, Charles adopted an austere management approach and included Dayak leaders in his administration. Meanwhile, Northeast Borneo, known today as Sabah, came under control of the British North Borneo Company via a royal charter obtained by British businessman Alfred Dent, mirroring the East India Company's charter.
summary_2: In 1841, James Brooke becomes Rajah of Sarawak, aiming to end piracy and head-hunting among Iban. He faces opposition when suppressing the opium trade, causing a Chinese uprising. After a military response, Chinese commercial influence decreases. Brooke passes rulership to his nephew, Charles, who adopts a restrained approach and includes Dayak leaders in his administration. In 1881, Northeast Borneo comes under British North Borneo Company's control through a royal charter obtained by Alfred Dent.
summary_3: James Brooke becomes Rajah of Sarawak in 1841, tackling piracy and head-hunting, but faces resistance suppressing the opium trade, leading to a Chinese uprising; Brooke later transfers rule to his nephew, Charles, who softens administration by including Dayak leaders, while Northeast Borneo falls under British North Borneo Company's control in 1881.

text: To say her face fell would do a disservice to Tasha and to literature.(Allow me my self-indulgences as you would those of a dying man -- when I convince my mindsmith to permit the wipe, there will be another Bernardo Flynn, one who knows no more of Tasha Cortez or Vega IV than he reads here.) Her brows drew together, creasing the lovely, caramel-colored skin around her eyes and showing the pattern for an old woman's wrinkles on her forehead.Her lower lip (a trifle too narrow for her face, perhaps her only physical flaw) thrust forward slightly as she started to speak.She caught herself, slid her jaw infinitesimally back into place, and said, "You don't like it?"I laughed.What could I do?I clapped her shoulder to show I was not laughing at her."Like it?I hate it, despise it, abhor it!It's gaudy, graceless, pretentious -- That house is an affront to taste and intelligence.I should buy it to raze it, but I am not so kind-hearted.I might, however, rent it."I think she only heard the last words of my speech."You will?""It amuses me.Show me around, and then I shall decide.""Of course, Señor Flynn.""And stop calling me 'señor'.Not even Los Mundos is so polite.Call me Bernardo."
summary_1: Tasha appears taken aback by Bernardo's reaction to the house. She looks visibly upset, with her eyebrows furrowing and her lower lip pushing forward slightly. When she speaks, she catches herself from saying something and corrects her posture before asking him about his thoughts. Bernardo admits that he hates the house, finding it garish, awkward, and offensive to good taste. He humorously suggests buying it to demolish it, but decides against it due to his lack of kindness. Instead, he considers renting it out for amusement. The chapter ends with Tasha agreecing to show him around the property, and asks him to call her by her first name.
summary_2: Bothered by Bernardo's dislike for her house, Tasha tries to hide her disappointment. Bernardo criticizes the house, suggesting he might buy it to tear down, then dismisses the idea due to his disposition. He contemplates leasing it for fun instead. The chapter concludes with Tasha consenting to tour the premises while encouraging familiarity between them.
summary_3: Tasha agrees to show Bernardo around her home despite his criticism and plans to lease it for amusement.

text: Some of the most unusual effects of Hellenization can be seen in Afghanistan and India, in the region of the relatively late-arising Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (250 BC-125 BC) in modern Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Tajikistan and the Greco-Indian Kingdom (180 BC - 10 CE) in modern Afghanistan and India.There on the newly formed Silk Road Greek culture apparently hybridized with Indian, and especially Buddhist culture.The resulting syncretism known as Greco-Buddhism heavily influenced the development of Buddhism and created a culture of Greco-Buddhist art.These Greco-Buddhist kingdoms sent some of the first Buddhist missionaries to China, Sri Lanka, and the Mediterranean (Greco-Buddhist monasticism).The first figural portrayals of the Buddha, previously avoided by Buddhists, appeared at this time; they were modeled on Greek statues of Apollo.Several Buddhist traditions may have been influenced by the ancient Greek religion: the concept of Boddhisatvas is reminiscent of Greek divine heroes, and some Mahayana ceremonial practices (burning incense, gifts of flowers, and food placed on altars) are similar to those practiced by the ancient Greeks.One Greek king, Menander I, probably became Buddhist, and was immortalized in Buddhist literature as 'Milinda'.The process of Hellenization extended to the sciences, where ideas from Greek astronomy filtered eastward and had profoundly influenced Indian astronomy by the early centuries AD.For example, Greek astronomical instruments dating to the 3rd century BC were found in the Greco-Bactrian city of Ai Khanoum in modern-day Afghanistan while the Greek concept of a spherical earth surrounded by the spheres of planets was adopted in India and eventually supplanted the long-standing Indian cosmological belief of a flat and circular earth.The Yavanajataka and Paulisa Siddhanta texts in particular show Greek influence.
summary_1: The Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (250 BC-125 BC) and Greco-Indian Kingdom (180 BC - 10 CE), established in modern Afghanistan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, and India, experienced significant Hellenization. This cultural fusion led to the emergence of Greco-Buddhism, which significantly impacted Buddhism and birthed Greco-Buddhist art. These kingdoms were instrumental in sending the first Buddhist missionaries to China, Sri Lanka, and the Mediterranean. The first anthropomorphic depictions of the Buddha, inspired by Greek statues of Apollo, emerged during this period. Buddhist traditions, such as the concept of Boddhisattvas and certain ceremonial practices like burning incense and offering flowers and food on altars, bear resemblances to Greek religious customs. Notably, King Menander I possibly converted to Buddhism and is revered in Buddhist literature as 'Milinda.' The scientific realm also felt the influence of Hellenization, with Greek astronomical concepts permeating Eastward. For instance, Greek astronomical instruments from the 3rd century BC were discovered in Ai Khanoum, Afghanistan, and the Greek notion of a spherical Earth surrounded by planetary spheres replaced the traditional Indian belief in a flat, circular Earth, as evidenced in texts like the Yavanajataka and Paulisa Siddhanta.
summary_2: The Greco-Bactrian and Greco-Indian Kingdoms saw significant Hellenization, leading to Greco-Buddhism and influencing Buddhist art and traditions. Key elements borrowed include anthropomorphic Buddha images, influenced by Greek sculptures, and practices like using incense, offerings, and the concept of Boddhisattvas. King Menander I may have adopted Buddhism. Additionally, Greek astronomy affected Eastern beliefs; for example, introducing the idea of a round Earth instead of a flat one.
summary_3: Greco-Bactrian and Greco-Indian Kingdoms greatly impacted Buddhism with Hellenistic influences, such as humanlike Buddha statues, new rituals, and potentially King Menander I's conversion, while also altering Eastern astronomical views, including the introduction of a spherical Earth concept.

text: (CNN) -- The U.S. space shuttle program retired in 2011, leaving American astronauts to hitchhike into orbit.But after three long years, NASA's successor is almost ready to make an entrance.Orion, the agency's newest manned spaceship, is being prepared for its first mission in December.In future missions, it will journey into deep space -- to Mars and beyond -- farther than humans have ever gone before.Orion comes loaded with superlatives.It boasts the largest heat shield ever built and a computer 400 times faster than the ones on the space shuttles.It will be launched into space on the most powerful rocket NASA has ever made.No astronauts will be aboard the December flight, which will test the spacecraft's systems for future manned missions.Final work on the spacecraft is under way at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.Orion came one step closer to completion this month with the stacking of the crew module atop the service module."Now that we're getting so close to launch, the spacecraft completion work is visible every day," Orion Program Manager Mark Geyer said in a statement.A 3,600-mile journey When complete, the Orion capsule will resemble a fencing foil, with a tall spire shooting up from a rounded base.At the top will sit a launch abort system, with downward-facing thrusters that would save the crew from a jarring crash in the event of a rocket malfunction.The bottom portion, the service module, will perform various functions such as in-space propulsion and cargo storage.Nestled between the two will be the crew module, capable of supporting human life from launch until recovery.Attached to the service module will be a United Launch Alliance Delta IV Heavy rocket.For the first time since the space shuttle's debut launch in 1981, the crew compartment will ride on the tip of the rocket rather than hanging onto its side, evoking the configuration of the famous Apollo or Gemini missions.
summary_1: NASA's new manned spaceship, Orion, is set for its initial mission in December, marking the end of a three-year hiatus since the retirement of the U.S. space shuttle program. Orion, designed for deep space travel, will venture further than humans have ever been, potentially reaching Mars and beyond. The spacecraft boasts a massive heat shield and a 400 times faster computer compared to those on the space shuttles. It will be launched using the most potent rocket NASA has ever constructed. Although there won't be any astronauts aboard during the inaugural flight, final preparations are ongoing at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Once completed, Orion will look like a fencing foil, equipped with a launch abort system for emergency situations. The service module will handle in-space propulsion and cargo storage, while the crew module supports human life from launch to recovery. An United Launch Alliance Delta IV Heavy rocket will lift the crew compartment, similar to early Apollo or Gemini missions.
summary_2: NASA's new spacecraft, Orion, is readying for its first mission in December, three years after the space shuttle program ended. Designed for deep space travel, it could reach Mars. Orion features a large heat shield, quicker computer, and powerful rocket. There won't be astronauts on the first flight, but final preparations continue at Kennedy Space Center, Florida. Post-preparation, Orion will resemble a fencing foil, complete with an abort system, service module for propulsion, and a crew module for human support. A Delta IV Heavy rocket will carry the crew compartment.
summary_3: Orion, NASA's new spacecraft designed for deep space travel, will launch in December from Kennedy Space Center, aiming to eventually reach Mars, with a heat shield, faster computer, and powerful rocket, set to be carried by a Delta IV Heavy rocket.

text: Plants also detect the daily cycle of light and darkness.Do you know how plants respond to these changes?Some plants open their leaves during the day.It is during these hours the plant can collect sunlight.At night, the plant closes its leaves to prevent water loss.Many plants respond to the change in the length of the day.As days grow shorter, some plants respond by going dormant.Dormant is when a plant suspends its growth.It does this in order to survive.Shorter days signal the coming of winter.Winter in most areas means extreme cold.It is also very dry in the winter months.As winter approaches, some plants respond by their leaves changing color.After the change in color, they fall off.This dormancy period helps trees.It allows them to survive the cold and dry winter.Plants only want to grow when conditions are right.
summary_1: Plants have the ability to perceive both daylight and dark periods. They react differently depending on the time of day; for instance, certain plants open their leaves during daylight hours to absorb sunlight and close them at night to minimize water loss. As seasons shift and daylight diminishes, several plants enter a state known as dormancy, which involves suspending growth to endure harsh weather conditions like freezing temperatures and low moisture levels that typically occur in winter. This phase enables many species to survive unfavorable environmental circumstances. Furthermore, before entering dormancy, numerous trees alter their leaf colors and shed them in preparation for the challenging season ahead. Essentially, plants aim to conserve energy and ensure survival until favorable growing conditions return.
summary_2: Certain plants adjust daily activities according to light/dark cycles, minimizing water loss by closing leaves at night. During autumn, they prepare for harsh weather by changing leaf color and shedding them, then suspend growth in a stage called dormancy, conserving energy and ensuring survival till better conditions arrive.
summary_3: During autumn, plants adapt to harsh weather by altering leaf colors, shedding them, and entering a dormant state to conserve energy until better conditions return.

text: The Reconquest: The aim of the Crusades in Spain was the eviction of the Muslims.After the recovery of Jerusalem in 1099, it took four hundred years of sieges and battles, treaties, betrayals, and yet more battles, before Christian kings and warlords succeeded in subduing the Moors.On 10 September 1229, a Catalan army led by King Jaume I of Aragón and Catalunya took the Mallorcan shore near the present-day resort of Santa Ponça.The defenders retreated inside the walls of Palma, but on the last day of 1229 the city fell, and pockets of resistance throughout the island were also defeated.Jaume I proved to be an enlightened ruler who profited from the talents of the Moors — converted by force to Christianity — as well as of the island's large Jewish and Genoese trading communities.Mallorca prospered.The Moors on Menorca speedily agreed to pay an annual tribute to Aragón and were left in peace.The island's tranquility lasted until 1287, when Alfonso III of Aragón, smarting over a series of humiliations at the hands of his nobles, found a pretext for invasion.The Moors were defeated and expelled or killed.In contrast to Mallorca, Menorca's economy was devastated for decades.Jaume I died after reigning in Aragón for six decades, but he made the cardinal error of dividing between his sons the lands he had fought for so long to unite.At first this resulted in an Independent Kingdom of Mallorca, under Jaume II, followed by Sanç and Jaume III.But family rivalry triggered the overthrow of Jaume III by his cousin Pedro IV, who then seized the Balearics for Aragón.Attempting a comeback, Jaume was killed in battle near Llucmajor in 1349.A newly unified Christian Spain under the Catholic Monarchs, Ferdinand and Isabella, completed the Reconquest, defeating the only Moorish enclave left on the Iberian peninsula, Granada, in 1492.However, the centralized kingdom failed to incorporate the Balearics politically or economically.
summary_1: King Jaume I of Aragon and Catalonia led a successful conquest of Majorca in 1229, marking a significant step in the Reconquista. After landing near Santa Ponça, the Catalan army overcame the Muslim defense and captured Palma by the end of 1229. Post-conquest, Jaume I ruled wisely, harnessing the skills of converted Muslims, Jews, and Genoese traders to establish prosperity. Meanwhile, Menorca's Moors accepted paying tributes to Aragon, preserving their peaceful existence. However, conflict resurfaced in 1287 when Alfonso III targeted Menorca due to past grievances against local nobles. Following the defeat and expulsion of the Moors, economic turmoil ensued. Despite ruling Aragon for six decades, Jaume I erred by partitioning his territories among his sons. This division paved the way for an independent Kingdom of Mallorca under Jaume II, later challenged by Pedro IV seizing the Balearics for Aragon. In 1349, Jaume III tried to reclaim power but perished in combat. Ultimately, unified Christian Spain under Ferdinand and Isabella concluded the Reconquista with Granada's fall in 1492; however, the centralized monarchy struggled to integrate the Balearics both politically and economically.
summary_2: Jaume I conquered Majorca in 1229, during the Reconquista, establishing prosperity through wise rule and cooperation with Muslims, Jews, and Genoese traders. Menorca's Moors paid tributes instead of facing invasion. Conflict resumed in 1287 when Alfonso III targeted Menorca due to historical disputes, leading to economic instability. Jaume I's decision to divide his territories amongst his sons resulted in an independent Kingdom of Mallorca under Jaume II, which was later incorporated into Aragon by Pedro IV. The attempt of Jaume III to regain control ended tragically in 1349. Although united Christian Spain completed the Reconquista in 1492, integrating the Balearics remained challenging for the centralized monarchy.
summary_3: The Reconquista led to Jaume I's conquest of Majorca in 1229, establishing prosperity until conflicts, including Alfonso III's targeting of Menorca in 1287 and the division of Jaume I's kingdom, destabilized the region, ultimately incorporating it into Aragon by 1349 despite resistance.

text: Mr. Thorndike had risen, and, in farewell, was holding out his hand to Andrews.He turned, and across the court-room the eyes of the financier and the stenographer met.At the sight of the great man, Spear flushed crimson, and then his look of despair slowly disappeared; and into his eyes there came incredulously hope and gratitude.He turned his head suddenly to the wall.Mr. Thorndike stood irresolute, and then sank back into his chair.The first man in the line was already at the railing, and the questions put to him by the judge were being repeated to him by the other assistant district attorney and a court attendant.His muttered answers were in turn repeated to the judge."Says he's married, naturalized citizen, Lutheran Church, die- cutter by profession." The probation officer, her hands filled with papers, bustled forward and whispered."Mrs. Austin says," continued the district attorney, "she's looked into this case, and asks to have the man turned over to her.He has a wife and three children; has supported them for five years." "Is the wife in court?" the judge said.A thin, washed-out, pretty woman stood up, and clasped her hands in front of her."Has this man been a good husband to you, madam?" asked the young judge.The woman broke into vehement assurances.No man could have been a better husband.Would she take him back?Indeed she would take him back.She held out her hands as though she would physically drag her husband from the pillory.The judge bowed toward the probation officer, and she beckoned the prisoner to her.
summary_1: In the courtroom, Mr. Thorndike bids farewell to Andrews, while Spear looks on, initially disheartened. However, upon seeing Mr. Thorndike, Spear blushes and feels a surge of hope and gratitude, turning away towards the wall. Meanwhile, the trial proceeds with the first defendant approaching the railing. The judge and another assistant district attorney repeat the questions posed to the defendant. It is revealed that the defendant is a married, naturalized citizen, who works as a die-cutter and practices Lutheranism. A probation officer steps forth, carrying documents related to the case. She requests custody of the defendant, explaining that the defendant's wife seeks reconciliation. The couple shares three children, and the defendant has faithfully provided for them for five consecutive years. In response to questioning from the sympathetic female judge, the wife confirms her willingness to accept her husband back, expressing heartfelt pleas for his release. Consequently, the probation officer summons the defendant to approach her side.
summary_2: Mr. Thorndike says goodbye to Andrews, leaving Spear feeling hopeful and grateful. The first defendant, a family man and churchgoer, stands trial. His wife wants him home, supported by their kids and faithful past. The judge considers this, seeking reconciliation.
summary_3: Judge considers reconciling family while trying a churchgoing father with his family's support.

text: You may wonder if there are other examples of static discharge.The answer is yes.Lightning is a form of static discharge.It is much more dramatic than what happens between you and the door knocker, but it is the same principle.You can see how it occurs in the following diagram and animation.You have no doubt seen lightning in a rainstorm.What does lighting have to do with static electricity?As it turns out, everything!During a rainstorm, clouds develop regions of different charges.This happens due to the movement of air molecules, water drops, and ice particles.The negative charges are concentrated at the base of the clouds.The positive charges are concentrated at the top.The negative charges repel electrons on the ground below.The ground then becomes positively charged.Over time the differences increase.Eventually the electrons are discharged.This is what we see as lightning.You can watch an awesome slow-motion lightning strike below.
summary_1: Static discharge isn't limited to the spark you might get from touching a door knocker; it also includes phenomena like lightning. This natural occurrence is essentially the same principle, just on a grander scale. As illustrated in the provided diagram and animation, during a rainstorm, clouds amass areas of varying charges due to the motion of air molecules, water droplets, and ice particles. The negatively charged zones typically form at the cloud's base, while the positively charged ones concentrate at the top. These opposing charges cause electrons on the ground to be repelled, resulting in a positive charge on the surface. Over time, these disparities escalate until electrons are released, manifesting as lightning. Witness this spectacular phenomenon in the linked slow-motion video of a lightning bolt.
summary_2: Lightning is a large-scale example of static discharge, caused by built-up electrical charges in storm clouds. Negative charges collect at the bottom, positive at the top, creating an imbalance that attracts electrons towards the earth's surface. Eventually, the tension releases as lightning. Watch this process in a slow-motion video.
summary_3: During thunderstorms, lightning occurs when built-up electrical charges in clouds release due to attraction between negative and positive charges, resulting in a transfer of electrons towards the ground.

text: The Legal Services Corp. (LSC), a quasi-governmental agency that provides legal aid for the poor, would receive $329 million in fiscal 2004 under President Bush's proposal - the same amount requested in 2003 and approved for 2002 and 2001.If approved, the hold-the-line request for LSC means its budget would erode with inflation for another year, but it could be worse for the organization: Many conservatives fought for years to do away with the LSC altogether, saying legal services attorneys were spending too much time fighting for liberal causes or pursuing politically charged cases against the government instead of representing the needy.Opposition to the organization has cooled since 1996, when Congress approved restrictions (PL 104-134) on the sorts of cases federally funded legal aid attorneys can take.(1996 Almanac, p.5-36) Republicans cut the organization's budget deeply in 1996, but its funding has recovered slowly.Last month, in the omnibus spending bill for fiscal 2003, the Senate added a onetime increase of $19 million, which, if approved in the final version, would bring the LSC budget to $348 million.The money would go to help states, such as Michigan and Ohio, that lost money when the organization redistributed its funding based on census counts made in 2000 of poor households.If the extra money survives a conference with the House and makes it to the president's desk, LSC supporters may try to include it in the organization's fiscal 2004 funding.The federal government began funding some programs to provide legal assistance to the poor in the late 1960s; the Legal Services Corporation was created in 1974 (PL 93-355).LSC gives nearly all its money to state and local agencies, which provide civil legal assistance to those whose income is less than 125 percent of the federal poverty level - $11,075 a year for an individual and $22,625 for a family of four.Funding for legal services goes to defend needy clients in domestic violence cases, custody cases and other such matters, according to LSC.Since 1996, lawyers who receive money from Legal Services have been prohibited from such activities as lobbying legislatures, filing class-action suits, participating in political demonstrations or strikes, pursuing abortion-related litigation, representing illegal aliens or prisoners, or defending public housing tenants evicted because they were charged with selling drugs
summary_1: President Bush proposed providing $329 million to the Legal Services Corporation (LSC) in fiscal 2004, maintaining the same funding level as in previous years. This flat funding would result in a decrease in purchasing power due to inflation. The LSC, which offers legal aid to the impoverished, has faced opposition from conservatives who believe its attorneys prioritize liberal causes over assisting the needy. In 1996, limitations were imposed on the types of cases LSC-funded attorneys could handle, and their budget was significantly reduced. However, funding has gradually increased since then. A one-time addition of $19 million was included in the fiscal 2003 omnibus spending bill, potentially bringing the LSC budget to $348 million. If this increase is maintained in fiscal 2004, it will benefit states like Michigan and Ohio, which experienced funding cuts after the 2000 census. Established in 1974, the LSC allocates almost all its funds to state and local organizations that offer civil legal assistance to individuals earning below 125% of the federal poverty line. These resources are used primarily for defending low-income clients in various cases, including domestic violence, child custody disputes, and other legal issues. Since 1996, LSC-supported lawyers have been barred from engaging in certain activities, such as lobbying, pursuing class-action lawsuits, and handling abortion-related litigation.
summary_2: Bush suggested retaining LSC's $329 million funding for 2004, but critics claim this amount won't cover inflation. The LSC, offering legal help to the indigent, has faced conservative resistance since 1996 when they limited LSC-backed lawyer tasks and slashed their budget. Despite gradual increases, LSC faces case type restrictions and cannot engage in lobbying, pursue class actions, or deal with abortion litigation. Additional $19 million was granted in 2003, possibly raising the total to $348 million. Retaining this boost may aid Michigan and Ohio, previously affected by post-census fund reductions. Set up in 1974, LSC mainly distributes funds to regional entities supporting civil legal aid for people making under 125% of the federal poverty threshold. Funds serve to protect disadvantaged clients facing family, child custody, and other legal matters.
summary_3: President Bush proposed maintaining the Legal Services Corporation (LSC)'s $329 million funding for 2004, though critics argue it falls short due to inflation; despite some budget increases, LSC remains restricted in handling certain cases and regions like Michigan and Ohio have been impacted by past census-related cuts.

text: In short, the United States has to help defeat an ideology, not just a group of people, and we must do so under difficult circumstances.How can the United States and its friends help moderate Muslims combat the extremist ideas?Recommendation: The U.S. government must define what the message is, what it stands for.We should offer an example of moral leadership in the world, committed to treat people humanely, abide by the rule of law, and be generous and caring to our neighbors.America and Muslim friends can agree on respect for human dignity and opportunity.To Muslim parents, terrorists like  Bin Laden have nothing to offer their children but visions of violence and death.America and its friends have a crucial advantage-we can offer these parents a vision that might give their children a better future.If we heed the views of thoughtful leaders in the Arab and Muslim world, a moderate consensus can be found.That vision of the future should stress life over death: individual educational and economic opportunity.This vision includes widespread political participation and contempt for indiscriminate violence.It includes respect for the rule of law, openness in discussing differences, and tolerance for opposing points of view.Recommendation: Where Muslim governments, even those who are friends, do not respect these principles, the United States must stand for a better future.One of the lessons of the long Cold War was that short-term gains in cooperating with the most repressive and brutal governments were too often outweighed by long-term setbacks for America's stature and interests.American foreign policy is part of the message.America's policy choices have consequences.Right or wrong, it is simply a fact that American policy regarding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and American actions in Iraq are dominant staples of popular commentary across the Arab and Muslim world.That does not mean U.S. choices have been wrong.It means those choices must be integrated with America's message of opportunity to the Arab and Muslim world.
summary_1: The United States is tasked with combatting an ideology rather than merely defeating a specific group, which poses challenges. To aid moderate Muslims against extremism, the US needs to present a clear stance promoting moral leadership, humane treatment, adherence to rule of law, generosity, and concern for others. A shared respect for human dignity and opportunities exists between America and Muslim communities. Terrorist organizations such as Al-Qaeda cannot provide a promising future; instead, they offer violent and lethal ideologies. In contrast, the US and its allies can promote hope through offering individual educational and economic prospects, fostering wide political involvement, rejecting arbitrary violence, upholding legal norms, encouraging free expression, and accepting diverse perspectives. When governments disregard these values, the US should advocate for improvements. Historical evidence from the Cold War indicates that collaborations with oppressive regimes may lead to temporary benefits but ultimately harm America's standing and objectives. Current issues including the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the situation in Iraq significantly impact global perceptions of the US within the Arab and Muslim worlds. Consequently, American policies need to align with messages of opportunity extended to the Middle East.
summary_2: The U.S. must counter an ideology, not just a group, demanding clear moral leadership against extremism. This involves supporting moderates, respecting human dignity, and offering education/economic prospects. The U.S. and Muslim communities share respect for human dignity and opportunities. Terrorist groups like Al-Qaeda promise nothing but violence. The U.S. and allies should foster hope, encourage free expression, and accept diverse views, advocating for improvements where governments disregard these values. Policies should reflect messages of opportunity to the Middle East, considering issues like the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and Iraq's situation. Collaboration with oppressive regimes may bring temporary gains but harm long-term goals.
summary_3: To combat extremism, the U.S. should support moderates, promote human dignity, offer educational and economic prospects, and collaborate with Muslim communities, while avoiding alliances with oppressive regimes and addressing conflicts like the Israeli-Palestinian issue.

text: Still untaken are several steps that required goodwill from local bar associations and others who had opposed the combination."[I am] not a fan of Neal's," admitted John Peck, a former board member of the San Gabriel-Pomona Valley program and a Pasadena Bar Association board member.Peck says bad feelings still linger among Ailies of the old program who feel left out."They really screwed us.We had a good program," Peck said.An observer familiar with the reconfiguration debate who requested anonymity wondered why Dudovitz had not spent more time mending fences."He ought to be bending over backwards for reconciliation, but if you want to do impact work and people in the San Gabriel Valley want direct services, you have to accommodate that or change your approach," the observer said."Neal would never consider doing that."More than a year after he officially incorporated the San Gabriel-Pomona Valley, Dudovitz had not placed a local resident on the board of Neighborhood Legal Services or made the rounds of the private legal community to recruit the volunteer lawyers."Our emphasis has been on having our potential clients know about us and deliver services to them," Dudovitz said."We have done that spectacularly."He did not hire any of the old program's nine lawyers and has yet to permanently place any of his 18 new hires in the San Gabriel-Pomona Valley.The lack of a legal aid presence in Pomona prompted the bar association and court officials to start their own once-monthly family law clinic.After learning of the effort, Dudovitz sent personnel to staff the clinic for three hours per week and is helping to write a grant application to fund a self-help kiosk for Pomona patterned on the center he pioneered in Van Nuys.The help, although late, has earned Dudovitz some appreciation."There has been a transition and [the clinic] has helped to fill some void," said Deni Butler, administrator for the Eastern District Superior Court."But we are working together quite nicely contrary to what the other side issue is."Scott Wheeler, president of the Eastern Bar Association of Los Angeles and an ally of the old program, said he mobilized his 200 members to staff the clinic after watching the ranks of unserved poor grow over the past year.
summary_1: Tensions remain between Neighborhood Legal Services (NLS) and those associated with the previous San Gabriel-Pomona Valley program, which was absorbed by NLS. John Peck, a former board member of the San Gabriel-Pomona Valley program and a Pasadena Bar Association board member, expressed dissent, stating that those from the old program felt sidelined. The integration process has been slow; for instance, NLS head Neal Dudovitz hadn't added any locals to the NLS board or actively recruited volunteers from the private legal community. However, Dudovitz emphasizes focusing on client awareness and service delivery, citing successful outreach efforts. No lawyers from the old program were hired, nor have permanent positions been filled with the new hires in the San Gabriel-Pomona Valley area. In response to this gap, the local bar association and court officials initiated a monthly family law clinic, which NLS later joined by providing staffing and assisting with a grant proposal for a self-help kiosk in Pomona. This collaboration has improved relations, according to Deni Butler, administrator for the Eastern District Superior Court. Scott Wheeler, president of the Eastern Bar Association of Los Angeles, also supports the joint initiative, noting increased access to legal assistance since its implementation.
summary_2: Ex-San Gabriel-Pomona Valley program members feel marginalized after merging into Neighborhood Legal Services (NLS). Tension arises due to slow integration, such as lack of local representation on the NLS board or recruitment from the private legal sector. Despite this, NLS focuses on enhancing client awareness and services. A monthly family law clinic, led by the local bar association and court officials, improves relations. NLS contributes by offering support and aid for a self-help kiosk project in Pomona. While there's progress in cooperation, tensions persist over hiring and integrating professionals from the original program.
summary_3: Tension remains between ex-members of San Gabriel-Pomona Valley and Neighborhood Legal Services despite efforts to improve relations through joint clinics and projects.

text: Triumph and Disaster: The 20th century saw a stupendous release of energies that had been pent up for the 250 years of Tokugawa isolation.By 1930 raw-material production had tripled the figure of 1900, manufactured goods had increased twelve-fold, and heavy industry was galloping towards maturity.Britain led the World War I Ailies in large orders for munitions, while Japan expanded sales of manufactured goods to Asian and other markets cut off from their usual European suppliers.Merchant shipping doubled in size and increased its income ten-fold as the European fleets were destroyed.Setbacks in the 1930s caused by the European postwar slump were only a spur to redouble efforts by diversifying heavy industry into the machine-making, metallurgical, and chemical sectors.Even the terrible 1923 Tokyo earthquake, which cost over 100,000 lives and billions of dollars, provided another stimulus due to the construction boom that followed.Riding the crest of this economic upsurge were the zaibatsu conglomerates — a dozen family-run combines, each involved in mining, manufacturing, marketing, shipping, and banking.These tightly controlled commercial pyramids were the true heirs to the old feudal structures.Japan's progress toward parliamentary democracy was halted in the 1930s by the growing nationalism being imposed on government by the generals and admirals.They proclaimed Japan's mission to bring progress to its backward Asian neighbors in language not so very different from that of the Europeans in Africa or the US in Latin America.After the Russian Revolution of 1917, the Soviet Union was regarded as a major threat to Japan's security, and the army felt it needed Manchuria and whatever other Chinese territory it could control as a buffer against Russian advances.In 1931 the Japanese occupied Manchuria.And then in 1937, with the popular support of ultra-right-wing groups, the army overrode parliamentary resistance in Tokyo and went to war against the Chinese Nationalists.By 1938, they held Nanking, Hankow, and Canton.Japanese expansionist policies were leading to direct confrontation with the West.Japan hoped that war in Europe would divert the Soviet Union from interference in East Asia, giving Japan a free hand both in China and, through its alliance with Germany, in French IndoChina after the defeat of France.The US responded to the Japanese invasion of IndoChina with a trade and fuel embargo, cutting off 90 percent of Japan's supplies.The result was the attack on the American fleet at Pearl Harbor (7 December 1941) and total war.
summary_1: The 20th century marked an energy surge in Japan, tripling raw material output and increasing manufactured goods twelve-fold by 1930. Heavy industries thrived, particularly during WWI when Britain sourced most munitions from Japan. Post-WW1, merchant shipping doubled, and the Tokyo earthquake even boosted the economy via reconstruction projects. Zaibatsu conglomerates, the new faces of feudal structures, dominated various sectors like mining, manufacturing, and finance. However, Japan's democratic growth halted in the '30s due to rising military influence. Generals and admirals propagated Japan's "civilizing" mission in Asia, reminiscent of Western attitudes in Africa and Latin America. Fearful of Soviet influence post-1917, Japan invaded Manchuria in 1931 and battled Chinese Nationalists by 1937, controlling crucial cities by 1938. As tensions escalated between Japan and the West, the US enforced a trade embargo after Japan's Indochina invasion. In response, Japan attacked Pearl Harbor, triggering full-scale conflict.
summary_2: In the 20th century, Japan experienced significant economic growth, with heavy industries flourishing, especially during WWI. The country saw a boom in merchant shipping and was heavily influenced by zaibatsu conglomerates. Despite democratic progress, military influence increased in the '30s, leading to invasions of Manchuria and China. Fearing Soviet influence, Japan responded to the US trade embargo with the attack on Pearl Harbor, sparking full-blown conflict.
summary_3: During the 1900s, Japan underwent substantial economic expansion, particularly in heavy industry due to WWI; however, despite growing democracy, military influence escalated in the '30s, resulting in invasions of Manchuria and China, ultimately culminating in Japan's assault on Pearl Harbor in response to U.S. trade restrictions due to perceived Soviet threat, thus igniting full-scale warfare.

text: The grant also will help victims go through court proceedings after losing a job or being evicted because of an abuser's actions, Xanthopoulos said."It's going to help the victims, but it's also going to help their children," he said.More than 270 domestic violence assaults in Madison County were reported last year, according to Tennessee Bureau of Investigation statistics.In Jackson, more than 730 domestic violence assaults were reported last year, according to records."Domestic violence is certainly on the increase and we need to do something to curve that.I see this as helping that," Madison County Sheriff David Woolfork said of the grant.Domestic violence accounted for five of 12 murders in 2001 in Jackson, police have said.And the increase in calls prompted Jackson Police Chief Rick Staples in March to form a focus group to determine if police officers need to make changes in their response to domestic calls.
summary_1: A new grant aims to aid domestic violence victims in Madison County, assisting them during legal proceedings arising from abuse-related unemployment or eviction. The funding will benefit both victims and their children. In 2021, Madison County recorded over 270 domestic violence incidents, while Jackson saw more than 730 such cases. Domestic violence has been linked to half of Jackson's homicides in 2001. Concerned by the rise in these figures, local law enforcement officials are considering adjustments to their approach to domestic violence calls. This grant could potentially contribute to reducing instances of domestic violence.
summary_2: The new grant funds efforts to help domestic violence victims in Madison County, supporting those facing employment or housing issues due to abuse. With 270+ reported incidents in 2021, there's concern about the link between domestic violence and half of Jackson's murders that year. Law enforcement considers alterations to address this issue, hoping the grant may decrease domestic violence occurrences.
summary_3: A new grant aims to aid Madison County domestic violence victims, particularly with employment and housing challenges, potentially reducing local murder rates linked to such violence.

text: How would the universe look without gravity?It would have no planets and no stars.Thats how it looked when it was young.When the universe was young, there was only gas and dust.From this gas and dust, everything we now see was made.How were stars and planets created from just gas and dust?The answer is gravity.The same gravity that holds you down on Earth.The same force that causes your pencil to roll off your desk.The same force that causes it to fall to the floor.The invisible force of gravity caused dust and gas particles to be pulled together.This force is what formed all the objects in our solar system.This force formed the smallest moons.It also formed our Sun.This force caused more than just our solar system to form.It caused all the other solar systems to form.It caused the formation of all the galaxies of the universe.
summary_1: In a gravity-less universe, there would be no stars or planets, resembling its initial state after the Big Bang, which only contained gas and dust. The creation of celestial bodies hinges on gravity, the same force responsible for pulling objects towards each other, causing a pencil to roll off a desk and fall to the floor. This gravitational pull amalgamates dust and gas particles, leading to the formation of small moons, the sun, and eventually, solar systems and galaxies. Thus, gravity plays a pivotal role in shaping the cosmos.
summary_2: Gravity shapes the universe by drawing together gas and dust, forming celestial bodies like stars and planets. Without it, particles wouldn't coalesce into moons, the sun, or galaxies. Gravity's pull gathers particles from post-Big Bang chaos into complex structures.
summary_3: Gravity draws particles together after the Big Bang, forming celestial bodies such as stars and planets.

text: Once upon a time there a little girl named Ana.Ana was a smart girl.Everyone in Ana's school knew and liked her very much.She had a big dream of becoming spelling bee winner.Ana studied very hard to be the best she could be at spelling.Ana's best friend would help her study every day after school.By the time the spelling bee arrived Ana and her best friend were sure she would win.There were ten students in the spelling bee.This made Ana very nervous, but when she looked out and saw her dad cheering her on she knew she could do it.The spelling bee had five rounds and Ana made it through them all.She was now in the finals.During the final round James, the boy she was in the finals with, was given a really hard word and he spelled it wrong.All Ana had to do was spell this last word and she would be the winner.Ana stepped to the microphone, thought really hard and spelled the word.She waited and finally her teacher said "That is correct".Ana had won the spelling bee.Ana was so happy.She won a trophy.Ana also won a big yellow ribbon.The whole school was also happy, and everyone clapped for her.The whole school went outside.They had a picnic to celebrate Ana winning.
summary_1: A young girl named Ana, known for her intelligence, aspired to triumph in a spelling bee. She worked diligently, aided by her closest companion, who assisted her daily in her studies. Entering the competition, which featured ten participants, Ana felt anxious. However, spotting her father's encouraging gaze, she gained confidence. The bee consisted of five rounds, and Ana successfully navigated each one. Reaching the finale, she faced James, her fellow finalist. Given an intricate word, James misspelled it, leaving Ana to correctly spell her assigned term. Upon doing so, she became the victor. Overjoyed, she received a trophy and a large yellow ribbon. Her school celebrated her achievement with applause, leading to an outdoor picnic honoring her victory.
summary_2: Intelligent girl Ana trains hard for a spelling bee with help from a friend, making it to the final round against James. After he stumbles on a difficult word, Ana spells hers right, winning a trophy, praise, and a celebratory picnic at school.
summary_3: Ana wins the spelling bee after correctly spelling a challenging word in the final round against James, earning a trophy and celebration.

text: In her storage room-turned-office, Jennifer Baum works under an expanding leak that is causing the ceiling to turn brown and crumble.Mold grows in the buckets positioned to catch the water.She shrugs it off.Outside her office she has taped up a clear plastic suit, and a sign that reads, "All employees must don protective gear before coming in."Such is life in limbo.Nearly a year after Sept. 11, the Legal Aid Society-the lawyers for New York's poor and homeless-remains, well, homeless.The nonprofit has been barred from returning to its 90 Church St. headquarters, across from the World Trade Center site, because of environmental concerns.Legal Aid has uncomfortable company.More than 11,500 New Yorkers continue to work out of temporary space, according to analysis by Manhattan-based real estate brokerage TenantWise.com Inc. and Crain's New York Business.That's 8% of the 137,000 workers who lost their offices or access to them when the Twin Towers collapsed.Legal Aid's 450 displaced attorneys and staffers have spent the past 12 months spread among previously unused spaces-some unused for good reason-in the nonprofit's other offices.It could be another year and a half before they return to their old desks.They have contended with difficult working conditions as demand for Legal Aid's services is on the rise because of Sept. 11 and the deteriorating economy.The civil division is spread among a few boroughs.Their papers and documents, some 20,000 boxes worth, are stuck in a storage facility in Linden, N.J. "I am counting the days till we can have all the parts back in one place," says Steven Banks, Legal Aid's associate attorney in chief.In the memories of the exiled workers, the old office has achieved mythical proportions.They say the wood paneling and rugs had the ability to cool emotions and lift spirits.The Legal Aid office on Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, where 65 displaced workers have cobbled together space amid the faded and scratched walls, looks more like a bargain basement.
summary_1: Since September 11, the Legal Aid Society, which provides legal aid to New York's impoverished and homeless, has been unable to return to its 90 Church St. headquarters due to environmental concerns. The society's 450 attorneys and staff members have been dispersed among the organization's other offices, occupying various unused spaces. This arrangement may last another year and a half. The civil division is scattered across several boroughs, and over 20,000 boxes of paperwork are stored in a New Jersey facility. As the demand for Legal Aid's services increases due to the aftermath of 9/11 and economic decline, employees cope with challenging working conditions. The iconic Wood Paneling and carpets of their previous office are fondly remembered, while their current location, shared with 65 other workers in Brooklyn Heights, appears worn and shabby in comparison. Meanwhile, approximately 11,500 New Yorkers still work in temporary spaces, making up 8% of the 137,000 individuals affected by the collapse of the Twin Towers.
summary_2: Post-9/11, the Legal Aid Society was displaced from its 90 Church St. HQ due to safety issues. Its 450 lawyers and staff now operate from different offices, a situation likely to continue for another year and a half. The civil division is spread across boroughs, with over 20,000 boxes of documents housed in New Jersey. Amid rising demand due to 9/11 and economic downturn, employees endure tough conditions. The once-familiar wood paneling and carpets of their old office are missed, replaced by a worn-out space shared with 65 others in Brooklyn Heights. Around 11,500 New Yorkers remain in temporary settings, constituting 8% of those impacted by the Twin Towers' fall.
summary_3: Following 9/11, the Legal Aid Society was forced to leave its 90 Church St. headquarters due to safety concerns, scattering its 450 lawyers and staff across various locations, a situation expected to persist for another year and a half; the civil division is distributed across boroughs, managing over 20,000 boxes of records in New Jersey warehouses, while employees cope with challenging working conditions in a worn-out shared space in Brooklyn Heights, serving approximately 11,500 New Yorkers still residing in temporary accommodations, representing 8% of those affected by the Twin Towers' collapse.

text: A West Tennessee nonprofit organization will use a $300,000 federal grant to hire an attorney and a Spanish-speaking paralegal to help provide legal assistance to domestic violence victims.The U.S. Department of Justice two-year grant will begin Oct. 1, which is the start of domestic violence awareness month.U.S. Rep. John Tanner announced Monday that the grant was awarded to West Tennessee Legal Services of Jackson.The organization provides legal assistance and advocacy in 17 counties."This award will offer assistance as we look for whatever ways possible to stop domestic violence and help the women, men and children who are victims of abuse," Tanner said in a news statement.The organization doesn't have a staff member who speaks Spanish and the need is increasing with growing Hispanic populations, said the organization's executive director Steven Xanthopoulos.He estimated the money will help handle at least another 180 cases next year.The group closes about 2,500 cases a year.The money was timed well because the legal group had recently lost about $120,000 in grant money due to a decrease in the poverty population in West Tennessee in Census 2000, Xanthopoulos said."The drop in poverty is a good thing, but there is still a great need out there," he said."So this was a very good thing."Having legal representation at divorce and child custody hearings is important in helping victims leave abusive and sometimes dangerous situations, said Margaret Cole, executive director of Wo/Men's Resource and Rape Assistance Program in Jackson.Her organization and Northwest Safeline are partners in the grant.Northwest Safeline, based in Dyersburg, is a family violence intervention project that serves Dyer, Obion, Lake and Crockett counties.
summary_1: West Tennessee Legal Services has received a $300,000 federal grant from the U.S. Department of Justice to aid domestic violence victims. The funds will be used to employ an attorney and a Spanish-speaking paralegal, addressing a growing need as Hispanic populations increase. The two-year grant commences on October 1, aligning with the beginning of Domestic Violence Awareness Month. This grant will enable the organization to manage approximately 180 additional cases annually, supplementing their current caseload of around 2,500 cases per year. The funding comes as a relief after the organization lost about $120,000 in grants due to a decline in the poverty population in West Tennessee during Census 2000. The legal group's executive director, Steven Xanthopoulos, expressed gratitude for the grant, stating it will significantly assist in providing crucial legal support to victims at divorce and child custody hearings, enabling them to navigate away from harmful situations. Two partner organizations, Wo/Men's Resource and Rape Assistance Program in Jackson and Northwest Safeline in Dyersburg, also benefit from the grant.
summary_2: West Tennessee Legal Services obtained a $300,000 federal grant from the US DOJ to help domestic abuse victims. The money employs an attorney and a bilingual paralegal, handling around 180 extra cases annually, primarily Hispanics. The grant starts on Oct 1, which coincides with Domestic Violence Awareness Month. It compensates for lost grants worth $120,000 due to decreased poverty rates. The funding helps provide legal assistance in divorce and child custody matters, benefiting two partner organizations too.
summary_3: West Tennessee Legal Services received a $300,000 federal grant from the US DOJ to assist domestic abuse victims, employing an attorney and a bilingual paralegal to handle about 180 additional cases each year, mainly serving Hispanics, and providing legal aid in family law matters.

text: U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell arrived here on Tuesday night for meetings with fellow foreign ministers aimed at solidifying a second front, in Southeast Asia, in the campaign against global terrorism.But he has had to balance that goal with longstanding concerns about human rights abuses in the region.In meetings on Tuesday in Malaysia and Singapore before touching down in this oil-producing sultanate for two days of talks with members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, Powell said he repeatedly raised the issue."We still believe strongly in human rights, and that everything we do has to be consistent with universal standards of human rights," he said.But at a news conference in Singapore, Powell hinted that the Bush administration was ready to discuss resuming military cooperation with Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation and a sometimes reluctant partner in the efforts to crack down on militant Islamic groups.The United States cut virtually all military links with Indonesia in 1999 after its forces were implicated in the violence that swept East Timor after that territory voted for independence.On Thursday, Powell and representatives of the nations of the Asian group, including Indonesia, are expected to sign a declaration promising cooperation to prevent terrorism by sharing information, blocking funds, tightening borders and making it hard to use forged travel papers."We recognized that terrorism is a global threat and that the disturbing acts of terrorism and transnational crimes, which continue to threaten world peace and stability, must be tackled by the international community," the ministers said in a communique on Tuesday.Powell is among the representatives from 13 nations outside Southeast Asia, including China, Japan and Russia, that are taking part in the annual meeting of the group's regional forum.Terrorism dominates the agenda, though the possibility of a meeting here between Powell and his North Korean counterpart, Paek Nam Sun, has generated the most news.It would be the highest-level contact between the United States and North Korea since President Bush took office.Powell heads to Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, late on Thursday before finishing a weeklong trip through the region in the Philippines on Saturday.He said that when he arrives in Jakarta, he will have "some ideas and some initiatives" to present to President Megawati Sukarnoputri.Indonesia is already receiving $400,000 in the current fiscal year for civilian training programs and is to receive a like amount next year; and the United States expects to provide an additional $16 million this year to train police officers in counterterrorism.At the same time, the Pentagon is reviewing how to allocate another $17 million in "counterterrorism fellowships," some of which could go to Indonesia.But a senior State Department official also acknowledged that some in the administration and Congress are pushing for more direct military cooperation, which would require congressional approval."I think they recognize the danger that we all face and I think they have been cooperating more fully with us as time goes by, and I'm quite sure that Mrs. Megawati is committed to this cause," Powell said in Singapore.He met there with Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, who endorsed the idea of renewed military ties between the United States and Indonesia as an important step in stabilizing that country.
summary_1: Colin Powell, U.S. Secretary of State, visited various countries in Southeast Asia to strengthen cooperation against global terrorism. His mission was twofold: to establish a secondary front against terrorism in Southeast Asia and to address human rights issues in the region. In Malaysia and Singapore, Powell discussed human rights concerns, reiterating the importance of adhering to universal human rights standards. Despite past human rights abuses, particularly in Indonesia, where U.S. military ties were severed due to Indonesian forces' involvement in East Timorese violence, Powell indicated a willingness to restore military cooperation. This potential reconciliation could facilitate counterterrorism efforts. On Thursday, Powell planned to sign a declaration with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), pledging collective action against terrorism through intelligence sharing, financial tracking, border control, and document verification. The U.S. has provided and plans to continue providing significant funding for civilian training programs, police officer training, and counterterrorism fellowships in Indonesia. Although some officials advocate for increased direct military cooperation, such actions would necessitate congressional approval. Powell expressed optimism regarding Indonesia's commitment to combatting terrorism and anticipates further collaboration during his visit to Jakarta.
summary_2: Secretary of State Colin Powell visits Southeast Asia, aiming to bolster regional anti-terrorism efforts and discuss human rights. He addresses human rights issues in Malaysia and Singapore, indicating openness to restoring military ties with Indonesia despite previous violations. ASEAN and US plan joint action against terrorism, focusing on intel sharing, border control, and financing. US funds civilian training, police, and counterterrorism fellowships in Indonesia, potentially leading to deeper collaboration.
summary_3: Colin Powell visits Southeast Asia to strengthen anti-terrorism efforts, discusses human rights, and initiates potential security cooperation with Indonesia, while ASEAN and US collaborate on combating terrorism through intelligence sharing, border control, and funding for counterterrorism initiatives in Indonesia.
